mnemonics.meaning: You find a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">toe</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>. It's weird, because it's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">above</mark> the ground, not where toes belong.
mnemonics.reading: Of course when you find a toe above the ground, you want to know where the toe came from. When you examine it, you see a name written on there. This toe belongs to the local clumsy farmhand, Joe (じょう).

mnemonics.meaning: There's the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>, and there's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">toe</mark> just <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">below</mark> it. Yep, you know this means "below" because the ground has a toe below it in this kanji.
mnemonics.reading: You keep digging in the ground for the toe below, but instead you hit something hard and metallic. You try to dig around it, but it's huge. Turns out it's a car (か). Keep digging until you unearth the car below. (Inside, you find the toe you were looking for.)

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">big</mark> kanji are exactly the same!
mnemonics.reading: There's this big guy (that's how you remember the radical, remember?), and he's wearing a huge Tie Dye (たい, だい) shirt. Because he's so huge, the tie dye shirt is also super huge. Everything about him is pretty big, but the tie dye stands out more than anything.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">construction</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: Every time a kanji uses the こう reading (there are a lot!), we'll use the character こういち. He's one of the people who started this website, so we'll do our best in the mnemonics to embarrass him as much as possible. Like this:

mnemonics.meaning: This isn't exactly the same as the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark> radical, but it's close. Sometimes this will happen (where we have to use a slightly "modified radical" version of the original), so it's good to understand that now, early on. In this case, we have fins. How many fins? <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Eight</mark> fins. How do you know that? Because you caught four fish with two fins each.
mnemonics.reading: After you count and smell all eight of your fins, it's time to put them away. You open a large hatch (はち) and put them in. This is where you keep your fins, always putting in eight at a time because that's what the boss wants.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">enter</mark> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">enter</mark> as well.
mnemonics.reading: Turns out, after you enter the tent (remember how the person in the radical is entering one?), you're given a new (にゅう) one! Why? No idea, but hey — it's new!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mountain</mark> kanji are the same.
mnemonics.reading: Think about mountains talking to each other, calling each other by their names and adding the Japanese name-ender san (さん) to each of their names. "Hello, Everest-san." "Oh hi, Fuji-san."

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mouth</mark> kanji are exactly the same!
mnemonics.reading: Do you remember seeing the construction worker こういち earlier in the 工 mnemonic? If you haven't yet, not to worry!

mnemonics.meaning: Nice! This kanji is the same as the radical that looks just like it (down to the meaning, even!). The radical is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nine</mark> and the kanji is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">nine</mark>, making the meaning of this kanji really easy to remember as long as you know the radical first.
mnemonics.reading: Although this kanji has two on'yomi to learn, the pronunciations of those two on'yomi are very similar, so that should make them easier to remember.

mnemonics.meaning: Lying on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> is something that looks just like the ground, the number <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">One</mark>. Why is this One lying down? It's been shot by the number two. It's lying there, bleeding out and dying. The number One doesn't have long to live.
mnemonics.reading: As you're sitting there next to One, holding him up, you start feeling a weird sensation all over your skin. From the wound comes a fine powder (obviously coming from the special bullet used to kill One) that causes the person it touches to get extremely itchy (いち).

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how the radical version of this kanji meant <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">person</mark> because it looks like a person with their arms down and their legs spread out? Well this is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">person</mark> too!
mnemonics.reading: Only one person at Nintendo (にん) complained about the new jeans (じん) policy, and that person was you.

mnemonics.meaning: The radical and the meaning of this kanji are the same. Both are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">power</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Who has the most power of anyone? It's the Power Rangers. They are battling their arch enemy Ricky (りき). They defeat him and lock (りょく) him up, so that he can't hurt anyone ever again.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">river</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">river</mark> kanji are the same as each other!
mnemonics.reading: You're standing next to a river that's actually used as a car wash (かわ).

mnemonics.meaning: Lucky for you (as is the case with many of the lower-stroke kanji), this kanji is the same as the radical you've already learned. The radical that makes up this kanji is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">seven</mark> and the kanji (which is exactly the same) is also <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">seven</mark>. So, if you know the radical, you know the meaning of the kanji as well.
mnemonics.reading: You know this kanji means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">seven</mark>, so let's use that to remember the reading too. <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Seven</mark> is a lucky number, usually, but this time it isn't so good:

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> is the symbol for the number <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ten</mark>. A good way to remember this is to think about all the religions that have crosses and also important sets of tens.
mnemonics.reading: This cross in particular has ten jewels (じゅう) on it. Two on each arm and two in the middle. That's ten jewels!

mnemonics.meaning: This kanji is made up of the ground radical (which also happens to be the kanji for "one") and the radical for two. Combine <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">one</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">two</mark> together and what do you get? <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Three</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: Three is the number of chances you get with Santa-san (さん). He has a list, and when you get to three "naughty things" lines, that's it. You're on Santa-san's three strikes and you're out list.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">two</mark> and the radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">two</mark> are the exact same things. Therefore, you know the kanji for two already!
mnemonics.reading: How do you count to two? Just use someone's knee (に), and then their other knee. There — two knees!

mnemonics.meaning: The radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> and the kanji for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">woman</mark> are exactly the same.
mnemonics.reading: When you think of a woman, think of Jo-Anne (じょ), though she usually goes by just "Jo."

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> has a big <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of liquid in his hand... but then he bounces it! The drop was really a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ball</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: When he's done playing with it, the king gives his ball to Tamara (たま), the resident ball girl, for safekeeping.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">book</mark> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">book</mark> as well.
mnemonics.reading: Books are one of the best ways to hone (ほん) your intellect, you know?

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">child</mark> kanji are exactly the same.
mnemonics.reading: The main reading here is し, so to remember it we'll use this mnemonic:

mnemonics.meaning: What's something with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nine</mark> sides? Just add a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> and you'll have something that's almost a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">circle</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Do you know about the adorable cat Maru? If not, you should check it out. May seem like a distraction, but if you come back knowing the reading for this kanji, then it's totally worth while.

mnemonics.meaning: There is a line on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> so you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stop</mark>, making a giant sign pop up that says <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">CORRECT</mark>! You obeyed the rules of the road and did the correct thing. Good on you.
mnemonics.reading: You did the correct thing, so here's your reward: a saber (せい) from the Shougun (しょう) himself!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dirt</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: Who spends a lot of time in dirt? Dogs (ど) do! Dogs dig in dirt, they roll in dirt, sometimes they try to eat dirt (which isn't so great).

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dog</mark> radical and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dog</mark> kanji are exactly the same!
mnemonics.reading: Every dog likes to eat noodles (いぬ). Like that movie where the dogs share a noodle and end up kissing, right? So when you see 犬, just imagine how those two eat noodles.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">evening</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">evening</mark> kanji are the same. If you know the radical you know the meaning of the kanji.
mnemonics.reading: The evening is when all the youths (ゆう) come outside to play.

mnemonics.meaning: There are two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountains</mark> in front of you... and probably a bunch more around you too. You are in a pass, and don't know how to get out. You are frantically looking for the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">exit</mark> before you freeze to death. The most important thing is to find the exit from this mountain range - your life depends on it.
mnemonics.reading: As you're trying to exit this mountain range, you suddenly realize that someone is actually hunting you. What? Make sure to feel that sudden realization. It's crazy. Then, you find the exit and run towards it. Sadly, the hunter is waiting there, and he shoots you (しゅつ) through the leg, knocking you down.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark> radical and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">eye</mark> kanji are the same as each other, so now you know them both.
mnemonics.reading: Your eyes are important to you, right? Sadly, one of your eyes is missing right now, because a sheep grabbed it and pulled it out, and is now running away from you, yelling his sheep call.... "Mehhhhhh (め)!"

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fire</mark> kanji are the same as each other.
mnemonics.reading: Whenever we need to remember か, we use the word car.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">five</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">five</mark> kanji are the same.
mnemonics.reading: Five is the number of buildings Godzilla (ご) will knock down. Oh, look! There he goes now.

mnemonics.meaning: Imagine contorting yourself in such a way that your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> now has your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">legs</mark> inside it. You've bent your body in all the wrong ways to achieve this. In fact, if you look at yourself, you look like a square now... You're just a person with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">four</mark> sides.
mnemonics.reading: Now that you have four sides, you look like a four-sided animal: the sheep (し). Look at yourself in the mirror and see an adorable four-sided sheep looking back at you. Imagine yourself with perfectly square wool. (You can only see four sides because mirrors aren't 3D. So you're a flat, cartoonish sheep.)

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hand</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hand</mark> kanji are identical in looks and meaning! That should make things easy!
mnemonics.reading: To remember the reading て we will use the word "television." You have great hands. Go ahead and look at them. OH MY GOD. You have little televisions (て) on your hands. They are playing the dumbest show you can think of, too, both hands at the same time.

mnemonics.meaning: The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heaven</mark> is the same as the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">heaven</mark>, making this an easy kanji to memorize.
mnemonics.reading: Heaven... nowadays, people aren't all that good. Things have gotten bad. That's why the acceptance rate to get into heaven is only ten (てん) percent!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">king</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: When you see the king you need to say, "Oh (おう) King! Oh King, oh no, oh why are you looking at me like that? Oh King... you aren't going to chop off my head are you? OH NO!"

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Narwhal</mark>s do <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark> with their <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">left</mark> hands (or flippers, I guess). That's because all narwhals are left-handed!
mnemonics.reading: In their left hands, the narwhals all hold saws (さ). That's because the ice for their homes is already there, so they just need to saw away at them to make the shapes they want. Narwhal construction is actually very simple.

mnemonics.meaning: The radical <mark class="reading-highlight" title="Reading">middle</mark> and the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">middle</mark> are both the same. So if you know one, you know the other.
mnemonics.reading: To remember the reading for this kanji, we use the word Chewbacca to pull up ちゅう in our memory.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">moon</mark> kanji is made up of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> radical. This kanji is also used to mean <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">month</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The moon really gets (げつ) to your guts (がつ). Staring at the moon for too long will give you terrible indigestion, so be careful!

mnemonics.meaning: This is a strange kanji because it doesn't really mean anything at all. In fact, what it does is it repeats the kanji that comes before it. For example: 人々 is actually 人人. This kanji shows up whenever there's a repeating kanji, because it's often easier to write than writing a more complicated kanji twice. That's why this kanji is the repeater. It repeats what comes before it.
mnemonics.reading: This symbol doesn't really have a name, but it's sometimes called the のま because it looks like the katakana characters ノ and マ put together. If you know katakana then this will be easy to read. If you don't, think of it this way:

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rice paddy</mark> kanji are the same, making this one super easy to remember, at least meaning-wise.
mnemonics.reading: To remember the reading た, we use the word "taco."

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Narwhal</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>s are on the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">right</mark> side of their head. In fact, some people didn't think they had mouths at all because they weren't looking from the right. Rookie mistake.
mnemonics.reading: How did we know to look from the right, though? Because the youths (ゆう) figured it out. Youths think in ways that older people usually don't. That's why they can see the swirls on cereal, hear the music behind noise, and of course, look at things from the right side.

mnemonics.meaning: Just imagine a beast with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> for a head and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark> for feet, running around looking as insane as possible (really imagine it!). When it runs up to you, it shows you the top of its lid-head. On it is written the numbers 666. Why? Because it's a spawn of the devil, and the number <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">six</mark> is the devil's number.
mnemonics.reading: Whenever we need to remember the reading ろく we just use the word rock.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">small</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">small</mark> kanji are exactly the same.
mnemonics.reading: This small kanji would be the perfect gift to give to the Shougun (しょう). The Shougun loves little things, and the little kanji represents all of that.

mnemonics.meaning: The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> and the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stand</mark> are the same thing, so now you know them both.
mnemonics.reading: Think of someone who has to stand up straight for you. These people are pros in hospitality. These are the doormen at the Ritz (りつ).

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the radical that look like this are exactly the same. They are both <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">street</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: So you're walking down this street, and off in the distance you see the silhouette of somebody. A lady. Big, black curly hair and red eyes. It is the street-woman, Mrs. Chou (ちょう).

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> radical and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sun</mark> kanji are the same, huzzah! Also, if you want to remember <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">day</mark> as well, you can just think about how a day is the time it takes for the sun to cross the sky.
mnemonics.reading: There are so many on'yomi for this kanji, but since this kanji is so important and common, you'll end up learning them all eventually whether you want to or not. For now, you're only going to have to learn one of the readings, and that one is にち.

mnemonics.meaning: The radical and the meaning of this kanji are almost the same! The radical is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark>, but we're learning Japanese, so can you name a Japanese <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sword</mark>? That's right, the most common is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">katana</mark>, which happens to be the meaning of this kanji as well.
mnemonics.reading: So now you have this sweet katana in your hands and you're swinging it around like an idiot. Feel free to make whooshing noises as you swing it around. To become a master katana wielder, you decide to travel to とうきょう (Tokyo). とうきょう has the best sword and katana schools in the world, so it makes sense to travel to とうきょう.

mnemonics.meaning: On the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> you put <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">barb</mark>s at the bottom of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark>. This is your special <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">talent</mark>. When you go down the slide, you fly right past the barbs like some kind of daredevil. Any normal kid would land on the barbs and get hurt, but you have this talent.
mnemonics.reading: But then people start to say that no human could have so much talent, that you must be a cyborg (さい). Are you really a talented cyborg?

mnemonics.meaning: This kanji is the same as the radical you learned, so it means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">thousand</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Remember the thousand people going down the slide on a cross in the radical 千? Turns out each one of them was carrying a thousand cents (せん). Go ahead and try to calculate what a thousand times a thousand cents would come out to. It's quite a lot, actually.

mnemonics.meaning: This is another kanji that is the same as the radical. Both <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tree</mark> are the same in looks and meaning.
mnemonics.reading: You’re walking through the trees, looking at them. They look ominous. Suddenly, you trip and fall. The trees start to mock (もく) you. Even the mocking birds mock you. It’s terrible. It’s painful. You’re being mocked as you pull yourself up off the ground.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">water</mark> kanji are the same.
mnemonics.reading: Imagine a lake (i.e. a whole bunch of water). When you think of water, you should try to think of this beautiful lake. It’s sunny, the trees smell nice (imagine a tree smell if you can – the more senses you use the better!) and on that tree there is an awesome tire swing (すい). You get onto the tire swing and you are swinging back and forth. The water is right in front of you, and you are able to use the swing to throw yourself into the water. It’s a lot colder than you expected, and you come back to the surface, gasping for breath. The water gets into your mouth and you taste it. How strange, it’s very, very sweet. Imagine the sweetness of the water and how weird it is (really really sweet, this water is).

mnemonics.meaning: The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark> and the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">white</mark> are the same.
mnemonics.reading: The white team was the first to be able to hack (はく) the white iPhone.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">writing</mark> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">writing</mark> as well.
mnemonics.reading: This kanji has more than one important reading you need to learn! But don't worry, here's a mnemonic to help you:

mnemonics.meaning: Here we have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">head</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> in it, near the top. Imagine the top of someone's head being closed by a lid. Open that lid up and peer inside... it's full of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">yen</mark> coins, the currency of Japan. Jackpot! And all those yen coins have a nice <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">round</mark> shape, naturally.
mnemonics.reading: What does the word yen sound like? It sounds like えん. Why? because back in the day, Japanese used to have a "ye" sound, but now it doesn't. Instead, it's an "e" sound, which is why yen = えん!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">arrow</mark> kanji are the same. Sort of a "straight" shot to memorizing this kanji, you know?
mnemonics.reading: To remember the reading や we use the word “Yankees” (like the evil baseball team, go M’s!).

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bright</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bright</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: What do you say when you see something bright? "Ah (あ)!" Like when you open the curtain and the sunshine hits your eyes, or someone shines a flashlight right into your face. Ahhhh, so bright!

mnemonics.meaning: You see a manhole <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark>, both with the name of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">city</mark> on them. Decorative manhole lids and souvenir towels — two things cities love to slap their names on, especially in Japan.
mnemonics.reading: This city must have a lot of sheep (し) because, besides the manhole lid and the towel, all you can see are sheep. There are sheep everywhere. It's a sheep city.

mnemonics.meaning: The radical and the kanji for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cow</mark> are exactly the same! That makes it easy to remember, so long as you know your radicals well enough.
mnemonics.reading: Have you ever heard of わぎゅう (wagyu) beef? That ぎゅう is this ぎゅう.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">seven</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">swords</mark>, there's only so much you can do with them. The main thing? Probably using them to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cut</mark> something.
mnemonics.reading: Because having seven swords for yourself is too much, you decide to take the swords and divide them up amongst pairs of people. You cut them into pairs, and give sets (せつ) to everyone who needs them in the village.

mnemonics.meaning: The radical and the kanji for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">direction</mark> are the same! Huzzah!
mnemonics.reading: What direction do you always know? Which direction do you always want to go? Home (ほう). Something about your home always stays with you, no matter how far away you go. So if you're lost and you don't know which direction to go, just think of home!

mnemonics.meaning: The radical and the kanji for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">door</mark> are the same!
mnemonics.reading: You open the door and immediately get it closed back on your toe (と), literally causing your toe to explode.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji is the same as the radical, so this means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fat</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Imagine a fat person who loves to sleep on futon (ふと).

mnemonics.meaning: The radical and the kanji for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">father</mark> are the same.
mnemonics.reading: Imagine your father is Cheech (ちち) from Cheech and Chong.

mnemonics.meaning: You have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">small</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark>. The thing about small slides is that <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">few</mark> people can use them. Not everyone can fit their bum in a small slide — only a few small ones can make it down.
mnemonics.reading: Another reason so few people can use it is that the Shogun (しょう) is trying to go down the slide. We're talking a grown man who's way too big for this little slide, so a few people have to wait behind him — it's a slide traffic jam.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">narwhal</mark> sitting on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> is your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">friend</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: "Hi friend," says the narwhal. "I must warn you about all the youths." (ゆう)

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Fur</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fur</mark> are the same as each other, so the meaning of this kanji should be simple. This can also mean <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hair</mark>, too, though more like furry hair.
mnemonics.reading: With fur, whisk your imagination to a land where there are stalks of fur all around, just like a big tall grassy field (except instead of grass, it's fur). You're surrounded by the black fur, the wind is blowing. Imagine yourself touching the long fur and smelling it. What does it feel and smell like? Now it's time to get rid of it. There's just too much hair! To get rid of it, you'll need to mow (もう) it down with a lawn mower. Imagine yourself starting up the lawn mower, and taking it around, mowing down the hair. Hear the sound of the mower in your head (they're loud and distinct). The important thing is to imagine yourself mowing everything. Key is to think "fur → in the fur → get rid of the fur → mow the fur," in that order. That'll get you to "mow," which will help you to remember the on’yomi.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">triceratops</mark> is lying out to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark>. But it's so big, and it's lying on its side, so only <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">half</mark> of it gets dry.
mnemonics.reading: "You're half wet and half dry! I will cut you in half with my laser blaster so you're proper again," a voice says. It is Han Solo (はん), the anti-establishment guy who hates when things aren't even.

mnemonics.meaning: The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> and the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">heart</mark> are the same. Rejoice and let your heart be free!
mnemonics.reading: The heart, where is it stored in your body? Most people thought it was in the chest, but in reality, your heart is stored in your shin (しん).

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">head</mark> has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">person</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">inside</mark> it!
mnemonics.reading: You know this kanji means inside, so you can keep thinking about the person that's inside you, running around. You finally discover him, and try to take him out, but before you can, he pulls out a knife (ない) and threatens to cut you if you do anything irrational.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark> stands upon the roof, holding up a single <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">letter</mark>, a single <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">character</mark>, a single <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">symbol</mark> for the world to see.
mnemonics.reading: The character that is being shown is "J," which stands for Jesus (じ). The kid wants everyone to see this letter and symbol.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">life</mark> kanji are the same, so hopefully you now just know them both.
mnemonics.reading: You can save life or take it away with your new saber (せい). This is the saber you got from doing the correct thing (remember?), and now you need to figure out how to use it with this life. So what do you do?

mnemonics.meaning: You have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> that's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">machine</mark>. But you have to keep your machine mouth private because it would scare all the non-machine people around you.
mnemonics.reading: To make sure they can't tell what's machine and what's human, you dye (だい) the mouth to make it look like skin. You find dye the same shade as your normal mouth and just slap it on there.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone breaks part of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">window</mark>. Who did this? It was your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mother</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: Suddenly your mother points her bloodied finger at you and laughs, "Haha (はは)!" She keeps laughing, haha haha haha, over and over. You feel even more alarmed.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark> at <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">noon</mark>. The sun is brightest at noon, so it dries the morning dew off the slide, making noon the perfect time to slide.
mnemonics.reading: Noon also happens to be the time Godzilla (ご) decided to attack for the same reasons: it's dry and kids are using the slide.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji is the same as the radical — it means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">north</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You go north, and notice that everyone has a keytar (きた). You know, those keyboards that people hold and play like a guitar?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">now</mark> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">now</mark> as well.
mnemonics.reading: Right now the condors (こん) are in danger! Not next week, not next year, right now! Haven't you heard that deforestation and pollution are killing all of the condors?!

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">old</mark> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">old</mark> as well.
mnemonics.reading: Old things are misunderstood by the 子s (こ) of the world.

mnemonics.meaning: You're known to get the ailment <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">evening</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">toe</mark>, which is when your toe catches on fire after getting really, really hot (imagine this happening, ouch!). The only way to fix it is to cool your toe down, and the best way to do that is to go <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">outside</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You go outside (you’re not supposed to be out there at night!) and you’re accosted by a couple of guys. Then, all of a sudden, Guy (がい) Fawkes jumps from the roof above you and takes them out, then starts running. “Guy Fawkes!” you yell after him!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark> that fell onto my <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark> were sliced into many <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">part</mark>s. Following this logic, this also means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">minute</mark>, which is part of an hour, and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">divide</mark>, which is the action of splitting something into many parts.
mnemonics.reading: Now that the fins have been cut into neat parts, it's time to cut something else: buns (ぶん).

mnemonics.meaning: If you have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bow</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stick</mark> you need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pull</mark> the two back together to shoot it. If you can't pull it, you won't be shooting anything.
mnemonics.reading: When you pull the bow back, your body strains and you feel an immense heat (ひ) rise inside of you. You keep pulling and the heat grows hotter and hotter.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stop</mark> radical is the same as the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stop</mark> kanji.
mnemonics.reading: You have to stop because there is a sheep (し) in front of you. You try to walk around the sheep, but it moves to stop in front of you again. Every time the sheep stops you stop too.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">task</mark> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">task</mark> as well.
mnemonics.reading: Today, your task is to eat yogurt (よう). It's nutritious, it's delicious, and I'm telling you to do it, so you have to. A task is basically just something you have to do, so that's what this is.

mnemonics.meaning: You cut the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leaf</mark> with your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark> into <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ten thousand</mark> pieces!
mnemonics.reading: Now that you have ten thousand pieces of tiny leaf paper, you decide to turn them into a manga (まん)! Each little leaf piece will become a panel.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> you use in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> is very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wide</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You like being wide because it makes you feel like a different person. But not just any person, like a super hero (ひろ)!

mnemonics.meaning: You’ve got a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> with lots of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ice</mark>. But doesn't any winter have lots of ice? Exactly. That's why this is just <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">winter</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Winter is also the time of year you give out presents: "One fu' you, one fu' you and… one fu' you (ふゆ)!"

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bamboo</mark> kanji are exactly the same!
mnemonics.reading: Today is free bamboo day, so just take (たけ) all the bamboo you want.

mnemonics.meaning: The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> and the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">car</mark> are exactly the same.
mnemonics.reading: When we need to remember the reading しゃ, we use "shaman".

mnemonics.meaning: The radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">center</mark> and the kanji for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">center</mark> are exactly the same.
mnemonics.reading: Remember that guy from the 央 radical fastening his belt across the center of his body? This guy always secures his belt at the center — not slightly to the left, not slightly to the right, but dead center. His precision is so mind-blowing that everyone watching can't help but say, "Ohh!"(おう).

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> of this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">beggar</mark> is on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>. Except it's not exactly the ground, it's a giant <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">copy</mark> machine, and he's making copies of his forehead!
mnemonics.reading: This ground copy machine can only be the work of one person: a shaman (しゃ)!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">samurai</mark> didn't become leader by sitting around not taking action. He got to where he is by <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">doing</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: He was doing things with sheep (し). He is the leader of the sheep clan, and he was able to do more with sheep than anyone else. That's why he's the leader.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ear</mark> radical and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ear</mark> kanji are the same in looks as well as meaning.
mnemonics.reading: Put your hand to your ear and sing... "Mimimimimimiiiii!" (みみ) and listen to your tone with your ear.

mnemonics.meaning: When the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> is over the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> it's time to go to church... which is so darn <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">early</mark>. And if you want to get to church early, you need to be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fast</mark>, otherwise you'll be too late.
mnemonics.reading: To remember the そう reading we use the word "soul."

mnemonics.meaning: These days <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">energy</mark> is the greatest <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure</mark>. Not gold, money, or anything like that. Imagine finding some in a literal treasure chest. As soon as you open it, out bursts the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">energy</mark> in a kind of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">spirit</mark> ball.
mnemonics.reading: As you reach inside the energy spirit ball, you feel something hard inside. It's a large key (き) that gives you access to another treasure.

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark> your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> you need to lay them <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">flat</mark>. If they aren't flat they'll always be a little damp somewhere and you'll never have a moment's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">peace</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Being flat isn't enough, so you cover the whole thing in hay (へい). Hay absorbs water, so you add a flat layer of it.

mnemonics.meaning: All these <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> were planted by your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> with nothing but a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark>. Now the whole place is absolutely full with beautiful <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">flower</mark>s. Flowers everywhere.
mnemonics.reading: But for some reason, the leader just can't stop planting flowers... He's going crazy. Maybe it's the pollen? Now there’s only one person that can save him: Hannah (はな).

mnemonics.meaning: The radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">foot</mark> and the kanji for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">foot</mark> are exactly the same.
mnemonics.reading: What do you wear on your foot? You wear a sock (そく).

mnemonics.meaning: Take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">street</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hit</mark> some people! Street fingers are for curling into a fist. And that street fist wants to do some hitting!
mnemonics.reading: As you hit one chump after another, suddenly your dad (だ) comes marching out of your house. Uh oh. Dad caught you hitting, which, honestly, isn't a very nice thing to do, so he has every right to stop you.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hole</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hole</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Spectacular!
mnemonics.reading: Ana (あな) fell into a hole. Laugh at Ana and her unfortunate misfortune of having fallen into a hole like a ninny. Haha, Ana – you’re stupid and clumsy!

mnemonics.meaning: There is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leaf</mark> growing out of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>! You fly out into space to check it out and when you get closer you see that it isn't just one leaf, it's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hundred</mark>! That makes sense, you wouldn't be able to see just one leaf on the sun from where you were on earth.
mnemonics.reading: You fly closer, counting all one hundred leaves when you hear a strange sound. You take off your space helmet and hear, "GUH HYUCK (ひゃく)!" You know that laugh... it's Goofy! On top of the hundredth leaf is Goofy laughing and waving around. He must have built this leaf tower to get your attention.

mnemonics.meaning: Add a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of something magical to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark> and suddenly it turns into big block of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ice</mark>, just like that.
mnemonics.reading: When you think of ice, I want you to think of someone frozen with ice. Do you know anyone named Corey (こおり)? Anyone famous named Corey, perhaps Corey Feldman? Imagine this Corey person frozen solid with ice.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark> radical and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">insect</mark> are the same in looks as well as and meaning.
mnemonics.reading: It's an insect! Get it! You squish it with your foot - what sound does it make? A mush (むし) sound.

mnemonics.meaning: The radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">man</mark> and the kanji for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">man</mark> are exactly the same.
mnemonics.reading: When you think of a man, think of dawn (だん), because that man has to get up at dawn to power his rice paddy every day.

mnemonics.meaning: The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">master</mark> and the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">master</mark> have the same meanings!
mnemonics.reading: Do you remember back to the radical mnemonic, where the master is floating a water drop above his head? Imagine back to there. Once you do, the most amazing thing happens. The master sends the drop of water into a chute (しゅ) and it goes careening through an intricate series of them.

mnemonics.meaning: What is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">evening</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>? Imagine a mouth that’s up in the night sky. It’s just there, talking, and only comes out at night. It only appears in one area of the world (what area would you choose? Imagine yourself going to that place to see the “night mouth.”), and appears only one month out of the year (more on this in a second). The “evening mouth” is the most famous thing in the _____ area (this is the area you choose). He’s so <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">famous</mark> that everybody knows his <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">name</mark> (“Evening Mouth.”).
mnemonics.reading: So, when does “Evening Mouth” appear? Turns out, “Evening Mouth” only comes out to talk in May (めい). You know this because it’s just starting to be spring, and when you look around (you’re watching “Evening Mouth” again) you see some spring flowers come up.

mnemonics.meaning: The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">not</mark> and the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">not</mark> are the same thing! That makes it easy... Not!
mnemonics.reading: To remember ふ we'll use the word "fool."

mnemonics.meaning: There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> (in our case, it's a hatch), and inside is some kind of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> you can't quite get to. If you've ever seen Lost, this will sound familiar... on the hatch, there's actually a series of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">number</mark>s that you don't understand.
mnemonics.reading: "You want to know the number to the hatch?" yells an old voice from inside. You say "yes," and the voice gives you the numbers and you're in! You go down into the prison, where there is one prisoner: Grandpa ごういち.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">origin</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">origin</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: The origin of everything can be found in Genji (げん). Genji is the name of the main character in the world's first ever novel, "The Tale of Genji."

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alligators</mark>... she's no ordinary leader, that's for sure. She's not a politician.. she's not a queen... She's one of the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Other</mark> Ones, a group of strange, eccentric people who become leaders of animals.
mnemonics.reading: To remember the reading た, we use the word "Taco"

mnemonics.meaning: If someone tries to dig up <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> life, tell them no thanks, that stuff is in the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">past</mark>. Some things should stay in the past. Not everyone needs to know everything about your life and your past.
mnemonics.reading: To remember the reading きょ, we'll use "Little Kyoto." This will differentiate きょ from きょう, which is regular-sized Kyoto. Get it? You decide to bury all this private dirt from your past in Little Kyoto (きょ). That stuff is from when you were just a little 子 (こ) and you don't like to think about it.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">plate</mark> kanji and the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">plate</mark> radical are exactly the same, like two matching pieces of china.
mnemonics.reading: The person washing all the dishes was named Sarah (さら). She was named that because of her large head, which was shaped like Sarah Jessica Parker’s head (very big).

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Slide</mark> some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">legs</mark> so you can feel like you're from a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">previous</mark> time. Everything from the past is in the dirt. Dead people, dinosaur bones, your mom's secrets in a box from her past life. All these things come back to you as you slide the dirt all over your legs.
mnemonics.reading: As you sit there, pretending you're in a previous time you see a centaur (せん)! That's right! Centaurs are from wayyyy in the past.

mnemonics.meaning: The radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">red</mark> and the kanji for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">red</mark> are the same thing!
mnemonics.reading: This kanji means red, AKA, also known as, あか.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> is next to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>. What is he doing? He's leaning against it, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rest</mark>ing.
mnemonics.reading: As he rests, he suddenly gets hungry and pulls a cucumber (きゅう) off the tree and bites into it. A good rest isn't complete without some crunchy tree cucumbers.

mnemonics.meaning: There’s a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>, so the things you say are very pious. Everything you say, you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">say humbly</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: As you're saying all these humble things, you're also mowing (もう) your neighbor's lawn. Your neighbors love you so much, because you're so humble, and you mow their lawn for them.

mnemonics.meaning: The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">see</mark> and the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">see</mark> are exactly the same!
mnemonics.reading: You see something. It's walking towards you, but you need to see better. When the person comes close, you realize "That person is me (み)!"

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shellfish</mark> kanji are the same! It can be just the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shell</mark> part too.
mnemonics.reading: To get some shellfish, all you have to do is hop in your kayak (かい) and get some. Shellfish live in the water.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark> radical and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stone</mark> kanji are the same thing!
mnemonics.reading: You throw a stone through a window... and, now you can see something very sexy (せき).

mnemonics.meaning: What do you get if you lend a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">umbrella</mark>? <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Thanks</mark>, of course! Especially if that spirit is Totoro, the spirit of the forest.
mnemonics.reading: So what did you receive as a thanks? You open it up, and there's a ray (れい) gun inside!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> radical and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">thread</mark> are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
mnemonics.reading: You have some thread... what's the first thing you do with it? You take it and put it in your mouth, and start sucking it down like spaghetti. You have decided to eat (いと) the thread.

mnemonics.meaning: When you see both a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">street</mark> in the same place, you have the makings of a whole <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">town</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: You go to visit this nice little town. But then, there she is... Every time you walk down the street, the street-woman Mrs. Chou (ちょう) arrives to ruin your day.

mnemonics.meaning: Under his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark>, the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> stares into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of water containing his greatest <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">treasure</mark>. Just kidding, the king has way more treasure than that. The drop of water is just reflecting what's around him: mounds and mounds of treasure, stacked all the way up to the roof.
mnemonics.reading: All of this treasure is kept in the king's home (ほう). He can't let other people see how much treasure he has, or they'll get mad. Or worse, ask him to share some with his people. Yuck. The treasure stays at home.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone's taking <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurements</mark>… Why are they taking measurements of trees? Because they're planning to cut them down to make their <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">village</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: They take all the wood back to where they're building their village, and once they construct the village center they paint a mural (むら) on the side of it. The mural is of the forest where they got the trees from, to honor the village's origins.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">world</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">world</mark> kanji are the same, but there is another really important meaning you need to know: <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">generation</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: It's your job to protect the world and every generation with your special saber (せい). It was given to you to uphold correctness, and you'll pass it on to the next generation when it's time. Then they'll watch out for the world when you're gone.

mnemonics.meaning: You have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cow</mark>, which must mean it's that time of the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">year</mark>! Every year on New Year's Eve, you get asked to shoot a cow, as per tradition. You really don't want to though, so you deliberately miss every time.
mnemonics.reading: It seems everyone has caught on to the fact that you deliberately miss every year, so this year you make a nendoroid (ねん) decoy in the shape of a cow.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">angle</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">angle</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: To see those kanji angles from every angle, you cock (かく) your head to the side.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">axe</mark> kanji are exactly the same, with one minor difference. This kanji is also used as the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bread loaf counter</mark>, probably because bread was so big and hard in the past that they had to use axes to slice them.
mnemonics.reading: You imagined being back in time too good and now you're stuck using an axe to be a bread loaf counter for the King (きん) of England. You aren't sure which king he is or when in time you are, but he's mean and keeps eating all the bread you cut up with your axe.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blue</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">blue</mark> kanji are exactly the same.
mnemonics.reading: You've been feeling really blue. Mostly because your skin, hair, and eyes have all turned blue. It was an out-of-the-blue transformation! But now someone places his hand on your shoulder and points at your saber (せい). It's blue too! You aren't alone!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">book</mark> all about the human <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">body</mark>. Knowing about bodies is a privilege. One that only leaders get—it helps them control all their subjects, like you.
mnemonics.reading: The leader's body book also taught her about something very body specific: how to tie a tie (たい). You can't have a tie on your body, no no. Those are for the leader and her smart body.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">color</mark> radical and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">color</mark> are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
mnemonics.reading: You already have color on the mind because you know the meaning of this kanji, so think of something colorful about yourself. Imagine your ear (いろ) being a weird color... green, purple, red, whatever. Just make it really bright and standing out.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> is scattered with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark>, which will cause the Predator to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">come</mark> because he loves rice. Then once he's gone, the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">next</mark> Predator will come to eat.
mnemonics.reading: When they come, though, they're all disappointed. It turns out it's rye (らい) grains, and rye grains taste terrible. Yuck.

mnemonics.meaning: Plant a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> before you start your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">company</mark> and it will be successful. That's what all the great, old Japanese companies did back in the olden days. That's why companies like Mitsubishi have been around for hundreds of years. They planted a spirit in the dirt to help their company grow, and grow it did!
mnemonics.reading: Where did you learn about this method of company growing? From a shaman (しゃ), of course. Shamans aren't just spouting nonsense, they know what they're talking about. And spirits are right up their shaman alley.

mnemonics.meaning: What superhero is most like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">triceratops</mark>? …If you said <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark>, you're <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">correct</mark>! Why is that the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">right</mark> answer? Because the triceratops has three horns, and Wolverine has three blades coming out of his hands. It's obvious, isn't it? But you knew that of course.
mnemonics.reading: Because you got the answer correct, you win a free trip to とうきょう. Congrats!

mnemonics.meaning: You have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> full of two massive <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark>s and… <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure</mark>?! Upon closer inspection, they appear to form some sort of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">diagram</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: After decades of analyzing the diagram, scientists found out it leads to… a zoo (ず)?!

mnemonics.meaning: You have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark> and you see some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">windows</mark>. What do you think you're going to do with this gun? Of course, you're going to shoot the windows... <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">every</mark> single one of them. <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Each</mark> and every one.
mnemonics.reading: Now that every window is broken, you feel pretty stupid because mice (まい) are pouring in through each one. You've made a way for mice to get into your house. That wasn't smart.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">feathers</mark> radical and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">feather</mark> kanji are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
mnemonics.reading: You've gathered feather after feather, like some kind of wannabe birdman or birdwoman, and now you're ready to fly. But as soon as you're about to take off, someone dumps honey (はね) on you, making your feathers all goopy.

mnemonics.meaning: You have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> and another <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>. You basically have yourself a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">forest</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: So, now you have this forest and you want to cut it down (so much money!). But, you don't have any tools, only your hands. You think... I've done karate for a while, so I can probably chop it down that way. You get in a chopping stance, then do your battle cry and hit: "HAYA ... .SHI******!" (はやし)

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">go</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">go</mark> kanji are exactly the same!
mnemonics.reading: "Oh, did he go again?" When こういち is not around, that's what people often say because he goes to the gyoza (ぎょう) restaurant almost every day. こういち just loves gyoza so much, you always know where he is when he is not home.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gold</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: The most gold in the land belongs to the King (きん) of England. In fact, you've never actually met someone with gold, it all goes straight to the King whenever someone finds some. You just have a few pennies to work with.

mnemonics.meaning: You plant your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> in the light of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> in the shape of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark>, but it's too hot—the sun is too strong—and you end up with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">grass</mark>. Flowers can't grow in these conditions.
mnemonics.reading: The grass on top is brown and burned from the sun, so you need to take a cool saw (くさ) and hack the tops off. The saw is actually physically cool to the touch, to help heal the grass' sunburned bits. It just happens to look cool too.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">village</mark> you always think of first is your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hometown</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Your hometown is where you sat (さと), nostalgia tugging at your heartstrings amid the endless rice fields and dirt.

mnemonics.meaning: You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">triceratops</mark> in the distance. But, it's odd. It's perfectly <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pi</mark> shaped (that is, circular, like a pie). Some kind of piceratops, if you will. The reason they are this shape is because they want to absorb as much <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">light</mark> as possible. They evolved to be round so they don't have any corners casting a shadow.
mnemonics.reading: As you watch this majestic beast absorbing light, suddenly several dozen feral こういちs burst out from the wilderness, spears in hand. Oh no! Those こういちs are hunting this rare piceratops!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">key</mark> is the key that <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">make</mark>s all the other keys. It's sort of like the one ring to rule them all, the one ring to bind them... except with keys.
mnemonics.reading: The leader makes all the keys and puts them in a sack (さく) to distribute them to the underlings, who then cut them into shape with a saw (さ).

mnemonics.meaning: How many <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">evenings</mark> are there? There are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">many</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: To remember the reading た we use the word "taco."

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">meat</mark> radical and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">meat</mark> are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
mnemonics.reading: You know who loves meat? Nick (にく). You probably know a Nick — imagine him eating some succulent meat right now.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">meet</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">meet</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: What better way to meet new people than to start kayaking (かい)! Get into your kayak and just float out into the water. You'll eventually bump into someone else in a kayak and boom, you're meeting someone new!

mnemonics.meaning: You put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">father</mark>. But, he won't taste good alone, so you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mix</mark> in some other ingredients. They <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mingle</mark> inside the pot with him.
mnemonics.reading: With a mix of your father and other ingredients mingling in your cooking pot, you lift up the lid... your father pops up. Your father is こういち. He stares back at you with a big smile.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> has an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark>, and they're getting <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">near</mark> to you really fast! Oh no, they're so <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">close</mark> now, you need to get out of here!
mnemonics.reading: As they draw near, you recognize who is riding the scooter: the King (きん) of England! Behind him, a bunch of his guards also on scooters and wielding axes appear and move close to you.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">night</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">night</mark> kanji are exactly the same.
mnemonics.reading: You call your friend at night and say "Yo, Lou (よる)!"

mnemonics.meaning: Who's someone who's just a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">legs</mark>? That's your know-it-all <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">older brother</mark>, who won't shut up about anything.
mnemonics.reading: You wish you could box your loud-mouth older brother up and send him far away to きょうと. きょうと is super far away from where you currently live, so just ship your older bro off so he can never bother you again.

mnemonics.meaning: When the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> is bright, it's easy to see that a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pig</mark> is indeed a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pig</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Legend has it that if you catch a pig in moonlight, it will tell you its secrets. Sure enough, this pig tells you it's from Bhutan (ぶた).

mnemonics.meaning: The radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rain</mark> and the kanji for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rain</mark> are the same thing.
mnemonics.reading: What if the rain actually tried to aim (あめ) for you? As in, drops would move out of their normal flight path just to hit you on your head? You'd be a lot wetter, that's for sure.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> radical and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rice</mark> kanji are the same in looks and meaning. This kanji can also mean <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">America</mark>, maybe because America is covered in rice or fields or something?
mnemonics.reading: A ton of rice is grown in America. And yet you never see rice in American cuisine. So where's all that unused rice going? Actually, it all gets dumped into a big bay (べい). They have too much rice and no place to store it, so they've started using bays to store it.

mnemonics.meaning: The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">run</mark> and the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">run</mark> are exactly the same!
mnemonics.reading: You run and run and run and suddenly you feel your soul (そう) leave your body. Still running, you turn around and see your soul running a few steps behind you.

mnemonics.meaning: There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mustache</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>. Upon closer inspection, you see that the mustache on the ground is exactly the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">same</mark> as yours!
mnemonics.reading: When we need to remember the reading どう, we use the word "doughnut".

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">say</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: If you aren't sure what to say, just think about Genji (げん) and ask yourself, "What would Genji say?"

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">self</mark> radical and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">self</mark> are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
mnemonics.reading: When we need to remember じ we use the word "Jesus."

mnemonics.meaning: You're walking at night when you discover a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lantern</mark> covered entirely in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark>, making it a very strange <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shape</mark>. In fact, this is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">form</mark> you'd never expect a lantern to take.
mnemonics.reading: You stare at the shape until you finally recognize it: cake (けい)! Well, it's hairy, glowing cake, but it's still shaped like a big slice of cake.

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> down a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">branch</mark> and your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">skin</mark> scrapes right off — ouch! Lucky for you, it was just your old outer layer of skin, and now you've got a fresh shiny layer. Yay for exfoliation! You're not sure what to do with this big, floppy layer of old skin, though…
mnemonics.reading: Without your rough old skin to protect you, you feel the full heat (ひ) of the sun now. It burns… it burns! Yeah, you better protect that fresh new skin from the heat.

mnemonics.meaning: What was the biggest <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hole</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark> of the world? The <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sky</mark>. If you think about it, the sky is like a big hole someone forgot to fill in. That's why this kanji also means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">empty</mark>! Makes sense — nothing is more empty than the sky.
mnemonics.reading: The sky is usually empty until clouds stage a coup (くう). Basically you can think of the sky as the site for one coup after another as the weather changes.

mnemonics.meaning: For some reason, you are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark>ing on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>. It's obviously very hot, but the thing you notice most is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sound</mark> of you burning up.
mnemonics.reading: This sound isn't just loud, it's familiar. Finally you place it: onions (おん)!

mnemonics.meaning: You have a wild <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">viking</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark> you have to take care of. He won't do anything but <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">study</mark>, surprisingly. You can't get him to eat, use the bathroom, or anything else. He just wants to study.
mnemonics.reading: This crazy viking child who prefers study over pillaging (and other viking activities)... the other vikings just stop and gawk (がく) at him when they walk by.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> for the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ceremony</mark> can't come so you need a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">substitute</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">replace</mark> them ASAP!
mnemonics.reading: The substitute leader is wearing the wrong color clothes, so you have to dye (だい) them, like they did in the olden ages.

mnemonics.meaning: In a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">coffin</mark> there's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">beggar</mark>, doing his begging. But it doesn't work, nobody helps him. So, he just begins to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">think</mark>: Why am I in this situation? How could I have avoided it? How will I get out? Think, dammit, think!!
mnemonics.reading: What does the beggar think of? A thought bubble appears near his head. In it is a picture of こういち! He's thinking that if こういち were here, he'd save him. Oh, if only こういち could save us all!

mnemonics.meaning: There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> inside a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>. But if you look even closer (not actually, but we're pretending), you can see another mouth inside that mouth... and another one inside of that one! It keeps going and going. Can you count the number of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">times</mark> there's a mouth inside a mouth? This kanji also means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">revolve</mark> too. Think of each "time" a thing happens, it loops back around and comes back to the beginning, revolving around again another time.
mnemonics.reading: If you're having a hard time wrapping your head around the infinite number of times these mouths revolve, just picture yourself in a little kayak (かい) going around and down through the mouths.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Fins</mark> decorate a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hat</mark>, with (presumably fish) <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouths</mark> stitched to it. Who wears strange hats like this? Turns out, the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">valley</mark> people are the ones who wear these. I'm talking about the "Valley Girls" of Los Angeles, California. They're into the crazy fashion, and they'll wear anything if it's deemed "cool" or something like that.
mnemonics.reading: Hanging around with all the Valley Girls in the sunny area of LA is also a robot. It's WALL-E's distant (and lazy, lounging) relative, TAN-E (たに). He sits around getting a tan in LA with the Valley Girls while his cousin picks up trash.

mnemonics.meaning: You have a samurai with a flag on a stick. On his flag is the symbol 声, the kanji for voice. Why does he have that there? He feels like his Shogun isn't giving him and his fellow Samurai a voice, so he's brought a flag with the word "voice" written on it to protest.
mnemonics.reading: You decide to join the samurai’s protest for more voice but immediately notice… they’re all 子, eh (こえ)?!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">west</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">west</mark> kanji are the same. Isn't that nice?
mnemonics.reading: You go off to the west. It's the Wild West, even. There aren't many people out here, making it easy to find a niche (にし) for your snake oil business.

mnemonics.meaning: Our <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lip ring</mark>. Wait, our leader has a lip ring? <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">WHAT</mark>??
mnemonics.reading: The leader with his lip ring is now eating some naan (なん) and curry. It's delicious, of course... but then he gets it caught on his lip ring, and tears half his lip off. He screams: "Nannnnn eeeeeeeeeehhh!!" (なに) in anger at the naan and curry.
