mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark> radical is without the slide (as it sometimes is), but when you combine that with the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> radical, you have life during winter. What gives you life during the winter? It's the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wheat</mark> you store away.
mnemonics.reading: You found your wheat. Thank God. You'll survive. You have to take the wheat back to your house, though. On your way, you get mugged (むぎ).

mnemonics.meaning: There is someone wearing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark>, holding a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bow</mark>, and going down a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> held up by a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stick</mark>. What type of person do you imagine? I'd say someone who's an immature boy. That would be your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">younger brother</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Your younger brother loves playing dress-up so much that he's now started dyeing (だい) his hair all kinds of colors.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hat</mark> crowns the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark>, because <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">all</mark> kings must have one.
mnemonics.reading: But, as you're going through all the kings, it turns out not all of them have hats after all. The last one you come to is hatless. He's the king of Zen (ぜん). He has simple clothes and a shaved head, unlike all the other fancy kings standing around nearby.

mnemonics.meaning: If you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark> around to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poop</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> you never know what could be happening <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">behind</mark> you. <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">After</mark> you're done you could turn <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">back</mark> to see something really crazy that you missed because you took so long to poop in the cold.
mnemonics.reading: You finally look behind you and see Godzilla (ご) and a giant こういち having a violent battle back there!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blood</mark> radical and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">blood</mark> are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
mnemonics.reading: To remember the reading けつ, we use the word "ketsup." The perfect mix of ketchup and catsup!

mnemonics.meaning: As you dig under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> you discover a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">head</mark> resting near a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark>, which are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">both</mark> strange things to find beneath the earth.
mnemonics.reading: But, you dig too deep and water flows into where you are. Your only hope is a row (りょう) boat floating off in the distance.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark> is a powerful thing. Even something as ordinary as a spoon can create great <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">change</mark> in the world when given to the right person.
mnemonics.reading: Then, this hero of yours takes their spoon and says some magic words into it, changing it into a car (か).

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> extends all the way around him (like in this kanji). Where his mouth reaches, that is his <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">country</mark>, give or take a few <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark>s.
mnemonics.reading: Turns out the king of this country loves drinking Coke (こく). Every morning that big mouth of his swallows a whole 2-liter bottle of Coke for breakfast.

mnemonics.meaning: The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">death</mark> and the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">death</mark> are the same.
mnemonics.reading: Your death will be because of a bowling (ぼう) accident. Oh, you didn't know? You're going to be hit by a giant bowling ball and crushed flat.

mnemonics.meaning: If the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yakuza</mark> hands you a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark>, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">death</mark> is coming for you. It's the death spoon, a sign that the yakuza is coming to cause your death.
mnemonics.reading: Death comes in the form of a sheep (し). The death sheep works for the yakuza, and kills anyone who has their spoon.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alligator</mark> lives in the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">earth</mark>, not the water. They can swim through the earth itself! Which is pretty scary.
mnemonics.reading: The only way to keep this dirt alligator from dragging you under the earth and eating you is to feed it cheese (ち). That way it won't lead you to a horrific death under the earth by dragging you under and spinning you around until you eat dirt (literally).

mnemonics.meaning: This is the same as the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">east</mark>, so it means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">east</mark> too.
mnemonics.reading: You see a man walk straight toward the sun rising in the east. It's so bright he can't see anything, so he trips and he gashes (ひがし) his knee on a rock. Yikes… But he gets back up, determined to head east, and, oh no, he gashes his other knee! OK, he should probably give up on going east.

mnemonics.meaning: The radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eat</mark> and the kanji for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">eat</mark> are the same! Lucky you.
mnemonics.reading: Thank goodness, you finally get to eat your meal. You're so hungry. Someone has been starving you and now they've finally given you food. Unfortunately, though, every time you take a bite, you get a shock (しょく) from somewhere.

mnemonics.meaning: There are some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">front</mark> of you. When you try to move, they always rotate around with you, staying right in front. You can't escape these objects, for some reason.
mnemonics.reading: You're going crazy with these things in front of you all the time. You finally seek the help of a Zen (ぜん) master, who tells you that meditation will save you from this curse. You try it out, and sure enough, the objects are gone! It worked!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">narwhal</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> is all you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">have</mark>. Imagine one of each under your arms.
mnemonics.reading: Everything you have (except the narwhal and the moon) were taken from you by a roving gang of youths (ゆう).

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">house</mark> radical makes up the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">house</mark> kanji! Pretty easy. This kanji is also used to mean <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">home</mark>, so try to remember that too.
mnemonics.reading: What do you do in your house? You eat eggs (いえ), that's what. You eat eggs three times a day, every day. You really love eating eggs in your home!

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark>s are meant to stay <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">private</mark>! You shouldn't be sharing them with the whole town, they're just for you.
mnemonics.reading: You're getting into the zone, thinking about yourself (I) and how much you love having things that are private and just yours, when you realize there is a sheep (し) in this grain bag. And it's eating all of your (I's) private grains. No!

mnemonics.meaning: You take an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> because you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">know</mark> too much. You know some very sensitive information, and someone's sent a bow-slinging enforcer to pin your big blabbermouth shut with arrows.
mnemonics.reading: One of the things you know too much about is the sheep (し) plan for world domination! Yes, you know that sheep are in fact plotting to overthrow humanity and take over the world.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tongue</mark>s is coming at you. As it washes over you, you feel each individual tongue moving around on your body, licking you. They make you feel so... <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lively</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: This lively feeling isn't just happening to you, the tongue tsunami is licking it into all of the cats (かつ) in your neighborhood too!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">long</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">long</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: You see a very long person. It's Mrs. Chou (ちょう), who has made herself long, like her street. "I made myself long so I can watch more of the street, my domain. I'm the leader of these streets. Watch yourself not-long person," says Mrs. Chou.

mnemonics.meaning: There are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>s, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">twenty</mark> of them, singing beautiful <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">music</mark> together. The music seems to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bend</mark> toward you through the air.
mnemonics.reading: The twenty mouths make so much music that they literally cloak you (きょく) with it. They cloak you with the music.

mnemonics.meaning: The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">neck</mark> and the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">neck</mark> are exactly the same!
mnemonics.reading: The only thing you do with your neck is use it to swallow lots of cool beans (くび). Mm mm. Feel those cool, cool beans sliding down your neck. You don't really taste them, but you know they're there.

mnemonics.meaning: The only <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> in this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">city</mark> is your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">older sister</mark>. She's the only woman surrounded by a bunch of men, but she's following her dreams in the big city.
mnemonics.reading: Your older sister may have moved to the city, but she kept her pet sheep (し) with her. Now the only woman in the city is your older sister, and the only sheep is her pet.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fortune</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark>s down to a single <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">point</mark> in time. One point in time determines how the rest of your future will go.
mnemonics.reading: As you stare at the point, you watch in awe as it moves to the ten (てん) spot in a long series of numbers.

mnemonics.meaning: With a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> over her head, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">relax</mark>. She doesn't have to worry about rain or snow or finding a place to sleep. The roof also happened to be super <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cheap</mark>, so she can even relax about her finances.
mnemonics.reading: As she relaxes, she pulls out the cheapest, most relaxing food in the world: anchovies (あん).

mnemonics.meaning: You put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> over the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> to make your own <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> patch of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>. This is your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">room</mark>! That's really all a room is, you know? A covered, private place where you can have some time to yourself.
mnemonics.reading: The only problem with your room is that you can't always be alone. Because of your dad's shih tzu (しつ). The shih tzu likes to come into your room and pee everywhere. Ruining your privacy completely.

mnemonics.meaning: You scoop some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark>s into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ladle</mark> to do <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">science</mark>. You're doing experiments on these grains in your science <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">course</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Using your science skills, the right temperatures and measurements, you manage to get these grains to grow into a car (か). This is the science department's special car now!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> is coming, so you point your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark> out the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">window</mark> at it. "You better turn back, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sea</mark>, or I'll shoot!"
mnemonics.reading: The sea decides it doesn't want to die today, so it turns its tsunami around and goes the other way. You hop in your kayak (かい) and chase after it with your gun, to make sure it actually returns to the sea and doesn't just drown someone else.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sheep</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sheep</mark> kanji are the same in looks as well in meaning.
mnemonics.reading: To remember よう, we use the word "Yogurt." The sheep are after you. There are too many of them, and they're chasing you down, stalking you... because you stole their sheep's milk yogurt (よう). Now you're running and crying and trying to eat the yogurt before the sheep catch up and stomp you down with their hooves.

mnemonics.meaning: A long time ago, someone put up a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> over their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fortune</mark> telling booth and created the first <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shop</mark>. This <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">store</mark> was fortune-based, but since then lots of different stores have popped up!
mnemonics.reading: This shop quickly turned into ten (てん) shops! It was a good idea, after all, so all of the other people selling goods and services decided to copy it and create their own shops. The next day there were ten more.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> that gives <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark> is our very own <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">star</mark> (which we happen to call the sun). Of course, all the other stars are probably giving life to other planets as well.
mnemonics.reading: "All these life-giving stars need a protector," you say, pulling out your saber (せい). It's a big responsibility, but with your trusty saber in hand, you're sure you can defend our star system.

mnemonics.meaning: Think about Japan. Japan is a country made up of islands. They're basically three <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark>s in the large <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">river</mark> that is the Pacific Ocean. These are Japan's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">states</mark> or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">province</mark>s.
mnemonics.reading: Each state has its own shoe (しゅう) to represent it. The bottom of each shoe is the shape of the state, so when you step it leaves a state-shaped imprint in the ground.

mnemonics.meaning: There's an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ear</mark> just sitting on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>. Nobody's watching, so, you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">take</mark> it.
mnemonics.reading: You're the kind of person who likes to take things. "What things?" you ask. Little toes (と). Because that isn't creepy.

mnemonics.meaning: If you can steal the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> that adorn a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hat</mark> worn by an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">angel</mark>, you can use them to make delicious <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tea</mark>. Naturally, angels decorate their hats with only the most aromatic and delicious flowers fit for brewing.
mnemonics.reading: After brewing the tea, you look at the hat again and find a nametag inside that says Chad (ちゃ). You decide that from now on this tea variety will be known as Chad tea, in honor of Chad.

mnemonics.meaning: In a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> you find a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> and it makes you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">think</mark>. You think a lot of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">thought</mark>s like, "Whose heart is this? Why is it in a rice paddy? Why am I thinking out loud?"
mnemonics.reading: As you are thinking these thoughts, you spot someone on the edge of the rice field. He really reminds you of someone. But who? That's it! He reminds you of that bartender on The Simpsons. What's his name? You think some more. What is it? Oh! Moe (おも) is his name!

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stop</mark> at a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">small</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark>. What were you doing before you stopped here? You were <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">walk</mark>ing.
mnemonics.reading: So, you're walking around, minding your own business, when suddenly something flips up and whacks you in the face. You stepped on the head of a hoe (ほ) and it caused it to swing up from the ground and hit you.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> hits your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mustache</mark>. Where did it come from? "Ah, it came from <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">yonder</mark>," you say, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">facing</mark> that way.
mnemonics.reading: Who shot this drop at you from yonder? You look over yonder, and see a figure. It is こういち.

mnemonics.meaning: Who's that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> pretending to be a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jet</mark>? That's my <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">younger sister</mark>. *Sigh*
mnemonics.reading: Your younger sister is giving some mice (まい) a ride on her back like a jet.

mnemonics.meaning: While riding your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark>, you take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark> and cut out an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">area</mark> on the ground.  You carefully cut all the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">side</mark>s as you go. This area's all yours now!
mnemonics.reading: As you look down at your area with its sword-carved sides, you suddenly realize there is a hen (へん) pecking at the ground in there. "Um, excuse me, hen, I believe I said this is MY area?!" You try to kick it out, but it hops over your leg.

mnemonics.meaning: When you take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark>s, you realize they're too short, so you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">attach</mark> things to them to make the measurements more impressive. Attach some heels to the shoes, then attach another head on top of theirs. There — perfect measurements thanks to these attachments.
mnemonics.reading: You have to remember the kun'yomi reading of this kanji, and the part you need to remember is つ. So, think of how you would attach something to something else. What would you need? You'd need two (つ) things to put together!

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> has an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">umbrella</mark>, which it's holding over its head. Strange, because trees normally like water… Turns out, this tree wasn't getting showered in water, but in dollar <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bill</mark>s instead.
mnemonics.reading: And the person who gave the tree an umbrella to protect it from all those bills? Satsuki (さつ), a little girl famous for… handing out umbrellas, I guess. Makes sense that Satsuki would take care of these bills then.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bird</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bird</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: Think of a run-of-the-mill bird, whatever comes to mind for you first is fine. Then, your lovely bird swells. The shape of a face, then a hand, start stretching the bird apart until it explodes outward. Covered in blood and feathers is Mrs. Chou (ちょう).

mnemonics.meaning: The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">black</mark> and the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">black</mark> are exactly the same.
mnemonics.reading: You're in a completely black room. There's no way out, and you can't see. The room starts to fill with liquid. It gets in your mouth. You taste it. It's Coke (こく)! Mm, tasty Coke.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boat</mark> has <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>! It's still a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">boat</mark> though.
mnemonics.reading: This boat belongs to the centaurs (せん). That's probably why you've never seen a boat like it before.

mnemonics.meaning: Through the patient's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> runs a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark>. It's a mad scientist's experiment to see if it's a good way to drain the body of blood. The patient is alive for now… but he's definitely slated for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">certain</mark> death.
mnemonics.reading: As the beeping heart thing starts to do one long continuous beeeeeeeeeeeeeep, the scientist puts his hands together and hits (ひつ) the dead patient over and over, attempting to bring him back.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">elephant</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">elephant</mark> kanji are the same. But! This kanji has another meaning: <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">phenomenon</mark>. If you were the first person to see an elephant, you'd call it that too.
mnemonics.reading: Elephants are great and all, except that when they die they turn into elephant zombies (ぞう). But you never see these zombies because the shougun (しょう) has a special project in place that destroys all elephant bodies when they die.

mnemonics.meaning: This kanji uses a modified <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jet</mark> radical. The front area of the wing is wider than the middle area of the wing. This may seem counterintuitive, but by doing this they can fit so much more jet fuel. The jet zooms off and keeps going for a long, long time, until it reaches the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">end</mark> of the earth.
mnemonics.reading: When you get to the end of the world, you land your jet and put out a few mats (まつ) to sit on so you can view the sights.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clan</mark> is where you get your name. But not your given name, your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">family name</mark>. That's why people have names that mean "in a rice paddy" and "near the ferry crossing." The location of your clan determined your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">surname</mark>! Hope your ancestors didn't live on "Poo Lake" or something.
mnemonics.reading: Don't worry, I'll tell you where your family name came from. Your family used to herd sheep (し). You read that right, your family was of the sheep clan because you took care of sheep all day.

mnemonics.meaning: That <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> is your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">husband</mark>'s only <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fault</mark>. He loves that slide, more than you, and it's the only thing you don't like about him.
mnemonics.reading: You try to come up with another fault of his so you can complain, when you see a tiny shih tzu (しつ) trotting by. Oh no! Before you can call out, your husband has fallen off the slide and crushed the poor thing. You hear a sharp yelp and then nothing.

mnemonics.meaning: The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fish</mark> and the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fish</mark> are exactly the same!
mnemonics.reading: You catch a fish. As you pull it out of the water, it starts yelling and pointing: "GO!" (ぎょ). "GO GYO GYO GYO!" There's a huge cruise ship coming right towards your little fishing boat. No wonder the fish was yelling GO at you.

mnemonics.meaning: Under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark>, you use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> for your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">floor</mark>. It also becomes your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bed</mark>, because hey, what is a floor but the original bed?
mnemonics.reading: It's great having a floor or bed, but whenever you use it you say yucka (ゆか) because it just gets so dirty. That's the one flaw of using a floor as a bed. In fact, it's the dirtiest floor you've ever seen, because it's covered in yucca (ゆか) leaves. You're sleeping on a yucca floor. Ew!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lion</mark> drops a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of saliva onto this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">person</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">from</mark> above. The person is in a much worse place <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">compared with</mark> where they were before, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">since</mark> they only just recently fell into this pit.
mnemonics.reading: From above there is a loud caw, and a giant eagle (い) swoops down, forcing the lion to back off. The eagle grabs the person with its talons, bringing him into the air! But now he's... in the air being carried by a giant eagle, compared with where he was before, is this really better?!

mnemonics.meaning: Sew <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> through your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">top hat</mark> and to the top hats of other people you know and you'll turn into a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">group</mark> of top hat wearing people. You're all connected by the thread now, so everyone will assume you're a group, even if that's all you guys have going for yourselves.
mnemonics.reading: Everyone in this group loves cumin (くみ). You know, the spice or seed. The group take off their top hats and fill them with cumin. You're officially a group for lovers of cumin.

mnemonics.meaning: You go down a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">street</mark> that cuts through a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> and leads to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">box</mark>. When you open the box at the end of the street, you see it's full of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">image</mark>s. Image after image. <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Drawing</mark>, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">painting</mark>, you name it. Someone must have left this box of images here.
mnemonics.reading: Okay, I didn't want to tell you this, but the images are all drawings and paintings of gargoyles (が) and cocks (かく). Male chickens, that is. Turns out that's what you wanted to see most. Don't worry, no one is judging you.

mnemonics.meaning: This kanji is the same as the radical it comes from. <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Lack</mark> becomes <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Lack</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: To remember けつ, we use the word "ketsup." It's the perfect blend of ketchup and catsup!

mnemonics.meaning: You're flying in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jet</mark>. Even though it's one of the fastest things on earth, your child is sitting in the back asking, "Are we there yet? Are we there yet?" You have to keep responding. "<mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Not yet</mark>! Not yet! NOT YET!"
mnemonics.reading: What a selfish kid, right? Well, all he thinks about is "Me (み) me me me me me me me me me me." Hate kids like that.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> that ties you to your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clan</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">paper</mark>. Your papers, that is.
mnemonics.reading: You need this specific paper to prove that you aren't a Commi (かみ), aka a Communist. Or that you are. It really depends on where you want to go and what decade this is.

mnemonics.meaning: There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> with your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mama</mark> carrying a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">task</mark> she needs to get done. You see her <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pass through</mark>, hurrying by to get that task done.
mnemonics.reading: As you watch your mama pass through the house, she yells, "YOU HAVE TO DO THIS TASK TOO (つう)!" Too?! Oh no, now you have to do it too. Hurry up!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clan</mark> are a group of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">people</mark>. They are the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">people</mark> of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">nation</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The mouth clan peoples are a nation of people who use their mouths to say mean (みん) things to other peoples.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">village</mark> is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">reason</mark> he's king. Without the village there would be no reason to have a king in the first place.
mnemonics.reading: You can't have reason without re (り).

mnemonics.meaning: A giant <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> stands above you. "I am <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">reason</mark>!" it says to you. It is the Cross of Reason.
mnemonics.reading: The reason that this Cross of Reason exists is to combat the youths (ゆう) of the world, who just bring chaos into everything.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">center</mark> of the sky gives off its light, which <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">reflect</mark>s off of everything around it.
mnemonics.reading: This reflected light is important for acorns (えい), in particular. Without light reflecting off everything, the sun's light would never make it down to the ground where they've fallen. They would never grow into trees. And we'd all suffocate.

mnemonics.meaning: Next to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> is put on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">father</mark>. "Hello child," he says. "This is your new <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">school</mark>."
mnemonics.reading: Your new school has other students too. They are all こういちs, though.

mnemonics.meaning: When <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rain</mark> falls on <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark>, it turns to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">snow</mark>. He's so emotionally distant and cold that the rain freezes into snow as soon as it gets near him.
mnemonics.reading: You're concerned for Wolverine's mental health. Him being so emotionally cold that he turns rain to snow means you keep (ゆき) asking if he's okay. But that only makes him want to be more distant.

mnemonics.meaning: You've seen this as a radical before, and the kanji means the same thing — <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">south</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: Think about the south. What's down there? Mean Amy (みなみ) lives down there. Think of the last mean thing she did to you and imagine it while yelling out "MEAN AMYYYYY" at the sky.

mnemonics.meaning: You keep your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bow</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> because it's made of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark>s, meaning it's extremely <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">strong</mark>. Insect bodies are really durable, so they make for super strong bows. That's why you have to keep this one private — it's simply too strong to let others get ahold of.
mnemonics.reading: You had this strong bow made especially for you in きょうと. きょうと is famous for their strong bows, so if you ever want another, you know where to go.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leaf</mark> shaped like an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark> only grows in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark>. Every other leaf, however, will do the opposite, which is to grow in the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">summer</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Now it's summertime! What do you do during the summer? You just sit around with your favorite string tying knots (なつ) in it over and over again.

mnemonics.meaning: There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mustache</mark>, covering up all your talking holes. This is because you kept saying how <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tall</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">expensive</mark> you are.
mnemonics.reading: "I am <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tall</mark>er and more <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">expensive</mark> than you."

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">teacher</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> is happiest because they get to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">teach</mark>! The kids can't go out and play because it's too cold. They all have to come in and stay warm as the teacher teaches!
mnemonics.reading: Teachers can teach the most about Japan in winter by going to きょうと. きょうと is where all the old temples and history of Japan is centered. And it's really gorgeous when it snows.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> is used in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">temple</mark> to tell <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">time</mark>. They don't have clocks or cell phones, they have sun dials and good old fashioned "looking up and seeing where the sun is right now."
mnemonics.reading: Time in a temple makes you think of Jesus (じ). Specifically, Jesus being able to perform time travel magic. He winks at you, goes back to the dinosaur ages, where he wrestles a T-rex. Then, he goes to WWII era and punches Hitler in the mouth.

mnemonics.meaning: You have two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bow</mark>s but they're both covered in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ice</mark>. This has made them very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">weak</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You give up on your trip and bring the weak bows back to your car, but it's stuck in the ice and snow. You decide to use the bows as a jack (じゃく) to try to get your car unstuck. Unfortunately, they're just too weak and they break in half.

mnemonics.meaning: Use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> to travel the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">circumference</mark> of the world and it will take you a full <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">week</mark>. Seven whole days!
mnemonics.reading: If you want to scoot for a week, you'll need shoes (しゅう). Good shoes too, not sandals or high heels or boots. Solid, high quality shoes, so you don't fall off the scooter and hurt yourself.

mnemonics.meaning: You look at a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">table</mark> and notice it is being used as a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> by <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark>s to launch themselves into the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wind</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You wonder what's pushing these insects to jump into the wind in such a manner, and you realize that it's because they've had way too much food (ふう).

mnemonics.meaning: What you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">oneself</mark> (yourself), you decide to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">write down</mark>. Whether this is in the form of a journal, diary, or blog, you feel the need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">record</mark> these important thoughts in some way.
mnemonics.reading: You need to protect what you write down and record for yourself with a key (き). These are your special thoughts and feelings, you don't want anyone else to see! Lock them away with a key!

mnemonics.meaning: The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yellow</mark> and the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">yellow</mark> are exactly the same!
mnemonics.reading: You're in a room, surrounded completely by yellow. You can't get out. Somewhere in the room is a yellow key (き) but you can't find it, because everything looks the same. You crawl around trying to find this tiny thing so that you can escape.

mnemonics.meaning: "Does the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> shirt <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">suit</mark> me?" you ask... but nobody will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">answer</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You pull out a quarter (こた) and offer it to whoever will give you an answer.

mnemonics.meaning: Under a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark> there's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>. If someone has a stool deep inside a cliff, they are most likely pretty <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">anti</mark>-society, hiding away like that.
mnemonics.reading: Turns out, when you go to this guy and pull off his beard, its the anti-hero from Star Wars, Han (はん) Solo! What is Han doing here, so hidden away? He's obviously hiding from Jabba because he doesn't want to get frozen in carbonite again.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark> is going down a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> and from your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> you scream, "Hey, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">buddy</mark>! Watch it with that slide, it's really fast and you might hurt yourself, buddy!"
mnemonics.reading: As you're about to embrace your buddy Wolverine, a coonhound (くん) tackles him off the slide, and bites him in the process.

mnemonics.meaning: Your nation's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> sits on top of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cape</mark>d <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>. This is the symbol for the "<mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Bureau</mark> of Secret Things." It's a special <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">department</mark> of your government made to keep things hidden.
mnemonics.reading: The bureau's best-kept secret is cloaking devices that cloak you (きょく) with the press of a button.

mnemonics.meaning: Here's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> full of of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> that you can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">buy</mark>. You can't just buy loose shellfish. You can only buy the ones that are in the net, bagged up and ready for your money.
mnemonics.reading: You decide to buy as many shellfish as you can fit in your car (か). You keep buying until your car is completely full of shellfish before you stop. Cars are totally a realistic unit of measure.

mnemonics.meaning: Just like the radical, the kanji means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">capital</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: To remember the reading きょう we use the old capital of Japan, Kyoto, which is spelled きょうと. It was the capital of Japan before Tokyo!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rain</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cloud</mark> is still a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cloud</mark>! It's probably going to rain on you soon though, so I hope you have a jacket or an umbrella.
mnemonics.reading: You lie down and try to figure out what the clouds are shaped like. The first cloud is shaped... like a cool mom (くも). She's wearing high pants, and holding a kid on each hip, but she's also listening to the latest music and using slang. Huh. You look to the next cloud and see... wait, another cool mom?

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ice</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> is a magical tree that radiates an aura of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">comfort</mark>, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ease</mark>, and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pleasure</mark>, with its icy foliage tinkling like beautiful <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">music</mark> whenever it sways in the breeze.
mnemonics.reading: You want more of this aura of comfort, so you chop down the magic tree and build a clothing rack (らく) out of it. Then, you put the rack in your house so you can enjoy that fuzzy feeling of comfort and ease every time you go to hang something up.

mnemonics.meaning: Give <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> so she can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">count</mark> it. The woman will count each individual grain of rice, then tell you the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">amount</mark> or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">number</mark> of grains.
mnemonics.reading: Why do you have to count your rice out like this? It's because someone sued (すう) your farm and took everything you owned. Since being sued, you only have a small amount of rice to last the winter.

mnemonics.meaning: You have at your disposal a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> to assassinate this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">person</mark>, or a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hook</mark>. Which method will you choose? <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Decide</mark> now!
mnemonics.reading: To remember the けつ reading, we always use the word "ketsup." It's a special mix of ketchup and catsup (yum):

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">master</mark>s gets to choose the place they <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dwell</mark>. So they <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">reside</mark> in a huge mansion on the top of the mountain, surrounded by all the other masters in their smaller dwellings.
mnemonics.reading: She needs this big place to dwell so she has somewhere to store all of her jewels (じゅう). Masters always have lots of fancy, expensive things, and she has jewels.

mnemonics.meaning: You're in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rain</mark>, in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark>, holding an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">umbrella</mark>. You're here because there's nothing else that's very tall around you. You want to get hit by <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">electricity</mark> (aka lightning), to prove that it exists.
mnemonics.reading: After the electricity hits you, you feel your face. In it is a huge dent (でん).

mnemonics.meaning: This kanji is just the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> radical three times. Just based off this, you should be able to figure it out. This kanji means "<mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">forest</mark>."
mnemonics.reading: One tree? No. Two trees? Not enough. I want more (もり) trees, please!

mnemonics.meaning: With <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">top hat</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark>, you're able to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">help</mark> anyone.
mnemonics.reading: The person you help with your top hat power? It's Jo-Anne (じょ).

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horse</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">horse</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Huzzah!
mnemonics.reading: You are looking at a horse. It's looking at you. You try making horse noises at it, to get a reaction. Instead of reacting with a normal horse noise, it just makes sheep noises: "Baaa," (ば) it says. "Baaaaa."

mnemonics.meaning: There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gate</mark> that the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> goes through at a regular <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">interval</mark>. There is an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">interval of time</mark> in the sense that the sun goes through it at the same time every day. And there is an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">interval of space</mark> in the sense that it has to go through the space between the gate posts.
mnemonics.reading: This method of keeping track of intervals of time was invented by the great Khans of Mongolia, specifically the most famous Khan of all: Genghis Khan (かん).

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Dirt</mark> makes it <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">easy</mark> to identify your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">location</mark>. Even if you add an extra line to mark the ground, it's still easy. Keep that in mind and you can go from <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">place</mark> to place.
mnemonics.reading: Knowing your location from dirt is quite a feat! Who taught you that? It was Joe (じょう), the big local farmhand. Despite being a bit weird, he can identify any place just from its dirt!

mnemonics.meaning: You're in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cage</mark> and you've been shot by an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark>. Obviously things are looking pretty bad. You need some <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">medicine</mark> if you hope to live.
mnemonics.reading: When we need to remember the sound い we use the word "Eagle."

mnemonics.meaning: There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> sticking out the top of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> and another <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> sticking out the bottom. The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> is off to the right. That's because it's the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">morning</mark>, which is when the sun and moon switch over. Those crosses are making sure the sun stays high in the sky for the rest of the day.
mnemonics.reading: Every morning you have Asahi (あさ) beer for breakfast.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Ice</mark> is what you're <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lack</mark>ing, so the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">next</mark> thing you need to do is go to the store and see if they have any. Nope, no ice. So, now you go to the next store. Is there ice here? Nope. Next!
mnemonics.reading: To remember the reading じ, we used the word "Jesus" - Finally, when you're at the last store in existence, you decide it's time to pray to Jesus (じ), asking for a miracle. He comes down from the heavens with ice in his hands.

mnemonics.meaning: You have to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sickle</mark> the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> today because it's your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">turn</mark>. This kanji also means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">number in a series</mark>, which is a lot like a turn. For example, you're number 3, so your turn will be number 3.
mnemonics.reading: This turn-based rice sickle system is a contest as well! But, you are disappointed to find out that you have been banned (ばん) from the game because of the performance enhancing steroids you've been taking.

mnemonics.meaning: When a bunch of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark>s are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">meet</mark>ing on paper (after you've dipped them in paint, say) they can create a masterpiece of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">picture</mark> (or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">painting</mark>).
mnemonics.reading: You tell someone you painted this masterpiece of a picture. Their response? "EH (え)?!"

mnemonics.meaning: You're tearing this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">door</mark> down with an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark>. You're absolutely crazy. "I HATE THIS <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">PLACE</mark>!!" you keep yelling as you smash in the door.
mnemonics.reading: You smash through the door and finally get inside the place, only to find some kind of show (しょ) going on. It's a circus show — elephants, tightrope walkers, bears on unicycles! The greatest show on earth, but why is it at this place?

mnemonics.meaning: The poor <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alligator</mark> was taken far inland by a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark>. Now his only source of water is a tiny <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pond</mark> that barely fits his body, and doesn't even provide much food.
mnemonics.reading: The worst part about this pond is that the only thing for the alligator to eat is cheese (ち). Cheese may be yummy for humans, but alligators hate it. They'd rather eat the cow the cheese came from. Sadly, this pond is full of cheese.

mnemonics.meaning: You dig a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hole</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nine</mark> times for your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">research</mark>. You should always do research with nine variables so you can compare them, and so there's an uneven number.
mnemonics.reading: Your research is on cucumbers (きゅう)!

mnemonics.meaning: Aim the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">neck</mark> at the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">road</mark>! Scooters are only meant for driving on <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">street</mark>s and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">path</mark>s, and if you go the wrong <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">way</mark>, you'll probably break your own neck!
mnemonics.reading: To remember the reading どう we use the word "doughnut."

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark> around with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark> because you're currently doing your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">service</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">duty</mark> to your country. You're standing guard outside, waiting just in case something will happen.
mnemonics.reading: You're about halfway through your service, when a yak (やく) walks by. It stops directly in front of you and grunts. "Excuse me, Mr. Yak, but it's my duty to escort you away from my country."

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lantern</mark> is an excellent way to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sharpen</mark> anything, even in the dark. Your knives, your forks, your spoons, and even your sword.
mnemonics.reading: Why did you sharpen your blade? Because you are about to do battle with Ken (けん), the famous samurai warrior.

mnemonics.meaning: The self radical is a bit modified, with things sticking out, but that’s because it’s falling down a slide.
mnemonics.reading: You’re falling down this metaphorical slide… And then you hit somebody… and you hit them really hard. On your metaphorical shin (しん). You split it in half and it’s at a right angle. The pain is incredible (shins have a lot of nerves!). It may have been broken, and you may not be able to walk correctly again… metaphorically speaking, that is.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">coffin</mark> has been left out in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> for too long. When dead bodies are out in the sun like this, they really begin to decompose. You are wondering who this person is, though. You can't tell because it's fallen apart too much. You look on the coffin. There's a label, but it only says "<mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">someone</mark>."
mnemonics.reading: To remember the sound しゃ we use "shaman."

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">branch</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">branch</mark> kanji are the same! This kanji also means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">support</mark>. To remember it, think about a tree with lots of branches. The branches support each other and the trunk of the tree. If you were to climb the tree, the branches would be able to support your weight too!
mnemonics.reading: You're happily sitting on this branch, letting it support all this weight, when a sheep (し) starts to climb the tree. A very, very big sheep. Uh oh... no no, sheep. If you get on this branch it won't be able to support all this weight!!!

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Say</mark> it with your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tongue</mark>. If you do, you'll be able to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">talk</mark>. You'll be able to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">speak</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: If something uses their tongue, it will be able to talk and speak. To prove this, you teach a walrus (わ) to use its tongue, and lo and behold, it speaks to you!

mnemonics.meaning: In your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark>, so you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">throw</mark> it. Maybe you're angry and you threw the weapon at a person you don't like. Maybe you're a pacifist and you threw it away so no one else could use it. Either way, when you have a weapon in your fingers you have to throw it.
mnemonics.reading: You throw your weapon away because you're about to enter とうきょう and there are no weapons allowed there. There is, however, a big pile of thrown away weapons by the border, which is where you're throwing yours right now.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Writing</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark> stand <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">versus</mark> one another. Writing is all about feeling and expression. Measurement is about cold hard numbers. Yep, in this world writing people are basically the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">opposite</mark> of measurement people. Which side are you on?
mnemonics.reading: Whenever it's you versus someone else, you wear a tie (たい). Naturally, your tie is always the opposite color of your opponent's tie. Kinda like how political rivals wear different color ties when they debate. It's pretty silly, but at least your tie makes it clear that it's you versus them.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone throws a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cleat</mark> at your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> while you sit on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>. You must <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">accept</mark> this. Then another guy cleats you in the forehead, but you remain on the stool and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">receive</mark> it without complaint. This is some kind of acceptance ritual for the most prestigious Spanish soccer club in the world. If a cleat to the forehead doesn't knock you off the stool, you'll receive an offer to join.
mnemonics.reading: After they accept you, they give you a small juice (じゅ) box. It's to help you recover from the trauma of getting kicked. And you receive the juice with grace.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sheep</mark> that's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> is a true <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">beauty</mark>. Big is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">beautiful</mark>, and that's all the more true for sheep.
mnemonics.reading: The big sheep's beauty has attracted a swarm of bees (び). The sheep is so beautiful that the bees have mistaken it for a flower.

mnemonics.meaning: What does your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mama</mark> tell you to do in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">street</mark>? Look before you cross! You gotta do it <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">beforehand</mark>, or it could be too late.
mnemonics.reading: As you look beforehand, you see a yo-yo (よ) lying in the street.

mnemonics.meaning: Take the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stamp</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> in front of you and use it on all of your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">clothes</mark>. Now even if you sell or lose a piece of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">clothing</mark>, you'll be able to find it again by checking for your special moon stamp.
mnemonics.reading: A few days later you're with a friend when you recognize the clothes they're wearing. You grab it, rip it off, and scream, "F**k (ふく) you!" There is your moon stamp! These are your clothes!!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">compare</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">compare</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Huzzah!
mnemonics.reading: Compare the heat (ひ) today with the heat yesterday. Is it hotter today? It's up to you to compare.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yurt</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> is always placed at certain <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">degree</mark>s. The degrees change depending on specific <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">occurrence</mark>s.
mnemonics.reading: Also angled at exact degrees is the dog (ど).

mnemonics.meaning: Go to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tent</mark> and take the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lantern</mark> from it, then we will be ready for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">departure</mark>. We can't leave the lantern inside of the tent; that's a fire hazard. We'd best take it with us before the departure. Don't you agree?
mnemonics.reading: Oh! Don't forget your hats (はつ) either. Wouldn’t want to start a departure without hats or a lantern. That'd be a short journey.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark> only if you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">determine</mark> that it is.
mnemonics.reading: You determined it, but you still have to test this determination. You go to the top and roll a tater (てい) tot down the roof. Tater tots will only roll down a perfectly correct roof.

mnemonics.meaning: Sometimes <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark> gives you a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kick</mark>, and you have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">express</mark> yourself to deal with it! How do you express yourself? On the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">surface</mark> (of your face)!
mnemonics.reading: You need to express yourself, so you call up a friend and say "Heyo!" (ひょう).

mnemonics.meaning: Under your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> there are more <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>s to feed because you let <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">guest</mark>s stay with you when it's cold. Some of them aren't family, so they have to pay to stay under your roof and get food. Those are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">customer</mark>s.
mnemonics.reading: One of your guests is a regular named Kyaku (きゃく) the customer. Kyaku is always staying over at one place or another, so everyone knows their name.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heavy</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">heavy</mark> kanji are the same.
mnemonics.reading: In your hand is a very heavy jewel (じゅう). Real jewels are always heavier than they look.

mnemonics.meaning: You need to get your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> around a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">temple</mark> if you want to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hold</mark> it. Is the temple too big? Hold smaller temples you can buy in the temple's souvenir shop.
mnemonics.reading: As you hold the temple you hear a voice. You look down through your fingers and see a tiny Jesus (じ). He's smiling and gives you a thumbs up. Aww, thanks Jesus!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">elephant</mark>s is so great, they put up an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">image</mark> or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">statue</mark> of him everywhere. Every house, every street corner — his image looks down on all the other elephants at all times.
mnemonics.reading: When they unveil the images and statues of the leader elephant, everyone gasps. They look like him, but he's a zombie (ぞう). Gasp!

mnemonics.meaning: When you're in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark>, whoever ends up with the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lose</mark>. It's the game all prisoners play. It's like keep away from the shellfish. And if you end up with the shellfish BZZZZTT that's it, you're the loser.
mnemonics.reading: If you lose, you're a fool (ふ). All you had to do was not hold the prison shellfish. It really shouldn't have been that hard to not lose, ya fool.

mnemonics.meaning: You need to look a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark> to gain a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mutual</mark> respect for each other. Stand up straight, look the tree directly in its eye(s). If it looks right back, you know things are mutual.
mnemonics.reading: If your respect for the tree is mutual with the respect the tree feels for you, you'll be able to see the tree's soul (そう). Right now its soul looks pretty sad, like it's trying to say, "Why are your people cutting down all my friends? I thought we had a mutual understanding."

mnemonics.meaning: When a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">helicopter</mark> is piloted by a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark>, it stirs an insatiable <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">need</mark> in her. She doesn't know what it is. But she needs it. And that's why she's flying around looking for it!
mnemonics.reading: Finally she knows what she needs! It's yogurt (よう)! Delicious, creamy yogurt!

mnemonics.meaning: There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark>ing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> that you're taking an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark> to. You're going to cut down this tree to let a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">new</mark> tree grow.
mnemonics.reading: You cut down the tree to make room for a new one, but it falls on your shin (しん).

mnemonics.meaning: You find a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark>. What a strange <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">occurrence</mark>. I guess he put it there, but why would he do such a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">thing</mark>? You ask him, but he says it's a personal <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">matter</mark> of utmost secrecy.
mnemonics.reading: This occurrence doesn't impress Jesus (じ), who appears and gently removes the cross from Wolverine's mouth.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clown</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> is over in that <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">part</mark> of town. We keep the clown part as separate as we can from the rest of the normal people. In fact, the entire clown education <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">department</mark> and their clown <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">club</mark>s have to stay in their part, they can't come in ours.
mnemonics.reading: You see, that part of town is full of booze (ぶ). Clowns need a lot of booze to keep their charade going, so we just let them have it. But they aren't allowed in our part anymore, because they all stink of nasty clown booze.

mnemonics.meaning: When everyone has <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark> in their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>, you will have <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">peace</mark>. That is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Japanese style</mark> of doing things.
mnemonics.reading: Peace is the Japanese style. The walruses (わ) living off of Japan see this, and start to emulate.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lion</mark>, still <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">small</mark> and curious, gazes upon the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">prefecture</mark> that will one day become his. He's a small lion, but once he grows up, everything reflected in his eye will be his prefecture to rule over.
mnemonics.reading: This small lion's prefecture is being protected by Ken (けん) the samurai, because the lion is too small to protect all of this land himself. Ken the samurai is used to wandering far and wide, so one prefecture is nothing to him.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> is all about trying to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">preserve</mark> the trees. In fact, she <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">guarantee</mark>s that she will preserve the trees if it's the last thing she does.
mnemonics.reading: She chains herself to a tree to preserve them. But, unfortunately, the lumberjacks just take a giant back hoe (ほ) and tear this tree leader and the tree she's attached to in half.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">anti</mark> scoot. It doesn't want to run. So you have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">return</mark> it.
mnemonics.reading: You return to the store and wait in line to return the scooter but the person working returns doesn't want you to return it. He stares you dead in the eyes, waves his hand, and turns you into a hen (へん)!

mnemonics.meaning: You put a grain in your mouth and let it take a ride. This kanji has the same radicals as 和, but this time the grain is in your mouth, which is why there's little pieces of grain sticking out of the 口 part ;)
mnemonics.reading: You decide the grain is probably lonely on this ride alone, so you add some nori (の) seaweed, so it has a friend.

mnemonics.meaning: You plant a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>, marking your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> patch of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>. In this spot you raise a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">roof</mark>, then fill the space beneath it with some <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shop</mark>s and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">store</mark>s.
mnemonics.reading: The roof covering the dirt is there so that the Yankees (や) can play baseball year round. The stores and shops are there to sell hot dogs and Yankees memorabilia.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">samurai</mark> has come bearing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark>s and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">legs</mark> that he's trying to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sell</mark>. He thought it was a waste to leave all his slain enemies on the battlefield, so he gathered up their foreheads and legs to sell on the black market for some extra cash. Hey, no judging! A samurai's gotta sell what a samurai's gotta sell, okay?
mnemonics.reading: If you run into this samurai who sells severed foreheads and legs, you should just say "bye (ばい)!" and get the heck out of there. Actually, if anyone tries to sell you severed body parts — samurai or not — you should probably say bye over and over until you can get away from them.

mnemonics.meaning: On its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark>, a creature with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> from <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heaven</mark> will take things you want to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">send</mark> there.
mnemonics.reading: You want to send your soul (そう) to heaven. I mean, you don't want it to go to some of those other places you've heard of, so why not send your soul?

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spicy</mark> radical and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">spicy</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Hot!
mnemonics.reading: When you eat spicy food, it gives a からて chop to your mouth. That's where that spicy feeling comes from!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> have grown <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">old</mark>, so they're <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">suffering</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: If a flower or a person is growing old and suffering, give them a cookie (く).

mnemonics.meaning: If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> is going to last an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eternity</mark> you better learn how to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">swim</mark> now. We'll be under water for the rest of time and if you can't swim you're not gonna make it.
mnemonics.reading: Oy (およ)! Oy, stop daydreaming about swimming and actually do it!

mnemonics.meaning: You  <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> things around a  <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark>. In fact there are two  <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark>s, and you're <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">talk</mark>ing with a group of people, all sitting around two nice campfires.
mnemonics.reading: You talk in this intense, fiery way all the way until dawn (だん), but no longer! Once dawn comes the discussion needs to be concluded.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> is very <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">anti</mark>-everything, making it all <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">temporary</mark>. You get a new shirt, "I'm anti shirts!" she yells, and out it goes.
mnemonics.reading: The leader's most temporary possession is her car (か). Or... cars, because they're all very temporary. She buys one, drives it around, and then suddenly she's anti red car. She needs a blue one!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horse</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">squid</mark> are going to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">test</mark> you.
mnemonics.reading: The test is being supervised by Ken (けん) the samurai.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cow</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wing</mark>s is flying in the air. What a strange <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">thing</mark>! You've heard of flying pigs before, but cows? This is a new and strange thing indeed! Cows with wings! What a silly thing.
mnemonics.reading: You want a thing to help you fly with the cow so you put on your flying boots (ぶつ). Your flying boots are a pretty strange thing in themselves, but they're the only way you can keep up.

mnemonics.meaning: There's an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>, among some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark>. What happened? You killed a fish, and now you you must hide the murder <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tool</mark>. Quick, hide the tool before someone finds out it was you.
mnemonics.reading: The tool is dripping with goo (ぐ). Goopy, incriminating goo. It's the guts of the fish you just killed and it's all over your hands too. Yuck.

mnemonics.meaning: Climb onto the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spring</mark> to see the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">truth</mark>. The world is waking back up from winter and revealing the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">reality</mark> of what it is all around you.
mnemonics.reading: At the moment, you're trying to learn the truth about the deer that is coming out of the snowy woods when you see not one, but two baby deer appear with it! Gee! Two (じつ) babies! You keep looking around and realize that all of the animals seem to have two babies that they had hidden in the snow.

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> something at a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ceremony</mark> for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark> workers you're going to have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">try</mark> really hard. Construction is loud, so if you want to be heard you have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">attempt</mark> to be louder than the drilling and smashing and digging and handing out of awards.
mnemonics.reading: You try to get their attention the only way you know how, by lifting a sheep (し) above your head. The sheep baas and suddenly everything is silent, all eyes are on you. Well, they're on the sheep.

mnemonics.meaning: A good <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> can put the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">history</mark> to great <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">use</mark>. You are a good leader. You have studied the ground and dirt of the earth your entire life. You know the history of the ground and you know how to use it to lead your people.
mnemonics.reading: You use the ground to raise sheep (し). When you were down there sniffing around you realized that your people will flourish best if you use this land for grazing and raising sheep.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> grants a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gladiator</mark> its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> so he will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">win</mark>! <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Victory</mark> will be his!
mnemonics.reading: He wins over and over again, and soon the Shougun (しょう) is even rooting for him. In fact, the Shougun claims him as his personal gladiator of choice.
