mnemonics.meaning: Every <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> sits <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jammed in</mark> to the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">world</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: To get around this world of rice paddies, you need to use a kayak (かい).

mnemonics.meaning: You give your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> so that it can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">advance</mark>. The turkey was trying and failing to walk through a crowded street, so out of the goodness of your heart you gave it a scooter so it could advance.
mnemonics.reading: You wave as the turkey advances into the street at top speeds, collides with a car, and scrapes up its shins (しん) almost immediately. Ah!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> is an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark>ic beverage containing a lot of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">alcohol</mark>. It’s 3 different kinds of rums, pineapple juice, and grenadine. It’ll hit you like a tsunami though. This alcoholic drink has a kick to it.
mnemonics.reading: As you lie on this beach, the alcohol keeps coming down a chute (しゅ), straight into your mouth. You can feel the sand in your toes and the alcohol sliding down your throat from this special tsunami chute.

mnemonics.meaning: If you give a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">machine</mark> she'll <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">begin</mark> learning how to use it right away. She'll also get it to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">start</mark> before anyone else could. Women are really good at starting up new machines!
mnemonics.reading: Actually, before she can begin, she has to shear the sheep (し) over there. The machine is going to turn wool into yarn, but you can't just start that process by shoving the sheep in there. You have to keep the little sheep safe!

mnemonics.meaning: You have <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spikes</mark> growing out of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sheep</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark>. Turn this thing into a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">business</mark>! You could totally charge people money to look at it. Sure, you could also donate it to science, but a business-minded person like you knows a business opportunity when you see one. Step right up! Just five dollars for a glance at the rare spiky mer-sheep!
mnemonics.reading: As you evolve your business, you let customers feed the sheep gyoza (ぎょう) dumplings, its favorite snack. For a nominal fee, of course. People love it when the mutant sheep eats gyoza out of their hands. Wouldn't you?

mnemonics.meaning: If someone sticks <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">twenty</mark> times, the first thing your brain does is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">calculate</mark> how painful it is. Your brain's pain <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">calculation</mark> will determine how you calculate your next move.
mnemonics.reading: Next you want to calculate how much punishment your bamboo attacker deserves, so you call on Santa-san (さん). Santa-san is always calculating how many pieces of coal the naughty children deserve, so he's perfect for this calculation job.

mnemonics.meaning: While riding your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark>, you bang your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> in front. Your scooter's wrecked, so you have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">carry</mark> it home. You'll need a lot of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">luck</mark> to get that scooter home safely.
mnemonics.reading: As you carry the scooter, your luck turns, and it starts to rain, so you pull out your umbrella (うん). Now you're holding your scooter, your forehead, and an umbrella.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hit ancient <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">China</mark> and formed the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Chinese</mark> country we know now as... <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">China</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: You peer closer at China and see one man, Genghis Khan (かん), leading his troops into the vast country, ready to conquer all the Chinese people living in China!

mnemonics.meaning: When the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bird</mark> opens, you're most likely to hear a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chirp</mark>. This is how birds communicate. They open their mouths and let out a series of chirps. Chirp chirp chirp!
mnemonics.reading: The best way to experience the chirp-chirping of birds is to offer them nachos (な). Birds love nachos so much, it's a guaranteed way to make them chirp with delight.

mnemonics.meaning: You chase a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> up a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">collect</mark> it. At least, you will once you've <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gather</mark>ed enough turkeys into this one tree.
mnemonics.reading: Once you've collected enough turkeys, you're going to turn them into a shoe (しゅう). Maybe even two shoes, but that will mean gathering even more turkeys!

mnemonics.meaning: You don't want to keep all the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark> to yourself (<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">oneself</mark>), so you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">distribute</mark> it to all of your friends. Heck, not just your friends, to everyone you can find!
mnemonics.reading: As you distribute the alcohol you say a haiku (はい):

mnemonics.meaning: You can <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eat</mark> all you want, but you'll still <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lack</mark> something to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">drink</mark>. You can't live just from eating, you have to drink things too!
mnemonics.reading: You get desperate for a drink and put some nori (の) seaweed in a blender, trying to create a drink of your own.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ice</mark> has brought this year to its <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">end</mark>. Once you're in the long thread of winter and ice, you know the year will end soon.
mnemonics.reading: Whenever winter ends, you take the thread covered in ice, and lace it into your shoe (しゅう).

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark>'s breadth away from the edge, when out of nowhere a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark> slaps you in the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">face</mark>. The force makes you back away from the edge of the cliff, and your face is all slimy from the geoduck's residue.
mnemonics.reading: But where did that geoduck come from? As you turn from the cliff edge, you find yourself face-to-face with a cow (かお). This cow is the one who hit you in the face with a geoduck. You don't know why, but something about your face has upset the cow.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Flowers</mark> are knocked down by a violent <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark>, and swirl through the air to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kiss</mark> your face gently as they <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fall</mark>. With the tsunami came a great windy storm that blew the flowers down. Amongst all the destruction, it's a pretty sight to watch them fall.
mnemonics.reading: You want to save these flowers that fall around you, so you take out a drying rack (らく) and place them carefully on it. Any flowers that fall will go on the rack like this, so can save them for later.

mnemonics.meaning: You blast your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">music</mark> loud so it causes a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">landslide</mark>, revealing the perfect soil for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">farming</mark>! Musically moved dirt is perfect for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">agriculture</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The first person to come up with this farming method was Nostradamus (のう), the famous seer and prophecy man. He predicted humans of the future would use special "yell cubes" to "move that good earth."

mnemonics.meaning: You jump on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> with a big <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bundle</mark> to go as <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fast</mark> as you can! You have a bundle of pizzas in here, and they need to be delivered as fast as you can get them there!
mnemonics.reading: You were going so fast, you only put on socks (そく). So now you're barreling down the street at top speeds in just your sad, white socks.

mnemonics.meaning: Think about it this way. There is a famous fishing lure inventor, working on his best work ever. He’s old, and he’s been trying to make the best fishing lure for the last 50 years, and knows this will be his last invention. Then he figures it out. He takes one <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">barb</mark>, and connects the end of it to the top of another <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">barb</mark>. When he does this, he knows his work is finally <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">finish</mark>ed.
mnemonics.reading: How does the fish lure maker test his newly finished lure out? The one he just finished? He gets in a row (りょう) boat and rows out into the sea.

mnemonics.meaning: If you feed a lot of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">beans</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark>, its <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">head</mark> will grow larger. To a geoduck, beans are a brain food, so by eating beans, it can grow an incredibly large head. Geoducks already look strange enough as it is, let alone with engorged heads.
mnemonics.reading: As the geoduck eats more and more beans its head gets bigger and bigger, until finally the head explodes like an atomic (あたま) bomb. BOOM! Geoduck parts go flying everywhere and pieces of its massive head float to the ground as atomic fallout.

mnemonics.meaning: If you go up to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gate</mark> and press your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ear</mark> to it, you'll <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hear</mark> what's going on on the other side. The people on the other side will have no idea you can hear their conversation.
mnemonics.reading: From the other side of the gate, you hear one of the people start to play a song on a recorder. You recognize the song as "Hot Cross Buns (ぶん)." You haven't heard this song since grade school. "Hot cross buns, hot cross buns~"

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> and will teach you about the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">origin</mark> of many things. It's an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">institution</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: What does institution start with? In (いん)!

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> something about the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">circumference</mark> of this area. You've looked around this whole area, making a big circle around it, because you are trying to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">investigate</mark> something that happened here. You also say this thing in a really quiet <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tone</mark> of voice, because you don't want the person or thing you're investigating to know you're on to them.
mnemonics.reading: "I came here to investigate this place, and I did indeed find out who the criminal is... it's none other than Mrs. Chou (ちょう)!"

mnemonics.meaning: You look at some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> and notice a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fault</mark> in it. You scrape at the fault and see that it's just sprayed with gold paint. It's not gold, it's (comparatively) worthless <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">iron</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: Do you know that movie, Tetsuo (てつ) the Iron Man? We talked about it on Tofugu a while back. It’s one of the wackiest Japanese movies of all time. If you don’t know about Tetsuo the Iron Man, you should definitely look it up (if you aren't averse to horror/violent films). Tetsuo is one of the most insane movies in the history of ever.

mnemonics.meaning: What you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> between <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">five</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>s is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">language</mark>. As long as there are five different people saying these same words with their five mouths, it's considered its own language.
mnemonics.reading: Another mouth joins in speaking the language, but it's green and scaled and... it's Godzilla's (ご) mouth! Godzilla speaks this language too.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Flowers</mark> bring beauty to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">world</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">trees</mark>, but the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">leaf</mark> is what matters the most. <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Leaves</mark> are how flowers and trees get their nutrients from the sun!
mnemonics.reading: Picture a little flower working really hard to grow its first leaf. The leaf pops out and it shouts, "Ha (は)!"

mnemonics.meaning: You find some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">feathers</mark> that are so perfectly <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark>, you want to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">learn</mark> more about where they came from and what they're made of.
mnemonics.reading: You learn that you should tie these white feathers to your shoes (しゅう). You do it before you learn what it will do, and then suddenly you're jump-flying out of the building.

mnemonics.meaning: For a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tombstone</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lightweight</mark>. Cars are very strong, you see, so something heavy like a tombstone is no match for them. All cars find tombstones to be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">light</mark> and easy to transport.
mnemonics.reading: What do you wish you had to transport this tombstone? Oh, that’s right, a car. So you need some kind of car loophole (かる). If you had a car, this tombstone moving business would be no problem. To cars, tombstones are naught but lightweight pebbles! But the rules say you can't use cars to carry tombstones, so you need to find a car loophole.

mnemonics.meaning: You can use a long piece of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> during <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark> rafting as a safety <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">line</mark>. Sure it's thin, but if someone goes overboard even a line of thread is better than nothing. Throw them a line and drag them back aboard!
mnemonics.reading: The person who threw you that line of thread is actually a centaur (せん). How kind of him. After you are safe you hop on the centaur's back and ride around to get the wind to dry you off.

mnemonics.meaning: Let the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> shine into your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ear</mark> while sitting on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> and make sure <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">most</mark> of it gets in your head. You want to fill your brain with the most sun anyone ever has.
mnemonics.reading: Most of this is for your cyborg (さい). You're testing out a new way to power it, but if you can't get most of the sun into your ear, it won't be enough to power most of the cyborg's robo-parts.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gate</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lantern</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">open</mark> for you. That's convenient, since it's pretty dark out and you might not have seen the open gate without the lantern's help.
mnemonics.reading: This open gate is in the water though, so you'll need a kayak (かい) to get in. Luckily, you've been carrying your kayak with you just in case.

mnemonics.meaning: Did you know that those strange <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark> creatures were once used to make <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">page</mark>s? Okay maybe not, but it makes for a memorable image!
mnemonics.reading: A page is a page (ページ).

mnemonics.meaning: If you're <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark>ing under a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> and you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">see</mark> your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">parent</mark>, it's a good chance for a moment of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">intimacy</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Standing under the tree, you go to give your parent a big hug, but you manage to bang your shin (しん) on a huge tree root. Your parent pulls you in for a warm hug and rubs your shin. Despite the pain, it becomes an unforgettable "shin-timate" moment.

mnemonics.meaning: You have <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark>. But, you want the world to see them, so you take them <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">public</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You head out into the public where everyone can see your fins, but... things have changed. All people are the same. There are thousands of こういちs walking around, and they all stare at you (though they pretend like they aren't).

mnemonics.meaning: You have to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> what you’re <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sell</mark>ing because people don’t like to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">read</mark>. If they walk right by and don’t read, you better say what you have for sale so they’ll know! Read it out loud to them.
mnemonics.reading: What are you forced to read aloud to sell? Yo-yo (よ) instructions! You’d think they’d be self explanatory, but there are actually a lot of rules and tricks that you have to read to get good at yo-yoing. Read all of these out loud so you can sell them.

mnemonics.meaning: Look at the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>! You spilled some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark>s, so I <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">request</mark> that you wipe them up. I'd do it myself, but you're the one who spilled them, so I'm requesting that you do it. Pretty reasonable request, right?
mnemonics.reading: Oh, one more thing. I request that you wipe up the water with this cucumber (きゅう).

mnemonics.meaning: If your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> runs into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cloud</mark> you'll <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">revolve</mark> around it instead of going straight through. Clouds are really hard to see through, so even though you're trying not to, you revolve in a tight circle up and around the cloud anyway.
mnemonics.reading: You have to revolve around the cloud ten (てん) times before it disappears and you're able to go through.

mnemonics.meaning: If you've been walking all day, your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">foot</mark> is the last thing anyone would want to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kiss</mark>, especially after wandering barefoot down a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">road</mark>. Your feet are filthy, sweaty, and stinky. Nobody is going to want to kiss those feet.
mnemonics.reading: What was this person walking down again? Oh, that's right – a road (ろ). They were walking down a filthy road.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sick</mark> stick of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dynamite</mark> is going to be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sick</mark> forever. Unfortunately there are no medicines that are effective on sticks of dynamite, so once they contract a sickness, they’re sick for good.
mnemonics.reading: Being nervous all the time about spontaneously exploding would probably make you sweat profusely. And you know what sweating causes? B.O. (びょう). You’d be one smelly stick of dynamite. B.O. is a very unpleasant smell, and being sick is no excuse.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> marked with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yellow</mark> X on the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">side</mark> of the house is going to get cut down. You’ve marked it with a yellow X so the hired help knows which tree to cut down. There are a lot of trees on the side of the house, but the tree marked with a yellow X is the only one in danger of causing damage to your roof in the event of a storm.
mnemonics.reading: Wait, that woman with the chainsaw is Yoko (よこ) Ono! Yes, the same Yoko Ono who’s married to John Lennon of the Beatles. What’s she doing chopping down trees on the side of your house? Who can say. Silly Yoko.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Angle</mark> your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark> correctly at this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cow</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">solve</mark> its riddle. The key is to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">untie</mark> the cow with the sword without hurting it.
mnemonics.reading: Did I mention that you have to solve this whole riddle while on a kayak (かい)? No?! Whoops.

mnemonics.meaning: If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lip ring</mark> (or two in this case) is what you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lack</mark>, it's going to be way easier for you to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sing</mark> a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">song</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Where are you always singing songs, by the way? In your car (か). It's not just you, either. Pretty much everyone likes to sing in their car.

mnemonics.meaning: This kanji is the same as the radical — <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">straight</mark> as straight can be.
mnemonics.reading: Put food straight into your esophagus without chewing and you will choke (ちょく). You want to get straight to the most important part of eating — the digesting part — but if you don't follow all the intermediate steps, you'll end up choking.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Run</mark> into <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">oneself</mark> in a dream and you'll definitely <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wake up</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: If one runs into oneself and you don't wake up, just look down at your waist. If you're wearing an obi (お) you know it's a dream and you'll eventually wake up. If you aren't wearing an obi then it isn't a dream and you don't have anything to wake up from.

mnemonics.meaning: Using your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> you build something great. A true <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">achievement</mark> built for the achievement of making kanji learning easier!
mnemonics.reading: This achievement was made possible by こういち, so of course this construction project is a giant statue of the man himself. What an achievement of a statue. What an achievement of an achievement.

mnemonics.meaning: When a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> holds a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark> it <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">becomes</mark> something else. The drunkard doesn't become a swordsman, they're still just a drunkard. But the sword in their hands does.
mnemonics.reading: The sword has become a saber (せい)! It's just like the saber you have! Hey, wait.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark> on top of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark> from the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">coast</mark> below. Just from looking at the raging <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shore</mark> below, you'd think everything would be wet, it's splashing everywhere!
mnemonics.reading: Sitting up there, watching the coast with you, is Gandhi (がん). The world famous Gandhi, is just hanging out up here with you, looking down at what you now realize must be a coast in India.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Stand</mark> on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">older brother</mark>. Now <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">older brother</mark> again. You wish to stand on, and above, your older brother. You <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">compete</mark> over and over again, to stand atop your older brother.
mnemonics.reading: You compete with your older brother because only one of you may go to きょうと. Whoever stands on top the most gets to go to きょうと, so you must compete for a spot.

mnemonics.meaning: In <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark>, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark> gets picked on for the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">barb</mark>s coming out of his hands. This creates a lot of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">conflict</mark> between him and the other prisoners. They don't take kindly to mutants, and Wolverine doesn't take kindly to bigots — hence the conflict.
mnemonics.reading: This constant conflict between Wolverine and the other inmates is really affecting his soul (そう). Despite what people think, Wolverine really doesn't like to fight. He just hates injustice so much, he feels he has to do something about it.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> stands upon the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark>. She is searching for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure</mark>. It is said that this treasure here in this rice field will make things much easier for the leader (that's what leaders really want, after all). If she gets this treasure, it will be a great <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">convenience</mark> for her, because convenience is everything when you're the leader.
mnemonics.reading: She finds a place to dig in the ground. It looks like there's some fresh dirt here. Finally, the treasure of convenience that will make this leader's life so much easier. She digs into the ground and pulls out a box. When she opens it, she finds out it's a bento (べん). "My god," she thinks. "This really will make my life more convenient. My people can take their lunches with them now instead of coming back to base to eat, which will waste way less time!"

mnemonics.meaning: By the time you finish digging a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">coffin</mark> hole with nothing but a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark>, you’ll be an old <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">elderly</mark> person. Digging with nothing but a spoon takes a long time, especially when the hole needs to be big enough for a coffin. You might as well be digging it for yourself at this rate. By the time you finish, you’ll be all wrinkled and elderly and just about ready to keel over.
mnemonics.reading: Now that you’re elderly (and probably about to die) you suddenly crave some delicious roe (ろう). Salmon roe, sea urchin roe, tofugu roe, doesn’t matter. Your old, tired bones need roe after all that hard work!

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Orders</mark> coming from your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> will determine the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fate</mark> of your soldiers. You are their commanding officer and your orders determine their <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">life</mark> and death.
mnemonics.reading: You are the commanding officer on the Mayflower (めい). You give orders to colonize America. The orders spewing from your mouth hole determine the fate of the settlers and the fate of America and the fate of the world! You and the Mayflower have changed everything forever.

mnemonics.meaning: Try to use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark> out some of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> and you'll come back with just one <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">finger</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Don't worry, you aren't the only one out there with just one finger, sheep (し) only have one finger too. I mean, they're hooves, which are really just a single animal finger. It's just big and kind of flat.

mnemonics.meaning: If you want a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark>, you have to be the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">first</mark> one to find it. Do you really think the first person to come across a spirit sword wouldn't want it?! No. So if you're any place but first, you're not getting anything.
mnemonics.reading: If you were lucky enough to be the first one to find the spirit sword, you should open up a small show (しょ) to show it off! And then you can make yourself the first in line every day to see the show.

mnemonics.meaning: In your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> there is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jet</mark> dropping <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">flavor</mark> bombs. Every time you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">taste</mark> something, it's actually because a tiny jet has flown into your mouth to bomb you with flavor.
mnemonics.reading: And what has more flavor than a big slab of meat (み)? You love meat and its flavor nearly as much as you love the taste of its juice. So many good things to put in your mouth!

mnemonics.meaning: On a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> there is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bear</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> on its head trying to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">follow</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chase</mark> you! You accidentally splashed it with water and it's not happy about it. You're on your own scooter, luckily, but that doesn't make this any less terrifying.
mnemonics.reading: The bear is trying to follow you because it wants your obi (お) as compensation for its injured pride. The obi is waving in the wind behind your scooter, and the bear is reaching out with its teeth to try and grab it.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> should feel <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">humble</mark> before a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">god</mark>'s <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">spirit</mark>. You never really feel humble in front of anyone else, but if you meet a god's spirit… Well, you should probably lower yourself appropriately. Gods have powerful spirits.
mnemonics.reading: When you meet a god's spirit, you need to get down on your shins (しん). Get down on your ankles? No, not low enough. Knees? No, no, get your shins flat on the ground to show how humble you really are. Luckily, you're wearing jeans (じん), so at least that will stop your poor shins getting chafed!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of water to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">root</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">good</mark>. It's good for the roots to grow and live and thrive. And what's good for roots is good for our plants and us humans too.
mnemonics.reading: A good way to get a lot of drops of water for your roots is to buy a row boat (りょう). Then just row out to the middle of the lake and plonk all the roots right into the source!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sound</mark> of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> gives me an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">idea</mark>. The methodic thump thump thumping of a heart puts me in a trance that gives me great ideas. It’s a very inspirational sound, the sound of a heart is. It gives me an idea.
mnemonics.reading: The heart of an eagle (い) is very strong. The person who knew this probably came up with the idea to make the bald eagle a symbol of the United States. Eagles are always flying around and doing things, so their hearts are very strong.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Viking</mark> in a position of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> does not need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">labor</mark> in the fields. Labor is for the weak! A Viking of power takes what he wants, and need not labor for it. A powerful Viking plunders all and takes what he wants!
mnemonics.reading: It takes a lot of labor to harvest roe (ろう) so that’s what the Viking decides to take first! Roe is delicious, but it’s small and delicate. Vikings don’t labor for their own roe! They take it and eat it!

mnemonics.meaning: There are pieces of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> on each <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">escalator</mark> showing you what <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">level</mark> they go to in your school. Each escalator takes you to a different <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">grade</mark>, so make sure you follow the right thread or you'll end up in a class that's either way above or way below your level.
mnemonics.reading: You want to see what the highest level is, so you go up the wrong escalator. At the top you find a giant cucumber (きゅう).

mnemonics.meaning: There is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark> in front of you. You <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">like</mark> them very much.
mnemonics.reading: "I like you two," you say to the woman and child. They both turn their heads 180 degrees back towards you. They both have faces that look just like こういち's. "We like you too," they say in unison.

mnemonics.meaning: You've been playing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blackjack</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> since <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">long ago</mark>. This is the longest game of blackjack you've ever played and it feels like ages since you started. You've been sitting out in the sun playing blackjack since long, long ago.
mnemonics.reading: Once you finally finish the game, you walk the long walk back home, in the sun, barefoot, on a dirt road that hasn't been maintained since long ago. Your feet are all sweaty from being out in the sun, and walking on this dirt road gives you muck ashi (むかし). Your ashi (feet) are all mucky and muddy from the combination of dirt and sweat. Your muck ashi are really gross, man.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clan</mark> wants to live close to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> so he demands you get <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">low</mark>. Low, low, with your belly to the ground. That way you're always below him, since he's the leader.
mnemonics.reading: Low people like you can only eat low food like potatoes. But that's boring, so you low people learned to make tater (てい) tots. You roll them to each other and eat them without lifting your heads.

mnemonics.meaning: Give <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">trash</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> and it will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">nurture</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">raise</mark> that trash like it's its own little moon baby.
mnemonics.reading: The moon nurtures the trash ball until one day, it speaks! "行く (いく), 行く！" it says. It wants to go live with mom moon!

mnemonics.meaning: If you know the radical meaning <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">orders</mark> you know the kanji meaning <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">orders</mark> as well!
mnemonics.reading: Your orders are to get a ray (れい) gun.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> always seem to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">suit</mark> the random things you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pick up</mark> off the ground. An old thimble. A discarded onion ring. A dead worm you tie in a knot. Your incredible fingers suit them beautifully, almost as if they were jewelry, so of course you pick up all of them.
mnemonics.reading: You're walking around looking for something to pick up when you see a sword in a rock. Yes, this will suit you. You pick up the sword and people jump out around you and tell you that you are the new hero (ひろ)! Uh oh. Maybe you shouldn't have picked this up.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">master</mark> has the power to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pour</mark> water wherever he pleases. Tsunami masters are masters over the most powerful water force in the universe, so it makes sense that they have the ability to pour water at will, wherever they please. Best not tick off the master, unless you want a tsunami poured on your head.
mnemonics.reading: If Chewbacca (ちゅう) was trying to attack you, you’d be able to defend yourself easily. Simply pour a tsunami on him and Chewbacca would surrender in a heartbeat. Chewbacca doesn’t like having water poured on him, especially not all the water from a tsunami.

mnemonics.meaning: Cut <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark>s with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> to make them smaller and you'll make a great <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">profit</mark>. By cutting them, now you can get three grains worth of money for what was once a single grain.
mnemonics.reading: To make an even better profit, you decide to cut up reeds (り) too. You stuff the grains in the reeds and sell that as "self-cooking" sets.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark>s at the highest <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rank</mark> in an organization. The leader is of the highest rank and stands above all others.
mnemonics.reading: This great leader is actually the leader of the boy scouts. And as we all know, the highest rank in boy scouts is the rank of eagle (い) scout. This great leader has attained the rank of eagle scout and stands above all other scouts.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> who takes the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">middle</mark> of the road on every issue is likely to have an average <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">relationship</mark> with everyone. He doesn't really take sides in matters, and just stays in the middle. This makes him seem like a wishy-washy people-pleaser, and as such he's only able to maintain average, mid-tier relationships.
mnemonics.reading: Imagine a flip-flopping politician you have an average relationship with. Now imagine that there's a knocker (なか) on their forehead and you get to knock that knocker as hard as you like. Maybe you can knock some integrity into them and form a better relationship.

mnemonics.meaning: As the year starts moving in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark>, the trees must <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">release</mark> their leaves.
mnemonics.reading: The trees release all of their leaves onto your home (ほう). Slowly, you watch in horror as your home is consumed by the released leaves. They enter in through the windows, doors, and the chimney.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Grain</mark>s are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">few</mark>. Imagine the last few grains trickling down the hourglass. You only have a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">second</mark> left.
mnemonics.reading: After the final seconds go by, your awful B.O. (びょう) appears.

mnemonics.meaning: In your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> you put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark>. Now that you have them in there, you have to make them <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">separate</mark> from each other.
mnemonics.reading: Why are you trying to make a sword and knife separate in your mouth? Because someone bets (べつ) you can't do it.

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cow</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">temple</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">special</mark>. This cow must have been very important to have an entire temple dedicated to it.
mnemonics.reading: This cow is special because it belonged to Tokugawa (とく) Ieyasu, the first shōgun of the Tokugawa shogunate and uniter of Japan! He's a super important figure in Japanese history. You should absolutely look him up and read a bit about him (when you're caught up on these lessons, that is).

mnemonics.meaning: The card game fish are best at is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blackjack</mark> because they can easily hold the cards with their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">together</mark>. In blackjack you don't have to have a huge hand, full of cards. It's just a few, so fish fins can keep them together and just hit or stay.
mnemonics.reading: Once a year trillions of fish get together in きょうと to play blackjack. They have a huge tournament there once a year.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> sits on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> to conserve her <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark>, as her servants <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">toil</mark> away in the kitchen. They toil away preparing a feast for this powerful woman while she kicks back on her cozy stool. She's a queen and deserves to be pampered.
mnemonics.reading: As a servant you toil not just for the woman, but also for her dog (ど). Anything she gets, the dog gets too. That means double the toil for you. But hey, at least the dog is cute.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cloud</mark> that he uses to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">transmit</mark> all of the messages he needs to send to his people. The cloud floats above him and when he wants to tell people something he just whispers into the cloud and it transmits his message really, really loudly to all of them.
mnemonics.reading: As the leader transmits his latest series of messages to you and the others, you notice a pretty large dent (でん) in it. That dent is probably a clue to what this cloud is really made of.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">simple</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> starting a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">war</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The simple drunkard started a war with the centaurs (せん)! This is especially unfortunate, because the centaurs are really good at battles because they're all automatically cavalry troops.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hits your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">skin</mark> and creates smaller <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wave</mark>s. Those hit you too!
mnemonics.reading: When each wave hits your body, you shout, "Ha (は)!" It's not like it's on purpose. When the wave crashes into you, the wind gets knocked right out of your mouth, making a HA sound.

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> is ridden by a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sheep</mark> in classic <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Western style</mark>. And by Western style I mean the sheep is dressed in a cowboy outfit and has put a saddle atop the tsunami wave to ride it. It's a tsunami rodeo and this crazy sheep is riding that tsunami wave in classic Western style.
mnemonics.reading: After a whole day of riding this tsunami, the sheep is hankerin' for some Western-style food, namely yogurt (よう). Yogurt is Western-style food, right? If it helps you can imagine the yogurt is flavored like apple pie, to make it more American and Western.

mnemonics.meaning: Who will <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark>? Who? <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">WHO</mark>???
mnemonics.reading: Then, someone says turkey. "Who said turkey? You? How dare (だれ) you."

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> makes you lift <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heavy</mark> loads with all your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark>, since this is what you do for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">work</mark>. Why do you this kind of work? Well, you're good at it and the leader makes you do it, I guess.
mnemonics.reading: Where do you get the power to do all this work? From doughnuts (どう). You eat nothing but doughnuts. If you had no doughnuts, you couldn't work. In fact, your leader pays you for your work… in doughnuts.

mnemonics.meaning: In <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Asia</mark> they assume everyone's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> is automatically <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bad</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">evil</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Luckily, people in Asia know how to get the evil badness out of your heart with acupuncture (あく).

mnemonics.meaning: Imagining one’s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">self</mark> without a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> can make it hard to draw <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">breath</mark>. Without a heart, you’d have no blood pumping and you would start to die. This would make it increasingly harder to draw breath and get oxygen to stay alive.
mnemonics.reading: You know how when people are unconscious and their breath slows or comes to a stop, they use smelling salts to revive them? Well a smelly sock (そく) can work just as well. Socks get really stinky and their stench is powerful enough to revive someone who isn’t drawing breath.

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> at a podium <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">early</mark> in the morning to practice reading the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chapter</mark> from your latest book.
mnemonics.reading: You're practicing this specific chapter because you've been asked to read it for the Shougun (しょう). There will be a bunch of other authors reading chapters of their books to him too, and you want to make a good impression.

mnemonics.meaning: There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tent</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">beans</mark>. You try to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">climb</mark> it.
mnemonics.reading: You climb the bean tent, and from this vantage point you can see とうきょう in the distance.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark>, even though it's almost <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spring</mark>, is still covered in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ice</mark> so it's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cold</mark>. Inside the house is cold, outside the house is cold. Everything is cold!
mnemonics.reading: You can't stand the cold anymore, so you hire a samurai (さむ) to come try to hack the ice off of your roof with his sword. You stand outside shivering, and watching as the samurai tries to stab the ice off of your roof.

mnemonics.meaning: If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> is higher than your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> you better move those <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">legs</mark> and find a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> to climb, because that thing is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">deep</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: You wait until the tsunami is only as deep as your shin (しん). Then you climb down the tree and wade home in the shin-deep water.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> who hires his own personal <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clown</mark> will likely <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">double</mark> his entertainment. Clowns are funny and make people laugh, so the leader decided to hire one. Since that time, the leader's amount of mirth has doubled.
mnemonics.reading: When the clown stops being funny, it's time to say bye (ばい). At first, the clown doubled the leader's entertainment, but now the clown is just annoying. It's time to say bye-bye.

mnemonics.meaning: You'll have to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">excuse</mark> me, having all this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> puts a lot of strain and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">exertion</mark> on my body. My power comes from exertion of muscle, so please excuse me if I start to perspire.
mnemonics.reading: Excuse me, I don’t think I’ve introduced myself yet. My name is Ben (べん) and I use powerful muscle exertion to accomplish every task. Ben knows what Ben wants and how to get it. Remember that, kids.

mnemonics.meaning: A long time ago a huge <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> swept a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">triceratops</mark> up into the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">extinguish</mark>ed its life.
mnemonics.reading: This famous event where almost all life was extinguished is reenacted every year for the Shougun (しょう). He's got a bit of an unhealthy obsession with extinguishing life...

mnemonics.meaning: Under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark>, there’s a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark> on it. It’s all there for the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">festival</mark>. Festivals need activities, and at this festival, you can stand on a stool in the moonlight and use a jackhammer to make a lot of noise. Perfect for a festival!
mnemonics.reading: This festival is for cyborgs (さい) only. Picture the cyborg you made getting excited that you're taking it to the festival. That's why all of the activities have to do with heavy machinery. The rides are mostly just cyborgs letting other people ride them, but it's still pretty fun.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">village</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">beforehand</mark> (what the village was before it was a village) was a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">field</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: On this field, the Yankees (や) used to play.

mnemonics.meaning: Look at a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">compare</mark> the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark> parts. Each of those white parts is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">floor</mark>. Multi-<mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">story</mark> buildings have tons of different floors that you can see from the outside.
mnemonics.reading: One floor is just all kayaks (かい). You're looking at this building, and every other story is normal, but that one floor is kayak after kayak after kayak.

mnemonics.meaning: There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> and a man called the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Yoga</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">King</mark> standing in the middle of your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">garden</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Not only is this Yoga King taking over your garden, but he's ordering you to serve food to his class. "You there, peasant, fetch these people your freshest tater (てい) tots from this puny garden to give them strength."

mnemonics.meaning: There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> coming and you want to be <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">together</mark> with it by <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yourself</mark> (oneself) so you go to the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">harbor</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: As you look around at the harbor in your last moments you suddenly see someone in the water. It's こういち! He's sitting in an inner tube in the harbor waiting for the tsunami too.

mnemonics.meaning: If you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark> around my <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">skin</mark>, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">he</mark> will get angry at you. He's my very protective friend, and you don't wanna make him angry!
mnemonics.reading: He may get grumpy if you loiter around my skin, but a well-made curry (かれ) always brightens his mood. So give him some curry.

mnemonics.meaning: If the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> is on <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">someone</mark>, they will get <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hot</mark>. That's just how it is. Someone standing out in the sun for a long time will inevitably get hot. The sun is hot, and it makes you get hot too.
mnemonics.reading: One sun was hot enough, but then a second one shows up. "Ah, two (あつ)!" you scream. If you were sweaty and sticky from the heat of just one sun, imagine what this second one is going to do to you. Ah, two hot suns!

mnemonics.meaning: If there's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> it's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">easy</mark> to get <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hot water</mark>. Just stick your hand out the window as the tsunami goes by and poof! That water's HOT.
mnemonics.reading: As the hot water comes, you just lift up the bottom of the yurt (ゆ) you live in, and it comes flowing in. All of the cups, pots, and barrels you laid on your floor are now full of hot water.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">business</mark>? Ha! That's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">me</mark>! That's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">I</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: You use the word I a lot. You say it so much, you just start referring to yourself with the french beaucoup (ぼく) for a lot. Because you love yourself a lot.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bird</mark> sits upon a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark>. If you look at the radicals, the bird is quite large and the mountain quite small. Think of this in the mnemonic as well. The reason the mountain is small is because you can only see the top of it, sticking out of the water. On it is the bird. This small mountain with the bird on it is an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">island</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: But this island doesn't only belong to the bird. In fact, the bird shouldn't be on this island, because it belongs to the Sheep Mama (しま), who is like Mother Nature but for sheep. The all-powerful Sheep Mama comes to kick the bird off the island, because this place is only for sheep! All hail the Sheep Mama.

mnemonics.meaning: Those who <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> on top of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">village</mark> are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">juvenile</mark>. Imagine a bunch of young people standing on the roofs of buildings in the village. That's a juvenile thing to do.
mnemonics.reading: Mostly, though, the juveniles are standing on top of village buildings, eating doughnuts (どう).

mnemonics.meaning: Even a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>-bearing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">member</mark> of the invertebrate family. Yes, shellfish do have mouths, look it up!
mnemonics.reading: If you were a member of the same shellfish family, you'd be able to go to the special shellfish inn (いん). Every species has a members-only inn.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark>ing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mustache</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">legs</mark> is able to sell <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">merchandise</mark>. Most mustaches can’t stand because they don’t have legs. This mustache, however, does. It also has a keen business sense, which is why it’s selling merchandise.
mnemonics.reading: The mustache is selling his merchandise so well that even the Shougun (しょう) notices. He leans down really close to the standing mustache man's merchandise and stays very still. Then he snaps his fingers and his servants come rushing out to buy it all!

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Someone</mark>s and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark>s, someones and buildings, someones and buildings. So many someones and buildings. With so many someones and buildings, we have ourselves a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">metropolis</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: In this metropolis everything is a toe (と). The someones are toes, walking around. The buildings are toes, too.

mnemonics.meaning: When something is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heavy</mark>, you need a lot of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">move</mark> it. It’s not going to move unless you use a lot of power. That thing is heavy and unless you use all the power you got, it’s not moving.
mnemonics.reading: Remember that 1 ton weight? Well, actually it’s a doughnut (どう). A huge, massive, 1 ton doughnut. It’s super heavy and hard to move, but it’s delicious.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Bamboo</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">younger brother</mark> is counted with an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ordinal number prefix</mark>. An ordinal number is one that represents a position or rank in sequential order (like first, second, third, etc.). We use this ordinal number prefix before counting these things in Japanese sometimes. Like with bamboo, going down in order toward the youngest.
mnemonics.reading: To remember you need to use the ordinal number prefix before you count these bamboo, you dye (だい) them.

mnemonics.meaning: A "<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">crab</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark>" is a specific <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">period of time</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: When the crab moon period of time is upon us, we must take a special key (き) and lock everything in such a way that crabs cannot get in.

mnemonics.meaning: If you want a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> to grow <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">straight</mark>, you have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">plant</mark> it properly. Everyone knows that poorly planted trees grow all crooked and twisted. That's just how plants work. If your tree's not straight, start over and plant it again.
mnemonics.reading: You plant and re-plant your tree over and over, utterly shocked (しょく) at how hard it is to plant it right. You thought planting trees was easy, so this is a real shock to you.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">root</mark> is still just a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">root</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: Tree roots are the perfect roosting place for condors (こん). Unfortunately, living on roots is also why they're always endangered. Condors can be killed pretty easily living on the ground on roots like this.

mnemonics.meaning: If you use an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark> to shoot a stalk of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">beans</mark>, the bean plant will end up <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">short</mark>. When the beans are hit with that arrow, it severs the plant in two, and you are left with a stalk of beans that is much shorter than before.
mnemonics.reading: All this shooting of arrows to make the bean plants short is taking a long time. Since you're out in the sun, you're starting to get a tan (たん). After the day is finally over, your tan is really, really dark.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">request</mark>s a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sphere</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: The sphere is a cucumber (きゅう) sphere. A strange sphere shaped cucumber.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">White</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark> shoots out from a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">spring</mark> in the ground. Due to the force the water shoots from the spring, the water looks white with all the air bubbles.
mnemonics.reading: From the spring, a centaur (せん) emerges.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> lifts all the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">trash</mark> out of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">river</mark> and it <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stream</mark>s out onto the shores.
mnemonics.reading: Next to the trash stream you suddenly see Ryu (りゅう) from Street Fighter and he looks pissed. He's furious that so many people throw their trash in the river and it causes streams like this.

mnemonics.meaning: The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">suit</mark> and the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">suit</mark> are exactly the same! This kanji can also mean <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">join</mark> which makes sense. When something suits you well, like a hat or something, it joins together with you quite well too. Join me, my hat! You suit my head well. It just <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fit</mark>s, you know?
mnemonics.reading: You need someone who will suit you. Someone who can join you on your life journey. So you call Grandpa ごういち.

mnemonics.meaning: I have <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sick</mark> in my <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">skin</mark>. Just look at it, it doesn't look too good. Whenever I have sickness in my skin, I know that I'm probably <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tired</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Why so tired? Your body is heated (ひ) up from exercising way too much. You should let that heat cool down so your skin starts looking better.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Stop</mark>! That <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">box</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> is actually full of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">teeth</mark>! I know it says "rice" on the cover, but I promise you those are all teeth and if you bite into them you'll break a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tooth</mark> of your own.
mnemonics.reading: Why do I have a rice box full of teeth? Ha (は)! Wouldn't you like to know. Ha! I definitely have an answer that isn't weird or creepy. Ha... ha ha...

mnemonics.meaning: If someone is headed in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark>, nock an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark> in your bow and gather your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tribe</mark> behind you because it’s about to get real! This man with a gun is headed your direction and he doesn’t even know what you and your tribe are gonna do to him. If he gets any closer, you’re likely to shoot that arrow right at him.
mnemonics.reading: When he starts to get closer, you notice that this guy is a bosozoku (ぞく) bike gang member. Bosozoku means “running tribe” and this guy is running right at you. With a gun. So gather your own tribe behind you and prepare to defend yourself against this bosozoku member.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark> is facing leads straight to a block of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tofu</mark>. This might be a sign you need to take a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">trip</mark>. If you're out there pointing guns at tofu, you're probably a little… tired… and in need of a change of scenery. Take a trip!
mnemonics.reading: So, where do you go on your trip? To Rio (りょ). You had to go way down south to get as far away as possible from tofu. Ahh, nothing like a nice trip to Rio!

mnemonics.meaning: People who <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark> around the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">temple</mark> are probably just trying to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wait</mark>. They don't mean to look like they're up to no good, but it's hard to wait without looking suspicious when you're waiting outside a temple.
mnemonics.reading: As you wait outside the temple, you can't help but adjust your tie (たい). When you wait you get nervous, and when you get nervous you fidget. So now you're messing with your tie a whole bunch.

mnemonics.meaning: There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> which washes a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">plate</mark> out into the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>. Because it's in the sun, it becomes  <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">warm</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The plate starts to get so warm that you could fry an onion (おん) on it. Who doesn’t love fried onions? That plate sure is warm enough, so start cookin’ ‘em!

mnemonics.meaning: There are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sheep</mark> right before your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark>s, because they just love what you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wear</mark>. It's a little known fact that sheep are fashionistas, and they <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">arrive</mark> daily to admire your style. These sheep are so stylish they wear their tail to one side - in the latest fashion (check out the sheep radical - the tail is sweeping stylishly to the left!).
mnemonics.reading: More sheep arrive every day to admire the clothes you're wearing. You use a chalk (ちゃく) board to keep count of how many sheep come by each day.

mnemonics.meaning: If you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">compare</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark> light to the other colors you'll realize... white consists of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">all</mark> the colors in one. It contains all the colors in the spectrum in one color. It is the one color that is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">everything</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You decide white light is the ultimate color. You decide you want to put it on all things to make everything white. "What a great idea," you think. You try to put it on everything and you nearly succeed... except, the miners (みな). They keep getting dirty doing all their mining things. NOOO, your plan is ruined!

mnemonics.meaning: You thought it would be a good idea to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">body</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark>s of everyone in your village and now you have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">apologize</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You were told you had to apologize by the village shaman (しゃ). At first you didn't even know why everyone was glaring at you, but the shaman took you aside and explained. And now she's standing behind you with her arms crossed as you apologize to everybody.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bundle</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark> way to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">arrange</mark> things. Just make sure you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">organize</mark> it all before winter comes, or it'll be too late.
mnemonics.reading: But the most important things to arrange and organize are your sabers (せい). You have an extensive saber collection that you simply must organize before winter arrives.

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> must've been sent from <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heaven</mark>, because it has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mustache</mark>. Like some kind of special heaven tree that talks. And why was it sent? To be a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bridge</mark>. To be the great heavenly bridge that we all, someday, must cross.
mnemonics.reading: Actually, to get across this bridge you have to give it some hash (はし) browns. That's what the bridge's mouth is for. Hash browns to get across the heaven bridge? Small price to pay, really.

mnemonics.meaning: The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">can</mark> is the same as the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">can</mark>. Usually when we talk about a can with this kanji we mean a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tin can</mark>, though.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for a can is かん, which seems impossibly easy. If that isn't close enough for you, picture this:

mnemonics.meaning: You want to get a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark>, so you have one self (<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">oneself</mark>) and another self working <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">together</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">choose</mark>. The two tiny yous sit on each of your shoulders, like angel and devil, and argue about which scooter you should choose.
mnemonics.reading: Suddenly your selfs both gasp and choose a scooter in front of you that looks like a centaur (せん). The scooter is designed like a human on the top, the bars are its arms, and the bottom with the seat and the wheels are all horse. This centaur scooter is what you choose to ride.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Big</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">products</mark> need to be put in a big <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">container</mark>. A small container just won’t do. These products are big and they need a big container to be contained in.
mnemonics.reading: Once you get the big products into a container, you then lock it with a key (き). You wouldn’t want these products to bust out of their containers, so it’s best to lock them up with a key.

mnemonics.meaning: If the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> starts to make a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sound</mark>, you know it's about to go <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dark</mark>. The sun isn't supposed to make a sound, so if you can hear it, it's probably about to fizzle out or something. After it's gone, obviously everything will be pitch black. Get ready to be in the dark!
mnemonics.reading: Now wandering around your house in the dark you start to feel hungry, so you reach blindly for some food and take a bite. Yuck! It's anchovies (あん). You don't even like anchovies, how did they get in your house? Hmm… Dark forces are at work here…

mnemonics.meaning: You reach for a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark> to start eating, but your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mama</mark> hands you an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark> instead and points towards the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">coat rack</mark>. Hm, that's not like her… Suddenly you're filled with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">doubt</mark>. Is this really your mama? You doubt it.
mnemonics.reading: Now full of doubt, you decide to test your mama by putting her in a guillotine (ぎ). It sounds harsh, but the guillotine is the only way to clear up your doubts.

mnemonics.meaning: You have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ladle</mark> that's specifically for paying the rice <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fee</mark>. Each scoop of something has an extra fee tacked on, so when you use a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">material</mark>, there's a fee you have to pay in that material as well.
mnemonics.reading: One day, the fee ladle is suddenly the size of row (りょう) boat oars! What! You're supposed to pay a row boat sized fee now?!

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blue</mark>. As in, it's sad and not feeling well. This is because your soul changes colors depending on your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">feeling</mark>s or what <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">emotion</mark>s you're expressing.
mnemonics.reading: Why is your soul feeling blue? Because Joe (じょう), the big local farmhand, was extremely mean to you.

mnemonics.meaning: Down a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> comes and places a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">creeper</mark> into your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>. Your entire body is filled with a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">feeling</mark>. A feeling you don't like.
mnemonics.reading: This feeling wells up in you and bursts forth. You feel mad, you feel like you want revenge, you feel like Genghis Khan (かん) reborn! And you will have your revenge on this drunkard.

mnemonics.meaning: By a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>, there's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sheep</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark> with a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">formal name ender</mark>. That means everyone calls him Sheep-sama. No one calls him just "Sheep," since he's kind of a big deal. He's actually like sheep royalty. When he's not in his castle, Sheep-sama enjoys playing in the water by the trees.
mnemonics.reading: This sheep with the formal name ender only likes to play outside in the water during the summer (さま). Summer is the best season for this fancy sheep. The other seasons just can't compare.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Sheep</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark> are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">good</mark> for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">foster</mark> children. The sheep have been genetically combined with fish, so the sheep have fins (and they've lost their tails — which is why the tail part of the sheep radical is missing in this kanji). These sheep fins are rich in nutrients, so they're good for fostering big, strong foster children.
