mnemonics.reading: The best way to foster a better relationship with these foster kids would be to give them some yogurt (よう). Maybe they can dip the sheep fins in the yogurt to help mask the strange taste. Yogurt is also very nutritious, so it's a good supplement to the foster kids' diet.

mnemonics.meaning: If you tie a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> around <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark> and dip him in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark>, he'll turn <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">green</mark>, like the Hulk. Some kind of weird chemical reaction. But I… I wouldn't try it if I were you. You wouldn't like him when he's green.
mnemonics.reading: As the flailing Wolverine begins to turn even more green, he calls out, "HELP ME DORY (みどり)!" Me, Dory? No, not you. He's calling out to that fish from Finding Nemo, another Disney IP. "Help me Dory, I'm green!" Then Dory leaps out of the water to bite through the thread and save Wolverine… THE END. Fade to green.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">womb</mark> spins in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">circle</mark> and starts to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark> with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">heat</mark>. Uh oh, I think you have a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fever</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The heat from your fever is making your insides and your head and your entire body spin and boil, until your doctor throws some nets (ねつ) around you. You were flailing around and they couldn't get you to stop, so they had to catch you in a series of nets.

mnemonics.meaning: A cult <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> has a great <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">idea</mark> to recruit a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hundred million</mark> new members. Since he’s the guy with all the ideas, he is the leader of the cult. His idea is to give every new member a free puppy. He’ll have a hundred million new recruits in no time.
mnemonics.reading: The cult leader has his headquarters in Oklahoma (おく). Are there a hundred million people in Oklahoma? No, probably not. But hey, this leader is shooting for the stars. First Oklahoma, then the universe!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> is standing in the middle of said rice paddy with an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">umbrella</mark>. Who is this wacky leader? Why, it is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">I</mark>. It is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">me</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Why am I standing in the middle of this rice paddy with an umbrella? I'm digging for ore (おれ).

mnemonics.meaning: Only a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark>s and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> has the ability to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">imagine</mark> and to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">contemplate</mark>. For a tree to imagine and contemplate things, it needs eyes to see and a heart to feel.
mnemonics.reading: If a tree can imagine, it likely has a soul (そう). Its soul is what makes it possible for the tree to contemplate things, you see?

mnemonics.meaning: There's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure</mark> in this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> so you take out your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">kill</mark> it.
mnemonics.reading: But after the kill, Satsuki (さつ) appears and yells at you. She likes trees — remember how she protected one in the 札 mnemonic? — so Satsuki's pretty upset you'd kill one like that.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> under which the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> can house one <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hundred</mark> of his people is at the local <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lodge</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The lodge shook (しゅく) as the hundred people came tumbling in through the door. It shook, but it didn't fall over. The roof stayed firmly in place, and everyone got to sleep under it okay.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Gold</mark> reveals itself when you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">see</mark> into this <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mirror</mark>. Yes, even you are made of gold. You're so great and valuable, standing in front of that mirror. It's not hard to see, especially in a mirror – you're golden.
mnemonics.reading: As you look into the mirror you think, "Kaga… me (かがみ)?" You always forget that you're Chairman Kaga from the Iron Chef TV show. That's why you say "Kaga… me?" every time you look in the mirror.

mnemonics.meaning: Under a misshapen crescent <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dog</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark>s as much <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">nature</mark> as it can find.
mnemonics.reading: Destroying nature like this is the dog's way of practicing Zen (ぜん) Buddhism. As it breathes in the fumes from all of the different pieces of nature being boiled down, the dog gets really zen and chill.

mnemonics.meaning: What you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> at a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">temple</mark> is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">poem</mark>. It has to be a poem, because if you say anything else it's just plain disrespectful. All of the monks and priests at this temple have to read and recite poems all day, and if they can do it forever, you can while you're visiting.
mnemonics.reading: As you recite a long poem at the temple you see a sheep (し) in the crowd. It's opening and closing its mouth like it wants to say the poem too.

mnemonics.meaning: Pointing a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">east</mark> is what you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">practice</mark> every day. You're incredibly passionate about eastward thread-pointing, so you make sure to practice every day.
mnemonics.reading: You do all of this practice to try and afford all of your rentals (れん). One day, all of this practice will pay for all of your rentals.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Viking</mark> opens his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>, and below it, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> sits. Grab that shellfish and throw it into his mouth to win a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">prize</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: The prize you're working so hard to win is lunch with the Shougun (しょう). This is a pretty huge prize, considering all you're doing is knocking something over.

mnemonics.meaning: If you run into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gate</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> first, you’re going to have a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">problem</mark>. Smashing your mouth into a gate is going to hurt. A lot. The problem you’re now in is one of getting to a hospital and having your mouth sewn back on. The <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">question</mark> is, how are you going to get to the hospital?
mnemonics.reading: The reason you ran mouth first into this gate was because you were being chased by a monster (もん). A monster in and of itself is a big enough problem as is, let alone smashing your mouth into a gate. You poor, hapless soul.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Eat</mark>ing the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bear</mark>, because the roof is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">public building</mark>. Because it is a public building bears are allowed to eat the roof.
mnemonics.reading: Public buildings must make their roofs available for eating because of a law passed by Genghis Khan (かん).

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">samurai</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">samurai</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: The most famous samurai in Japanese history was the illustrious sheep (し) samurai. He wasn't JUST a sheep who learned the ways of the sword, he would use the wool from the sheep enemies he killed to create his armor!

mnemonics.meaning: I always <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fruit</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">section</mark> at the grocery should be at the front of the store. It’s the perfect place for the fruit section, I say.
mnemonics.reading: To get to the fruit section, you have to go to the store. To get to the store you have to drive a car (か). Driving a car is the fastest way to get to the fruit section at the store.

mnemonics.meaning: You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">helicopter</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark> tied to it. You look closer, because this is an odd sight, and realize that there is a sign here too. It's telling you to beware of helicopters and jackhammers in these woods. It's a poorly made <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">signpost</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: As you look at this weird signpost you notice a button. You press it because it will supposedly tell you more about these dangerous helicopters and jackhammers. Instead, it just yells out in a loud obnoxious voice: HEYO (ひょう)!!

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Gold</mark>, at its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">root</mark>, is made up of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">silver</mark>. Using silver as the root of a coin is a great way to save on gold! That's why, often, if you just scratch gold, you'll find there's silver hidden underneath, at its root.
mnemonics.reading: If you want to hunt for some silver for yourself, all you need is a guinea (ぎん) pig. Guinea pigs can smell silver, so get a couple and set them loose in the woods and they'll lead you straight to it.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horse</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shrimp</mark> are sitting next to each other. They are both at the train <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">station</mark>, waiting for a train to come and take them home.
mnemonics.reading: The train pulls into the station. They walk up to the train doors, but they don't open. "Perhaps a key (えき) would help?" asks the station master, as he goes over to open the door to the train.

mnemonics.meaning: If you use the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>, you can find the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark>. That's the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">topic</mark> of today's lecture.
mnemonics.reading: Our topic is actually mostly about using the sun to see different colored dyes (だい) in the water.

mnemonics.meaning: For your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> you use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hat</mark>, some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bookshelf</mark> to build a new <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wheel</mark>. I mean, it's generally <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ring</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">loop</mark> shaped, it just needs to be a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">circle</mark>, so it should work, right?
mnemonics.reading: Your wheel is... generally ring (りん) shaped, so that's good.

mnemonics.meaning: In a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> place on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark>, you hide two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark>s that give you a special <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ability</mark>. It's the ability to predict the future! The private moon spoons reflect the knowledge of time and space into your brain. Now that's a cool ability!
mnemonics.reading: This ability to predict the future makes you famous and now everyone knows your name: Nostradamus (のう)! And now that people know about your name and special ability, everyone will love you!

mnemonics.meaning: You put <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cloud</mark> and call it <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">art</mark>. Not everyone agrees that your flower cloud art is actually art, but you know it is.
mnemonics.reading: Your beautiful art is going to be displayed at a gay (げい) club. Imagine the pride you feel about having your art on display.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Rain</mark> makes up one <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">part</mark> of this, and the rest is air or something. I imagine this is what people thought the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">atmosphere</mark> was made out of thousands of years ago.
mnemonics.reading: Turns out, studying the atmosphere is fun (ふん)!

mnemonics.meaning: If you have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mustache</mark> and you hit your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark>, you’re probably going to break a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bone</mark>. Ok, so it doesn’t matter so much if you have a mustache, but if you’re travelling fast enough to make it to the moon, you’re definitely breaking a bone if you run into it.
mnemonics.reading: Outer space is cold, and if you're traveling to the moon, you're going to need a lot of coats (こつ). All of these coats will keep you warm, even if you do end up breaking your forehead bone.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bundle</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bundle</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: You should always bundle your socks (そく). If you don't, there is a 100% chance you'll lose all of the left ones.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">circumference</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">circumference</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: Practice how to measure the circumference of an item by using your shoe (しゅう). Your shoe is kind of round, and it's free. I mean it's right there on your foot.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gate</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">talent</mark> is now <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">closed</mark>. In fact, the gate to talent is always closed. It's not like anyone can just waltz in and get themselves some talent. You have to work for it! You have to work hard to get through that closed gate to talent!
mnemonics.reading: Outside the talent gate that's always closed, hay (へい) is piled up to make beds for the people who are still trying to get in. Who knows how long they'll be there outside the closed gate, sleeping in the hay, but they're all working hard to become talented.

mnemonics.meaning: Next to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> we combine our <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> so that we have <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cooperation</mark>. And with our powers combined, we become stronger than we ever could have been apart, lifting the cross above our heads!
mnemonics.reading: Nowhere is the power of cooperation more apparent than in きょうと. When invaders are attacking, when the townspeople want to rebel, when there is a kitty up a tree, the people combine their power from all reaches of Japan and cross into きょうと to put a stop to the madness through cooperation.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yakuza</mark> shows you his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark>. He says, "This is an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">example</mark> of a knife."
mnemonics.reading: "This is an example," the leader of the yakuza tells you. "Next time, I'll show you an example of a ray (れい) gun."

mnemonics.meaning: If your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> are strong enough, you can take an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fold</mark> it in half. But be careful not to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bend</mark> it too far, or you might just <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">break</mark> it!
mnemonics.reading: Unfortunately, as you fold these axes in half you realize they come in sets (せつ), so there are twice the axes you thought there would be. To compensate, you start folding them in sets too.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Crab</mark>s in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> make a great <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">foundation</mark> for a seaside hut. It's right on the seashore, where all the crabs dig their holes in the dirt. But as they get old and die, their bodies form a strong base. Perfect for the foundation of a building like this!
mnemonics.reading: Remember, a good foundation is the key (き) to a good house. No, literally. You have to use a piece of the foundation to make the key to your house.

mnemonics.meaning: Everyone has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> in their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark>, and that soul shapes their <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gender</mark>. It's not just about body parts — it's about what's inside. In the end, it's one's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji"> nature</mark> that truly matters.
mnemonics.reading: Once you've decided what your gender is, someone comes to your house and lays a saber (せい) on your shoulders. "This is now your nature," they say, lifting the saber. It's official! It's in all the newspapers, there's a parade, and everyone pats you on the back. Thanks, gender saber!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cleat</mark>-wearing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> is walking on someone's back, but she doesn't want to hurt him, so she has to be very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gentle</mark>. Cleats are sharp and pointy, and not designed for back-walking, so she's being extra gentle right now.
mnemonics.reading: Actually, the person she's being gentle with is her dad (だ). No one would ever want to hurt their dad, especially if he's asked you to walk gently on his back as a way of giving him a massage.

mnemonics.meaning: You give a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">person</mark> (two of them, in fact), then they put it on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> when you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">graduate</mark>. It's a symbolic ceremony, putting a lid over a cross, but it's just what you do when you graduate around these parts.
mnemonics.reading: Uh oh, looks like you forgot your lid. They decide not to let you graduate. So two (そつ) more years now until you can graduate, it seems. So two more years?! Just for forgetting a lid? Nonsense!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> that is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">old</mark> is going to be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hard</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You touch the old man's hard mouth and it crumbles away, revealing the face of a 子 (こ) inside.

mnemonics.meaning: Causing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">death</mark> at every turn, the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> sits inside his moon, getting ready to cause death on anything in his sights. Sounds a lot like the Death Star from a certain movie. One of which is "Star Wars: A New <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Hope</mark>."
mnemonics.reading: The name A New Hope, as we all know, comes from the ending where the moon king's son sends a bowling (ぼう) ball into that little opening and knocks it out of the sky.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">talent</mark> can become <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lumber</mark>. Not all trees can do this. Only the talented ones are able to turn themselves into lumber or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">material</mark>, to be used for a million different things.
mnemonics.reading: Trees can be turned into all kinds of things, but this one wants to use its lumber and material to build a xylophone (ざい). It's the most difficult instrument to create, so it suits the talent level of this tree!

mnemonics.meaning: You try to be <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark>, but because of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark> you end up having to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">participate</mark> in everything. Can you imagine people asking for volunteers or something, and you trying to look inconspicuous with your big hair? Of course they're going to notice you and make you participate.
mnemonics.reading: You know who has big hair and loves to participate in everything? Santa-san (さん)! Well, his hair is more big on the bottom (it's a beard) than whatever you have on your head, but hair is hair. And he participates in present-giving in every house in the world! See? Big hair = participation!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> that became the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">origin</mark> of all roofs was <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">perfect</mark>. It was tall and wide so it could fit and protect everyone. And the dimensions were perfect too.
mnemonics.reading: This perfect roof was commissioned by Genghis Khan (かん). We got all of the carpenters and home makers and construction workers he'd conquered together and tasked them with making the first roof, but only if they made it absolutely perfect.

mnemonics.meaning: When climbing a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">public</mark>, it’s best to choose a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pine</mark>. Pine trees offer the most coverage, so you’ll be able to hide, even out in public.
mnemonics.reading: In case you fall, someone has laid mats (まつ) out around the base of the pine tree. That way, you’ll land on the mats should something unfortunate happen.

mnemonics.meaning: You tie a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> on your finger before jumping in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pool</mark> to remind yourself of the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">promise</mark> you made to your mother. The thread represents the promise you made to mow the lawn after you finished swimming in the pool.
mnemonics.reading: After you get out of the pool, you keep the promise you made to your mother. So you get on your yak (やく) powered mower and trim the grass. Yes, your mower is pulled by a yak. It’s very efficient.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Yakuza</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bars</mark> barely exist. The <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">remainder</mark> of them aren't even in Japan.
mnemonics.reading: The remainder of the yakuza bars aren't in Japan. Strangely, they are all in Zanzibar (ざん).

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">original</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark> had a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">request</mark>. He wants there to be more geoducks in the world!
mnemonics.reading: The only person that would even hear the geoduck's request was Gandhi (がん). Gandhi closed his eyes, sat down, and spread the geoduck's request to the rest of the world.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark> will grow with the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">seasons</mark>. In spring the grain is born, it grows in summer, is harvested in fall, and dies in winter.
mnemonics.reading: All of the seasons have their own special key (き). As they change, that season's key appears and unlocks the next step in the grain's life.

mnemonics.meaning: If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> wants to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kiss</mark> you, it's a sign of your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">status</mark>. Only someone of high status would be worthy enough to receive the gnarly but gentle kiss of a tree. Trees don't kiss just anyone, you know.
mnemonics.reading: The best way to convince a tree of your status is to say "cock-a-doodle-doo" at it, like a cock (かく), i.e. a male chicken. Trees really place a lot of status on the ability to sound like a cock crowing.

mnemonics.meaning: The best kind of flowers to grow in your window? Strawberry, obviously. Yes, there are strawberry flowers — it's actually the flowers that turn into the strawberries, you know. And they're perfect as window flowers because they need a ton of light. That's why all your window flowers are strawberries.
mnemonics.reading: Believe it or not, your strawberry is the only cure for an itchy Godzilla (いちご).

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">origin</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark> is a pretty <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stubborn</mark> one. The geoduck race is so stubborn that it refused to evolve into an animal that made any sense. Hence, the origin of the geoduck is one of stubbornness.
mnemonics.reading: You know who else was stubborn? Gandhi (がん). Gandhi believed in non-violent resistance and he was pretty stubborn about it.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">well</mark> will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">surround</mark> you if you fall into it. The mouth of a well is the opening of the well, and if you fall into that well, the mouth as well as the rest of the well will surround you.
mnemonics.reading: The well walls surround you as you look up to the mouth once again. This time you see an eagle (い) flying overhead. You call out to the eagle to save you and the eagle comes swooping down into the well and flies you out to safety. What a nice eagle!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark> guy jumps into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pool</mark> with a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">target</mark> painted on the bottom. He's aiming for the target, of course.
mnemonics.reading: This white dude is a huge techie (てき) so he has electronic enhancements that make sure he hits the target. Being a techie has its advantages.

mnemonics.meaning: If you live in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">now</mark>, there’s a good chance your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> controls your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">thought</mark> process. You don’t have time to think with your brain, you need an answer now so you use your heart to make decisions and thought process.
mnemonics.reading: You're living in the now and letting your heart control all your thoughts. Why are you following your heart? You found you only have one 年 (ねん) to live, so you have to live for the now.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">well</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">well</mark> kanji are the same.
mnemonics.reading: Each time you go to the town well, there's a giant eagle (い) hiding inside, just waiting for you to show up.

mnemonics.meaning: There is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure</mark> on top of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">narwhal</mark> who wears a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> that will grant your greatest <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wish</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: In order to open the treasure and get your wish, you need the key (き). The narwhal knows where it's hidden, so you'll have to convince it to tell you where the key is.

mnemonics.meaning: One <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">animal</mark> that is particularly  <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">good</mark> is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wolf</mark>. Wolves have a bad reputation, but actually they're very, very good animals.
mnemonics.reading: A wolf might be good, but if you run into one, all you can do is scream Oh 神!” (おおかみ).

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> you weave together to tell others about <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">oneself</mark> is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">account</mark> of your life. It's your very own <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">narrative</mark>, tying everything you've been through together.
mnemonics.reading: You take this account and lock it with a special key (き). You only give this key to people you really trust, so they can read the account of your life and truly understand you.

mnemonics.meaning: You run into someone's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> with your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark>. The big forehead you hit is Kim Jong Un's. You know that now you're going to have the whole North Korean <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">army</mark> coming after you.
mnemonics.reading: The army is after you. Each army soldier has a gun (ぐん) and they want to use these guns of theirs to shoot you dead! You killed their leader with a car and now they’re gonna get you back with a gun!

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Grain</mark>s look like they're on <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark> in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">autumn</mark>. They all turn red and orange and brown, the colors of fire. It's also fun to set grains on fire in Autumn, since it's getting colder.
mnemonics.reading: As the grains burn, and the season changes to autumn, imagine them yelling out in pain: "ACK (あき)!"

mnemonics.meaning: To your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark>, you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark>: "<mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Believe</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">trust</mark> in me." The leader doesn't think you can handle your duties, so you have to say this to him. You want him to believe and trust that you're responsible. You can handle this task.
mnemonics.reading: As you face your leader and say "Believe and trust in me," you kneel down on each shin (しん). You have shin splints, so it hurts a bit, but you do it anyway to show how serious you are.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark> is probably going to be a really big stone. We're talking about a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">boulder</mark> here.
mnemonics.reading: "Boulder!!!" yells a voice from behind you. "Eee, wha...?" (いわ) you reply. You look up to see a boulder falling off the cliff above you. "Eeeeee! Whaaaat!?," you shout again, running and screaming this time.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Buddha</mark>. You don't feel the need to tell everyone. But when you're alone you give your time to Buddha and let him lead your life.
mnemonics.reading: Your private Buddha is a little different than other people's idea of him. Your Buddha is wearing boots (ぶつ). They're big and rubber, and they look fabulous on him.

mnemonics.meaning: If you see an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">animal</mark> among the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark>, chances are it’s a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cat</mark>. Cats love rice paddy flowers, almost as much as they love catnip.
mnemonics.reading: Wait a minute… This cat is pretty odd looking. You take a closer look, seeing it is missing its neck (ねこ). You go to pet it, but it's super sensitive about that area of its head, which is basically a face connected to a body...

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Again</mark> and again, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">change</mark>s you each year.
mnemonics.reading: You know what else changes each winter? Hens (へん)! They're constantly laying eggs, which then (possibly) turn into new hens.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> is out, the sky is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blue</mark>, things have begun to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">clear up</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: Now that it's starting to clear up you can't help but laugh. "Ha (は)! Ha ha ha!" you laugh up into the sky. The sun feels great on your face, making you feel lively! And that blue sky ain't too shabby either.

mnemonics.meaning: The radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">courage</mark> and the kanji for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">courage</mark> are exactly the same.
mnemonics.reading: A man needs courage to stand up to all the youths (ゆう) of the world. They are so numerous and difficult to understand, but the man can face them with courage thanks to his mama.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> approaches, and anyone who dares to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> in front of it will surely <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cry</mark>. That tsunami is going to hit you hard, and rip you right off the ground you're standing on. Who wouldn't cry?
mnemonics.reading: Do you know the only way to stop yourself crying after a tsunami? That's right, nachos (な)! Nachos are the only proven way to cheer people up after being hit by a tsunami.

mnemonics.meaning: Throw a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cape</mark> over a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">creeper</mark>, and suddenly they think they're a big-shot <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">director</mark>. They go around calling themselves managing director of this, director-general of that. They creep into meetings and ceremonies and try to direct the proceedings, all because of that stupid cape.
mnemonics.reading: After this creeper dons the cape, they decide to become Director of Sheep (し). From now on all sheep-related business, government policy, and law will be determined by this creeper in a cape, because they are the Director of Sheep.

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cage</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure</mark> in it is actually a map of the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">district</mark> the treasure is in.
mnemonics.reading: There is one district you're interested in, and that's the cookie (く) district.

mnemonics.meaning: There are many <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">center</mark> of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">England</mark>. It may seem rainy and gray at first, but if you walk right to the center you'll see all the flowers that grow there in the center of the country.
mnemonics.reading: You keep walking to the very central center of England and see a giant acorn (えい) planted in the middle of the ground. This acorn is the source of all the flowers and life in England.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">height</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">height</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: When you think of height, think of our huge farmhand friend, Joe (じょう). He's a big guy, and he has a lot of height to him. In fact, he's ten feet tall.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">husband</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">husband</mark> kanji are the same. How useful, unlike some husbands, I'd imagine.
mnemonics.reading: What do all husbands love? Food (ふう)! Can you hear your future husband? He’s saying, "Fooooood! FOOOOOD!” like some kind of food craving zombie.

mnemonics.meaning: Members of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tongue</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clan</mark> like to do one thing: <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lick</mark>. They go around licking everything to mark their tongue clan territory, you know? They even lick each other on the cheek by way of greeting.
mnemonics.reading: Unfortunately, the tongue clan members also lick your nachos (な). You'd been saving those nachos! They were your travel rations. Now each and every nacho has been licked clean.

mnemonics.meaning: When a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> decides to live in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scarecrow</mark>, you'll be granted good <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">luck</mark> and good <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fortune</mark>. Crows won't hang out in your farm. Everything you grow will become large and delicious. But not everyone is so lucky that a spirit will decide to live in their scarecrow. So maybe the luck was in you all along!
mnemonics.reading: You want to check the scarecrow to make sure your recent luck is coming from it, so you kick it. "F*** (ふく) you!" it yells. Oh yeah, there's a spirit in there.

mnemonics.meaning: You might want to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eat</mark>, but your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">anti</mark>-eating stance means your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">meal</mark> will just sit in front of you, uneaten. Food is meant to be eaten! Stop trying to fast and take a bite.
mnemonics.reading: As you stare at the meal, Han (はん) Solo appears before you and takes a bite! This is what happens if you don't eat your food, someone else will eat it.

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> how big a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> is, you have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">measure</mark> it. You can't say the size of something without measuring it first.
mnemonics.reading: You need to measure this cross but all you have is a cake (けい). Good enough! I'm sure all cakes are exactly the same size, so they're a reliable unit of measure.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Tsunami</mark>s in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">past</mark> changed the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">method</mark>s and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">law</mark>s of today.
mnemonics.reading: These methods and laws affected your own home (ほう) the most.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> has an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">excuse</mark> for disappearing at <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">night</mark>. The sun gets really tired, same as anyone else – so when night rolls around the sun excuses itself and goes to sleep. It’s a valid excuse.
mnemonics.reading: Unfortunately, you also have a history of overworking yourself, so you've been outright banned (ばん) from showing up at night.

mnemonics.meaning: A giant <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shrimp</mark> appears on top of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> after it rises high above the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>, and this is how you know it's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">noon</mark>. The shrimp appears on the sun exactly at noon every day, to announce that it's noon.
mnemonics.reading: At noon, the shrimp also puts on its high heels (ひる). It wants to look good for the other shrimp it's going to lunch with. High noon? More like high heels, am I right?

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark>, no one can see them unless they <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pay</mark>! And you decide if what they pay is enough to get a peek.
mnemonics.reading: If someone tries to look without paying, that's harassment (はら)! Nobody gets to see something of yours without proper payment, but more importantly, your consent!

mnemonics.meaning: To throw <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark> out the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">window</mark>, use <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">poison</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: If anything's worse than poison it's doing Sudoku (どく) puzzles.

mnemonics.meaning: Once the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> comes out, you can use this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">key</mark> to unlock it and take you to any <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">previous</mark> day, even just <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">yesterday</mark>! The sun is in charge of the day changes, so if you use a key to unlock it, you can control the flow of time and return to yesterday, or a previous day in the past. Behold the power of the sun.
mnemonics.reading: Time traveling to a previous time, like yesterday, can be rough on the body. As such, you wear a small sack (さく) to hold your valuables while you're ripped through the sands of time. The sack keeps your important stuff from getting lost. The sack holds your key to the sun as well.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> got stuck in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark>, and he has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> wrapped around it to stop the bleeding, but he really needs to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">return home</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Wolverine wants to return home, but he can't drive himself because there's a knife in his forehead and lots of blood, so he asks his friend the car elephant (かえ) to take him. Car elephant is just an elephant mutant that has a car on his back.

mnemonics.meaning: A good <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ceremony</mark> is under <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark> for a long time. You can't just make up a new ceremony on the spot. A ceremony is done a certain way because that's the way it's always been done. In short, to build a ceremony, you have to create a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ritual</mark> first. Then, the ritual can be constructed into a bigger, more lavish <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ceremony</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: So, you're at a ritual, but not just any old ritual. This is a full-blown ceremony and it's incredibly chic (しき). Imagine just how chic it is. Give it a shot — I'll let you come up with the chicness this time (it's good practice).

mnemonics.meaning: Take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yakuza</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> and put it in a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">row</mark> with the others.
mnemonics.reading: Should we put them in a row? Let's (れつ) put them in a row!

mnemonics.meaning: After a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark>, if you go to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bar</mark>, you'll find yourself standing in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shallow</mark> water. You're just trying to enjoy a drink, but with your feet constantly soaked, it's not exactly pleasant. Here's to hoping the conversations with your date won't be shallow too!
mnemonics.reading: What beer are you drinking at this bar while standing in shallow water? You’re drinking Asahi (あさ), the beer of the salaryman. Asahi is super dry, so it takes your attention away from the shallow water a bit.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">simple</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">simple</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: One of the most simple things in the world is getting a tan (たん). All you have to do is stand outside long enough. It doesn't matter what skin type you have or what the weather is like. Eventually, if you stand out there long enough, you'll get a tan.

mnemonics.meaning: You can make your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">branch</mark> out. It's your special <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">skill</mark>, a very advanced <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">technique</mark>. Your fingers branch out into smaller fingers and you can hold things really well. You can type super-duper fast. And you can win any tickle fight. These are skills you have thanks to your branching fingers.
mnemonics.reading: Unfortunately, these skills are too much for the normal skill-less people to handle, so they pull out the guillotine (ぎ). I guess they're going to chop off your skillful fingers because they're kinda scary.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Dirt</mark> is being <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">anti</mark>-social when it's in the shape of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">slope</mark>. Think about it — is there anything more annoying than having to walk up a steep slope? Why is the dirt here forming a slope?! Because the dirt is being anti-social, and a slope is how it tells you to stay away.
mnemonics.reading: You need to know these things about slopes if you want to play soccer (さか). Soccer is surprisingly slope-intensive, actually.

mnemonics.meaning: In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cage</mark> there are some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">legs</mark>. They are the legs attached to a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">small animal</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You look up through the cloth, and see a hairless cat. This small animal is hairless, but most surprisingly is covered in hickies (ひき).

mnemonics.meaning: When you see the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spring</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> you know it's finally the  <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">spring</mark> season.
mnemonics.reading: When the spring season comes around, it makes you want to laugh: "HAR (はる) HAR HAR!" you yell.

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> has <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">easy</mark> access to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sunshine</mark>. The <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sunlight</mark> shines right in, because it's a clear building.
mnemonics.reading: The sunshine gets into the building so easily, in fact, that it hits your yogurt (よう). The sunshine makes the yogurt... gross.

mnemonics.meaning: There <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">go</mark> some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">angel</mark>s with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark>s on their shoulders. Carrying drops like that requires <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">technique</mark>. It’s a real <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">art</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Angels are so good at this because they are trained in ninjutsu (じゅつ), or the "ninja techniques." Everyone knows that ninjas are great at carrying drops on the go!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">temple</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">temple</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Brilliant.
mnemonics.reading: Someone died. You ask how this person died, the person who's getting buried by the temple. The priest/monk says it was in a tragic terror (てら) attack.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hits a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">valley</mark>, filling it up with water. Lucky for you, you're a giant, so you just lay down in the valley and use it to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bathe</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You know what would make the bathing experience even better? If you had some egg yolks (よく) to eat. Just crack those yolks into the water you bathe in, and it'll cook to perfection. Yum!

mnemonics.meaning: With the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> from that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>, your trained <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark> can tell it'll make an excellent <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">box</mark>. Boxes made from bamboo trees are very sturdy and fashionable. You have an eye for fashion as well, you see.
mnemonics.reading: Now you can use that box to store all your hardcore (はこ) punk vinyl records. You're a real connoisseur, so you know that hardcore music should only ever be kept in bamboo boxes.

mnemonics.meaning: A psychic <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> kneels to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>, picks up a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark>, and instantly makes a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">connection</mark> with the person that it came from. This leader is very powerful, so even a thread is enough for them to make a psychic connection with the person who was wearing it.
mnemonics.reading: As you develop this psychic connection with the owner of the thread, you can tell that they're currently eating a cake (けい).

mnemonics.meaning: After a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark>, use this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">machine</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cure</mark> the people and the country from the damage. <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Heal</mark>ing machines are all over Japan just in case a tsunami does way more damage than they can handle.
mnemonics.reading: Alternative ways to cure yourself after a tsunami are either praying to Jesus (じ) or eating your weight in cheese (ち). I'm not sure if I have enough cheese for all the people that got hit though... Hmm, do you have cheese?

mnemonics.meaning: There is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark> surrounded by <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">snake</mark>s. Now that's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dangerous</mark> place. If you try to escape the prison you either fall to your death off the cliff or get bitten/squeezed to death by the snakes. Can you think of anything more dangerous than this? I can't.
mnemonics.reading: Lucky for you, even though you're stuck in this dangerous place, there is hope. There is a key (き). All dangerous prisons have a key. You just have to find and steal it so you can avoid the cliffs and snakes!

mnemonics.meaning: When the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> gets in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark>, I <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dare</mark> you to stare at it. I dare you to look right at the sun. I dare you.
mnemonics.reading: After you’ve blinded yourself from the dare of looking at the sun and losing sight in each eye, the guy dares you to go bowling (ぼう). You’re blind now, so bowling will be quite the challenge.

mnemonics.meaning: A group of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark> guys are in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark>. You must <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">detain</mark> them at once! Private sword guys are people who work for private companies and use their swords on people. They're basically paid assassins. And you're going to detain them!
mnemonics.reading: You're running out of steam and you're afraid you might not be able to detain all of these guys when Ryu (りゅう) from Street Fighter appears. He hates swords, and will only use fists because it's the honorable way to fight, so he starts helping you detain them!

mnemonics.meaning: If you listened in to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> lives of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">twenty</mark> people, all of them would have different <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dialect</mark>s and ways of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">speech</mark>. Whether they actually use these dialects with you is another story. But when they're alone, or with other people who are from the same place, their speech will be different.
mnemonics.reading: The best way to learn someone's dialect is to buy them a bento (べん) from where they're from. Not only do these bento have writing in their dialect on them, but their speech will immediately shift to match. Then you'll be able to hear how they sound in their head and in private!

mnemonics.meaning: What I <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark> 100%! You may use it as <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">evidence</mark> in this murder case.
mnemonics.reading: The officials force you to present this evidence in front of the Shougun (しょう), himself. Your knees quake, you feel like you're gonna be sick, but you try to stand up tall and tell him everything. After all, you know your proof is correct, so you shouldn't be so scared.

mnemonics.meaning: If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">narwhal</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stick</mark>s a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark> with its horn then you have to admit that it <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">exist</mark>s. We know some of you have been doubting narwhals and whether they're real. Well now your kid is a kabob, so do you believe they exist now? I <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">suppose</mark> you do.
mnemonics.reading: Oh, and the child we had to narwhal stab to prove they exist - that's your son (そん). Maybe you should have listened and kept your son out of the Narwhal Danger Zone (ぞん) after we warned you about it.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">face</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">face</mark> kanji are the same! But this isn't just a face like the one you're looking at your computer/phone with. It's the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">surface</mark> kind of face too!
mnemonics.reading: This face you're looking at, that has a lot of surface area, belongs to men (めん). Not a single man, but all men put together. It's hundreds of thousands of men's faces in a row.

mnemonics.meaning: You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">zombie</mark> on it, going really <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">far</mark> away. Someone tied that zombie to the scooter and now it's far off in the distance, groaning and growling.
mnemonics.reading: The zombie goes so far, that its life ends (えん). Zombies need to eat to live (it's really all they need), but they go so far on their scooter trip, that they just give up and end it all.

mnemonics.meaning: You examine the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">zombie</mark> and find a small <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">garden</mark> in there. There are even benches... it looks like a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">park</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You look closer at the garden and suddenly everything ends (えん).

mnemonics.meaning: The radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gate</mark> and the kanji for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gates</mark> are the same!
mnemonics.reading: You want to pass through this gate but it’s guarded by… a monster (もん)!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">attach</mark>ing your entire country is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">government</mark>. They loom over you all and try to keep you all organized and together under their control.
mnemonics.reading: Try to get out from under this government canopy and you'll be labeled a fool (ふ). Unless... you can fool them!

mnemonics.meaning: Put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> on something <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spicy</mark> and you'll cook up pure <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">happiness</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Out of spicy foods you made pure happiness. You give it to your sad friend こういち, who waits at the table.

mnemonics.meaning: If there's something about a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> that people are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">anti</mark> towards, it's usually the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">heights</mark> aspect. Another thing would be if it's on a big <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">slope</mark>. No one likes that kind of building.
mnemonics.reading: Another person you know who's afraid of heights is Han (はん) Solo. Now wait, you protest, he flies a space ship! You're right, but only because he doesn't like to walk all the way up high buildings, it freaks him out. He flies up instead so he doesn't have to think about heights.

mnemonics.meaning: In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> where you once kept <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark>, you find a beating <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>. You don't understand how it's still going, but you know you need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hurry</mark> up and do something, or it might stop all of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sudden</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You start to overheat as you hurry around, so you grab a cucumber (きゅう) to cool you down. The high water content re-hydrates you and lets you continue hurrying to help save this heart.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Bamboo</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heaven</mark> is a place for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">laugh</mark>ing. Bamboo is a very jolly plant, and they love to laugh. Even after death in bamboo heaven, the bamboo continue to laugh joyfully. Bamboo heaven is truly a place of laughter.
mnemonics.reading: There’s actually a war a goin’ on up in that there bamboo heaven, y’know? Ye might not have heard of it with all that there laughin’ a goin’ on, but there definitely be a war a (わら) goin’ on up in bamboo heaven, y’hear? The bamboo are scared so that’s why they be laughin’ so much. They nervous.

mnemonics.meaning: You offer <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> to your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> and compliment them on their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lip ring</mark>. You think that by doing this they might carry your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">luggage</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Unconvinced by your flattery, the leader refuses to carry your luggage, so you get on your knees (に) and beg them to carry it.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hat</mark> comes to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stop</mark>, thinking of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">plan</mark>. The hat had been pacing around for a while, trying to think of how to get off the head he's resting upon and back into the house where it's nice and cozy, and came to the sudden realization of a plan. This caused the hat to stop.
mnemonics.reading: The plan that made this hat stop right in its tracks was very simple. First, obtain the key (き) to the house. Then, use the key to get in the front door. How simple!

mnemonics.meaning: It's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> to focus on <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">politics</mark> and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">government</mark>. Elections are happening, in the new year politicians are being sworn in. Winter is government time!
mnemonics.reading: Everyone involved in politics and government wields a special saber (せい). If two political parties are arguing, they'll whip out their sabers and start slashing away!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">products</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">product</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Productive!
mnemonics.reading: As you try to sell these products, you finally get a buyer. It's a Hindu (ひん) person. She walks in and buys your products on the spot!

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> needs <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark>s done every year to make sure it will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">protect</mark> you properly.
mnemonics.reading: If the measurements are off, and your roof doesn't protect you, then you get to sue (す)! If you're still alive, that is.

mnemonics.meaning: When your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tongue</mark> becomes too <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spicy</mark> for you to bear, it’s time to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">quit</mark> the jalapeño eating contest. You’ve been eating them for three hours now and the spiciness from the peppers is really burning your tongue. Throw in the towel, it’s time to quit the contest.
mnemonics.reading: Oh, you're probably wondering who won that spicy food contest after you quit and became obsessed with words instead. It was Jesus (じ). Who did you expect? He was great with words AND never quitting when things got spicy.

mnemonics.meaning: If the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pope</mark> stays fixated on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>, staring at <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark>, he's going to lose touch with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">reality</mark>. He should be focusing on his popish duties, but instead he's looking at the fish fins he dropped, and now can't eat because they're dirty. Silly pope. You can't let this one thing get you down. You have other things to do.
mnemonics.reading: You're doing your best to bring the pope back to reality when he snaps and kicks you in the shin (しん). Oww! What the heck, pope! But he's already back staring at the fins and your shin is throbbing where he kicked it.

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gate</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> will take you to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heaven</mark>. These horns are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">related</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">connected</mark> to heaven in some way.
mnemonics.reading: They are related and connected to heaven because these are the horns that Genghis Khan (かん) made from his enemies. God said he could come into heaven if he made a gate of horns, so that's what he did.

mnemonics.meaning: Going into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> made by a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">squid</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">risky</mark>. First of all, squids only have tentacles, no bones, and they make all of their buildings out of risky materials like kelp and sharp coral.
mnemonics.reading: "It's too risky, leave me!" the squid cries. "I'll save you, underwater citizen! Nothing is too risky for Ken (けん) the samurai!" The building is collapsing on the squid, the risk is so great, but Ken the samurai dives in and saves him!

mnemonics.meaning: If you play <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">music</mark> with your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark>, one <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rule</mark> is that you must be a fish. You can’t play music using fish fins that don’t belong to you. That’s the rule. And it’s also rude.
mnemonics.reading: There’s also a rule in place to limit the amount of fish fin musicians. No more than ten (てん) are allowed to gather and play their music together. That’s the rule. No more than ten.

mnemonics.meaning: Sticking a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> to get its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark>s is your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">specialty</mark>. Most people get really confused when they have to measure their rice paddies, but that's where you come in. You plant a cross right in the middle, look down it from one end to the other, and voila! You know the measurements immediately. That's why it's your specialty!
mnemonics.reading: Hearing of your amazing specialty and cross measurement abilities, a centaur (せん) from a far off land recruits you for a job. The centaur’s father has just passed away and the centaur wants you to measure the rice paddies that have been left to him.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">table</mark> is completely <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">superfluous</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The only person you know with a superfluous forehead table is Joe (じょう), the ten foot tall, simple farmhand.

mnemonics.meaning: When the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> is out, you can see two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark>s and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> playing together, but only on a certain <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">weekday</mark>. Which <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">day of the week</mark> is it? I'll never tell you. It could be Sunday. It could be Monday. It could be any day of the week.
mnemonics.reading: Now that you know how to figure out what day of the week it is, you can start making yogurt (よう). It can take up to 24 hours to make yogurt. Knowing which weekday it is at any given moment means you can perfect your yogurt-making schedule.

mnemonics.meaning: Why would you try to take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">brush</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>? It's almost too obvious, because you want to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">write</mark> something down.
mnemonics.reading: What did you write about? You were writing about this amazing circus show (しょ) you just watched on the sun. You didn't expect there to be any shows here, but turns out you were wrong!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark>, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">absolutely</mark>. The mighty sun is never wrong. It is absolutely correct, always.
mnemonics.reading: Then, a zeppelin (ぜ) flies in front of the sun, blocking it out. Absolutely, the sun cannot ignore this transgression. Therefore, the sun corrects the zeppelin’s evil ways by frying it with sunshine and bringing it to the ground.

mnemonics.meaning: You use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">good luck</mark> by <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bind</mark>ing two fingers together. You <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tie</mark> them nice and tight.
mnemonics.reading: After you bind your fingers, the good luck starts pouring in. Literally. Suddenly ketsup (けつ) starts pouring down from the heavens.

mnemonics.meaning: Under a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clan</mark> digs in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>, trying to get to the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bottom</mark>. They want to build a nice home your entire clan can live in, but they need to get to the bottom before they'll start building.
mnemonics.reading: Suddenly someone down in the hole shouts that they've reached the bottom, but it's full of water and they're all soaked (そこ)!

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> is so <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> that it's the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cause</mark> of all your problems.
mnemonics.reading: Your big mouth is the cause behind all your friends and family moving to an inn (いん). They move to the inn so they don't have to live with you and hear you talk anymore.

mnemonics.meaning: They <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sheep</mark> are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">detailed</mark> creatures. I mean, I never thought sheep were very detailed, but that’s what they say.
mnemonics.reading: The reason these sheep are so detailed is that they are trying to impress the Shougun (しょう). If they're fancy enough, perhaps the Shougun won’t kill them for their meat and make their wool into clothing.

mnemonics.meaning: If you can <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> what <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sound</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> makes, you must be very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">discerning</mark>. Few people are able to discern what sound a drunkard makes, but you — you can say, because you're a very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">discriminating</mark> listener.
mnemonics.reading: Discerning individuals like you are considered chic (しき). What's more chic than your discriminating way of listening?

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tiger</mark> kills a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pig</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> in this new <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">drama</mark> about the animal kingdom! The tiger and pig used to be friends when they were younger, but now they're bitter enemies and the tiger just stabbed the pig right in the chest with a knife.
mnemonics.reading: This drama is being put on by Gecki (げき), your childhood pet gecko. Gecki is playing all the parts, because as true drama fans know, one-gecko-shows are the highest form of art.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dry</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: You need to dry Genghis Khan (かん). He hates being wet, all of the Mongols do, so your job is to dry his entire body. And his clothes, and his horse. In fact, when it rains, you have to ride next to him keeping him dry by holding an umbrella above his head.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> that can't live through <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">failure</mark>. Any proper shellfish would survive through the winter, so this is quite an embarrassing <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">defeat</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The best way to avoid failure is to say a little haiku (はい) to distract you from the cold. In fact, this can work in any situation where you're afraid of defeat. Say a haiku aloud, it will calm your nerves and warm you from the inside.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> is coming, and you want to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">walk</mark> over it, so you have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ford</mark> it. You don’t walk across a tsunami, you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wade</mark> across it.
mnemonics.reading: Your ability to ford this tsunami impresses everyone who witnesses it, especially the Shougun (しょう). Now that you've taught him a tsunami can be forded, he's going to start sending his troops through them instead of waiting for them to pass.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fruit</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fruit</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Bodacious!
mnemonics.reading: They sell fruit at the store, and you need to drive your car (か) to get there. A car is the fastest way to fruit.

mnemonics.meaning: Under this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bear</mark> who works for the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">government</mark>. If you saw a bear out in the wild you might be afraid and try to run, but if you see a bear inside a building under a roof, don't be scared! It's just a government bear.
mnemonics.reading: The first government that allowed bears was set up by Genghis Khan (かん). He was all about conquering people and then using them as efficiently as possible. He discovered that bears are incredibly useful in government buildings as government workers.

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> is for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">someone</mark> who works in a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">government office</mark>. You'll also take someone from a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">political office</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Government office and political office people put on the best shows (しょ). That's why you want to capture someone from there with your net.

mnemonics.meaning: If you're on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">festival</mark> you'll have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">guess</mark> what's actually going on below you. You can kind of see that there are rides and maybe food? It smells like food. But you have to guess on the specifics because you're above it and not in it.
mnemonics.reading: To get a better guess, you ask Satsuki (さつ) for help. She's that little girl you know from some earlier mnemonics, and she happens to be up on the roof with you. Picture her as you ask, "What's your guess, Satsuki?"

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Viking</mark> will empty his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> of all its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> in the great <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hall</mark>. They all get together in some kind of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">public chamber</mark> and dish all the dirt (literal and figurative) that they've got.
mnemonics.reading: While the Vikings gather to spill the dirt in their hall, they also stuff their faces with doughnuts (どう). Ah yes, Vikings love to eat doughnuts when they talk trash.

mnemonics.meaning: You hide <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poop</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cape</mark> as part of the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">illusion</mark> in your magic show. Your acts are kind of gross and this one involves creating the illusion of disappearing poop by hiding it within the folds of your cape.
mnemonics.reading: Somehow the poop cape illusion goes over really well. The crowd is giving you a standing ovation and right in the center is Genji (げん). He marches up to you, wipes a tear from his eye, and says, "Your illusion cape is wonderful. I must have it!"

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">criminal</mark> has done an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">injustice</mark> on the world or other people. Being a criminal is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">negative</mark> thing, and even if it was just a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mistake</mark>, it was still a crime.
mnemonics.reading: When you commit an injustice, you'll know because heat (ひ) fills your body. Maybe you've never done any kind of big thing, but when you make a mistake your face fills with heat and you turn red!
