mnemonics.meaning: Put on <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cleat</mark>s so you can plant a kiss on your sweetheart's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> — that's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">love</mark>. You'll be braving the harsh winter elements for love, so you put on your cleats to get a better grip on the snow. Sure, you could just wait for better weather to go see them, but then it wouldn't be true love, would it?
mnemonics.reading: Walking through the winter snow with your cleats on, you've gotta keep your eye (あい) on the prize. It's a really hard journey, but you keep your eye on the prize, which is your love and the time you'll get to spend with them.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Flowers</mark> can be used for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">comfort</mark>, but also for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">medicine</mark>. Sure, it’s a comfort to smell flowers because they smell nice, but one can also use them as medicine to heal people.
mnemonics.reading: The best way to transport all the medicine on land is with a yak (やく). Yaks are big, strong, and very capable of transporting flower medicine like these.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Viking</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">see</mark>, Viking <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">memorize</mark>. That’s how Vikings learn things. They see something, and then they memorize it. Quite simple, really.
mnemonics.reading: Every morning, a cock (かく) crows and rouses the Vikings. Seeing this, one of the Vikings memorizes the cock crow so that he can mimic it and play pranks on his fellow Vikings.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">viking</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> is a totally <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">normal</mark> thing. It's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ordinary</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: It's normal for a viking to have a mouth towel, but your sloppy farmhand friend Joe(じょう) has a mouth towel too. That's a habit that's only normal for vikings, so why does he have one?

mnemonics.meaning: You're all by your lonesome <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">self</mark> and have to check each <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> you own, all <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">twenty</mark> of them! Luckily, you have a very astute <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">nose</mark>, allowing you to quickly assess the state of your twenty rice paddies all by yourself.
mnemonics.reading: As you're about to finish checking your paddies, your nose picks up an additional smell: It's Hannah, bringing you a bunch of 花 (はな)!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nothing</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">nothing</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Woah!
mnemonics.reading: Nothing can moo (む) quite like a cow can moo. Cows are the best at going moo. That’s a fact.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">original</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">original</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: The original Japanese hero was Genji (げん), from "The Tale of Genji."

mnemonics.meaning: If there is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drum</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> it's time to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rejoice</mark>! And because of your mouth drum your rejoicing will be loud and booming!
mnemonics.reading: You loudly rejoice for a while when suddenly someone runs over and shoves a key (き) in your mouth, locking it shut. You can't rejoice anymore! You need that key to unlock your mouth!

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Again</mark> and again, your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> comes back to the same person. Is this <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">romance</mark>? Are you in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">love</mark>?
mnemonics.reading: But, remember that your romance isn’t a rental (れん). You really wanna reserve it for the right person!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">criminal</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> will always be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sad</mark>. No one chooses a life of crime if they're happy. And even if they seem like they're doing fine on the outside, deep down they're really sad.
mnemonics.reading: The sad feelings fill the criminal's body with heat (ひ). This heat spreads and radiates out. If you walk next to them on the street, you'll feel the sad heat floating by you.

mnemonics.meaning: In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>, there's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark>. Its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> points toward a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">plate</mark>. What's on the plate? Why, it's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">salt</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: When you see the salt, you think to yourself, "She owes (しお) me big time, so I'm going to go ahead and snatch her salt!" Who is she, you ask? She's the lady who owns the salt. And the gun in the dirt, of course.

mnemonics.meaning: In a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yurt</mark> you use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> as a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">seat</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Something about using a towel for a seat is very sexy (せき) to you. Probably because you associate it with sexy people using towel seats on the beach.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> in its <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">side</mark>. It's fine though, don't worry, it's just a reminder that he won the great shellfish war back when they were trying to choose the new leader.
mnemonics.reading: Because of this knife in his side, he can't pronounce certain words correctly. The most obvious one is when he says 川 (かわ), but it comes out of the side of his mouth as がわ.

mnemonics.meaning: When you swing your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark>, the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> ends up covered in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark>, because you're a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">soldier</mark>. Only a skilled axe soldier could make such precise cuts as to de-fin a bunch of fish like that.
mnemonics.reading: Uh-oh, it looks like this axe soldier was so excited about chopping the fins off his fish that he didn't think about how he was going to cook them. The only thing nearby to light on fire is a bale of hay (へい). Well, it's not the best thing, but at least it will get these fish cooked.

mnemonics.meaning: What do you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">guard</mark>? Your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">theory</mark> about how the thing he's guarding isn't even real. Yeah, you have this whole thing figured out. You have for a while. At this point, it's only fair that you tell your theory to the guard who's wasting his time.
mnemonics.reading: The guard listens to your theory but then he says his OWN! He thinks there are two sets (せつ) of guarded items, and he's only guarding one. According to his theory, either one could be real! His theory is more plausible, don't you think?

mnemonics.meaning: If you take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> and plant a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> on it, the rice paddy is going to be extremely <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">thin</mark>, but also <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">detailed</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: This thin rice paddy is for your cyborg (さい). You gave your cyborg a very thin human stomach, so it can only digest one thin line of rice at a time.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> you aim your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark> at from your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">window</mark> is an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ume</mark>, aka a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Japanese plum</mark>. Why? Because shooting the ume out of Japanese plum trees is, in your opinion, the best way to harvest plums.
mnemonics.reading: You've probably heard of ume before, depending on your exposure to Japan, but an ume (うめ) is a Japanese plum.

mnemonics.meaning: You have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poem</mark> about <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> that you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">warn</mark> people against going outside. It's cold and dangerous in winter! You <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">admonish</mark> anyone and everyone you see going out there with your scary winter poem.
mnemonics.reading: To make sure people listen to your warning, you threaten to take away their cake (けい). People will do anything for cake, so when you bring it up, they actually take your attempts to warn them about winter seriously.

mnemonics.meaning: Saying you're going to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> out of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> is just another way of saying you're going to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">announce</mark> something. All that information is the dirt, and to announce that dirt you just slide it on out of your mouth. How's that for a visual?
mnemonics.reading: Now that you're about to announce something important, you should maybe get it nice and smooth in your mouth so the dirt can slide out easier. So take a big gulp of Coke (こく). Coke is just like, the dirt of soda anyway, you know?

mnemonics.meaning: You ride your scooter through the dirt while carrying a sheep because you're determined to attain something. Greatness? Glory? Everlasting fame? Maybe you'll attain a plural combination of all those things. After all, you are the best sheep-carrying off-road scooterist the world has ever seen.
mnemonics.reading: After you attain that plural combination of glory, greatness, and fame, you get a tattoo (たつ) to celebrate: "world's greatest," in gothic lettering, above a picture of you and your sheep on your scooter.

mnemonics.meaning: In a dangerous <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gambler</mark> will always try to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bake</mark> something before fleeing to safety. It could be his own house on fire, and the gambler would still use the free heat source to get some baking done. Maybe he's gambling that those baked goods will offset the cost of a new home…
mnemonics.reading: He used to bake for the Yankees (や). Baseball cakes, bat baguettes, that kind of thing. A career-ending kitchen injury forced him to retire. That's when he developed a gambling problem. But he still likes to bake whenever the Yankees are on TV.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> from <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">long ago</mark> thought to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">borrow</mark> something precious from you. This leader did not return the thing he borrowed, and now he will pay.
mnemonics.reading: In your rage, you decide to find this leader, take back what's yours, and in return, borrow the leader's life. So you found him, grabbed him, and threw him into a shack (しゃく) — where you "borrow" a few parts of the leader himself, and do other terrible things to him.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bow</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bow</mark> kanji are exactly the same!
mnemonics.reading: You have a bow in one hand and in the other... a cucumber (きゅう). You're going to shoot this cucumber with this bow into the salad you're making. Many people don't know this, but this makes your cucumbers taste better.

mnemonics.meaning: Nestled in the light of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grass</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure chest</mark> that you can see with your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">brain</mark>. You close your eyes, and you can see the spot, but it's kept deep in your brain, and you have to use its power to find it.
mnemonics.reading: If you can unlock the secrets of your brain you'll have powers like Nostradamus (のう). Nostradamus was able to look inward at his own hidden brain treasure chest and see the future, so maybe you can be like him too.

mnemonics.meaning: What do you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eat</mark> like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">machine</mark>? <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Candy</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: This candy in particular is just drops of hardened, clear sugar that looks like 雨 (あめ) drops.

mnemonics.meaning: In a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark>, there lies a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure chest</mark> containing a golden <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chest</mark> piece. This mighty chest armor will grant you protection from nearly any attack, because it is imbued with moon magic.
mnemonics.reading: Where is this chest armor from? It's from the moon. Now how would you say that if you were Canadian? It's from the moon, eh (むね). Right, this here chest armor is from the moon, eh.

mnemonics.meaning: You've got a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark>, and some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> lying around. So of course you decide to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">connect</mark> them all together.
mnemonics.reading: There's only one reason you've connected all this together: Tuna (つな) fishing. Obviously!

mnemonics.meaning: In your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> you put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark> on the line by putting in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark> that is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark>. You put it all the way down there, so you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">consume</mark> it.
mnemonics.reading: The "consume a sword" illusion came with a cheap magic kit (きつ) you had.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">temple</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">equal</mark> to all of the other non-bamboo temples. Just because it's made of bamboo doesn't make it any less special and spiritual.
mnemonics.reading: The bamboo temple is also an equal distance away from the other temples in とうきょう. When you look at a map of とうきょう temples, you can measure them out and they'll all be perfectly equal.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> that's been sliced up in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> can be used as a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">flat object counter</mark>. Since it's winter, all the leaves have fallen off the tree, so it's easy to cut into slats. These slats can be used as counters for flat objects.
mnemonics.reading: As you count each counter for flat objects, a bunch of mice (まい) show up and start climbing all over you. This won't do, so you take two slats and start smashing and flattening all the mice. Now that the mice are flat too, you can also use them as a counter for flat objects. Good job, mice.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">death</mark> of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> will cause you to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">forget</mark> all of the most important things. People think memories are kept in your brain, but that's not true. Your heart is where all of your most precious memories are kept, and when it dies, you forget them all.
mnemonics.reading: When someone forgets everything they're left with only one thing to do: go bowling (ぼう). Bowling is easy, and there's nothing to forget. You pick up a ball. You drop it. Everything else is automatically taken care of.

mnemonics.meaning: Using <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> to make a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lip ring</mark> is always going to end in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">frustration</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: After some frustration, you made your flower lip ring. Now you look like an Egyptian (いじ) pharaoh. Because all ancient Egyptian monarchs wore flower lip rings (historical fact)!

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> stuff to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">river</mark>, giving it <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">instruction</mark>. This river is a new river so it needs you to say things, giving it instruction on what to do. Otherwise the river wouldn’t know how to behave.
mnemonics.reading: While giving instruction to the river, you see a small boat coming down it. Inside the miniature boat is a raccoon (くん) captain and his raccoon crew. The raccoon captain is instructing them, “Stroke! Stroke!”

mnemonics.meaning: If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark> seems extra <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heavy</mark>, you know it's a different <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">kind</mark>. Not all <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">type</mark>s of grains are the same. So when you feel the heavy type, you know it isn't the same as the light kind.
mnemonics.reading: You sort all of the different kinds and types by putting them in the right chutes (しゅ). They slide away, probably to some big type-based piles you can't see.

mnemonics.meaning: You want to share <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">happiness</mark> with people so you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stamp</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>s with the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">news</mark>. Now when people want a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">report</mark> of all the happy things going on, they can just look down before they sit.
mnemonics.reading: You research and report the news from home (ほう). Only after, once all of the news is stamped onto the stools, do you leave your home.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">paragraph</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">paragraph</mark> kanji are exactly the same!
mnemonics.reading: You have to write an entire paragraph about a topic, so you choose cookies (く).

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Say</mark> it at <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">noon</mark>. That's the only time I will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">allow</mark> you to say it. That's the only time I will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">permit</mark> you to say it. Other than that, no saying anything. Noon is your window.
mnemonics.reading: Where do these archaic horrible rules exist? The smaller version of Kyoto, Little Kyoto (きょ). Normal Kyoto is just fine. This smaller one is where a group of people went to create their own little town with their own dumb rules.

mnemonics.meaning: With a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lip ring</mark>, anything is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">possible</mark>. Having a lip ring grants you the power to conquer any obstacle, achieve any goal. As long as it's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">passable</mark> lip ring, that is. If it isn't good enough, it isn't possible to be passable.
mnemonics.reading: Since anything and everything is possible with your new passable lip ring, you use it to get a new car (か). You go to the car dealership and ask for a free (passable) car. The manager is impressed with your lip ring and gladly hands over the keys to the latest model of your favorite car. Not bad.

mnemonics.meaning: A religious <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> wearing a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mask</mark> could be either a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">monk</mark> or a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">priest</mark>. You don’t know, their face is covered by a mask!
mnemonics.reading: This monk or priest is wearing a mask to protect their soul (そう). You aren't a monk or a priest, so they don't want your not-religious-enough eyes to dirty their soul.

mnemonics.meaning: Killing two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>s with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark> is expressly <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">prohibit</mark>ed. Don't get me wrong, you can rip up one tree with your jackhammer, but not two.
mnemonics.reading: The person who decided to prohibit jackhammering two trees is the King (きん) of England. He's the only person who's able to prohibit certain things, so it had to be him.

mnemonics.meaning: Within the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blue</mark> water, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">conflict</mark> stirs, but is made <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">quiet</mark> by the muffling power of liquid. Under this blue water is a great conflict between two sea monsters, but on the surface it appears peaceful and quiet as the water prevents sound from rising above the surface.
mnemonics.reading: As you watch below the quiet water, every once in a while a saber (せい) breaches the surface and quietly slices back down.

mnemonics.meaning: Under a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark>, there are two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">person</mark>s on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>. What do they do there? They <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sit</mark>. The people use the dirt under the canopy as a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">seat</mark> for their butts.
mnemonics.reading: Who decided people have to sit like this? The Czar (ざ). The Czar wants to be above everyone, so he makes them sit on the dirt under canopies while he goes around on horseback or something, towering over them as they sit.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">helicopter</mark> hovering beside it, there's going to be a lot of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">smoke</mark> billowing around. Mostly smoke, on account of the fire. Now it's in your eyes and mouth. It gets in your lungs and you can't breathe. Why, helicopter, why!
mnemonics.reading: The smoke is too much and you realize this is the end (えん) for you. You're gonna die here!

mnemonics.meaning: The water from a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> can create a lot of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">energy</mark> when made into <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">steam</mark>. Steam power used to be all the rage back in the day. Steam comes from water, water comes from tsunamis, so logically, tsunamis are a great source of energy.
mnemonics.reading: In order to contain this steam energy and store it for later, you lock it up in a box with a key (き). That way the energy can be used at a later time. Provided you don’t lose the key, that is.

mnemonics.meaning: On your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stamp</mark> that you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tap</mark>, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">strike</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">slap</mark> to create a beat! The stamp looks like a little drum, but you're really just hitting your mouth for fun (the stamp was an excuse to make it seem normal).
mnemonics.reading: When you tap and strike the stamp on your mouth, you make a ta-ta (たた) sound. Imagine yourself making a beat with the little stamp drum on your mouth. Now listen... たた! There! Did you hear it?

mnemonics.meaning: Into your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> shot an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark> with an attached <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hook</mark> so that they'd be able to see into your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">throat</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: From your throat you hear a voice. Not yours, but one you recognize. It's こういち! What's that rascal doing down in your throat?

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> you feed to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark> can be of any <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">type</mark>, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">kind</mark>, or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">category</mark>. It doesn't matter what kind of rice it is, the big geoduck will eat it.
mnemonics.reading: While eating every type and kind of rice from every category, the big geoduck has become even bigger. Its body is ruined (るい). It's painfully obese. This geoduck has eaten itself to ruin.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">previous</mark>ly gave everything in this town a good <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wash</mark>. There are many laundromats in this town, so when the previous tsunami hit, all of the detergent mixed with the water and gave everything a good wash.
mnemonics.reading: It wasn't just the town that got a wash, it was the centaurs (せん) too. (Centaurs happen to live in this town.) And being half horse, centaurs have a lot of hair that needs washing. Luckily, the soap tsunami gave them a good wash too.

mnemonics.meaning: You want your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> to be <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">simple</mark> so you practice <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Zen Buddhism</mark>. Zen is all about meditating and letting earthly things go. There's nothing more simple for your spirit than being <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Zen</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this kanji is Zen (ぜん), just like the Zen in Zen Buddhism. Pretty easy to remember, no? Just remember that the reading is the same as the meaning. It’s easy!

mnemonics.meaning: If you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark> around the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">temple</mark>, it's likely you'll <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">acquire</mark> something. When you loiter around like that it looks like you're waiting for something, so if someone puts something in your hands and you just happen to acquire it, well, no one can fault you for that.
mnemonics.reading: You managed to acquire some tobacco, but just as you're about to leave Tokugawa (とく) Ieyasu comes marching up to you!! Or at least, his ghost does. He stares you dead in the eyes and says, "I didn't found the shogunate for you to acquire illegal goods and kill your body toking on my soil."

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> lets you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">add</mark> words together to form a sentence. Marvel at the mighty additive power your mouth holds! You add words together in an amazing fashion!
mnemonics.reading: Your parents are so proud of you being able to add words together that they surprise you with a new car (か). Wow! You add some stickers to your bumper and add your favorite playlist to the car radio. Let's drive.

mnemonics.meaning: You use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bookshelf</mark> as a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">book counter</mark>. Duh. What, are you gonna count them one by one? Okay, well maybe, but you should count them while they're nice and organized on the shelves. Otherwise counting is going to be a huge pain.
mnemonics.reading: You use this book counter method to count all the books Satsuki (さつ) has in her house. Remember her? She's got, like, a ton of books, but she's just a little girl so she needs some help. That's where your book counter know-how comes in handy.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> next to your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">village</mark> is where you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bury</mark> the dead. People don't live forever, so every village has a patch of dirt specifically used for burying dead things.
mnemonics.reading: You don't just bury dead relatives here. You also buried your dead pet uni (う) in that dirt. You thought having an uni as a pet would be a good idea. Too bad uni need water to survive.

mnemonics.meaning: You'll work your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">death</mark> if you're too <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">busy</mark>. Being busy just isn't good for your soul. Take breaks. Go on vacation. Don't be so busy that you destroy yourself.
mnemonics.reading: Take time out of your busy life and go bowling (ぼう) once in a while. In fact, you should probably go bowling once a week at least. Nothing brings energy back to your life like some relaxing bowling.

mnemonics.meaning: Passed out in front of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gate</mark> lies a former <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark>. He's now a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark>, but once ran a popular <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">clique</mark> called the Cool Kids <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Clan</mark>. The clan has fallen apart, and he no longer has a clique to call his own.
mnemonics.reading: Eventually you get sick and tired of this washed up clan leader and you gather your own clique to chase this guy away from your gate and your property. You and your friends grab some bats (ばつ) and use these bats to beat the drunkard leader. Being beaten with bats frightens him, and he scurries away.

mnemonics.meaning: To a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">narwhal</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> is just normal <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cloth</mark>. They're always wet so towel cloth is all they know.
mnemonics.reading: If you use this type of cloth for your clothes and blankets people will call you a fool (ふ). They think you're a fool who can't tell the difference between human cloth and towel cloth.

mnemonics.meaning: At the edge of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark>, two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>s mark the spot where you must <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stop</mark>, since any <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">continuation</mark> requires a way across. The trees seem long enough to reach to the other side, but how are you going to chop them down?
mnemonics.reading: Continuation is impossible unless you chop these trees down to make a bridge to the other side. You decide to use a wrecking (れき) ball. Luckily, there's one right by you. So you take the wrecking ball and knock the trees over, making a bridge with them.

mnemonics.meaning: You have to gather <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sell</mark> if you want to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">continue</mark> living. You want to make a living, don't you? Make sure you continue to sell that thread every single day!
mnemonics.reading: You have to continue to sell that thread because a Bosozoku (ぞく) bike gang is forcing you to do it. You see? If you want to continue to live, you have to appease this Bosozoku gang. You better keep selling!

mnemonics.meaning: There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> coming, but the escape <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> is being blocked by a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">creeper</mark>, and you can see your chances of escaping <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">decrease</mark> rapidly.
mnemonics.reading: This decrease in the chances of escaping the tsunami is really upsetting Genji (げん), who's waiting impatiently behind you.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">easy</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">easy</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: What would be an easy reading for this kanji? い! The sound easy starts with!

mnemonics.meaning: If you put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> in the middle of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kiss</mark>, you’re going to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">entangle</mark> it. Things can get pretty messy in a kiss, so adding a thread to the mix will definitely entangle it.
mnemonics.reading: This isn't going well, so you pull out the weird kiss thread and entangle it around a rack (らく). Good thing that rack was there! Much better to have it entangled around a rack when you're trying to kiss someone.

mnemonics.meaning: Within the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> grove, someone asks your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">reason</mark> for being there, and you explain it's to harvest bamboo to craft a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">flute</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You cut down the bamboo and whittle a flute. You start playing a song. You know the reason why. An alien spacecraft comes flying down and drops a box full of alien tech (てき) in front of you.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark>s in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">black hole</mark>. This flag marks (in the black hole) where you left your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">footwear</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You grab your footwear from the black hole. In your footwear (thanks to the shelter they provided), some reeds (り) have grown in!

mnemonics.meaning: If you put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> over a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">valley</mark> it will change its <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">form</mark>. Its <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">appearance</mark> will alter completely!
mnemonics.reading: Its new appearance looks familiar to you, like it's a big yogurt (よう) cup! A valley with a roof on it looks exactly like a yogurt cup. Huh!

mnemonics.meaning: Use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> to take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark> of this <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">group</mark>. Just stretch your mouth out and around every single person. Get 'em all in there.
mnemonics.reading: This group is so big it takes you till dawn (だん) to get your measurement: they weigh a ton (とん) too!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">history</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">history</mark> kanji are the same.
mnemonics.reading: History was full of famous sheep (し). Sure there are people and stuff, but historical sheep are where it's at. There's the famous sheep samurai, the death sheep who works for the yakuza, just tons!

mnemonics.meaning: If the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">compare</mark>d to an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">insect</mark>, you’ll see that they're both shiny, but that the sun is much shinier than the insect.
mnemonics.reading: While you’re holding up an insect to the sun for comparison, a flock of condors (こん) flies by, blocking out the sun. There are so many condors that they manage to totally block out the sun.

mnemonics.meaning: “Don’t <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark> – <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">run</mark>, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Junior</mark>!” said Indiana Jones Senior to Indiana Jones Junior. They’re escaping from a sticky situation and Junior was just loitering around like a fool. It’s no time to loiter, it’s time to run!
mnemonics.reading: Deciding not to loiter any longer, Indiana Jones Junior takes his dad’s advice and starts to run. Unfortunately he wasn’t paying attention to where his feet were and he stubbed his toe (と) on a jagged rock. His toe is in so much pain that he can’t bear to run any longer.

mnemonics.meaning: You jumped off your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> for some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">reason</mark> and now you're floating in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">midair</mark>! You kick your legs a bit and move your arms like you're in water, but you're still just stuck there in midair.
mnemonics.reading: As you spin a bit in midair you look up and see Chewbacca (ちゅう) looking down at you from a spaceship. He's laughing his Chewbacca laugh and you realize he has you trapped in his tractor beam.

mnemonics.meaning: A raging <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> rises next to the calm <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>. When you try to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">compare</mark> these two things, it's clear that they cannot <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mix</mark>. If a tsunami is coming, it will likely get in the way of the sun.
mnemonics.reading: Just before the tsunami crashes over you, a condor (こん) swoops out of the sky and grabs you up. This condor must be a mix — a normal condor is not strong enough to pick up a human. The condor must be mixed with something else. Like a pterodactyl.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sheep</mark> loses its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> so it picks them up in its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> to take them to someone who's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">morally good</mark> enough to attach them back onto its head. Sheep don’t have hands, so the sheep had to pick the horns up off the ground with his mouth. Someone evil would just murder the sheep and steal his horns, so the sheep must find someone <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">good</mark> to reaffix them.
mnemonics.reading: Since you are morally good, you decide not to murder the sheep and harvest its organs. Instead, as a practitioner of the good teachings of Zen (ぜん) Buddhism, you decided to help the sheep out. Your Zen teachings have increased the power of your healing abilities, so you fix the sheep up in no time.

mnemonics.meaning: When they migrate to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">river</mark>, a group of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoducks</mark> must do so in a certain <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">order</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sequence</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Actually, they go in birth-month order, starting from June (じゅん). No one knows why they follow this June-based sequence. But the geoducks born in June always go first in the migration order.

mnemonics.meaning: You use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> to keep yourself <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark> and safe from <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">outer space</mark>. Look outside, above your roof, and you'll see outer space stretching above you.
mnemonics.reading: Why isn't it dry in outer space, you ask? Because of all the uni (う) swimming around up there. They have nasty, wet, pointy spikes and they're all over the place.

mnemonics.meaning: What you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">director</mark> is judged immediately. You're having trouble understanding this <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">part of speech</mark>, so he's trying to help you. But you say it over and over and he keeps saying you're wrong.
mnemonics.reading: The director asks you again, "What is the part of speech for the word sheep (し)?"

mnemonics.meaning: If you see some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> that are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark>, pull them up and you'll find a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">potato</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Potatoes are totally emo (いも) because of the way they dry out flowers. Emo people and potatoes both like to dry out flowers.

mnemonics.meaning: It's important to focus <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">oneself</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> so that one can emerge <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">renew</mark>ed! You can't really go outside in winter without getting cold or sick, so spend winter focusing on YOU.
mnemonics.reading: Winter ends and, renewed, you come out ready to start a new hobby: kayaking (かい)! Nothing says renewal like a brand new kayak and sense of purpose in life.

mnemonics.meaning: If you stab somebody in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tongue</mark> with an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">umbrella</mark>, it’s sure to start a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">riot</mark> and cause <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">disorder</mark>. Nobody likes to get stabbed in the tongue with an umbrella, so they’re probably going to retaliate, and before you know it, you’ve a full scale riot on your hands. Look what you’ve done.
mnemonics.reading: Just now you realize that the man you stabbed in the tongue with your umbrella was none other than Macho Man Randy Savage (らん). Being a professional wrestler, Macho Man Randy Savage is ready to throw down at a moment’s notice. A riot immediately erupts. It’s a battle royal with you and Randy at the epicenter.

mnemonics.meaning: On the bottom of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">root</mark>s, there’s a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stamp</mark> that tells you the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">season</mark> in which it was cut.
mnemonics.reading: These season stamps are marked on bamboo sets (せつ). You can't buy a single banana or a single grape, and just like that, if you want some nice seasonal bamboo, you have to buy them in sets.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> and your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> is what you always <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">take along</mark> with you. Make sure they're <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">connect</mark>ed well so you don't lose them!
mnemonics.reading: You take along your scooter and your car. Anything else, you can do a rental (れん) for!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tongue</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tongue</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Yee-haw!
mnemonics.reading: You’re sound asleep in bed when your tongue drops out of your mouth and you start to drool, getting saliva all over the bed sheet (した). You wake up with a soggy patch of sheet near your mouth and wipe the drool off your face. Your significant other sees the whole thing.

mnemonics.meaning: When the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> gets <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">together</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark>, only <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">violence</mark> can ensue. They don’t mix well together. The sun loves to fight water and water loves to fight the sun. Lots and lots of violence.
mnemonics.reading: But after a while, the sun and the water have had enough of violence. They decide to settle their differences with a friendly game of bowling (ぼう). Bowling is a great way to relieve stress and in the end, they bond over it.

mnemonics.meaning: Give some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">talent</mark>ed person and they'll have no problem accumulating <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wealth</mark>. People with talent can make money out of pretty much anything, so shellfish are like easy-mode.
mnemonics.reading: This talented person really starts accumulating wealth when their cyborg (さい) is unveiled. It's a half-man, half-shellfish cyborg that plays the xylophone , and everyone wants to buy it.

mnemonics.meaning: There are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">right</mark> to show that you're still <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">young</mark>. Your body still works, you're happy, you have your entire life ahead of you! And everything smells like flowers.
mnemonics.reading: When young people look to the right, they'll see their future: a walker (わか). You know, those metal contraptions with tennis balls on the bottoms to make sure they don't scrape the floor. Everything may be flowers and happiness now, but your future is in a walker.

mnemonics.meaning: In <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">valley</mark>, spirits are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">abundant</mark>. Hence the name. Spirit valley has over two billion spirits floating in it.
mnemonics.reading: In spirit valley, it's not just spirits that are abundant. There is an abundance of youths (ゆう) as well.

mnemonics.meaning: You take some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark>s, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nine</mark> in total, and put them one by one up your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">butt</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Now that you have nine flags inside your butt, you have to get them out. But, you don't know how to. So you ask Siri (しり), "How do I get nine flags out of my butt?"

mnemonics.meaning: You take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark>. It is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">certain</mark> that you will damage it.
mnemonics.reading: You're killing this turkey, and you need to make sure he's dead for certain. The reason you need to make sure this turkey is dead is because of the cock (かく) in your life. Male chickens get really jealous when turkeys are around.

mnemonics.meaning: Under a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> sits with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">twenty</mark> little <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">contraptions</mark>. There's little electronic ones, little bopping ones, little walking ones... twenty of them.
mnemonics.reading: You want to know what these contraptions are for, so you ask. The drunkard says, "These are kayak (かい) contraptions *urp* they're for your uh *blarp* kayak... things."

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> loses its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">skin</mark> as a part of the damage it <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">incur</mark>s after death. That's why the spirit goes on looking for new skin to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cover</mark> itself with.
mnemonics.reading: When you incur the wrath of an angry spirit it'll try to cover itself with your skin, and you'll feel your skin heat (ひ) up.

mnemonics.meaning: In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">animal</mark> kingdom, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">snake</mark> is the most likely to commit a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">crime</mark>. Remember the Garden of Eden? The snake was the bad guy. Ever since then, snakes are the animal most known for committing crimes.
mnemonics.reading: This snake has evaded the law for too long. It’s time for a true hero to put an end to its crime spree. Enter Han (はん) Solo. Han Solo is the only man strong and brave enough to put an end to this snake and his crime filled ways.

mnemonics.meaning: You slip off the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark>, your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark> flashes before your eyes, and you smash your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> on the ground causing some serious <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">damage</mark>. Oof, this is a really bad <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">injury</mark>, you fell all the way off the roof and onto your mouth.
mnemonics.reading: As you try to assess the damage, you hear someone shout, "Guy (がい), hey, you okay, guy?" They run up to you, but your mouth is too damaged, you can't respond. "Okay guy, I'm gonna call you Guy now. Let's get you to the hospital."

mnemonics.meaning: What you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">righteousness</mark>, at least that's what you believe. You keep talking and saying these things, and you don't listen to anyone else's words. This is your style of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">deliberation</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">discussion</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: What are you in deliberation about? Whether or not to send some poor soul to the guillotine (ぎ). "I think he should go," you say. "I don't think he should," says another. This deliberation is going nowhere...

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Chinese</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">difficult</mark> to find because they are so rare. Chinese turkeys are the rarest variety of turkey, so naturally, finding one is exceedingly difficult.
mnemonics.reading: Do you know the actual reason Chinese turkey are so difficult to find? It’s because they’re all made out of Naan (なん). Of course they’re elusive when they blend in so well with all the other Naan!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flood</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark>! At the same time? This is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">disaster</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: This disaster was caused by your cyborg (さい)! It's malfunctioning, running around leaking large amounts of water and breathing fire. I guess you didn't work out all the kinks before you let it roam wild.

mnemonics.meaning: When a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> sees the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Mona Lisa</mark>, she feels a strong feeling of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dislike</mark>. All women dislike the Mona Lisa because of how much attention she gets.
mnemonics.reading: You dislike the Mona Lisa so much you hire Ken (けん) the samurai to cut her up.

mnemonics.meaning: If you put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> and try to eat it, you’re probably a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">distressed</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">troubled</mark> individual (unless you’re a woodchuck). You don’t need to eat this tree, you have plenty of food at home. Get your mouth off that tree you distressed child.
mnemonics.reading: You thought you were the most distressed and troubled person in this situation, but then you look up and see a very equally distressed and troubled condor (こん). The tree you've been mouthing is its home. And now you've slobbered all over it, ruining this condor's day.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> is upon your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">evening</mark>. These appear on your head at night whenever you are having a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dream</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You dream about cows saying "moo (む), moo, moo!"

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Rain</mark> causes a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">landslide</mark> that causes an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">earthquake</mark>!!! The earth doesn't just slide, it <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shake</mark>s and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">quake</mark>s.
mnemonics.reading: The earthquake shakes you so violently that you fall over, banging your shin (しん) on the coffee table. The edge of the coffee table is very sharp, so it cuts into your shin pretty badly.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">narwhal</mark> sticks a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stick</mark> into the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> to see what might <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">exist</mark> underneath it. Narwhals live in the sea, you see. So they're convinced nothing can exist anywhere else.
mnemonics.reading: The narwhal can't find anything but it can't stop thinking about what could exist outside of its world. It pulls out a xylophone (ざい) and starts tapping the keys with its horn. It plays a sad song about the meaning of life and whether existence is worth it.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fly</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fly</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Awesome!
mnemonics.reading: When you fly, you generate a lot of heat (ひ) because you’re moving so fast through the atmosphere. Normally this heat would be a nuisance, but you’re a superhero so it doesn’t bother you. This is actually the reason you’re able to fly – you’re a superhero and super resistant to heat.

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Cliff</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Life</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">give birth</mark> to a child. Oh no! You’re standing too close to the edge of the Cliff of Life! The baby falls off the cliff right after you give birth to it! In your despair, you throw all your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">property</mark> off the cliff too.
mnemonics.reading: You give birth, and now this happens. Such bad luck. But wait! What's that sound? Sleigh bells? Could it be?! It's Santa-san (さん)! He caught your baby! And all your property.

mnemonics.meaning: Put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> around a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">criminal</mark> to show their <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">guilt</mark>. Criminals look like anyone else on the street, so you decide to tie them in nets to make sure people know who they're dealing with.
mnemonics.reading: The guilt shows on the criminal's face. They smile, shrug, and pull a stolen xylophone (ざい) out of their back pocket.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> has grown <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">old</mark> from saying so many things. This is what makes them different from everyone else, they speak truly like an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">individual</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: As an individual, they must teach all the 子s (こ) their way. Their individual way.

mnemonics.meaning: Next to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>, you spot <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poop</mark>, not once but twice. Only a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> would be the type of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">person</mark> to not use the nearby <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">machine</mark> toilet. There's a perfectly good outhouse with a machine toilet right there, but this drunkard is so drunk that he decides to poop under the tree instead. And not only does he poop once, he poops twice.
mnemonics.reading: Oh, I see — the door to the outhouse with the machine toilet is locked, and the drunkard doesn't have the key (き). If he had a machine like a jackhammer, or a circular saw, or some other heavy duty machine, he might be able to get in without a key, but since he has none of those or a key, he's reduced to pooping under the tree instead.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone stabbed the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mole</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">overthrow</mark> it. Now there is a new mole leader. Because that's what happens when you overthrow someone—someone else needs to take over. In this case, a vengeful mole.
mnemonics.reading: Where do leaders get overthrown the most? In とうきょう. Just think back in Japanese history, back when everyone was at war with one another. People were taking over and getting overthrown and then that guy gets overthrown and then THAT guy gets overthrown. Basically, it used to be hard to stay a leader in とうきょう.

mnemonics.meaning: Tying a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tombstone</mark> each year will help you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">manage</mark> the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">passage of time</mark>. That way you’ll know how many years you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pass through</mark>, since you’ll have one thread for each year to count.
mnemonics.reading: Dealing with the passage of time can be tough, so after you tie the thread to the tombstone, each year you eat a piece of cake (けい). You already eat cake to mark the passage of time on your birthday, so why not here as well?

mnemonics.meaning: Sitting on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> of a toilet, you're praying your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poop</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">explosion</mark> will be flushed away, beseeching the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> decorating the bathroom wall. The poop needs to be one hundred <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">percent</mark> flushed away because you're on a date, and you don't want even one percent of your explosion left for them to see.
mnemonics.reading: It was extra important that there was zero percent poop left, because you're not on a date just anywhere, you're at the Ritz (りつ)!

mnemonics.meaning: Under any <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark>, there's some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> that's under a lot of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pressure</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You want to increase the pressure, so you stack on a second cliff. "Ah, two (あつ)?!" the dirt cries out in dismay. This dirt is tough, but it's really starting to feel the pressure now.

mnemonics.meaning: If there is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> you want to go it will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">prevent</mark> you from going any further. Like, come on kid, you think you can just walk right through a building? Don't make me laugh!
mnemonics.reading: The building is preventing you from going the right direction, so you pull a bowling (ぼう) ball out of your bag, aim, and bowl the building over. The building, and all the ones around it, go tumbling down. But now the rubble is preventing you from going further.

mnemonics.meaning: You walk into this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> and hit your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">head</mark> on it, then a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> falls out of it to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stab</mark> you. Ow! What the heck?! What was a knife doing in that tree?
mnemonics.reading: There's nothing more dangerous than a tree that likes to stab, so you get your saw (さ) and start to saw it down. Trees that stab get sawed.

mnemonics.meaning: Wash your<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">self</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> bar of soap if you're <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stinking</mark> everything up.
mnemonics.reading: You're stinking up the room because you spent your day rolling in 草 (くさ). And based on this particular stench, I'd say an animal left something in that 草 too...

mnemonics.meaning: Regardless of whether or not you wear a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hat</mark> while you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark>, you’re going to have a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">surplus</mark> of noise. Jackhammers are loud, and your hat is doing nothing to dampen the racket. There’s a surplus of commotion coming from the jackhammer and onlookers are not amused.
mnemonics.reading: One of the people walking by is the owner of a push cart yo-yo (よ) stand. Having a surplus of yo-yos, he starts throwing them at you. This makes you stop using the jackhammer as you need both hands to fend off the yo-yo barrage.

mnemonics.meaning: You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> stuck in the ground with a little bit of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fur</mark> coming out from it and on closer inspection you realize it’s actually a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tail</mark>. Someone stuck a flag into some sort of animal, pushing it under the ground. All that’s visible now is some fur and part of the tail.
mnemonics.reading: You try to pull the flag out of the ground and hear a rumbling buzzing sound. At the end of the flagpole you see a huge beehive (び)! These bees made their home under the tail! Maybe that’s why the flag was sticking in it… to warn people. Oops.

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark>, throwing your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hat</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> in front of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bookshelf</mark>, "I have a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">theory</mark>!" All this reading and thinking has finally given you a wonderful idea, a theory you think might solve all of your problems!
mnemonics.reading: "What is your theory, Ron (ろん)?" asks Hermione. You're Ron Weasley, and you just came up with a theory that you think will help you stop Voldemort.

mnemonics.meaning: Hanging off the edge of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>-worshipping <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark> with a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">thick</mark> unibrow. Hanging off the cliff, the child cries out to the sun to save them from this cruel fate. Even the thickness of their unibrow is not enough to give the child the strength to climb back up on their own.
mnemonics.reading: The child glances up at their thick unibrow and yells, "ah, two (あつ)!" Yup, it turns out the sun misunderstood the child's pleas for help. Instead of pulling them up from the cliff, it gave them a second thick unibrow on top of the first one.

mnemonics.meaning: You place a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark>. She's gone now, but she was once your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wife</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Wait a minute… She can't be dead because your wife is a cyborg (さい)! How could you forget?!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> is filled with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">blame</mark>. They take the blame for everything from food poisoning and allergies, to cutting people's feet on beaches.
mnemonics.reading: When those poor shellfish aren't having blame piled on them, they're being eaten, because shellfish are thought to make for a very sexy (せき) meal.

mnemonics.meaning: Your magic <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yoga</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">brush</mark> lets you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">build</mark> what's in your mind's eye.
mnemonics.reading: You build a bridge. Immediately after, someone is climbing up onto it. It's Ken (けん) the samurai. He waves at you and says, "Did you build this? The craftsmanship is amazing."

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> is only a winter tree due to a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">clause</mark> in its tree contract.
mnemonics.reading: This clause was written into all trees' contracts by Joe (じょう), the large farmhand.

mnemonics.meaning: You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> that's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">simultaneous</mark> (with another tsunami, I assume) and you know the world is about to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">come to an end</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Just as the world is about to come to an end, your cyborg (さい) appears and blocks it with its cyborg body!

mnemonics.meaning: You keep your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> close to your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark>, praying for all your wishes to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">come true</mark>. Perhaps some gracious god will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">grant</mark> what you wish for?
mnemonics.reading: And if you really want your wish to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">come true</mark>, make sure to write it down in <mark class="reading-highlight" title="Reading">kana</mark>!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> is a woman who talks about grain with other women on a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">committee</mark>. Together they're known as the Committee of Grain Women. What does this committee discuss, you wonder.
mnemonics.reading: Well, they formed this committee because eagles (い) have been eating all the grain. The women meet as a committee and try to come up with ways to stop these pesky eagles from eating all the grain and leaving none for the humans.

mnemonics.meaning: You only have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">few</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark>s so you need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">conserve</mark> what's left.
mnemonics.reading: You're trying to conserve your eyes, when the Shougun (しょう) marches by. He stops, sees you, and demands you give him your remaining eyes! But sir, I'm conserving what little I have left!

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Cow</mark>s, using nothing more than a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark>, have taken <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">control</mark> of the world. Their <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">system</mark> of control is brutal — payback for how we humans have treated them, I guess.
mnemonics.reading: It's time to take control back from the cows! Pull out your saber (せい) and fight back!

mnemonics.meaning: If you use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to point when you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">compare</mark> things you're really just throwing around <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">criticism</mark>. You should never need to point fingers when you're just comparing things. If you're pointing and picking and being mean, that's criticism.
mnemonics.reading: If you're having trouble not giving out criticism, just think about how you would react if someone criticized you. You'd feel an embarrassed heat (ひ) rise throughout your body. That heat will cover your whole face.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lion</mark> harvesting <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> uses an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cut off</mark> the tops of the stalks. The lion is roaming the rice fields using his axe to harvest the rice. He does so by cutting off the part of the rice stalks he needs.
mnemonics.reading: The lion will cut off rice stalks until dawn (だん). But at the first light of dawn, it will run and hide in the shade of the trees, cut off from the rice.

mnemonics.meaning: Both a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> have a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">duty</mark> to protect their people. A good leader always protects his followers, and a good king always protects his subjects. This is their duty.
mnemonics.reading: You’re the village nincompoop (にん), but the king and the leader still have a duty to protect you. Even a nincompoop is important to the kings and leaders of the world.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> is an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">element</mark> essential to all living things. This thread of life joins all things together, providing an essential relationship between all life. This element is all that holds this world together.
mnemonics.reading: You need to keep this element clean, so you make sure to wash it with soap (そ) every single day. This turns out to be pretty hard because the element is an invisible thread, but you do your best.

mnemonics.meaning: Seeing a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mohawk</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> means the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">enemy</mark> is nearby. You are from the dreadlock tribe and the mohawk tribe is your enemy. You’re deep in the heart of battle and winter has fallen. Now is the time to take out the enemy.
mnemonics.reading: You're kind of a techie (てき), so you have an advantage over your enemy. You're armed with night vision goggles and other cool tech gear as well. Being a techie certainly has its advantages.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Sheep</mark> are always looking at the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">next</mark> animal, full of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">envy</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">jealousy</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The reason the sheep feels such envy and jealousy is that the next creature is a centaur (せん)! Who wouldn't be jealous of a creature as noble as a centaur?

mnemonics.meaning: If you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> a new <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark> idea out loud, then it will be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">establish</mark>ed immediately.
mnemonics.reading: Weapons have to be established in sets (せつ). So you have to make another one that goes with it. Make them cohesive please.

mnemonics.meaning: You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">squid</mark> on it, so you get closer to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">examine</mark> it.
mnemonics.reading: You're sticking your face in really, really close to examine this little squid in the tree when Ken (けん) the samurai appears behind you. "There you are, squid! Thank you citizen, I've been looking all over for my little chum."

mnemonics.meaning: You have a scene going on inside your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">head</mark>. It is of a pair of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> atop a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark>. No. It is not just one pair of horns. It is many. So many that they create a giant <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hill</mark> atop the mountain, which is already pretty high.
mnemonics.reading: How was standing atop this hill of horns on top of a mountain to touch the sky? Eh. It was okay (おか), but that's about it.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mask</mark> is a mask which, when put on, will greatly <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">increase</mark> the amount of dirt.
mnemonics.reading: Use the dirt mask to increase the dirt around you. The zombies (ぞう) are trying to escape, so you just keep increasing the dirt on top of them so they can't get out.

mnemonics.meaning: If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> is growing out of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">top hat</mark> you need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">inspect</mark> it to find out why and how this happened. You should probably <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">investigate</mark> the area too. I mean, how could a tree grow out of a top hat anyway? Seems suspicious.
mnemonics.reading: As you inspect the tree, you pick up a saw(さ) and start cutting it. You need to investigate how the tree and the top hat are connected, and a saw is the only way to do it properly.

mnemonics.meaning: I hereby cut your assets in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">half</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark>, says the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">judge</mark>. At someone's divorce proceedings. Ah, the oldest judge trick in the book.
mnemonics.reading: This judge is Han (はん) Solo, so you know he's not going to back down.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cow</mark> tribe is too important to deal with small <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">matter</mark>s and trivial <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">affair</mark>s.
mnemonics.reading: All of his affairs are taken care of by Ken (けん) the samurai, who he hired as his underling.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Building</mark>s hold <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">festival</mark>s on special <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">occasion</mark>s.
mnemonics.reading: The occasion this time is to celebrate your wonderful cyborg (さい). It's about time you did something nice for it.

mnemonics.meaning: If you see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> with an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark>, you better <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pray</mark> for your life. Spirits only hold axes if they're thinking about murder, so pray as hard as you can to try and get it to spare you.
mnemonics.reading: You pray and pray and pray and nothing happens. You stop praying and dare to open your eyes. There is a key (き) in front of you. Grab the key and hold it before you and pray for the spirit to take it. Moments later, both the key and the spirit are gone.

mnemonics.meaning: If there’s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grass</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hand</mark>, you need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">raise</mark> that hand up to the sky. You’re in the middle of a fisherman’s ritual, which can only be performed on grassy ground. You take fish fins from the previous year, and raise them up to the sky in order to ensure a good fishing harvest.
