mnemonics.reading: This ritual only works in one part of the world however. It absolutely must be performed in Little Kyoto (きょ). The way Little Kyoto lines up with the sun and the sky and all that astrological junk makes it the best place for you to raise fish fins up in the air.

mnemonics.meaning: All the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">world</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> are yours to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">receive</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Why do you want to receive all these shellfish? Because it's the moral (もら) thing to do. Oh benevolent, moral king of all the world's shellfish, please receive us.

mnemonics.meaning: Whatever people <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> to you will be carved by a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blade</mark> into your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>. Sounds cruel, but it's a way to make you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">recognize</mark> their power.
mnemonics.reading: Having their words carved into your heart makes you recognize the authority of many people. But the only one you could ever truly acknowledge, is Nintendo (にん).

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">next</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> will be yours, but this shellfish will be mine. These are the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">resources</mark> we have to share and distribute.
mnemonics.reading: You save up all of your resources so you can buy a sheep (し). You bring a big sack of your shellfish resources to the market and finally get to pick out that sheep you've had your eyes on for months.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the radical are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Righteousness</mark> is as <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">righteousness</mark> does, right?
mnemonics.reading: Such righteousness! Well, at least according to the king who thinks he's being righteous. His version of righteousness is to send anyone who disagrees with him to the guillotine (ぎ).

mnemonics.meaning: Under a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> there's a broken <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark> stuck in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark>, because it (the turkey) has no <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rights</mark>. People can just shoot turkeys with arrows and no one is punished, because they (the turkeys) don't have any rights.
mnemonics.reading: "You have rights, so I won't shoot you like this turkey," says the voice of Ken (けん) the samurai, from above you in the tree.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> is coming for the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark> made of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tofu</mark>, but there is a special <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sect</mark> that protects this tofu cliff.
mnemonics.reading: All of the members of the sect are standing on the cliff, their hands raised, and right as the tsunami is about to collide with them, they shout, "Ha (は)!" and it's repelled! The tsunami sinks and rolls back out to sea, the tofu cliff is safe!

mnemonics.meaning: You use a special <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spear</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> to give yourself the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> to do all of your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">task</mark>s.
mnemonics.reading: Your task is to spear this cow. "Moo (む)!" it yells at you and runs away. You need to make dinner though... that's your task, so you better catch up to that cow and put an end to its mooing.

mnemonics.meaning: Some of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark> has just been taken by a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">guard</mark>. This is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tax</mark> you pay for living in this town. Back in the day, grain was used like currency, so it makes sense that guards went around collecting grain tax.
mnemonics.reading: You have to pay this tax, because if you don't the guard will cut you down with his special German saber, a zeiber (ぜい). "Don't you hear vat I zei? Pay ze tax or I vill zlei you vis my zeiber!" he shouts.

mnemonics.meaning: Taking out your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark>, you sew together the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">public</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>s to make them <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">whole</mark> again.
mnemonics.reading: Once their hearts are whole, the public's soul (そう) becomes one!

mnemonics.meaning: You use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> in the game of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">football</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">aid</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">assist</mark> the other players. And when you smash your fingers in football, you need to get some aid yourself.
mnemonics.reading: When you need aid for your football wrecked fingers you can't help but feel like it's the end (えん) for you. Your fingers hurt so much, you don't even want the nice nurses to aid you.

mnemonics.meaning: You have a great <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ability</mark> because your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> gives you the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">appearance</mark> of a superhuman. Your heart is really strong and powerful, fuelling your body to the best of its ability. All this together gives you the appearance of someone in top condition.
mnemonics.reading: While you may have the appearance of someone who is super strong, powerful, and awesome, you do have one shortcoming. You don’t know how to tie (たい) a tie. Actually, you don’t even know how to tie your shoes, let alone your tie. How embarrassing.

mnemonics.meaning: They <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yoga</mark> is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark> way to go through <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">birth</mark>. Birth isn't easy, but people keep telling you that yoga is the right way to prepare and actually do it.
mnemonics.reading: To prepare for giving birth you end up doing so much yoga outside that you get a really deep tan (たん).

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clothes</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">clothes</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Surprising!
mnemonics.reading: An eagle (い) sees a pile of your clothes and lays an egg (え) in them. The eagle’s egg needs a soft warm place to incubate, and your pile of clothes is the perfect place.

mnemonics.meaning: See all those <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">icicle</mark>s to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dog</mark>'s left? Good thing they all fell on his left, or he would've been in a terrible <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">condition</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: What saved the dog's condition was none other than Joe (じょう), the local farmhand. He constantly keeps an eye on the dog's condition, including any dangerously sharp icicles that could descend on him.

mnemonics.meaning: You use the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> to spit <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> at people as a form of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">congratulations</mark>! In fact, you yell "CONGRATULATIONS!" as the shellfish come pouring out of your powerful mouth.
mnemonics.reading: When you say congratulations like this, you look just like a gargoyle (が). You're crouching down, your mouth wide open, just like a stone gargoyle.

mnemonics.meaning: You use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">saw</mark> to cut down <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>s to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">construct</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">build</mark> a building. The bamboo saw was crafted by a master bamboosmith, and cuts through trees with ease so you can quickly construct this new building.
mnemonics.reading: As you construct and build this building, you hear a strange cheeping noise. Suddenly a chick (ちく) pops out of one of the logs you are building with. Then another, and another. You're surrounded by chicks! Is this because you used the magical(?) bamboo saw??

mnemonics.meaning: Inside the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Winter</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Cow</mark>. You need to see it, so you go inside. It is deep down in there, and you'll have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">descend</mark> to reach it.
mnemonics.reading: You descend to the bottom and there it is, the Winter Cow. You walk up to the cow, and it swings its head back to see you. Instead of a cow's face, it's こういち's face.

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kiss</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">each</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">every</mark> one of your best pals to show them how much you love and care for them. You kiss each friend right on the mouth.
mnemonics.reading: Actually, each and every one of your best pals is of the cock (かく) variety. By that, I mean each of them is a rooster. Imagine kissing each cock on its beak.

mnemonics.meaning: You should <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> "<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">peace</mark>" before you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">evaluate</mark> a situation. That way everyone will know where you’re coming from. If you’re honest and say "peace" before you evaluate a situation out loud, everyone will know where you stand.
mnemonics.reading: When you say "peace," you end up making a really bad pun and you hear somebody say “Heyo!” (ひょう) You look at the people around you and try to evaluate who said heyo, but you can’t tell. You start talking again when somebody exclaims “That’s what she said” and another person shouts “Heyo!” once again, but you still can’t evaluate who’s saying these things.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Dollar</mark>s and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> are used to pay <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">expense</mark>s and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cost</mark>s. Shellfish used to be used as currency, so they're like the coins that go with dollars.
mnemonics.reading: What is the biggest expense and cost? It's the heat (ひ) bill.

mnemonics.meaning: “Bring in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">next</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> so that I may examine her <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">figure</mark>!” We’re holding auditions for a commercial and we need to find a woman with a nice figure. The last woman was no good, so bring in the next one.
mnemonics.reading: The next woman comes in and you examine her figure. The figure you've been searching for! It just happens to belong to a sheep (し) woman. But she's soft, fluffy, and round. The perfect figure!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">womb</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">circle</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> where a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">force</mark> of nature is formed. The womb has the power to create life. Life is a force of nature, and the circle of life starts in the womb.
mnemonics.reading: Now pretend you're the mother. You'll need all the force you can muster to bring that baby into the world, so you grab hold of your special saber (せい) and slice it about in the air to give you the extra force you need.

mnemonics.meaning: You have something to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark>, you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark>, and shout, "I <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">GIVE UP</mark>!"
mnemonics.reading: Just before you're ready to give up on something, you yell, "AKIRA (あきら)!"

mnemonics.meaning: You can use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">indicate</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">show</mark> someone where the prize is buried. You buried the prize to keep it safe, but the jackhammer is great at unearthing it. Jackhammers do a great job and show where the treasure lies. They indicate quite clearly where one needs to go.
mnemonics.reading: Actually, you're unearthing Jesus (じ). He’s the treasure. For your soul. He’s here to show you that Jesus is still a hip and cool guy and he wants to indicate to you that having faith in Jesus and God and stuff is super rad. Jesus is all like, “Who has two thumbs and wants to show you the way of the Lord? This guy.”

mnemonics.meaning: From the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark>, an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">icicle</mark> falls and hits <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark>, and he has to go over to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lie down</mark>. And eventually he goes to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sleep</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: While wolverine sleeps, he makes a horrible neighing (ね) sound. It's like there's a giant horse in his mouth screaming to get out! NEIGH NEIGH!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Viking</mark> who knows how to use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bathtub</mark> will have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">manage</mark> all the baths for the other Vikings. Vikings aren't so great with bathing... if you can get one Viking to figure it out he has to manage the rest of them.
mnemonics.reading: The poor Viking trying to manage all the others keeps having to confiscate acorns (えい). "You can't take baths in acorns and wood, it has to be water!" he shouts.

mnemonics.meaning: Can you look at the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> and know which <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> you need to go? Then you might be a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">monk</mark>. Monks have amazing skills like that. And I'm sure you've seen monks wandering around in lots of media. They don't need maps or smartphones. They just look at the dirt and let the earth guide them to where they need to be.
mnemonics.reading: You want to know the monk's trick so you hide behind him for a while as he walks. Finally the monk stops, looks around, takes out a bowling (ぼう) ball and starts bowling in the dirt. The bowling ball rolls off, the monk follows it, and then heads off in that direction.

mnemonics.meaning: You'll be put in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> if you try to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> things with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> — that's your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">penalty</mark>. You can't just go up to other people and say things with a knife out. That's why the police have to put you in a net, as a penalty.
mnemonics.reading: Your penalty for breaking the law isn't over. Now that you're stuck in a net, you can't fight back when they hit you with bats (ばつ).

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cheap</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> has a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">plan</mark>. A plan to stay cheap.
mnemonics.reading: The cheap tree's plan involves only buying anchovies (あん) and surviving on them. Good exposure to the sun and fresh water is too expensive. The tree plans to save money by eating anchovies.

mnemonics.meaning: With a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> resting atop your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">head</mark>, you devise a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">plan</mark>. The plan is actually for getting the bamboo tree off of your head. You’re trapped under it.
mnemonics.reading: But why is this bamboo tree so heavy? You look to each end of the bamboo and realize that there is a sack (さく) tied on each end. Each sack seems to be filled with heavy rocks. Looks like someone made a plan to trap you here. Now you have to devise a plan to escape!

mnemonics.meaning: Pointing your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark> way to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">present</mark> yourself or offer to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">submit</mark> your ideas. You're really just raising your hand. And when you want to present yourself, your ideas, or offer anything, the correct way is to raise your fingers to the sun. You definitely learned this in school.
mnemonics.reading: You want to present your show and tell of tater tots (てい) to the class. You raise your hand, the teacher calls on you, and you submit the tater tots for her and the class's approval. "Oh my!" the teacher exclaims, "I hope you brought enough tater tots to present to the whole class!" You raise your hand once more to the sky, and in it you submit a whole tray of tater tots!

mnemonics.meaning: You need your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> to be <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">straight</mark> before you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">put</mark> it on the ground and try to lure something into it. You put your net there to catch something, but if it's twisted or tangled, it won't be very effective.
mnemonics.reading: Then you decide to put cheese (ち) in your net. With a perfectly straight net and the cheese you put down as bait, there’s no way this fails. Success is all about how you put the net down and the cheese you put in it.

mnemonics.meaning: Lying in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> puts her <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> to understand the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">region</mark>. She loves to know all the regional differences among wines and other alcohols, and to her there's no better way to do this than putting her mouth on the ground and literally tasting each region.
mnemonics.reading: Turns out she thinks everything from this region is icky (いき). In fact, to the drunkard, every region tastes icky and gross. You don't have the heart to tell her it's the dirt and ground, not the region itself, that tastes icky…

mnemonics.meaning: In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure</mark>. As you pull it out of the mucky ground, you can feel your life force being<mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">renew</mark>ed.
mnemonics.reading: Just as you were getting accustomed to this life renewing treasure, こういち comes out of nowhere, stealing your treasure and running off with it.

mnemonics.meaning: If someone gets under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> over your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> you should <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">respond</mark> to them.
mnemonics.reading: You respond and it turns out it was to the 王 (おう).

mnemonics.meaning: It may just be a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> over a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bathtub</mark>, but this here is actually a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Shinto shrine</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: What god does this Shinto shrine hold? You see that "It's a-me-ya (みや)! (Mario!)"

mnemonics.meaning: A mix of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">reason</mark> helped you invent the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sleeve</mark>. Your spirit told you your arms were uncomfortable, stuck to your sides under that shirt. Reason told you that maybe, just maybe, if you made holes for your arms something good would come out of it. And that's how sleeves were born!
mnemonics.reading: And without these sleeves, your arms would be so dead (そで). They'd be all exposed and defenseless!

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> is like an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">escalator</mark> you use to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">suck</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">inhale</mark> things into your body.
mnemonics.reading: Use this mouth ability to suck cucumbers (きゅう) into your mouth. Cucumbers are shaped like cylinders so you can suck them into your mouth like this. Just as nature intended.

mnemonics.meaning: While riding on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark>, you grow a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mustache</mark> on top of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mustache</mark> you already have in order to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">surpass</mark> the people around you. You're in a scooter race and your mustache is the only thing keeping you in the lead, but someone else has a mustache too! So you grow another mustache to surpass them once again!
mnemonics.reading: Suddenly, something else manages to surpass you all. It's a car (か)! A car with two mustaches is also riding on a scooter and going way faster than you.

mnemonics.meaning: Taking <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">orders</mark> from a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark> will place you into enemy <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">territory</mark>. Geoducks make terrible commanders, so if you take orders from one, expect to end up in unknown territory, potentially even enemy territory. Be prepared.
mnemonics.reading: Not wanting to end up dead in enemy territory, you decide to escape this geoduck leader by getting on a row (りょう) boat and rowing your way outta there. The geoduck commander orders you to halt your escape, but you still get in your row boat and row away.

mnemonics.meaning: The light of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> is shining on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">guard</mark> who’s been on duty all night. In fact, the moon light is making him so warm, he’s trying to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">undress</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">escape</mark>! Somebody stop him!
mnemonics.reading: You’re unable to stop the guard from undressing and making his escape, so you decide to start throwing some darts (だつ) at him. Perhaps that’ll make him stop.

mnemonics.meaning: You take all of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">allocate</mark> them into one place to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">unite</mark> them. With all your thread united and wrapped together, you're ready to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rule</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">govern</mark> the world!
mnemonics.reading: You're busy trying to unite all of your thread, twisting and tying and wrapping, and suddenly you look at the ball in your hands and see とうきょう. You've united this thread into the shape of とうきょう. There are even little pins for all the famous neighborhoods and tourist spots. This is strange, because you don't remember putting them there.

mnemonics.meaning: A great <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> can look <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">straight</mark> at something and know its <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">value</mark>. That social media site? 44 billion dollars. That job position? 50k a year. A four-day work week? Um… sorry, no, there's no value there. See? Leaders can see straight to the heart of matters to grasp something's true value.
mnemonics.reading: One thing your leader knows has great value is cheese (ち). Say goodbye to your days of casually snacking on cheesy treats from the conbini, because your leader's decided the value of cheese is going up 1000%!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> only uses the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">helicopter</mark> with the highest <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">value</mark>. They choose to fly in only the very best, most valuable helicopter. That's why it's worth way more than the others. Actually, any helicopter they use goes up in value. That's the amazing effect of a good leader.
mnemonics.reading: To further increase the helicopter's value, the leader tied it to a car (か). Wow, now it has the value of a helicopter and a car combined! For a total value of… Well, imagine for yourself what value the car adds.

mnemonics.meaning: That <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scarecrow</mark> with the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">vice</mark> president. Yeah, I know how he looks, and I'm pretty sure he does some murdering on the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">side</mark>, but you didn't hear that from me.
mnemonics.reading: It's the vice president's turn to speak at the podium and he just clears his throat and yells, "F**k (ふく) you!" to the crowd, holding up his knife. They cheer.

mnemonics.meaning: There's an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> that you can <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">see</mark> in your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">view</mark>. The turkey seems to be viewing you too, from afar.
mnemonics.reading: As you view the turkey, Genghis Khan (かん) suddenly comes into your view too. He towers over the injured turkey, leans down, and... pulls the arrow out!?

mnemonics.meaning: The only <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> that the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gladiator</mark>s will <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark> are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wisteria</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Since they're on the moon, where did they get the wisteria from? Actually, from one of the points on earth that is nearest to the moon, Mt. Fuji (ふじ).

mnemonics.meaning: There's going to be a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark>. So you get up on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark>. You see people across the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">street</mark>, in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark>. They watch as you put on a pair of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark>. And you begin <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">acting</mark>. This is your last chance to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">perform</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: As the acting ends (えん), so do you all.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> that wants <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">peace</mark> can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">call</mark> for it. If you don’t have a mouth, you can’t call for peace. So use your mouth and call for peace when you can. Peace is great.
mnemonics.reading: But before you call for peace, you must first placate the masses. To do so, you astound them with your yo-yo (よ) skills. Once they are so entranced by how talented you are with a yo-yo, you easily convince them to make peace.

mnemonics.meaning: From the top of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark> you see something that looks like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lip ring</mark> jutting out into the ocean: it's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cape</mark>! You know, the geological formation where a big piece of land sticks out into the ocean? That kind of cape.
mnemonics.reading: Looking down at the cape, you realize capes always make the coastline look jagged, like a saw or key (さき). Thanks for keeping the coastline interesting, you saw-key capes!

mnemonics.meaning: Moving in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark>, an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alligator</mark> can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">carry out</mark> a murder once it reaches it. This alligator wants to kill someone. The alligator wants to carry out their execution.
mnemonics.reading: In order to carry out this murder, the alligator has to sneak up on its prey, so it can shoot it. You look across the water and see a sheep (し) grazing by the shore. The alligator is going to carry out a murder on that sheep!

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Dirt</mark> can <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">become</mark> a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">castle</mark> at any time. You just have to have the right conditions. The right time, the right people, and any patch of dirt can grow into a huge castle.
mnemonics.reading: Once you turn dirt into a castle, that's all she wrote (しろ). That's it. It's done. The story is over.

mnemonics.meaning: They <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> held by a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> are good to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">defend</mark> yourself with. Even better than a guard dog they say. People are so confused by the turkey sitting on a stool holding flowers that they just lose their will to fight. This turkey is great to defend yourself and your home.
mnemonics.reading: The only thing this flower-bearing turkey can't defend against is Godzilla (ご). Godzilla is pretty much undefeatable, especially for a turkey. The turkey is totally unable to defend anything from the mighty Godzilla.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">demon</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">demon</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Wicked!
mnemonics.reading: How do you keep a demon locked up? Use a key (き). Use a lock and key and keep that demon locked up safely behind bars so he can’t get out and do bad demon stuff.

mnemonics.meaning: Under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">divide</mark>s cells to create life.
mnemonics.reading: As it divides life, the mouth begins to look really familiar. It has big teeth and a crooked mustache... it's Wario (わり)!

mnemonics.meaning: Reaching your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ear</mark> is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sound</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> who can’t find <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">employment</mark>. You hear him before you see him because he’s behind some trash cans. Being a drunkard, he’s like, super wasted and just kind of rambling to himself, making strange sounds. No wonder he can’t find employment.
mnemonics.reading: Since this guy is such a pathetic drunkard, it comes as no shock (しょく) that he can’t find employment. If he did find employment, I would be filled with both shock and awe.

mnemonics.meaning: If you can eat <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark>s while running up <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stairs</mark>, you'll <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">excel</mark> at everything.
mnemonics.reading: In order to excel at this, though, you need a good pair of shoes (しゅう).

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Dirt</mark> shifts <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark>, and instead of the usual stuff it starts to grow <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> that are very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">extravagant</mark>. These shellfish are so extravagant because they can only be grown in the dirt in winter (after the dirt has shifted "direction" and started sustaining shellfish instead of plants, that is).
mnemonics.reading: To make this experience even more extravagant, you eat them with a zeiber (ぜい), a German saber. A fork is just too plain for these extravagant shellfish — you gotta use a zeiber for maximum extravagance.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> wishing to stop <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">criminal</mark>s will write a moving <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">haiku</mark>. The leader pleads with the criminals to stop their crimes, to look within, and to realize there's more to life (like poetry!).
mnemonics.reading: A haiku is still a haiku (はい). Whether it's written by a law abiding leader or a criminal leader.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">restaurant</mark> says, "<mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Halt</mark>!" to everyone who wants to come in. The leader looks them up and down. Stares into their eyes. And then, maybe, they may go into the restaurant to eat.
mnemonics.reading: People only halt because they want this restaurant's world famous tater (てい) tots. Which is probably why there is a leader out front making sure only people who can really appreciate the tater tots can get in to eat them.

mnemonics.meaning: You need to go up on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> down <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">seven</mark> times to make this your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">house</mark>. A house isn't a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">home</mark> until you've slid down it exactly seven times, you know.
mnemonics.reading: If you try to slide down your new house and you land on a tack (たく), that means the house has rejected you. It isn't your home now. You need to leave and find a new home.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sick</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sheep</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">itchy</mark> and it can barely sit still. Help the poor sheep!
mnemonics.reading: Even though the sheep is itchy, look how kah-yute (かゆ) it is! It’s not just cute. It’s kah-yute!

mnemonics.meaning: You place a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> on this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clothes</mark> to show him you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">judge</mark> him. In fact, you yell, "I JUDGE YOU FOR BEING DRUNK AND WEARING THESE CLOTHES, TAKE THIS!"
mnemonics.reading: As you judge each other, your cyborg (さい) comes stomping over and slams the drunkard against the wall. With your trusty cyborg coming to your rescue, you can continue to judge this guy all you want.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Loiter</mark>ing around with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">brush</mark>? Sorry, but you're breaking the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">law</mark>. If you have a brush, that's okay. If you're loitering, that's okay. If you combine the two? Well... watch your back.
mnemonics.reading: Where were you loitering with your brush, breaking the law? Right outside the Ritz (りつ) Hotel. You'd think that it would be okay since you were staying there, but the law is the law.

mnemonics.meaning: Take this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">road</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark>. Hmm. It seems a bit too long. As you measure it, you continue down this road, wondering where it will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lead</mark> you.
mnemonics.reading: Where does the road that you're measuring lead to? To a doughnut (どう) shop!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leather</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">leather</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Cool!
mnemonics.reading: One way to get leather is to skin a male chicken, a cock (かく). Not a very efficient way to get leather, but one way nonetheless.

mnemonics.meaning: Giving <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cleat</mark>s to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark> carrying an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">umbrella</mark> is the best way to gather <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">milk</mark>. You don't have any containers, so the child has to hold milk in the upside-down umbrella. The cleats are so the child can run back and forth to transport the milk around.
mnemonics.reading: But where is this child exactly? He’s in New (にゅう) York City. What’s he doing in New York City you ask? Well, he's milking a cow. Why is there a cow to be milked in New York City? Good question. It’s the end of the world and New York City is the last remaining civilization. This is how people live now. Milk is important.

mnemonics.meaning: Wrap <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">vines</mark> around a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">obtain</mark> it. Don't worry about paying for it, sneak into the stool store and tie some vines around the legs. Then when you leave, pull the vines and the stool will come out after. That's how you obtain a stool!
mnemonics.reading: Today you want to obtain a new pair of shoes (しゅう). You tie your vines around the stool they're on, and slowly inch them toward the door.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> can <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">see</mark> the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">present time</mark> for what it really is. The future isn't important. The past isn't important. The present is when everything <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">appear</mark>s.
mnemonics.reading: At the present time the king is Genji (げん). The time has finally come for him to get serious, and as they say, there's no time like the present.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> put <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark>. That is their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">task</mark>. It is to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">provide</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">equip</mark> the cliff with flowers.
mnemonics.reading: Why do they provide and equip the cliff with flowers? It's all for the bees (び).

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stop</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark> from moving by tying it with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> that's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">purple</mark>. The spoon wouldn't stop moving around, so you had to use your favorite purple thread to make it stop. It's the strongest thread you have.
mnemonics.reading: To remember this reading, think about how the village you previously went to was all purple. It was the "村先" (むらさき) that you went to.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> makes all the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rule</mark>s. It isn't supposed to be making rules, but it has a knife, so who's going to argue?
mnemonics.reading: The first rule the shellfish enacts is that all humans take off their socks (そく) and give them to him. Hmm... is this some kind of nasty shellfish? Who would want socks?

mnemonics.meaning: Take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> and make two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark>-shaped <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shelf</mark> units with it. Moon radical-shaped, that is. Those moon radicals standing side by side kinda look like a shelf, don't you think? The tree on the left is just there to remind you it's made of wood, I guess. A lovely wooden shelf.
mnemonics.reading: To match the moon radical shape, this would have to be a pretty tall shelf, meaning you can store a ton-a-stuff (たな) on it.

mnemonics.meaning: How do you make a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hole</mark> nice and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark>? You gotta <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stab</mark> something in it. Just <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">thrust</mark> it right in there. And make sure your movements are really <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sudden</mark>. Stabs and thrusts are more effective when they're sudden.
mnemonics.reading: Give that hole one last big stab, now you've totes (とつ) showed that hole who's boss. What did I tell you about the sudden thrust technique? It's totes super effective. Like, totes.

mnemonics.meaning: Riding a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> you see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> carrying a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark>, but that’s pretty <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">standard</mark> here. This is your dreamland. You always dream about tsunamis and the turkeys carrying crosses that ride them. This might be strange for other people, but for you it’s pretty normal.
mnemonics.reading: These wacky dreams are only standard fare in June (じゅん) though. You don’t have them any other time of the year, just in June. You don’t know why June is the only time you have dreams about tsunami riding turkeys, but that’s just the way it is.

mnemonics.meaning: You have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bow</mark> and you want to make it <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">long</mark>. To do that, you'd naturally just <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stretch</mark> it.
mnemonics.reading: As you stretch the bow, you hear someone running at you. "That's my bow you're stretching!" yells Mrs. Chou (ちょう). She is not happy that you're stretching her things. You should probably try to un-stretch it, put it down, and run before she beats you.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hundred</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark>s in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">superior</mark> at being <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gentle</mark>. These hundred foreheads are sensitive, especially in the heart of winter, so the leader must be very gentle. Not just any kind of gentle though—the superior kind of gentle that will keep a hundred foreheads following.
mnemonics.reading: You need to be superior because all of these foreheads belong to youths (ゆう). They don't know how to take care of themselves, though they try to convince you they can. They're too young to know any better.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shrimp</mark> crashes into a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">swamp</mark>. Now the swamp is filled with shrimp. They used to live in the ocean, but the tsunami has carried them to their new home in the swamp.
mnemonics.reading: Your house was right next to the swamp and on this side of your house you had many a tack (たく) there to hang things on. Now, on every tack there is skewered a shrimp. The force of the tsunami drove them into the tacks on the side of your house.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of water falls from a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bear</mark> onto the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> and needs to be wiped up with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark>. Only a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">teacher</mark> or an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">expert</mark> could get away with getting close to this wet bear to wipe up after it.
mnemonics.reading: The teacher tells you to start with something smaller, after all, you're not an expert yet. You have to practice on a wet sheep (し). "I became a wet, dangerous animal expert by starting with sheep, you will too!" your teacher says.

mnemonics.meaning: In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">morning</mark>, if you want your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hat</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark>, you need to hang it on a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tree trunk</mark>. In the morning, everything is covered in dew. The grass is wet, the leaves are wet, but the tree trunk isn't wet! It was protected by the rest of the tree, so you can hang your hat there to dry.
mnemonics.reading: You lean against the tree trunk, waiting for your hat to dry, and suddenly you realize Genghis Khan (かん) is on the other side of it. You look around and see that all of the tree trunks around you have Mongols drying their hats under them.

mnemonics.meaning: Put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hand</mark> over your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">watch over</mark> others.
mnemonics.reading: As you watch over your friends and neighbors you see movement in the distance. Oh no, it's Genghis Khan (かん) and his army!

mnemonics.meaning: There are people under a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">street</mark> forming their own <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">agency</mark>. They're banding together right here in the street, making a new <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">government office</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: This new <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">agency</mark> is just starting to make progress when you hear a low rumble... then a screech.

mnemonics.meaning: When you're a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">guest</mark> somewhere it's important to bring <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark>s. But more than that, the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">amount</mark> of geoducks you bring is really what matters. If you don't have any live geoducks go ahead and bring any amount of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">framed picture</mark>s of geoducks instead.
mnemonics.reading: Unfortunately, if you mess up the amount or the framed pictures, every other guest will gawk (がく) at you.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> shines on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">evening</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">snake</mark> suddenly appears! Wait, that's not a snake, it's your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">arm</mark>, sticking out from under the roof.
mnemonics.reading: Your arm is exposed to the moon and the outside and you feel a chill. Where are your clothes? Ah, you're nude, eh (うで)?! I guess it is pretty common to sleep in the nude, eh?

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> where you just <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">see</mark> is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">boundary</mark>. You don't want to cross the boundary, you just stand there and see over it. As a general rule, you can stand in the dirt and see beyond boundaries, but you don't usually cross them.
mnemonics.reading: The boundary you're looking at now is the Kyoto (きょう) boundary. Kyoto is one of the most famous places in Japan, so you can imagine its boundary is really clear and marked by all kinds of boundary signs that say KYOTO.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Fire</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nature</mark> will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">burn</mark> down everything in its path. In nature, there are no firefighters to contain the flames, so the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">blaze</mark> will burn until nothing's left.
mnemonics.reading: What is the worst thing that could burn in this fire? Your nendoroid (ねん) collection. You've spent a lot of time and money collecting all these cool and rare and unique nendoroids and now they've all burned in the fire.

mnemonics.meaning: You use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> at <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dawn</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">carry</mark> many things. You have to carry yourself out of bed. You have to carry your backpack or purse or laptop bag to school or work. Your fingers have to carry a lot of weight around at dawn.
mnemonics.reading: Once you're carrying everything, and the dawn sun is shining bright, you start getting tan (たん). Especially those fingers you're using to carry things.

mnemonics.meaning: If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> blesses your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">older brother</mark> it's time to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">celebrate</mark>! This isn't something that happens every day to everyone's older brother. Yours is very good and very lucky. So celebrate with him!
mnemonics.reading: Unfortunately, the two of you celebrated too much, and you went a little crazy. The spirit grabbed your brother and shook (しゅく) him. Shook him so hard his head popped off.

mnemonics.meaning: The American <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">reason</mark> you need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">deliver</mark> this package. The flag is inside the package, and you need to deliver it to the president. He lost his old flag, so now it’s up to you to deliver this new one to him. What more of a reason do you need?
mnemonics.reading: To deliver this flag is something you just have to do (とど). Need to do. Want to do. There is no one else to do it. This is something only you are equipped to do.

mnemonics.meaning: You take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Korea</mark> and everything is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">different</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: What's also different is that there's a weird tiger bouncing on its tail alongside you yelling that its name is Tigger (ちが). You didn't know Tigger was living in Korea these days. That's definitely different.

mnemonics.meaning: When a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sheep</mark> tries its hoof at <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark>, it gains <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">distinction</mark>. Now that is something that really sets a sheep apart! After all, have you ever seen a sheep working in construction?
mnemonics.reading: The extra distinction of this sheep is that its really skilled with a saw (さ). That's why it's so good at construction.

mnemonics.meaning: There’s a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blackjack</mark> table that you can <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kick</mark> in order to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">expand</mark> the table. Sometimes you only have a few people playing blackjack so you don’t need to kick the flag at all, and sometimes  there are many people playing blackjack so you need to kick the flag many times in order to expand it to a proper size.
mnemonics.reading: The blackjack table does have a limit though of how many times it will expand, and that limit is ten (てん). You can only kick the flag to get the table to expand ten times.

mnemonics.meaning: You're about to enter a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> that has your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">number</mark> on it so you can face the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">judge</mark>. You've been sitting here for what feels like hours, waiting for your number to come up. Finally the time has come—the judge will see you now.
mnemonics.reading: The judge is not happy with you. He tells you to come closer and when you do, he takes his gavel and hits you in the shins (しん). Ouch!

mnemonics.meaning: Behind the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> lies a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mask</mark>—yet another <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">layer</mark> of secrecy. You’re standing in front of a crowd, giving a rousing speech. Hiding your face is the flag of your country, and behind that flag you’re also wearing a mask, just in case the flag falls down. The extra layer of secrecy is just to be safe.
mnemonics.reading: Someone jumps up on stage and starts peeling off your layers! You stand there, first goes the flag, then the mask, then ... your soul (そう) is laid bare. No, literally. You don't have a body, your soul was under that mask. And now it's floating there for all to see.

mnemonics.meaning: If you use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">see</mark> something, it means you really <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">look at</mark> it. You're not just seeing something passively with your eyes, you're actually looking at it with your whole spirit.
mnemonics.reading: The first thing you want to look at like this is a sheep (し). You've seen a lot of sheep, but you've never really looked at them closely, so your image of them is kind of… woolly.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> is showing his people how to put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> around a weird <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">zombie</mark> by walking around it in a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">loop</mark>. It's a weird zombie because it has the ground on top of its head instead of dirt.
mnemonics.reading: The king also explains that this loop technique was used by Genghis Khan (かん) when he was conquering cities. He'd loop around the entire place with a net and trap them.

mnemonics.meaning: In an attempt to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">control</mark> your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clothes</mark>, you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">manufacture</mark> a mind control device. This mind control device will allow you to control the mind of your clothes and all that they do. You just need to manufacture it.
mnemonics.reading: You manufacture these clothes to control your saber (せい). It's hard to manufacture, you have to do a lot of work, but you manage to make your clothes control your saber. Now you don't need to rely on your hands!

mnemonics.meaning: On this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark>, there's an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">angel</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of sweat coming off of it, because it forgot to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mention</mark> something to you! It seems like it's something important too, since they're sweating so much.
mnemonics.reading: "I forgot to mention, you have to study ninjutsu (じゅつ)!" the angel yells. But it's too late, there are ninjas jumping out of the bushes around you and taking you hostage.

mnemonics.meaning: On the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> there's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ceremony</mark> where everyone keeps <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stop</mark>ping. This stopping ceremony is being performed by the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">military</mark>. They'll march one direction, then stop and turn, then march another direction, then stop again.
mnemonics.reading: You look closer at the people in the military and realize that every time they stop they take a drink of booze (ぶ)!

mnemonics.meaning: There is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lantern</mark> on top of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>. You walk up to take the knife and lantern when you realize it's just a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">model</mark>. It all looked real from far away, but now that you're up close you can see none of it is real.
mnemonics.reading: You touch the model and see that it's made of cake (けい)! Someone really into lanterns and knives must have been given this model cake as a birthday present! Though they left it out here so they probably didn't like it.

mnemonics.meaning: You have an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">animal</mark> for a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">husband</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> that are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">narrow</mark>. This animal husband of yours is a goat. A goat with narrow horns. Why is this animal your husband? You’re weird, that’s why.
mnemonics.reading: I’m not even going to get into the semantics (せま) of how this weird relationship of yours works. Nope, this reading explanation is on the straight and narrow. Need to know basis. Classified. All that junk. There will be no discussion of the semantics between you and your goat lover.

mnemonics.meaning: When a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> wants to work <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">together</mark>, it means they want what you have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">offer</mark>. Congrats! Now you can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">accompany</mark> them everywhere and offer them hot towels and bottled water, or whatever it is you do…
mnemonics.reading: Once a year, the leader will offer you a vacation in きょうと. It's an all-expenses-paid trip! The catch is that you have to accompany your leader to きょうと…

mnemonics.meaning: On your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bear</mark>. It is pulling the bamboo off, because it wants to use it to make a long <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pipe</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The pipe will be for Genghis Khan (かん), who would like some pipes for his house.

mnemonics.meaning: You have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> for a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark>, to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">place on</mark> its dashboard. Drunkards should not drive, and when you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">put on</mark> a cross, it prevents the car from starting!
mnemonics.reading: You have a lot of crosses to place on drunkard cars, so you get your cyborg (さい) to do it for you. The cyborg doesn't need sleep, so it can patrol the streets 24/7 for the sake of public safety. What a saintly cyborg.

mnemonics.meaning: You have to use two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark>s to open these <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark>. That seems like overkill, but it is necessary. These particular shellfish are of very high <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">quality</mark> meaning they won't open so easily.
mnemonics.reading: You finally get all of the shellfish open and you're admiring their quality, when your shih tzu (しつ) jumps up on the table and gobbles them down. NO! You try to chase after the little dog, but it's too late. They're gone.

mnemonics.meaning: When <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dawn</mark> reaches this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">village</mark> it increases in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">quantity</mark>. That's right. Every morning the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">amount</mark> of people or animals living here goes up by at least one.
mnemonics.reading: Today's dawn has brought with it an increase in the quantity of row(りょう) boats! Aww, aren't they cute? Look at all of the new row boats lined up together. They all have their own sets of oars too.

mnemonics.meaning: A sudden aversion to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> makes you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">anti</mark>-shellfish, so you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sell</mark> off every shellfish in sight.
mnemonics.reading: You're going to sell all of our shellfish to Han (はん) Solo. He isn't anti-shellfish like you, and he knows how to turn a profit too!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">door</mark> leading to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> can be broken down with one’s <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shoulder</mark>. It’s not a very sturdy door to the moon, so it’s quite easy to drop your shoulder and ram it open.
mnemonics.reading: "Wow, your shoulder is just like my catapult (かた)!" you hear someone shout. As you turn you're just in time to see a man catapulting through his own moon door!

mnemonics.meaning: A man who is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">husband</mark> material can <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">see</mark> a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">standard</mark> woman and think she’s the greatest thing ever. This man will make a great husband. Even though the lady is pretty standard, the husband treats her like she’s anything but.
mnemonics.reading: It’s pretty standard for a husband and wife to exchange vows when getting married, and the husband said this girl held the key (き) to his heart. She unlocked the husband’s heart with the key and now he’s a man made whole.

mnemonics.meaning: What might cause a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> down a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jet</mark> would be if its <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stock</mark>s and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">share</mark>s took a dive in the market. This tree was on a jet for an important investor meeting when it got the news that its stocks and shares had just plummeted. Being very upset, the tree got up and got on the emergency slide out of the jet and plummeted into the ground just like his stocks and shares.
mnemonics.reading: Once the tree hits the ground with his stocks and his shares, the impact creates a large KABOOM (かぶ)! Stocks hit the ground - KABOOM! Shares! KABOOM! Tree! KABOOOOOOM~!

mnemonics.meaning: If, at a certain <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">angle</mark>, you approach an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark>, you’ll be able to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">touch</mark> it without it noticing. Most of the time, insects will run away from you when you try and touch them, but if you do so from the right angle, the insect will have no idea.
mnemonics.reading: Uh oh, looks like this particular insect is a lightning bug so when you touch it you get a shock (しょく). Did you know that lightning bugs contain bazillions of volts inside them? Well they do, and if you touch one, you get a shock. A very big shock.

mnemonics.meaning: What does a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> and the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Death Star</mark> have in common? They're both used to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">transport</mark> people and things.
mnemonics.reading: Right now you and the Death Star are transporting yurts (ゆ). They're the universe's #1 best transportable homes!

mnemonics.meaning: You approach the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Moon</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">helicopter</mark> and see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> there on the surface, touching her <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">waist</mark>. She's posing with one hand on her waist, like she's Sailor Moon or something. I guess that would explain what she's doing here on the Moon!
mnemonics.reading: Once you get close, you see that her waist looks weird and… puffy? You realize she's stuffed some 子 sheep (こし) under her skirt's waistband to line her waist with them. Guess it's cold up here on the moon, so the 子 sheep keep her waist warm. And they had to be 子 sheep, otherwise they wouldn't be small enough to fit under her clothes.

mnemonics.meaning: If you could just get your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> to open the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">window</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark>, you'll grow <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">accustomed</mark> to them sooner or later! I know shellfish are a bit of an acquired taste, but if you don't open that window, you'll never like them!
mnemonics.reading: You'll need to become accustomed to eating shellfish if you want to grow up big and strong like Genghis Khan (かん). He didn't have shellfish growing up either you know, he had to grow accustomed to their taste too, but look how successful he was!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">old</mark> but that doesn't mean it's not still <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">alive</mark>. This is a living flag, and it gets old just like other living things.
mnemonics.reading: The flag that is old and alive is actually a Buddhist relic (that's why it's alive, in fact ... and old!). But, it's a really dumb relic, so it's put in Little Kyoto (きょ).

mnemonics.meaning: When you ride your scooter, you always carry an ink brush and some water. The water is to stay hydrated, obviously, and the brush is to write tickets for the criminals you apprehend. Why apprehend? I guess you're some kind of thirsty, scooter-riding cop who writes tickets in calligraphy. By the way, the shape of this brush (肀) is a little different from usual, but it's still a brush!
mnemonics.reading: When you do catch up and apprehend someone, you always tie them down with the tie (たい) from your neck.

mnemonics.meaning: You have to fly in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">helicopter</mark> and use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark> to punch your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ballot</mark>. The helicopter gets you far away from prying eyes, and the jackhammer makes you really try for whoever you're voting for on that thing. It's foolproof!
mnemonics.reading: While using the jackhammer on the ballot, the helicopter pilot keeps yelling “Heyo (ひょう), don't mess up! Heyo! Watch out, don't let me see!” as he flies the helicopter all over the place.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mantis</mark> perched just underneath it, and you know for a fact that it does not <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">belong</mark> there. Insects should be in trees and on the ground. Not up high on a flag pole. Insects belong in the wild!
mnemonics.reading: Luckily for you, and unluckily for this mantis who doesn't belong on your flag, you're a Bosozoku (ぞく) bike gang member, and you don't take crap from nobody. You climb the flagpole, punch the mantis and yell, "YOU DON'T BELONG HERE!"

mnemonics.meaning: Use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to grab this guy's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">foot</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">catch</mark> him! Not physically though, you do grab his foot, but you close your eyes, and catch the idea of him in your mind just by touching your fingers to his foot.
mnemonics.reading: As you touch his foot, you catch a glimpse of the Torah (とら) in your mind. Suddenly, you are able to grasp and understand every single thing written in the Torah. You fall to the ground.

mnemonics.meaning: Use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> at your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wedding</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">catch</mark> anything thrown at you. Catch the bouquet, for example, or catch the rice everyone throws at you. Weddings are really more about catching things with your fingers than they are about whoever is standing across from you.
mnemonics.reading: You're having a good time catching things until it's cleanup time and someone throws a hoe (ほ) at you. First of all, ouch, that was your face. Second, this is your wedding. You aren't supposed to have to hoe it all up. You're supposed to drop everything you caught and leave!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stick</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hook</mark>, and an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark> is able to change the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">climate</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">weather</mark>. Not just the type of climate that causes sunny and rainy days though, the political climate too, because they're a political <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">candidate</mark> too.
mnemonics.reading: Who is this climate and weather-changing candidate leader with the hook, stick, and arrow? It's none other than こういち.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">criminal</mark> that stole your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> was your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">comrade</mark>! You thought the two of you were friends, but you were probably wrong.
mnemonics.reading: You feel really weird about this whole situation so you write your comrade a haiku (はい). It's really all you can do, since your car is long gone.

mnemonics.meaning: There’s a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> coming and your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">older brother</mark> is in no <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">condition</mark> to escape. Your older brother has brittle bone syndrome so there’s no way he’ll be able to escape the tsunami in time in his condition.
mnemonics.reading: His condition gets worse and you have to travel all the way to his home in きょうと to get him out.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> causes the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">capital</mark> to become very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cool</mark>. The capital was already a pretty cool temperature, but with the addition of the water from the tsunami, the capital is now very cool.
mnemonics.reading: You find out that the cool tsunami water is coming from Sue Zoo (すず). The only animal there is a penguin named Sue, so the Sue Zoo is always kept cool for her. But now that Sue's fountain broke, the cool water is everywhere! Time to sue the zoo…

mnemonics.meaning: If you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poop</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">root</mark>s of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark>, the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sound</mark> will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">echo</mark> all the way through the building, and each and every person in there will know what you did.
mnemonics.reading: The echo doesn't stop there, this building's roots extend throughout the entire city of きょうと. The echo reverberates and soon everyone in きょうと is listening, horrified, to your poop.

mnemonics.meaning: If you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mix</mark> different types of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> you'll produce something <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">effective</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The most effective mix of two powers is two こういちs. Take one, mix it with another, and you have something with immeasurable power. You use it to attack that animal-like creature. It's super effective!

mnemonics.meaning: You have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">greenhouse</mark> that is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">endless</mark>. Imagine your endless greenhouse, which goes on and on, as far as the eye can see. Lucky you.
mnemonics.reading: Your flowers have grown so big that now the only way you can fit into your endless greenhouse is by lying on your back (ばく).

mnemonics.meaning: Sometime in the future, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> of every <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">color</mark> will be faced with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">extinction</mark>. Eventually there will be nothing else to make thread out of, and thread of every kind and color will reach extinction.
mnemonics.reading: The extinction of thread was brought on by a very strange thing. Deadly zits (ぜつ). These zits killed off all the producers of thread, and eventually the thread went extinct. Dang zits.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fish</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sheep</mark> are very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fresh</mark> here. This is a great place to get fresh fish and fresh sheep. I kid you not.
mnemonics.reading: This place also serves fresh centaur (せん), but that’s just weird. Centaur is endangered and you don’t believe in eating endangered things. Even if they are incredibly fresh.

mnemonics.meaning: If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hits these <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> they'll <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">both</mark> become <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">full</mark> of water. Tsunamis carry a lot of water, definitely enough to make both of these flowers full.
mnemonics.reading: As you stare at the full flowers, you decide to write a manga (まん) about them. Your head is full of manga ideas!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">beggar</mark> lies sprawled on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> so you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">give</mark> him some money. You feel bad for the beggar on the ground, so that’s why you decided to give him something.
mnemonics.reading: When you set the money down next to the beggar he shouts, “No! I want a yo-yo (よ)!” so you go to the corner store and buy him a yo-yo with the money instead. You give the yo-yo to the beggar and he looks very happy.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone covered your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> and also got dirt on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">toe</mark>s. So you're going to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hang</mark> them upside-down and slap them with your dirty extremities.
mnemonics.reading: You hang this person upside-down but they don't seem to be suffering enough, so you hit them with your car (か). No mercy.

mnemonics.meaning: Behind a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cleat</mark>-wearing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark> is holding his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> and trying to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hide</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Wolverine looks up at the building he's trying to hide behind and sees it's an inn (いん).

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> grows next to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">greenhouse</mark> enclosing an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">imitation</mark> of the tree. The imitation greenhouse tree wants to be big and impressive like the tree outside, so it does its very best imitation of a real tree.
