mnemonics.reading: The greenhouse tree realizes that its imitation will never be as good as the real thing. When it realizes this, the tree moans (も) aloud. The tree is still kinda tiny, so the moan isn’t very loud, but it is still pretty strange to witness. Speaking of witnesses, Bobo (ぼ) the clown sees this greenhouse tree moaning and decides to take it for his next clown show. Surely this miniature moaning tree can be worked into Bobo's next clown act.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Now</mark> your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">include</mark> more words than ever before! With our new and improved “Mouth Now!” program, your mouth will include more words than you ever thought possible!
mnemonics.reading: If you buy now, we’ll also include a handful of books by Gandhi (がん) himself. Gandhi didn’t use our program, but we’re sure if he’d had the opportunity to, he would have used it. So buy now, and get the words of Gandhi in your hands as well as your mouth!

mnemonics.meaning: Be careful what you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">public</mark>, otherwise you might face a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lawsuit</mark>. People will sue you for just about anything these days, so you really need to watch what you say in public, otherwise you might find yourself with a lawsuit on your hands.
mnemonics.reading: Any and all lawsuits need to be brought before the Shougun (しょう). Oh, you thought you'd get a judge or a jury? Nope, the Shougun decides your fate.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">root</mark>s will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">limit</mark> the things under and around it.
mnemonics.reading: The person who hates these limits more than anyone else is Genji (げん). He wants to be able to tunnel under buildings, sneak in, smooch ladies, and sneak back out. But all the building root limits make that impossible!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> who stays in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bed</mark> all day every day will soon become <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">obese</mark>. A healthy moon needs movement and exercise to stay fit and not become obese. If a moon stays in bed all day, they’ll be sure to grow obese over time.
mnemonics.reading: Since the obese moon is in bed all day, and since the moon stays pretty cold, she needs some extra heat (ひ) to stay warm. A heated blanket should do the trick.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Music</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">beans</mark> make farts <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">plentiful</mark>. And lucky for you, you have an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">abundant</mark> stock of these music beans, so you can eat plenty of them to power your musical bean toots.
mnemonics.reading: Your music bean farts are too plentiful to leave your home (ほう). If you tried to leave your home you'd definitely fart all over people outside, so you keep your plentiful farts to yourself.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Viking</mark> with enough <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>s will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">prosper</mark>. Vikings need trees to build their boats and homes, and they <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">flourish</mark> when they have enough.
mnemonics.reading: Vikings knew that in order to prosper they also needed to collect acorns (えい). If you're chopping down trees all the time, you need to actively grow them back too. That's why acorns are the actual, secret key to Viking prosperity.

mnemonics.meaning: Touch your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">friend</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pull out</mark> their friendship. Pull it out with a high five. Pull it out with a back rub. Pull it out with an, "Oh no, there's some lint on your shirt, let me get that for you."
mnemonics.reading: Your friend looks you in the eye and says, I want you to pull out my hair. I want my head to be nude (ぬ). Now you have to use your fingers on your friend to pull out their hair and make their head all nude.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">husband</mark> marries a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">husband</mark> while the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> goes down and the men <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">replace</mark> their solitary lives with one of everlasting companionship. Instead of one husband and one wife, we have two husbands here. They shed their lives of bachelorhood and replace it with one of monogamy.
mnemonics.reading: After the ceremony, the husband and his husband get in a car (か) and drive off into the sunset. They’ll never be able to replace this memory with anything. Truly it is the happiest day of these husbands’ lives.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark>s have to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">suit</mark> you if you want a good <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">salary</mark>. No one is going to give you a salary if your clothes don't suit you. You have to look professional!
mnemonics.reading: Your salary is paid in cucumbers (きゅう). Maybe you shouldn't have worn that cucumber tie when you interviewed for this job, even though it suited you well.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> rises over the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">capital</mark>, creating a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">scene</mark> of breathtaking beauty. The sun is bright and warm as it crests over the capital. It’s quite the scene to behold.
mnemonics.reading: The only way to make this scene better would be to add cake (けい). Now that you think about it, as the sun rises and frosts the capital with light, the buildings start to look like big, shiny cakes.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gladiator</mark> only sees himself (<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">oneself</mark>) on those big <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">scroll</mark>s they advertise the fights with. Gladiators don't get mirrors and there are no cameras or videos yet. The scroll drawings are all they get of themselves.
mnemonics.reading: When you look at the scroll you realize... you look just like Genghis Khan (かん)! You excitedly fist pump and start showing everyone how cool you are.

mnemonics.meaning: You want to get your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">humble</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>, so you dedicate your life to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">search</mark> for it. Wait, the humble stool? You know, like the holy grail or the ark of the covenant, but it's called the humble stool. It's from some bible or something, I promise.
mnemonics.reading: You search and you search and, unfortunately, you spend your entire life searching and you die without finding the humble stool. But don't worry, your soul (そう) comes back and now you get to continue your search but with afterlife powers!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> is what a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lifeguard</mark> uses to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">set up</mark> the station where he'll <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">care</mark> for the people on the beach and in the water. Trees provide the shade lifeguards need to take care of half-drowned kids and grannies with sand stuck in their bathing suits. That's why they set up their care stations here.
mnemonics.reading: You look closer at the set up and realize the lifeguard is こういち! You know he teaches Japanese but... is こういち really qualified to care for people like this?

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> rises over the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">capital</mark>, shines down on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark>, and casts a long <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shadow</mark> on the ground in front of you.
mnemonics.reading: In the shade from your shadow you see a small acorn (えい) laying on the ground. You're about to reach down and pick it up when you realize that your shadow is keeping this little acorn from growing up big and strong.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mix</mark>ed all around and begins to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">strangle</mark> you.
mnemonics.reading: As you are strangled you see who set this trap. (What else could it be, with all this thread everywhere?) It is こういち, who just watches you as you lose consciousness, tapping his fingers together.

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> you have an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of blood on it. You hit someone with that axe and now they're going to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sue</mark> you. That drop of blood on your axe is pretty incriminating, which is why they have enough of a case to sue you.
mnemonics.reading: You want to sue them back so you clean the axe with some soap (そ). "Your honor," you say in court, "I don't see any drops of blood, I countersue!"

mnemonics.meaning: There is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> at your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wedding</mark>. It's there as a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">supplement</mark> to the guests because not enough people came.
mnemonics.reading: Along with the spirits to supplement your wedding guests, you made everyone carry a hoe (ほ). That way no one had to bring a date, they carry a garden hoe as a supplement and no one feels bad about being dateless. Everyone is!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> carries your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yurt</mark> and you on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> under it away. You are now in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">transit</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The transit of yourself and your yurt home is due to the water (わた). This is water transit.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> touch as you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">adjoin</mark> yourselves. You are united, you are one.
mnemonics.reading: All the women adjoin in sets (せつ). Sets of two, of course. One woman with another woman, standing in unison.

mnemonics.meaning: Under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">head</mark> covered in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> emerges... <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">again</mark>! It's not the first time you've seen this buried head, nor is it the last. This dirt-covered head hides beneath the ground wherever you go, and keeps popping up to scare you again and again.
mnemonics.reading: The dirt-covered head asks for help again and again, but you've only got a saw (さ). So you start digging with it, scraping the dirt away, until you see this head has the body of a cyborg (さい)!

mnemonics.meaning: There once was an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">animal</mark> with an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark> friend who felt very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">alone</mark> unless he was around. An animal and an insect are an unlikely pairing, but these two get along delightfully and hate to be alone without the other.
mnemonics.reading: One activity that the animal can never do alone is solve Sudoku (どく) puzzles. The insect always has to help him out with them, and together they are an unstoppable Sudoku solving team.

mnemonics.meaning: On the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grass</mark> near a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> sits a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">creeper</mark> that is some sort of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dog</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">beast</mark>, a vicious <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">animal</mark>. This creeper isn’t just a normal dog, it is more beast-like, more like a feral animal than domesticated pet.
mnemonics.reading: The beast is guarding its precious jewels (じゅう), which it buried in the grass or the rice paddy somewhere. If you don't want the beast to think you're coming to steal those jewels, you better keep your distance.

mnemonics.meaning: You take some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> and some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fruit</mark> and you make a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cake</mark> out of it. It’s a very nice looking, flavorful cake. The fruit makes it taste great and the flowers make for great cake decorations.
mnemonics.reading: You’re standing back, admiring your cake when you hear a car (か) engine revving and before you know it your cake has been run over. The car came out of nowhere and ran your cake right over, spraying fruit cake bits and flowers all over the place. Stupid car!

mnemonics.meaning: They <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> using a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark> device (like a ruler) is a good way to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chastise</mark> someone. They do something bad? Chastise them by slapping their wrists, their feet, their eyes, ears, anything! They say something out of turn? CHASTISE THEM!
mnemonics.reading: You're being chastised because you tried to say something in English in とうきょう. Everyone around you slowly turned around, eyes aflame and rulers in hand, ready to chastise you for uttering those forbidden words.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">old</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> is to blame for today's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">circumstance</mark>. It is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">reason</mark> things are bad now.
mnemonics.reading: In reality, this circumstance was actually caused by a single 子 (こ), though. This kid went through town, destroying everything in their path.

mnemonics.meaning: Your new <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> doesn’t <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mix</mark> well with the other cars in your garage because its color is in stark <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">contrast</mark> to the others. All of your other cars are pristine white in color, but this new car is a mix of lots of colors. It almost looks like a peacock or something it’s so colorful. Such a contrast.
mnemonics.reading: What did I say this car looks like? Oh that’s right, a peacock (かく). This car looks like a peacock. It’s the color of a peacock and you’ll look like you’re peacocking when you’re out on the town driving it. It really is such a stark contrast to like, every other car out there.

mnemonics.meaning: "A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark>!" you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">announce</mark>. You are announcing this because you decided this is what you would <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">create</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: But, a scooter has been created before. What is different about yours? The scooter you will create is specifically designed to keep zombies (ぞう) busy.

mnemonics.meaning: In your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">warehouse</mark> you use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">create</mark>. You keep old pieces of wood in your warehouse, and you use your knife to carve them into new things that only you could create.
mnemonics.reading: When you create it's good for your soul (そう). It's so freeing, in fact, that when you get really into your creating, sometimes you'd swear your soul was floating a little bit outside of your body. But every time you notice, it sinks back down. Hmm.

mnemonics.meaning: The "<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Cliff</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Ten Thousand</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Power</mark>" is where you go if you want to be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">encourage</mark>d.
mnemonics.reading: When you get there, it does encourage you. The cliff says "Hey, I encourage you to buy a ray (れい) gun."

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> that is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark>, traveling in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fierce</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">violent</mark> force of nature. This white tsunami is chasing after winter, and that’s why the tsunami is white—it’s a winter tsunami. It’s the most fierce and most violent kind of tsunami in existence.
mnemonics.reading: The tsunami is too fierce, too violent, and before you realize what's happening, Gecki (げき), your beloved gecko, is lifted up and carried off into the air.

mnemonics.meaning: The  <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fortune</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fortune</mark> kanji are exactly the same! This can also mean <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">occupy</mark>, maybe because learning your fortune shows you how you're going to occupy your life. Or how it will occupy you…
mnemonics.reading: To occupy some free time you have, you go and get your fortune told at a fortune teller. Your fortune is that you’ll have an encounter with a centaur (せん) in the near future. Just then you realize that the fortune teller is actually a centaur! The fortune has come true!

mnemonics.meaning: There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> standing in the way of the next <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">chapter</mark> in your life, and it's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hinder</mark>ing you. It's not like you couldn't find another way around, but it's definitely inconvenient.
mnemonics.reading: Someone put this building here specifically to hinder you. They knew you were close to the next chapter of your life, and they wanted to hinder you really good. And there they are, sitting on a throne smirking. It's the Shougun (しょう).

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ego</mark>... it's totally out of control. <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">I</mark> mean, my ego isn't out of control. I'm the greatest. That's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">me</mark>. But your ego? Ugh, so out of control unlike my amazing ego.
mnemonics.reading: I am the greatest in the world! I am no baby like you, that's why. A baby who says "ga (が) ga ga ga!"

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark>ing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> is an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">indication</mark> or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sign</mark> of something to come.
mnemonics.reading: When you spot a loitering mountain king in the winter, you know it's an indication that soon Mrs. Chou (ちょう) will appear. It's like a Groundhog's Day kind of situation, but instead it means Mrs. Chou is about to come out, perhaps early for the season.

mnemonics.meaning: There are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> reaching towards you asking you to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">accept</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">instruct</mark> them. They're the fingers of students. And you're the teacher. See them reach out for knowledge. They want to accept this knowledge into their hearts and brains. Instruct them!
mnemonics.reading: "Yes! I will instruct you, my dear students!" you cry, "I will instruct you on how to open a small juice (じゅ) box!" That's right. These little kids need help learning how to open small juice boxes (small because kids are small).

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark> around your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">master</mark> until he <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">depart</mark>s on a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">journey</mark>. You have a lot more freedom to do things after your master has departed, so until that time you just loiter about looking busy and staying out of his way.
mnemonics.reading: Finally, it's time for your master's journey and he calls to you and says, "You are the 王 (おう) of the house now. Take care of everything while I'm gone."

mnemonics.meaning: You hold <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> while shopping for pencil <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lead</mark> at the store. This pencil lead store only accepts gold fins as payment, but your fins don’t fit in your pockets and you need your hands to carry the lead so the gold fins go in your mouth.
mnemonics.reading: You pay for your lead but the cashier puts it in your mouth where the gold fins were and... everything ends (えん).

mnemonics.meaning: A broken <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> sits in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark>. You need to get rid of it, so you put it in the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mail</mark>. Or, depending on where you live, maybe you put it in the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">post</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Who did you address this broken car mail (or post) to? You sent it to the youths (ゆう) of the world.

mnemonics.meaning: In a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark>, you see a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">needle</mark> sticking out of it. The needle is right in the middle of the gold cross. If Jesus were on there, the needle would be sticking him right in the chest.
mnemonics.reading: You're about to give up on the needle when it pops out and flies directly into your shin (しん). Ouch! Now you're desperately trying to pull the needle out of your shin, but it really won't budge this time. Maybe you should have minded your own business.

mnemonics.meaning: If you see someone <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark>ing around with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> on their head you'd be <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">obey</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">accompany</mark> them.
mnemonics.reading: If you obey the horned man you'll end up with a ton of jewels (じゅう)!

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark> around a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">black hole</mark>, waiting for it to finish destroying and switch to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">restore</mark> mode. You were told all black holes finish eventually, and when they do you can press a button to restore everything back to the way it was.
mnemonics.reading: Finally there's nothing else for the black hole to eat so you hit the restore button.... but nothing happens. "Oh f**k (ふく) you!" you scream as you realize you were lied to.

mnemonics.meaning: During a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark>, your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lip ring</mark> is ripped off while you’re trying to cross a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">river</mark>. There was no other path to safety, you had to cross the raging river, but you lost your footing and smashed your face on a rock and lost your lip ring.
mnemonics.reading: But why were you trying to cross this river anyway? Well your car (か) was on the other side of it, and you figured if you could get to your car you could outrun the tsunami and be safe. Too bad you fell and ripped out your lip ring though.

mnemonics.meaning: You keep all of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> under a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> down the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">street</mark> and it's your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">savings</mark>. Shellfish used to be used as money way back, and these aren't shellfish you're spending, they're ones you're saving up for later.
mnemonics.reading: When you want to withdraw from your savings you force yourself to use chopsticks (ちょ) to pick up the shellfish. They're especially slippery, hard to use chopsticks too, that way it's really hard to take too much out of your savings.

mnemonics.meaning: You take this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">comb</mark>, break the handle off, and use it to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stamp</mark> your official <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">seal</mark> of approval onto a document. It's kind of a messy <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mark</mark>ing process, but it gets the job done.
mnemonics.reading: You need this seal to stay at an inn (いん). All inns require official paperwork, so you had to improvise and make a seal on the fly.

mnemonics.meaning: You're trying to use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to cause a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">landslide</mark> so you have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shake</mark> the earth. You probably won't succeed, but the best you can do is to shake your hands on the dirt as hard as you can. It looks like you're trying to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wave</mark> at the ground now.
mnemonics.reading: You think you finally got the earth to shake but when you look down it's just your shins (しん). Darn you shins, I thought I made some progress. Hey wait... why won't you stop?!

mnemonics.meaning: When you hold out your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">person</mark> — and then a second <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">person</mark> — stomps them into the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>, leaving you with a serious finger <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sprain</mark>. That wasn't very nice of either person, and now you feel awfully <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">discourage</mark>d about things.
mnemonics.reading: You show your sprain to a doctor, and he tells you to go see the Czar (ざ). In your country, only the Czar has the authority to treat a sprain of this severity.

mnemonics.meaning: You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> floating around a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tombstone</mark> acting <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">suspicious</mark>. To be fair, if a soul is going to be anywhere, a tombstone is probably high up on the list, but this one seems like it's doing something weird.
mnemonics.reading: You sneak around the tombstone to see what this suspicious soul is doing, and you realize it's pretending to kayak (かい). The soul is sitting behind the tombstone, in a small kayak, moving its arms like it's rowing through water.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> going down your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark> face is just <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sweat</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The sweat isn't just on your face, it's also dripping down your ass (あせ).

mnemonics.meaning: "Take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark>. <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Now</mark>, put them on your foe's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">twist</mark>." These are the words of your martial arts master as he teaches you his final, ultimate technique: the "finger-heart twister."
mnemonics.reading: The last challenger to appear is… your own master, who taught you the twist technique. Turns out he's a nendoroid (ねん), so he doesn't even have a heart for you to twist. Welp, you're screwed.

mnemonics.meaning: You're using your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to do something important for this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ceremony</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark>. What's really important for this ceremony's construction, using your fingers? Well… you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wipe</mark> the floors.
mnemonics.reading: Now wipe these floors, you fool (ふ)!

mnemonics.meaning: Out of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark>, you make a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">brush</mark> – a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">writing brush</mark>. This is no ordinary brush, mind you. It is a brush specifically designed for writing elegant characters. And it’s made from bamboo!
mnemonics.reading: Once the writing brush hits (ひつ) that paper, it’s like you transform into a totally different person. All of a sudden you’re a master calligrapher, writing anything and everything in a most beautiful fashion. Once that brush hits the paper, it’s on!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> sitting on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> with a broken <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> is very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">angry</mark>. She had her heart broken by some jerk and now she’s sitting on the stool, just stewing over the guy and how angry she is with him.
mnemonics.reading: As you're sitting on that stool feeling angry, your dog (ど) comes up to console you. He nuzzles his head into your lap, and you start to feel the anger melt away.

mnemonics.meaning: You want to go to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> so you set up a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">twenty</mark> stories tall so you can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ascend</mark> into the heavens.
mnemonics.reading: You need to ascend into the sky and toward the sun because the Shougun (しょう) said so. He's testing out some space travel technology (the twenty story slide) and you're his guinea pig.

mnemonics.meaning: If you're riding your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> through some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark>, it's likely you've gone <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">astray</mark>. Also you might be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lost</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You got so lost and went so astray you ended up on the Mayflower (めい), a ship that eventually took you across the Atlantic Ocean. Now you've really, really gone astray.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone is reaching out with their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">call</mark> for you. They <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">beckon</mark> you closer, this way.
mnemonics.reading: The person beckoning you is the Shougun (しょう). You can't help but obey the Shougun's beckoning call.

mnemonics.meaning: Inside this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">black hole</mark>... haha just kidding, it's your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">belly</mark>! It's beautiful and round like the moon and it eats up everything you give it like a black hole. What a good <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stomach</mark> you have!
mnemonics.reading: If you don't treat your belly with respect, when you look down at it, it'll yell, "F**k (ふく) you!" Be nice to your stomach!

mnemonics.meaning: After a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hit your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">farming</mark> land, you're gonna see a lot of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dense</mark> silt left behind. This <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">thick</mark> layer really enriches the soil, and your crops will come out tasting extra thick and dense in flavor.
mnemonics.reading: Know who’s likely responsible for this dense, thick layer of silt? Nostradamus (のう). He’s the one who urged you to buy this farmland in the first place, likely because he predicted the tsunami would bring this thick layer of silt.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark>s start to close as you drive your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> because you’re getting <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">drowsy</mark>. This is a very dangerous way to drive your car, especially since your car is missing its top and its bottom. This is no time to be getting drowsy. Keep your eyes open and drive for your life!
mnemonics.reading: The reason you’re so drowsy, and also the reason your car is missing part of its bottom, is because you took one of the car’s tires and made a tire swing (すい) out of it. You’d been swinging on the tire swing all day and now you’re super drowsy and worn out.

mnemonics.meaning: You see a canopy under which someone has left a brush (in its 肀 form) next to the water, creating a scene of such ease and peace!
mnemonics.reading: It turns out this place of ease and peace was created by こういち, who suddenly comes in looking for the brush he left.

mnemonics.meaning: Setting up a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> on the top of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark>, you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rake</mark> all the rocks to the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">edge</mark> of it. You want to clear the area around your stand, so you get your rake out and you rake all the stones and debris away from the stand and toward the edge of the mountain top. It also creates a small barrier around the edge as well.
mnemonics.reading: You set up this stand at the top of the mountain so you could give a speech to the world. But you need to look your best, so you decide to get a tan (たん). You lie next to the edge of the mountain, and prepare to tan. Everyone likes a person with a healthy tan.

mnemonics.meaning: There aren't many <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>s in your under<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark>, so you've been given a task: using only your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>, plant as many in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> as you can. It's an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">extreme</mark> challenge!
mnemonics.reading: This extreme challenge could only be solved by one person: Goku (ごく) from Dragon Ball Z! He has a special cloak that'll allow you to plant trees in record time, so he quickly cloaks you (きょく) to help with your extreme task.

mnemonics.meaning: In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">capital</mark>, even a broken <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dog</mark> can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">get a position</mark>. That's because the capital has so many jobs available that even a poor, broken dog can find a place to work.
mnemonics.reading: In order to help the dog get a position, the capital cobbler made him a pair of nice shoes (しゅう). The shoes help him walk on his hurt legs, but more importantly, they boost his confidence and make him feel ready for any position.

mnemonics.meaning: Inside the "<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Good</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Building</mark>" there's a single <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">guy</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You talk to that guy. The only thing he does is offer you roe (ろう).

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yoga</mark> class uses a special <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">brush</mark> to stay <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">healthy</mark>. She rubs the brush on her long arms and legs, and she never ever gets sick.
mnemonics.reading: Not everyone wants to be healthy, but Ken (けん) the samurai sure does. He needs to be ready at a moment's notice so he can do tasks for other people. He's at every class, rubbing himself down with the brush.

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> you've left some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stairs</mark>. This is how you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">invite</mark> people into your place.
mnemonics.reading: You've invited people in by leaving grain on the stairs but some youths (ゆう) have ended up eating all the grain.

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">substitute</mark> some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> for collateral so your friend will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lend</mark> you some money. Normally he would ask for something more valuable, but you’ve convinced him to substitute these shellfish for what he would normally take as collateral when lending to people.
mnemonics.reading: You want your friend to lend you some money so you can buy yourself a car (か). You need money and a car a lot more than you need this pile of shellfish, so you’re happy to put them up as collateral for the loan.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark>s in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">village</mark> you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">long for</mark>. It's the village you're from, and no matter how far you go, no matter how old you get, your soul is still there, and you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">yearn</mark> for it.
mnemonics.reading: No matter how much you long for it, you can't go back because a cougar (あこが) is in the way. Whenever you try to return to your village to be reunited with the soul you yearn for, a cougar is back, and won't let you in.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> who has his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>, has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> that is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">misguided</mark>. First of all, he tries to drink his problems away, but worse, he's so drunk he's trying to drink out of the ground.
mnemonics.reading: Nowadays we don't say misguided, we say wack (わく). Like, damn that drunkard is so messed up, he's wack.

mnemonics.meaning: When your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sick</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mama</mark> tries to do a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">task</mark> she's filled with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pain</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: Your mama's pain is too (つう) much for her to handle, so now you have to do all of her tasks too.

mnemonics.meaning: If you're on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> and you run over a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">root</mark>, you'll need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">retreat</mark>. The roots have obviously <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">reject</mark>ed you, they want you to leave, so you should.
mnemonics.reading: You're trying to retreat by scooting backwards, but the roots grab onto your tie (たい). You try to pull your tie off but it's just getting tighter and tighter around your neck.

mnemonics.meaning: When you ride a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> you'll have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">surplus</mark> of possible <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">route</mark>s. Not only can you drive on any road, but you can ride on the sidewalk too!
mnemonics.reading: You decide to take the fastest route, since you have so many options, and drive on the sidewalk. However, in doing so you run over every single toe (と) on every single person trying to walk there.

mnemonics.meaning: Take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leather</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">change</mark> it into <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shoes</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Some shoes aren’t made from leather anymore these days, but you know who always wears shoes made of leather? Old coots (くつ). Old coots are so old that the only shoes they wore growing up were made from leather so they refuse to wear any shoes that aren’t made from leather. Crazy old coots.

mnemonics.meaning: Closing each <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark> is something that the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">peoples</mark> do before they <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sleep</mark>. The peoples can’t sleep with both eyes open and they can’t sleep with just one eye open either. Peoples have to close each eye before they can sleep.
mnemonics.reading: The reason you want to sleep is because all the other peoples were mean (みん) to you. They were so mean that the only way you could get over it was to close your eyes and sleep. You just want to sleep.

mnemonics.meaning: In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> while holding a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">comb</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cage</mark> and sitting on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>, you comb your hair in your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">spare time</mark>. Since you’re in a cage, you actually fashioned this comb yourself, so it’s a little messed up, missing a prong. You’re working on improving it in your spare time, and you also use it to style your mop.
mnemonics.reading: So how did you get in this cage? Well, before you used to comb your hair in your spare time, you used to steal cars (か). You’d stolen many a car in your day, but you finally got caught in the act of stealing a car, and now you’re spending all of your spare time in that cage, just combing your hair.

mnemonics.meaning: Cut this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">comb</mark> up with your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark> and turn it into the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">steps</mark> for some <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stairs</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You slowly work to create these stairs, you have to slice up a lot of combs, and at dawn (だん) they are done!

mnemonics.meaning: If you eat a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> the size of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark>, your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stomach</mark> is going to hurt. All the rice in a rice paddy the size of the moon is way too much rice for anyone to consume. If you do, your stomach is going to ache like crazy.
mnemonics.reading: From the sky, an eagle swoops down and flies right into your distended stomach. Bam! The eagle (い) hits your stomach and you vomit up the entire moon sized rice paddy.

mnemonics.meaning: When someone is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sick</mark> in order to diagnose the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark> cause and treatment, you need to check their <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">symptom</mark>s. You have to be especially careful too, because if you get a symptom wrong, you could kill them!
mnemonics.reading: You need to figure out the symptoms the Shougun (しょう) is having. This is really serious too, so you better be correct about which sickness he has. If something bad happens to the Shougun it will be off with your head.

mnemonics.meaning: This special <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> lets you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> up and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tighten</mark> it without trouble.
mnemonics.reading: You tighten your towel before you eat tater (てい) tots every night. That way it stands up nice and straight next to your eating chair, ready for all that delicious tater tot grease that gets on your fingers.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark>. This color will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">urge</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">compel</mark> you to use it. Scooter companies use colors to get you to do what they want. Some would say they are trying to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">coerce</mark> you, even.
mnemonics.reading: When they urge, compel and coerce you like this, they are hacking (はく) your brain.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone just asked you to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> which <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> they should <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">visit</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You end up saying, "You should visit my home (ほう)." How kind of you!

mnemonics.meaning: Taking a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> and moving to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sound</mark> of the music, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> makes a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">weave</mark> through some fabric. He’s using the thread to weave his clothes back together after he damaged them in a fall down the stairs. You know, because he’s a drunkard.
mnemonics.reading: This drunkard is really chic (しき), but he's just fallen on hard times and has been hitting the bottle pretty hard lately. The piece of clothing he's using the thread to weave back together is one of his fancy chic outfits.

mnemonics.meaning: If your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> is lying in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grass</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure chest</mark>, you're going to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">worry</mark> about it. It's just sitting there, out in the open, waiting for anyone to come and open it.
mnemonics.reading: Unfortunately, you also worry about opening it yourself. You stand in front of the chest and think, "Should I open it? Nah, yah (なや). Wait. Nah. Yah. Dang, you can't make up your mind.

mnemonics.meaning: You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> by the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">exit</mark> letting you know to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">yield</mark>. There’s cross traffic just outside the exit, and the flag lets you know that you need to yield to them.
mnemonics.reading: Even though the flag told you to yield, you’re starting to lose your patience. The people walking outside the exit are all a bunch of crazy old coots (くつ)! These crazy coots keep walking right in front of the door, getting in the way. The old coots aren’t even going anywhere, they just keep looping around to obstruct the way!

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Construction</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> leads to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">aggression</mark>. Just think about it. It's cold, it's unpleasant, and you don't want to be there. So, you start to develop an aggression towards other people working with you on this winter project.
mnemonics.reading: You're taking your aggression out on everyone. Then, the sexy construction worker from WaniKani Level 1, こういち, walks by without a shirt on. You take out all your aggression on him.

mnemonics.meaning: If someone is coming toward you in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark>, holding a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark> in their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hand</mark>, they're going to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">attack</mark> you!
mnemonics.reading: Right before the attack begins, you recognize the hand holding this weapon and driving this car. It's Gecki (げき), your long-lost gecko who you may or may not have let fly off into a really fierce tsunami. Oops. I think he may be here attacking you out of revenge.

mnemonics.meaning: After a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark>, you find an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> next to some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark> on the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">beach</mark>. The tsunami was pretty violent, and it looks like this axe got blown into some fish and cut off their fins and now those things are just on the ground by the beach.
mnemonics.reading: Walking down the beach a bit more, you also find a hammer (はま). Gosh, looks like the tsunami hit a workshop or a hardware store or something. First the axe, now a hammer.

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">odd</mark>, but that's what makes it <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">beautiful</mark>. It's a little frayed, it's a little miscolored, but that's what makes it appealing to you.
mnemonics.reading: You take this beautiful thread and lock it up with a key (き). You want to keep it all to yourself, you want its beauty to be for your eyes only!

mnemonics.meaning: There are some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> next to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">plate</mark> that are meant to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">benefit</mark> everyone. If you're a member of this town, one of your benefits is this little set up.
mnemonics.reading: Another benefit is free 駅 (えき) usage! Whenever you come back home from places on the train, this 駅 is completely free.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> can't resist the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">call</mark> of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bog</mark>. Whenever a tsunami is headed toward land, a bog will always call out to it, "Hey tsunami, don't you want to hit me with your water? Come this way~"
mnemonics.reading: As you listen to the bog's call you realize it looks just like the Numa (ぬま) Numa guy in your mind. You open your eyes and it's just a bog. You close your eyes, and there he is. The Numa Numa guy.

mnemonics.meaning: Pointing your magic solar powered wishing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stick</mark> at the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>, you attain the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">legs</mark> of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">child</mark>. You’re old and want young legs to carry you around, so you took your wishing stick that’s powered by the sun, and you wished for the legs of a child.
mnemonics.reading: As you delight in your new legs, Jesus (じ) descends from the sky. “My child,” he says, “why have you pointed the stick at the sun and wished for the legs of a child? You were already perfect, just as all of God’s children are perfect.”

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">before</mark> were <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">complete</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: To have your complete fingers back, you gotta run to the hospital solo (そろ).

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> protecting your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark> and the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> protecting your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> are both protected by the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">constitution</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Your country's constitution is being protected by none other than Ken (けん) the samurai, hero for hire.

mnemonics.meaning: You got your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ice</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">orders</mark>. Of course, your ice orders are to make things <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cool</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cold</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: How will you make things cool and cold? You'll use a special ray (れい) gun that shoots a cold ray.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">table</mark> would be an odd thing to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">deal with</mark>. Winter can be hard to deal with on its own, but turn your table into winter? Just dealing with your food getting cold would be the worst!
mnemonics.reading: This winter table is something you have to deal with, sure, but what if you just gave it to a circus show (しょ)? They like weird stuff like this.

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark>, reading off the digits of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pi</mark> on this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> morning. The cold mountain air is so <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">delicate</mark>, and changes only in very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tiny</mark> ways — just like pi when you add another digit to it.
mnemonics.reading: Ah! Of course! The delicate bumble bee (び). Slightly out of place in winter, but this tiny creature is your idea of delicate. It lands on your finger, and you look at every tiny fiber of its being.

mnemonics.meaning: You wear a great big <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> on it, and head to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">specialty</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">exhibition</mark> for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gambling</mark>. The big cross and drop on your chest is your badge for being admitted into the exhibition. Everyone at the specialty exhibition has a cross and drop, and everyone is gambling.
mnemonics.reading: You’re not very good at gambling, but you are pretty good at cheating. You hack (はく) the specialty exhibition gambling machines to pay out lots of cash just for you. You hack quickly and quietly, so luckily no one notices that you’ve hacked the system.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Grain</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Mouth</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">King</mark> pours grain from his mouth for you and his other subjects. You go to him and pull his finger. When you do this, grain pours from his mouth. But we were greedy. We didn't understand the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">extent</mark> to which we were harvesting his mouth wheat.
mnemonics.reading: The extent to which we were harvesting grain from his mouth was too great. The Grain Mouth King has run out of grain. He worries he will lose power if he has no grain to offer, so he switches to barfing out tater (てい) tots instead.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Ice</mark> from the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">east</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">frozen</mark>. Well, of course, all ice is frozen, but ice from the east is like, really super frozen.
mnemonics.reading: Japan is a country in the east, and this ice was frozen in とうきょう. とうきょう is really good at freezing frozen things, so it makes sense that this frozen ice came from there.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">giant</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">giant</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Massive!
mnemonics.reading: Just recently, a giant rampaged through Little Kyoto (きょ), so now it's even smaller than before. Poor Little Kyoto.

mnemonics.meaning: Only give <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark>s to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> if it's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">immature</mark>. Adult turkeys should be eating healthier things, like insects and grass. But immature turkeys don't care if they get fat, so they whine and whine and whine until you give them grains.
mnemonics.reading: Another thing immature turkeys (and people) love is cheese (ち). Most of us non-immature people and birds still like cheese, but if you didn't have an immature cheese phase as a kid or teen, you won't be able to like cheese as a mature old person.

mnemonics.meaning: Super <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poop</mark> is a super <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> you have in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">infancy</mark>. Those in infancy have the power to poop at will, whenever and wherever they please. Infancy poop power!
mnemonics.reading: In infancy, one eats a lot of soft foods, such as yogurt (よう). Yogurt is the food item above all others that grants superior pooping power.

mnemonics.meaning: You stick <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> using them as <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spikes</mark> and you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">line up</mark> the horns in a straight line. Horns are pretty much the same thing as spikes once you stick them in the ground, and you line these ones up precisely for optimal protection.
mnemonics.reading: As you line up these horns and stick them into the ground, you notice a bull munching on hay (へい) nearby. It's staring at the horns you're lining up. Somehow it feels like it's munching that hay angrily. You gulp, looking at its horn as it grabs another mouthful of hay, and you feel pretty guilty.

mnemonics.meaning: If you know the radical meaning <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lovely</mark>, you know the kanji meaning <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lovely</mark> as well!
mnemonics.reading: "Lovely" is the name of my ray (れい) gun. It's more lovely than any other thing.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> is using a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stick</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> made of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark>. This is the stick of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mastering</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">repair</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: What's the key to mastering any skill? A stick and a shoe (しゅう)!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">odd</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">odd</mark> kanji are the same. They're both... really <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">strange</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You're odd too, just like this kanji. But you don't want anyone to know, so you lock away your strange habits with a key (き).

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> is one of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">few</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">peculiar</mark> things in the world. Everything but a woman can be explained and made sense of. There are only a few truly peculiar things in this world, with woman being one of them.
mnemonics.reading: But when you think about it, we're all a little peculiar. Me, you, myou (みょう) everybody!

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Blood</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tofu</mark> make up the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">populace</mark>. Those are the three categories the entire populace fits into, anyway.
mnemonics.reading: The entire populace deserves shoes (しゅう). It's a basic thing all humans should have like flowing blood, hair (somewhere), and tofu to eat.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> that's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blue</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pure</mark>. Some tsunami are other colors, like brown or red because they aren't pure, they'll full of trash and poop and other horrible things. But a blue tsunami is completely pure!
mnemonics.reading: Seeing this pure blue tsunami inspires you to pull out your glowing blue saber (せい)! As the pure water comes toward you, you take one, long slash!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> takes <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark>, cuts it like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark> through <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark>, and leaves everything behind completely <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pure</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">clean</mark>. Everything is dead and gone, wiped clean off the face of the earth, thanks to the tsunami. It's back to the way it was before humans were here, completely undefiled.
mnemonics.reading: After the tsunami pulls away, everything left is pure white. You hate this, so you run over and squirt ketsup (けつ) all over the place to make it not so pure.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark> swam in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark> while his father made a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">record</mark> of it. Wolverine is gold in color because he just won the gold medal in swimming, so now he is gold. Way to go, Wolverine.
mnemonics.reading: Since Wolverine is actually a mutant, he is soon disqualified from his gold medal. His father makes a record of this also. One angry fan threw a rock (ろく) at Wolverine afterwards. Then another threw a rock. And another rock. Before you knew it, everyone was throwing rocks at Wolverine. Wolverine’s dad didn’t step in to help though, he just kept keeping records.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> takes you to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">barracks</mark>, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark>s you off, and then goes in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">reverse</mark> all the way back home in the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">opposite</mark> direction.
mnemonics.reading: Your scooter going in reverse and leaving you here is opposite of what you want. You want to ride it back home when you're done, so you stuff the wheels with Gak (ぎゃく). If you don’t know what Gak is, check out this Gak commercial.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark>, from one <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">evening</mark> to the next <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">evening</mark>, experiences a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shift</mark>. After two evenings, the grain has shifted from one location to another.
mnemonics.reading: This shift is caused by the eagle (い) that wants to eat the grains. Every other evening, the eagle swoops down, shifts the grains (eating a few) and then flies off.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Rice</mark> that is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blue</mark> has a strong <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">spirit</mark>. Our spirits are blue, so if you ever see rice (or other food, or even people) that's blue, you know that's their spirit radiating out!
mnemonics.reading: You want to see the spirit up close, so you take your saber (せい), throw the blue rice in the air, and slice it in half! The rice explodes and blue light fills everything!

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> features <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pig</mark> to represent our <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">squad</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Our squad also wears special ties (たい) with our horned pig on it. And we don't care if you think that's lame, because we're A SQUAD.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> is over your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> because your car is in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">storage</mark> in a large <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">storehouse</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Your car is in this storage warehouse, just sitting there. A 子 (こ) notices this, and decides to take your car on a joyride. You won't notice, right? You never drive it.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gladiator</mark> in front of you draws his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark>. He points the sword at your chest and right when you think everything is about to end, you realize he's pointing the sword at the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ticket</mark> in your hand.
mnemonics.reading: The gladiator happily marks your ticket with his blade, when Ken (けん) the samurai pushes past you. He holds up his own sword, challenging the gladiator, who just shakes his head and points at your ticket again.

mnemonics.meaning: Using a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hat</mark>, four <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">person</mark>s with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> make an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">umbrella</mark>. The hat is big enough to be an umbrella for all four people, so it makes sense. All four of them are religious missionaries, so that's why they're holding the cross under the "umbrella."
mnemonics.reading: You know the Spanish phrase "Mi casa (かさ) es su casa"? Well, this is kind of like that, but only with a hat. And that hat is also an umbrella. Mi casa es yours too, because it's an umbrella and also a hat. This makes sense, trust me.

mnemonics.meaning: That <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> dressed as <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark> with her <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> wrapped in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> is your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wife</mark>. You're cosplaying together!
mnemonics.reading: Your wife suddenly looks at you and calls you a fool (ふ). Wuh! Then you look down and see that you're also dressed as Wolverine.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> you'd want to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kiss</mark> is one that would probably have a cool <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">abbreviation</mark> for their name, like Ri'-Pad. Yeah, that's definitely a cool abbreviation!
mnemonics.reading: An abbreviation like Ri'-Pad is sure to get a strong reaction (りゃく) — some will find it a little pretentious, some will hate it, but most will probably think it's really cool.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Grain</mark>s get <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blame</mark>d for how much they <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">accumulate</mark>. If the grains accumulate too much then they make more work for the farmers. If they accumulate too little, then they're starving the people. Ugh, grains just can't win with you people. They're blamed for everything.
mnemonics.reading: Now the grains have accumulated a ton, they're overflowing in their grain sacks, and the farmer freezes and says, "Now those are some sexy (せき) grains."

mnemonics.meaning: There’s a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heaven</mark> and you take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">small</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of water and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">append</mark> it to the tsunami. Now the tsunami is big enough to destroy all of heaven. The small drop that you appended to the tsunami was just enough to push it over the edge, reaching full destruction capability.
mnemonics.reading: Just after you append the small drop of water to the tsunami, it grows ten (てん) stories high. Before it was only nine, but since you appended that drop, the tsunami is now a full ten stories tall.

mnemonics.meaning: Under a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark>, but still in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> is laying out a fabulous <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">banquet</mark>. The woman doesn't want anyone to burn from the sun, but banquets are best outside, so she's set up a roof to protect her and her guests.
mnemonics.reading: Unfortunately, the banquet roof comes crashing down right before the guests arrive, and it ends (えん) before it can start.

mnemonics.meaning: If you're a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">anti</mark> (someone who's against trees), then you won't mind if turn all of them into <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">board</mark>s! Hahaha!
mnemonics.reading: The Tree Lovers Association has one word when they see you turning trees into boards: "Banned (ばん)," they shout at you. "Boards mean you're banned!"

mnemonics.meaning: In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> you place a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> and surround it with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> made of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clothes</mark> to keep it safe, but this net tends to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">break</mark>. Of course it breaks, it's just some clothes you tied together.
mnemonics.reading: You realize what keeps making your net break are kayaks (かい). The cross and net are right next to a river trail that kayakers do their kayaking in, and every time they go by their paddles smack into your net and break it.

mnemonics.meaning: A good <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> will use <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">charcoal</mark> to mark her <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">colleague</mark>s. Sometimes if leaders aren't around all the time, people will get rebellious and act badly toward people who can get them in trouble. So when you mark them with charcoal you know that someone close with your leader is around and you should probably stop being a butt.
mnemonics.reading: You have to be good around her colleagues, because if you aren't your row (りょう) boat permit will be taken away. Row boating is the only fun you ever get to have, besides learning kanji. So act as best you can around the leader's colleagues so you don't lose your row boat rights.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">not</mark> a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cup of liquid</mark> or a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">counter for cups</mark>. Don’t get them mixed up. The last time you tried making a cup out of a tree to count your throat got filled with splinters when you used it. There wasn't even any liquid in it.
mnemonics.reading: Another way to remember the counter for cups using a cup of liquid would be by creating and memorizing a haiku (はい) about them. Aren’t haikus useful?

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> who is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">good</mark> is my <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">daughter</mark>. My daughter is a good woman, I guarantee it.
mnemonics.reading: Your daughter, on the other hand, is not a good woman. Your daughter looks like a moose who may (むすめ) not be able to find its way out of a wet paper bag. Your daughter looks like a moose who may lose its way without a map. Your daughter looks like a moose who may do lots of stupid things.

mnemonics.meaning: They <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> to wear a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hat</mark> to cover your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark> if your doctor <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">diagnose</mark>s you with hair loss. It's the best option, folks.
mnemonics.reading: You just had the doctor diagnose you with hair loss. How terrible! You stumble out of the room, dumbfounded. Not paying attention, you bang your shin (しん) on the table. Your shin really hurts. What an awful day.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Above</mark> you on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">small</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark> of the one who will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">direct</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">supervise</mark> you at work. He’s really high above you, so all you can see is the glint of his supervising eye. But you can hear him shouting directions clearly, telling you exactly what to do.
mnemonics.reading: A man who can direct others so well must be Tokugawa (とく) Ieyasu. Sure enough, when he finally comes down off his stool you see that he’s the ghost of Tokugawa Ieyasu!!! That explains why you could only make out the ghostly gleam of his supervising eye before.

mnemonics.meaning: Under this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> someone <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">odd</mark> is trying to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">draw near</mark> to you. You back up, but they continue to draw near anyway.
mnemonics.reading: They continue to draw near until you can't take it anymore. You run out from under the roof, slam the door closed, and lock it with a key (き).

mnemonics.meaning: In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">morning</mark>, you use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark> on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nose</mark> to make it <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dry</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: This technique for a nice dry nose was invented by Genghis Khan (かん)! Well, not him, but someone who worked under him. You see, he had a bit of a damp nose problem.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">district</mark> that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lack</mark>s things will be in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Europe</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Europe is lacking so much because their 王 (おう) keeps taking everything.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">saw</mark> cuts into your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> and you are filled with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fear</mark>. Well, you were filled with fear before the saw reached your heart too, but now that the saw is cutting into your heart, you’re feeling more fear than ever.
mnemonics.reading: Even more so than your fear of dying, you are filled with the fear that you’ll never get to vacation in きょうと. You always wanted to take a trip to きょうと, but if you die from this saw wound to the heart, you’ll never get the chance to go.

mnemonics.meaning: An <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">animal</mark> eats a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark> from a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">plate</mark> in a very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fierce</mark> manner. This is a fierce animal, so it makes sense that it would eat the child in a fierce style.
mnemonics.reading: The reason this fierce animal is eating the child from the plate is because the child forgot to mow (もう) the animal’s lawn. The fierce animal had hired the child to mow his lawn today, and when the child forgot to do it, the fierce animal hunted the child down and ate him.
