mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> rolls in and destroys all the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark> that was being done on the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">inlet</mark> and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bay</mark>. Both the inlet and the bay were having a lot of construction done on them to repair the damage from the last tsunami, and then another tsunami rolled in and destroyed all that too. Bummer.
mnemonics.reading: Imagine the Japanese people standing on the bay and the inlet as the tsunami approaches. “Eh (え)? What is that, Akiko?” “Eh? Where? Oh gawd, it’s a tsunami!!”

mnemonics.meaning: In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">morning</mark>, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Korea</mark> will still be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Korea</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Korea is still here today on this beautiful morning because of Genghis Khan (かん). When he was conquering all that land in Asia and Europe he looked at Korea in the morning light and said, "Nah, they can keep it."

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">narwhal</mark> is meeting in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> with the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> so they can, uh, show each other some private things. Doing this they realize they're both <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">male</mark>! You gotta be pretty <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">manly</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">brave</mark> to do something like that.
mnemonics.reading: These male animals are obviously experimenting with things still. Ah, they must be youths (ゆう)! To be a youth, again!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mysterious</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mysterious</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: There is no one more mysterious than Genji (げん). He's tall, dark, handsome, and most of all... 〜mysterious〜!

mnemonics.meaning: On every <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boat</mark> there is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">table</mark> that's used for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">navigation</mark>. When you take the lid off, there is a big map, a sextant, and some little boat miniatures. All the navigation tools.
mnemonics.reading: You watch the navigation equipment roll away and then you feel a slap on the back of your head. Ouch! You turn around and there stands こういち, who you took with you as the navigator of this expedition. And, you just lost all his stuff!

mnemonics.meaning: To the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">servant</mark> you say: "<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark>, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">plate</mark>." It is your job to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">oversee</mark> everything they do.
mnemonics.reading: Why must you oversee everything? Because you are Genghis Khan (かん), and Genghis Khan oversees everything.

mnemonics.meaning: There’s an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark> in that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> and you do everything in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">recommend</mark> that we don’t eat the turkey. There’s an arrow in this turkey. The arrow looks a little broken, so there’s probably splinters all up inside that turkey. I know you’re all hungry but I can’t recommend eating this bird.
mnemonics.reading: You recommend the Genghis Khan (かん) special instead of this arrow-tainted turkey! When it comes out, your heart sinks. Genghis Khan apparently ate a cow with an arrow broken off in it.

mnemonics.meaning: Under this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark> your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">religion</mark> into people.
mnemonics.reading: Your religion requires everyone to take off their shoes (しゅう). Mostly because the shoes will help them resist the jackhammering, so you tell them that to join your religion they have to leave their shoes at the door.

mnemonics.meaning: If what you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> comes out <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blue</mark>, everyone knows that means you made a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">request</mark>. You request a favor and the words slide out of your mouth in a bright, blue blob. They hover in front of you for a few seconds, before splashing onto the person you made the request to.
mnemonics.reading: The next time someone requests something from you, take out your saber (せい) and slice it in half!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">narwhal</mark> was sucked into its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark>, which is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">scary</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: As you watch this scary scene you can't help but mutter, "Fool," (ふ) under your breath. Then you hear "Fool, fool, fool, it's too scary you fool!" and you realize all of the other narwhals are chanting.

mnemonics.meaning: There is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> attached to it, forcing you to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">search</mark> where it leads. You’re not sure how the cross got stuck in your forehead, but you are interested in seeing where this piece of thread leads. The search is on.
mnemonics.reading: Your search is over. You found the end of the thread. The thread leads you to a sack (さく). A sack filled with more crosses with more threads attached to them. What does it all mean!?!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">servant</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">servant</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Just remember that the kanji also means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">retainer</mark> and you’ll be fine.
mnemonics.reading: Your servant, also known as your retainer, bangs his shins (しん) all the time so you make him wear jeans (じん) to work now. He bangs his shins on all the furniture in the house, knocking over all your valuables. But at least when he’s wearing jeans it doesn’t leave bruises like it did when he wasn’t wearing pants.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark>s is our <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sponsor</mark>. He's paying us to say and type everything you're reading.
mnemonics.reading: This same sponsor is also how you made your cyborg (さい). You didn't think you were able to get all those body parts yourself, did you? No no, the leader of the mountain turkeys sponsored you so you could do your experiments.

mnemonics.meaning: If <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> and more <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> is all you see as you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">go</mark> from place to place, you must be roaming the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">streets</mark> of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">city</mark>. Cities are notoriously dirty places, so watch your step when you head out into the streets.
mnemonics.reading: As you roam the streets, brushing the dirt off yourself, a guy (がい) bumps into you: "Hey guy, watch where you're going!" As he says this he bumps into another guy. "Whoa there, guy — you think you own these streets or somethin'?" "As a matter of fact, my guy, I run these streets, so you'd better check yourself."

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Say</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">good luck</mark> to one person enough and they'll be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stuffed</mark> full of that luck.
mnemonics.reading: You stuffed them by saying good luck two (つ) whole times!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">servant</mark> sits on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>, holding a piece of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark>, looking very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tense</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You ask the servant why they're so tense, and they say they've been assigned to assassinate the King (きん) of England with this piece of thread.

mnemonics.meaning: At the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gate</mark>, you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kiss</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">the cabinet</mark> members, one by one. In order to gain access to this government building, you have to kiss all the members of the cabinet at the gate. What a strange ritual.
mnemonics.reading: You need to kiss each member of the cabinet to gain access to their building. And you need to get into the building to recover your cock (かく). Your prize winning cock has been captured by a member of the cabinet and you need to infiltrate their headquarters and recover your rooster!

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> sees your bare <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">foot</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">urge</mark>s you to put a sock on it.
mnemonics.reading: As urged, you put a sock (そく) on your foot. Ahh, that feels so much better. What a great thing, this sock.

mnemonics.meaning: When a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yakuza</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark>s, you know something very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">violent</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">intense</mark> is about to happen.
mnemonics.reading: When someone gets violent or intense, they always yell "Let's (れつ) get violent and intense!"

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">demon</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jet</mark> is pretty <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">alluring</mark>. Demons themselves are pretty intriguing, but put one on a jet? Now that’s alluring.
mnemonics.reading: This alluring demon on a jet wants one thing and one thing only. Meat (み). Human meat. This demon needs human meat to survive so he is taking his jet into the city to feast on some meat.

mnemonics.meaning: You fly <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">north</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> and break your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">back</mark> when you finally land on it. You weren’t braced for impact so when you hit the moon, your back took all of the impact.
mnemonics.reading: Your back hurts so much that the only way to properly explain the pain is in haiku (はい) form.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horse</mark> gets trapped in a small room with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> and an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark>, and together they create a very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">boisterous</mark> situation. The horse and the insect are both scrambling frantically to get out of the small room, knocking the stool around all over the place.
mnemonics.reading: At the height of their boisterous sounds, there's a sudden, awful CRONCH(!) and you see the soul (そう) of the insect slowly rising out of the room, through the ceiling.

mnemonics.meaning: When you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eat</mark> you want to see the shape of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark> from under a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark>, so you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">decorate</mark> your house with them.
mnemonics.reading: If you actually decorate your house like this it will give people quite a shock (しょく). In fact, they might be so shocked they run out of there screaming.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Beforehand</mark>, to buy a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark>, you have to go to the bank to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">deposit</mark> enough money. If you don't deposit your money you won't have enough in your account to buy one! They're expensive, after all.
mnemonics.reading: You go to the bank to make the deposit, and there is a kid standing in your way playing with a yo-yo (よ). You try to squeeze past and he hits you in the face with the yo-yo. Now you can't even see, let alone make the deposit.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hits the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>, where you're in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark> trying to catch some of it before it starts to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dry up</mark>. Being in prison on the sun means your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">thirst</mark> is truly great, and this spoon will help you quench it when the tsunami comes.
mnemonics.reading: This method of quenching your thirst reminds you of being in a car wash (かわ). The water pours over you in waves, and you're stuck inside a metal cage. Totally the same thing as a car wash, right?

mnemonics.meaning: If you're a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">one-sided</mark> paper <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">anti</mark> (someone against one-sided paper), then you should bind all those one-sided papers into an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">edition</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The first edition you create is a fan fiction all about the adventures of Han (はん) Solo. You hated how short and one-sided his story in Star Wars seemed to be, and trying to keep track of it all was really hard. But not anymore!

mnemonics.meaning: You've made yourself a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bookshelf</mark> (that is, a bookshelf cut into a tree), so you build a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fence</mark> to keep the riffraff out.
mnemonics.reading: On your fence, you hang up a sack (さく) to accept donations.

mnemonics.meaning: Traveling in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> of the ocean, you take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark> and shoot a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">crab</mark>, then stick a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">flag</mark> in the beach and claim it as your own. The crab was the only thing standing in the way of you conquering the area. Now that the flag is in the ground, no one can dispute who it belongs to.
mnemonics.reading: To make sure that no one removes your flag, you lock it to one of the lifeguard posts and you throw away the key (き). Since no one will have the key to unlock the flag, no one will be able to remove it.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> knocks a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cleat</mark> off a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark> and the shoe begins to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">float</mark> away in the water. This child was just out playing soccer, minding his own business, when the tsunami crashed in and knocked his cleats off his feet. Now the cleat is floating away with the tsunami.
mnemonics.reading: While you float in the water, an uni (う) jabs into your foot. “Uwaaa~ (うわ)” you cry. That uni really hurts. They’re all spikey and painful and junk. “Uwaaaa~”

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">run</mark> every day and soon you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">become</mark> a human that can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">go beyond</mark> the normal speed limits of man. You run and you run and you run. This training allows you to become super human. You go beyond the limits of a normal human. You become a human who can run really fast.
mnemonics.reading: To solidify your ability to go beyond the abilities of other humans, you etch (えつ) sacred runes into your legs to preserve your running abilities. Etching these runes makes sure that your skills will never deteriorate.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> is being <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">call</mark>ed on to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark> the earth by <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">illuminating</mark> it.
mnemonics.reading: The person who calls the sun asking it to illuminate the earth is the Shougun (しょう). It's very specifically the Shougun's responsibility to make sure the earth is illuminated every morning.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> rips a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> off your house in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rain</mark>, causing a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">leak</mark> where it was ripped out. The rain and the tsunami combined just tore the flag right off your house. The force was so strong that it actually removed part of the wall, and now you have a leak in your home.
mnemonics.reading: The leak is getting worse and worse and so is the tsunami, when you see something outside. It’s a bunch of roe (ろう) floating in the waves. Using your quick thinking skills you scoop it up and shove it into the cracks where the water is leaking in. It works like a charm!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lineage</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lineage</mark> kanji are the same. Sometimes this kanji can also mean <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">system</mark>. I guess a lineage is a kind of system, if you think about it.
mnemonics.reading: You trace your lineage back through your whole family system and realize every single relative loved cake (けい). Most of them were cake bakers too!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">servant</mark> holding a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark> sits on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">see</mark> if he can find something to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">look at</mark>. The servant is on watch duty and has the gun to protect the perimeter. He patrols the grounds to look at the distance to see if there are any trespassers.
mnemonics.reading: You start backing away, but then you realize that you are Macho Man Randy (らん) Savage. Randy Savage backs away from no fight! I mean, look at this guy – this servant guy. Take away the gun and he’s not much to look at. You can take him.

mnemonics.meaning: You meet a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> from another <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clan</mark> under the rising <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> to prepare for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">marriage</mark>. Your clan and her clan are standing together as the two of you watch the sun rise together.
mnemonics.reading: For the marriage to be official, you need to wait for a condor (こん) to appear. If it doesn't show up before the sun goes down again, the marriage was a failure. You have to try again tomorrow with a different woman.

mnemonics.meaning: Who is this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mole</mark>?! It's your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">niece</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: Not only are they moles, all of your nieces were also born in May (めい)!

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> will <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> through your body and into the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clothes</mark> so that you'll be hit with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">nostalgia</mark> when you wear them again. Nostalgia for all the things that happened every single time you wore those clothes.
mnemonics.reading: This nostalgia ties knots (なつ) in your stomach and your chest. Even if the memories and feelings weren't particularly bad, there's something about the wistful feeling of nostalgia that knots up your insides.

mnemonics.meaning: Point some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> at the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> and put some others in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ear</mark> as you sit on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> — now you can have your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">photograph</mark> taken. This is a glamour <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">photo</mark>, so you have to be in one of these weird, artsy poses for it to come out juuust right.
mnemonics.reading: As you're getting the photograph taken, the photographer tells you to say Satsuki (さつ). He says it's like saying cheese but more effective. Satsuki!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pirate</mark> jumps from a tree and attacks you by hitting you with a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pillow</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: As he hits you with his pillow he makes a demand: "Give me your Mac cooler (まくら). He wants the device that cools down your Mac computer.

mnemonics.meaning: On a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> running in one <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark>-toting <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark>. This is a terribly dangerous situation, but to the child it is just <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">play</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Everything is play for youths (ゆう), even if it's a terrible, scary, not good situation like this one.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">person</mark> has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hook</mark> that can make them <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pleasant</mark>. When you see, hear, or feel something pleasant, can't you feel that hook pressing into the middle of your body?
mnemonics.reading: If you want to feel this pleasant feeling just look at a kayak (かい). Kayaks are the most pleasant boats in the world. Feel that pleasant feeling in your chest just from reading about kayaks in this mnemonic right now.

mnemonics.meaning: Those that can only eat a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">part</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> are probably a bit <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">poor</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: And since they are poor, they are getting these shellfish parts from the trash bin (びん). It's quite unfortunate.

mnemonics.meaning: If you do <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yoga</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark>ly, you will not only <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">prolong</mark> your body but your life!
mnemonics.reading: You can prolong your life with correct yoga techniques, but unfortunately, if you ever stop doing yoga after you've started this prolonging process, it will just end (えん) suddenly.

mnemonics.meaning: You give a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lifeguard</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">purchase</mark> their services. You think lifeguards are interested in normal money? Come on, they're obviously out there using shellfish for their purchases. It's only natural, given their seaside habitat.
mnemonics.reading: This time you purchase some こういち goods. You know, since you're such a fan. How else can you show love in this world, if not through purchases? The lifeguard hands over a little haul of こういち plushies and figurines. Nice.

mnemonics.meaning: Take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark>, put them on this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turtle shell</mark>, and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">push</mark> push push! Push the turtle right on out of there.
mnemonics.reading: You're trying to push this turtle out so you can use the shell for your new obi (お). You keep seeing other people wearing turtle shell patterns on their obi, but you're going to go a step further. You're going to MAKE your obi out of actual turtle shells! You just have to push this darn turtle out first.

mnemonics.meaning: If you look for a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leaf</mark> among the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hills</mark> you will notice they are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">scarce</mark>. The hills have no trees around them, so there are no leaves. The leaves are scarce here on the hills.
mnemonics.reading: Still looking for a leaf, you determine that they are far too scarce to find here. Just before you give up, you discover a giant bowling (ぼう) ball. As you pick it up, another one comes thundering down the hill knocking over a tiny tree.

mnemonics.meaning: You're stuck in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> with nothing but a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark>, and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">smell</mark> in here is so bad you’re using the prison spoon to waft it outside as best you can.
mnemonics.reading: You can’t believe how awful these smells are. You’re new in prison, so you call them all neo-smells (にお). They're neo, they're new to you.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">next</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">plate</mark> is the one you will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">steal</mark>. This one would be too obvious, better wait for the next one.
mnemonics.reading: You steal this plate from a とうきょう restaurant, so after you steal it, picture yourself running through the streets of とうきょう as you lose your pursuers.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mohawk</mark>, now that's the most <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">suitable</mark> hairstyle you could ever think of for a scooter!
mnemonics.reading: You want this suitable hairstyle for your scooter too, and luckily you're a techie (てき), so it's easy for you to install one.

mnemonics.meaning: Whenever all the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">feathers</mark> start <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark>ing, you know it's time for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">the next</mark> day. Once the day comes to its end, all feathers start standing up like clockwork.
mnemonics.reading: With the next day approaching and all feathers standing up, you get ready to drink your usual liter of yolk (よく). Yes, you heard that right.

mnemonics.meaning: You take some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">attach</mark> it together into a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">token</mark> of appreciation for your friend. Your friend greatly appreciates this token of friendship.
mnemonics.reading: You hand over the token but your friend drops it and yells, "You fool (ふ)! I'm allergic to bamboo!"

mnemonics.meaning: If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hits, it's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rain</mark>ing, and you're outside trying to use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rake</mark>, you're going to be very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wet</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">damp</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You can't stand how wet and damp you feel in these clothes so you rip them off and rake in the nude (ぬ)!

mnemonics.meaning: There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark> coming out of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> that you want to climb, but your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> needs a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> for all your sweat. You don't have a towel, so you take off your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">belt</mark> and tie it around your forehead.
mnemonics.reading: The belt isn't absorbent enough, so you wrap it in your tie (たい) and then tie the whole thing around your forehead again.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">guy</mark> is a guy who stands in the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">corridor</mark> trying to sell people canopies.
mnemonics.reading: You take the corridor, but this time the canopy guy is gone. In his place is a new salesman. This one is trying to sell you roe (ろう).

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rocket</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> has several points which will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">detach</mark> during takeoff.
mnemonics.reading: When the rocket turkey parts detach, they fall to the ground onto a bed of reeds (り).

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark> around a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tombstone</mark> to measure its <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">diameter</mark>. You’re doing this to each tombstone, and if you loiter around long enough, you’ll soon know the diameter of every tombstone.
mnemonics.reading: You need to know the diameter of each tombstone so you can make cakes (けい) for each one. But the cakes can't be wider than the tombstones, or they'll flop off onto the ground.

mnemonics.meaning: You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bully</mark> take an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dissolve</mark> it in some acid. Bullies are messed up, mean people. They do awful things that normal kids and people wouldn't do... like dissolve a living creature.
mnemonics.reading: The only bullies heartless enough to dissolve insects like this are youths (ゆう). Do you really think an adult would melt a harmless critter? No. Only inexperienced youths could be so cruel.

mnemonics.meaning: You have some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> next to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pool</mark> that has an extra <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of water in it because you need them to be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">equal</mark>. If there's too much dirt outside the pool and not enough water inside, it's gonna look weird. We can't have that.
mnemonics.reading: You spend a few hours making sure the water-to-dirt ratio is perfectly equal, not for yourself, but because the King (きん) of England told you to. You may agree that equality is important, but it's the King's responsibility to keep things that way. Which is why he ordered you, small peon, to do the equalizing work for him.

mnemonics.meaning: You put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> on a dish you're cooking, made up of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>s and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark>s of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pig</mark>. This is truly an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">exceptional</mark> dish you are cooking up.
mnemonics.reading: Exceptional pig mouth forehead soup is a favorite of Grandpa ごういち. You see him sniffing around your window, then he knocks and waves.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark>s are at a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">surplus</mark>. Because of that, we will need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">exclude</mark> some of them from our future plans. Also, we'll need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">remove</mark> some buildings too.
mnemonics.reading: Working with you on this project to exclude buildings from the plan, as well as remove buildings that already exist is little Jo-Anne (じょ).

mnemonics.meaning: You want to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">change</mark> your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> into <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">freight</mark> so you can transport it. That means packing them up into giant freight containers.
mnemonics.reading: To move this freight, you need a car (か). You strap all of the freight containers to the top of your car, stacked nice and high and precarious, so you can move it.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark> shares his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lineage</mark> with a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">grandchild</mark>. The child passes his lineage down to his child and then that child’s child is the grandchild and between them all a lineage is shared.
mnemonics.reading: The son (そん) of a son is a grandchild. In this case, a grandson. Easy.

mnemonics.meaning: Inside your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">greenhouse</mark> there's a mound of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> which appears to be someone's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">grave</mark>. When you dig into it, you discover that it's an entire <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tomb</mark>, with doors and passages and everything!
mnemonics.reading: You pry open the grave inside the inner chamber of the tomb, and are shocked to find the mummified body of Bobo (ぼ) the Clown staring back at you! How terrifying!

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poop</mark> twice on a sleeping <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">person</mark> and you find yourself wondering <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">how many</mark> more times you can poop on them and wonder <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">how much</mark> they can take before they realize what’s going on.
mnemonics.reading: As you continue thinking about how much poop this drunkard can take and how many more poops you can drop on him, he begins to wake up. Quickly, you eke (いく) out one last poop before you scurry away. You eke that poop out just in time to make your escape.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark> is doing a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark> job and using his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> to take <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark>s, so he knows how many folks he needs to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">inquire</mark> with about helping him. Using the mouth is a strange way to take measurements, but that's just how Wolverine does things. Once he measures it all out, he'll know how many construction workers he needs to inquire with about working for him.
mnemonics.reading: Another thing Wolverine has to inquire about is jeans (じん). He wants to make sure everyone on the construction site has good-fitting jeans to work in, so he inquires with them about their jean measurements.

mnemonics.meaning: Bring <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">library</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">knit</mark>. Libraries are quiet and generally pretty empty nowadays, so it's the perfect place to relax and do some knitting. Of course, if you find thread lying around in a library you know what to do now.
mnemonics.reading: You need to come to the library to knit because if you try to do it at home all your hens (へん) will try to eat the thread. Hens love eating things that look like worms, like hay, string, and thread. So it's important to get far away from them before you start to knit.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> made from a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">womb</mark> must be placed upon the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">land</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The land around your womb building will, unfortunately, reek (りく) though.

mnemonics.meaning: Put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> and stand your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">legs</mark> high up in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> if you want to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">look for</mark> something. After all, shielding your eyes and getting up high is the best way to look for something, isn’t it?
mnemonics.reading: You look for it for so long that you can't help getting a tan (たん). I mean, you're up some tree, shielding your eyes from the sun as you look for that thing, and it's been hours, days? Of course you're going to get a tan.

mnemonics.meaning: See that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> man <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">oversee</mark>ing everyone? He's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">model</mark> human. His goldenness is a sign of how exemplary he is, and he's overseeing all of us flawed, regular folks to try to help us get on his level.
mnemonics.reading: As you look closer at the golden model human, you realize he's actually Genghis Khan (かん)! No wonder he's covered in gold and overseeing everyone — he's the greatest conqueror in history!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> came in and buried your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> so now you have to use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark> and dig it out of the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mud</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You may know of Dora the Explorer. But have you heard about her dirty, muddy brother, Doro (どろ)? They're like a team. And because of all the exploring he does, Doro is always covered in mud.

mnemonics.meaning: Birds use <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grass</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fruit</mark> to make their <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">nest</mark>s.
mnemonics.reading: The bottom of the nest also seems to be padded with someone's suit (す). Did... did this bird attack a human for this?!

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">line up</mark> your body with the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> and everything looks <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">normal</mark>.  The sun is lined up behind you, and you’re looking at all the things the sun has lit up. Everything looks normal.
mnemonics.reading: Soon you see something that doesn’t look so normal. It’s a fool (ふ), a jester. Dressed all in fool’s garb, this fool is dancing up towards you with a ridiculously unsettling grin on his face.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> will have things <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">obstruct</mark> her path. It's a sad fact that it's still a man's world out there!
mnemonics.reading: This woman is truly magnificent. Some compare her to a bowling (ぼう) ball, because of how she knocks down the obstructions in her path like bowling pins.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spring</mark> that's nice and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark> will make a good <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pole</mark> or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rod</mark>. Break it out of the ground and give it a swing to see what a nice, sturdy <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stick</mark> it is!
mnemonics.reading: After much deliberation, you decide to use this pole to go bowling (ぼう). It's a pretty long pole, so you can just stand at the top of the lane and directly poke the bowling pins with it.

mnemonics.meaning: If you grind <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark>, every <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">part</mark> of it, eventually it will become a fine <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">powder</mark>. You can then use this rice powder as a part to create some other dish. Some kind of cake, perhaps.
mnemonics.reading: Actually, grinding the rice down to a powder is super fun (ふん). It’s so fun you don’t want to stop! AH HAHAHAHA! RICE POWDER! SO FUN!

mnemonics.meaning: There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">root</mark> where your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fang</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">previously</mark> was. Your fang isn't there anymore, you ripped it out.
mnemonics.reading: To remember the beautiful fangs you previously had, you keep all of the ones you pull out in a box you lock with a key (き).

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">request</mark> that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rescue</mark> you from the warmth of the other seasons.
mnemonics.reading: You get a note in the mail from winter! This is it, you're going to be rescued! You open the note and it says, "I have rescued you with this cucumber (きゅう)." A cucumber falls out of the note.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of (odd-looking) <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lion</mark>s puts a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of magic liquid on his face to look like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">person</mark> who <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">resemble</mark>s someone else. The leader of lions is going incognito, so he needs to resemble a person who is not himself. He takes this drop of powerful face paint and transforms.
mnemonics.reading: Now he resembles an even greater leader, and all the lions get down on one knee (に) to pay their respects.

mnemonics.meaning: On your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scarecrow</mark> because you're <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rich</mark>. You want to scare away all the poor, non-rich people so you put a scarecrow on your roof.
mnemonics.reading: You wake up the next morning and all of your riches have been stolen! You call the police and they call you a fool (ふ)! Pardon me?! "You basically put an advertisement on your roof telling everyone you're rich. Of course you got robbed, you fool."

mnemonics.meaning: If you play <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blackjack</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark>, your cards will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">scatter</mark> everywhere. The cards scatter because the gravity is so weak on the moon, so the blackjack game is prone to disaster.
mnemonics.reading: You are playing blackjack with Santa-san (さん). Santa-san is doing his best to use his Christmas magic to prevent the scatter of cards, but it’s not working out so well. Good effort, Santa-san.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Flowers</mark> growing out of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> into the shape of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> are really <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">showy</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">flower</mark>s.
mnemonics.reading: These flowers are too showy. You hate them. You hate these showy flowers so much you run them over with your car (か)!

mnemonics.meaning: You use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> when you see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Chinese</mark> person and you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sigh</mark>. You sigh so loud that it’s practically a roar coming out of your mouth. Chinese people and Chinese things make you sigh because it reminds you of when you stayed in China and it brings up memories. The sigh is a sigh of nostalgia.
mnemonics.reading: Your favorite Chinese thing to do is tan (たん). You can wander around without your shirt on and tan all day. No one will sigh or scoff at you, it’s perfectly acceptable. The Chinese just love to get their tan on.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> sticks his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">toe</mark> into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark>. You ask him why and he says he wants to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">spy</mark> on it.
mnemonics.reading: You and the leader review the spy footage and find a single tater (てい) tot hidden within the shellfish. Together you uncover a huge smuggling ring. Clams, oysters, mussels, you name it! Shellfish of all kinds are using their bodies to sneak tater tots to the undersea world.

mnemonics.meaning: If you can write an interesting <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poem</mark> about <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> while riding on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horse</mark>, I’ll be pretty <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">surprised</mark>. It’s hard enough to write a poem as it is, let alone an interesting one. And then you’re riding on a horse and the poem has to be about winter? Heck, I’d be surprised if you didn’t fall off the horse and injure yourself.
mnemonics.reading: You might also be surprised to learn that you are to ride this horse all across きょうと. That gives you a time limit. You have until you traverse きょうと to write this poem about winter.

mnemonics.meaning: Using his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark>, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark> wraps his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> to get ready to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sweep</mark>. Sweeping floors is hard work! That's why he always puts a towel around his forehead when he sweeps up the mess he made during yet another X-Men fight.
mnemonics.reading: Wolverine knows that sweeping is good for the soul (そう). Plus, if you don't help clean up after you defeat bad guys, you're just as bad as them. Sweeping up the mess cleans your soul of any guilt too!

mnemonics.meaning: You want some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> so you take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cleat</mark> to the side of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> hoping they'll fall down, but you get a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">vegetable</mark> instead. What? You kick the tree again and another, different vegetable falls out.
mnemonics.reading: You feed these vegetables (that you didn't even want) to your cyborg (さい). It only needs a little though, since its stomach is so thin, so you just make it hold the rest.

mnemonics.meaning: Under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> while you sit on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark>, you inject a syringe of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tofu</mark> right into your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">vein</mark>. Ahh, tofu. You're addicted to it. You sneak out to the cliff at night to get your tofu fix, injecting it straight into your vein.
mnemonics.reading: Eventually, your friends and family find you at the cliff, tripping on tofu. Each and every vein on your body is engorged, pulsating with the effects of tofu. Your friends try and take you home. "You cyan't myake (みゃく) me!" you slur, suffering from the effects of the tofu. "None of you cyan myake me go home! You cyan’t myake me! Nyah!"

mnemonics.meaning: You're <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark>ing, staring down at the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> that got caught in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>, because it's trying to teach you to act with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">virtue</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: As you try to decide if you want to live a life of virtue the ghost of Tokugawa (とく) Ieyasu appears before you. He points to your heart and the cross, then points to his own and you see a glowing cross in his own.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">warehouse</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">warehouse</mark> kanji are the same! You can call it a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">storehouse</mark> too.
mnemonics.reading: You have a warehouse to store all of your souls (そう). When people or animals you know pass away, you take their souls and store them in your dry warehouse for safekeeping. It's a public service, really.

mnemonics.meaning: Tie a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> to yourself whenever you take the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blame</mark> for someone. This marks your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">achievement</mark>. Your achievement in blame-taking, I guess. Isn't it a great achievement to selflessly shield others from blame? Of course it is! So these little blame-threads are symbols of your achievement.
mnemonics.reading: But your latest achievement is covering yourself in these threads and everyone thinking it's sexy (せき). The newspapers and fashion mags can't get enough of your sexy style. See? If you're a good person, people will think your achievements are sexy.

mnemonics.meaning: Take some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark> and put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spider</mark> in it to make <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">acid</mark>. Spiders have a little acid in them already, but if you want something really potent, smash one up in some whiskey to make a deadly acid that'll rip through anything.
mnemonics.reading: You're trying to find a container for this acid when Santa-san (さん) bursts through your wall. He frowns down at you. You're on the naughty list now. You killed spiders AND made dangerous acid? Ooooh you're in trouble.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">husband</mark> and his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">husband</mark> find a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">agree</mark> to share it.
mnemonics.reading: Since the husbands were able to agree, Santa-san (さん) believes they’re both good husbands and belong on the good list. Therefore, Santa-san gives them each lots and lots of shellfish for Christmas.

mnemonics.meaning: You come across a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> wearing a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">top hat</mark> and it claims to be your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ancestor</mark>. Well of course, if you remember correctly, all of your ancestors wore top hats when they were alive. This spirit must be your long lost, great great... uh... somebody.
mnemonics.reading: You ask your ancestor what it wants and it points to the soap (そ) by the sink. Soap? It nods at you. I guess your ancestor is here to see the wonders of soap.

mnemonics.meaning: To use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> at the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bar</mark> you need to turn it into a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">coin</mark>. Well, more than one coin, probably. But you know for sure that you can make at least one coin out of the gold you have.
mnemonics.reading: You use the coin to pay a centaur (せん) at the bar. The centaur is the bartender and he makes special drinks for those who pay in gold coins. Good for you!

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">go</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Korea</mark> you'll need a good <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">defense</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You need a good defense to go to Korea, so you fill your pockets with acorns (えい). When you get to Korea you plant them all around yourself. In no time you'll have a strong tree defense, keeping you safe.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> combines with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">table</mark> to make a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">desk</mark>. When you think about it, a desk is just a table with more stuff. To make this more stuff, like drawers and such, you need more wood, and wood comes from trees. Add materials from the tree to the table and you have a desk.
mnemonics.reading: When you finish the desk you turn to your friend and say, “It’s cool, eh (つくえ)?” Your friend looks at you and says, “S’coo’ eh? What?” “This desk, it’s cool. It’s cool, eh?” “Aw, yeah man. S’coo’ eh.”

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hit not one, but <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">TWO</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark>s, making them extremely <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dirty</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: What's the most dirty are the prisons' obi (お) collections. You can hear the prisoners crying, "Oh, not the obi. Our obi are all dirty, oh no!"

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eat</mark> part of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">director</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">domesticate</mark> him. This director has been going around kicking cameramen and punching actors and it’s really ruining his reputation. You need to domesticate him. The only way to do this is to shock him into submission. His ego is so big from two blockbusters that you have to eat part of him to get him to calm down.
mnemonics.reading: While you did succeed in your attempt to domesticate the director, he is now bleeding profusely from the bite wound. All over the script! You gotta get your car (か) and drive him to the hospital like right away. Get to the car! Hurry!

mnemonics.meaning: Put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">black hole</mark> and a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">duplicate</mark> comes out. The duplicate looks exactly like the original spirit that went in. How strange.
mnemonics.reading: Suddenly the duplicate spirit starts yelling, "Why did you throw me into that black hole?! F*** (ふく) you!"

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> runs into <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nine</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>s and produces a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dye</mark> the color of the forest. The tsunami water mixes with each tree, nine of them actually, and the resulting liquid is a forest green dye.
mnemonics.reading: The dye continues to pass through the forest and hits a group of centaurs (せん). Now each centaur is dyed with the forest green dye. They don’t look happy.

mnemonics.meaning: Two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pool</mark>s, both altered and not quite like a pool you’ve seen before are put together and flipped around – this is an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">egg</mark>. One pool is the egg white, the other pool is the egg yolk. They’re different, but similar.
mnemonics.reading: You remember Tamagotchi (たまご), right? Well, Tamagotchi is an egg, and the toy looks like an egg, so it’s pretty easy to remember that tamago means egg.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eternity</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">eternity</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: How long is an eternity? Just look at this little acorn (えい) and ask. The acorn starts small but it grows into a huge tree and can live for all eternity by dropping more acorns to create more trees. Its acorn line will live on forever!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">root</mark> is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">eyeball</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You know who has some pretty good eyeballs? Gandhi (がん). Gandhi used his eyes to see the oppression around him and decided to do something about it. But it's all thanks to his eyeballs.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> that hits at <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">night</mark> leaves even more <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fluid</mark> than normal. It's dark at night, so the sun isn't there to help evaporate all that tsunami <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">liquid</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: This fluid stays in the 駅 (えき) longer than anywhere else. All of those tsunami liquids pour deep inside the 駅 late at night and the sun still can't reach them to help evaporate them during the day. It's a real *night*mare.

mnemonics.meaning: Take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cleat</mark> to dig out bits of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gather</mark> them. Taking your fingers to this cleat is the only way to gather the tree bits stuck in it. Gather them in a big pile… as evidence to examine later.
mnemonics.reading: You gather them all together and realize there are cyborg (さい) parts mixed in with the tree bits. Uh oh, it's as you feared. Your cyborg definitely got into trouble somewhere around here and you walked all over it with your cleats.

mnemonics.meaning: If you look inside a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">samurai</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>, you'll discover their true <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">intention</mark>s and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ambition</mark>s.
mnemonics.reading: You try to read the intentions of the samurai in front of you and they're dark, evil, scary. Oh no! These are the intentions of the sheep (し) samurai!

mnemonics.meaning: There’s a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">comb</mark> and what looks like the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">same</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">comb</mark>, and you found them on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> next to some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark> you showed <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">interest</mark> in. At first, the shiny fins on the ground caught your interest, but once you got closer to the fins you also noticed a pair of combs that are interesting too.
mnemonics.reading: Since the combs interest you more than the fins, you examine the combs more closely. Taking interest in where they were made, you discover they were made in きょうと. Dang, きょうと sure does make some nice combs.

mnemonics.meaning: If you get on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">enter</mark> somewhere, you’re going <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">into</mark> that place.
mnemonics.reading: Once you’ve gone into this place, what do you see? Your 子 (こ)!

mnemonics.meaning: If your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> but your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> is in the right place, people will recognize your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">kindness</mark>. Even if you blabber on with your big mouth, as long as everyone knows that your heart is filled with kindness, they will love and accept you.
mnemonics.reading: To further show your kindness, you chop up some onions (おん) for a friend who always cries when they chop onions. The onions make you cry too, so it's a nice act of kindness that you're toughing it out for your pal.

mnemonics.meaning: If you use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">enter</mark> a building, you'll be sliding for a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">long time</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You slide for such a long time that you get hungry. Luckily, once in a while a cucumber (きゅう) comes tumbling down the slide next to you.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Viking</mark> and his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">older brother</mark> join a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">party</mark>. They can raid and pillage better in a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">group</mark> like this, so it makes sense that the Viking and his older brother would join a group with other Vikings.
mnemonics.reading: This party has decided to raid とうきょう. It’s a large undertaking, but they have a large group of Vikings on the job. とうきょう doesn’t stand a chance.

mnemonics.meaning: If the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> comes <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">beforehand</mark>, it's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">preface</mark> for the rest of the canopy.
mnemonics.reading: You read the preface. It just goes on and on and on about Jo-Anne (じょ), a short lady the author loves very much.

mnemonics.meaning: You count <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nine</mark> of them in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>, each <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> holding something <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">random</mark> or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">miscellaneous</mark>. There are nine turkeys in the tree and they’re all holding random, miscellaneous things. How odd.
mnemonics.reading: As if things couldn’t get any more random, Zazu (ざつ) from the Lion King flies into the tree and starts asking the nine turkeys miscellaneous trivia. Zazu always did have a thirst for knowledge, but this is kind of strange.

mnemonics.meaning: Under a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> sitting on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grass</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> who loves <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sakura</mark>, or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cherry tree</mark>, if you’re an English speaker. This woman really likes to just chill out in the grass under these cherry trees and watch the sakura blossoms. It’s very pretty.
mnemonics.reading: How do you say cherry tree in Japanese? Sakura (さくら). Sakura is Japanese for cherry tree. I’m sure you’ve probably heard this before, so it shouldn’t be too hard to remember.

mnemonics.meaning: Standing on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark>, you're <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">certain</mark> that the nearby <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark> is shrouded in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">secrecy</mark>. But you can't do much about it, stuck on your roof as you are. So much secrecy, but so far away.
mnemonics.reading: This secrecy is so secret that the people who know about it wear magical mitts (みつ) of secrecy that make it so we can't tell anyone, no matter what.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">certain</mark> to keep a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">secret</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: If someone finds out your secret (not from the grain though, it will certainly keep it) then your entire face will fill with heat (ひ).

mnemonics.meaning: If you see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grass</mark>y <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark> with an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">elf</mark> under it in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark>, it's because their parents are so <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">strict</mark>. When elf kids misbehave they're supposed to go stand under grassy cliffs to think about what they've done.
mnemonics.reading: One of the strict parents of this elf kid is... Genji (げん)?! Looks like he had another illegitimate kid... this time with an elf.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> have nothing to do when you're at your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cottage</mark> except <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">throw away</mark> things. Your cottage is for vacation. And vacation means being as lazy as possible. But you certainly don't want to live in filth, so you have to throw away your trash at least.
mnemonics.reading: The number one thing you throw away while in your cottage is your suit (す). Suits just don't fit the cottage vibe, man.

mnemonics.meaning: They <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shrimp</mark> who is bad with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">translation</mark> has no <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">reason</mark> to live. Most shrimp make a living with their translation skills. They are the translators of the ocean. If they don’t know how to say something in all the languages of the sea, they have no reason to live. They might as well be dead.
mnemonics.reading: The translation this shrimp failed to make was for the word “yak” (やく). The shrimp found no reason to translate yak because there are no yak in the sea and then the shrimp just started questioning everything in his life and fell apart.

mnemonics.meaning: In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">valley</mark> you feel a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lack</mark> of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">want</mark>. You want for nothing in this valley. It is the valley of plenty.
mnemonics.reading: Once you get to the valley, you want some protein. Egg yolk (よく) falls from the sky! It’s a miracle! You wanted protein, and egg yolk was presented. It falls right into your open mouth.

mnemonics.meaning: You're in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> playing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">football</mark> and you get very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">warm</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: It's warm like this because it's dawn (だん). That's when the sun comes up.

mnemonics.meaning: In its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cat pirate</mark> scoots up to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">welcome</mark> you!
mnemonics.reading: The cat pirate then launches into a speech about how they welcome all kinds of people. Especially gay (げい) people. He puts a certain emphasis on gay, so you figure that the cat pirate either thinks you're gay or wants you to be.

mnemonics.meaning: If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark> it's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">easy</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wound</mark> people. When you have a gun and a lot of responsibility it's easy to get carried away and mess up, wounding the people you were supposed to be protecting. You can even wound yourself.
mnemonics.reading: Which leader wounded the Japanese people? The Shougun (しょう). The Shougun is a military leader. The Shougun even has gun in the name. And they wounded hundreds of thousands of samurai and soldiers.

mnemonics.meaning: On a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark> burns to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ashes</mark>. The ashes then blow off the cliff, and follow the wind wherever it may go.
mnemonics.reading: The ashes inspire you to write a haiku (はい). Using the ashes you write a haiku on a rock for everyone to enjoy.

mnemonics.meaning: If you see <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">icicle</mark>s hanging off of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">samurai</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clothes</mark>, don't worry, those are just part of his winter <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">attire</mark>. Samurai have to travel and fight in all sorts of conditions, so it only makes sense that they have attire for every season.
mnemonics.reading: Attire like this is important because it reflects your soul (そう). The samurai is wearing clothing with icicles because that's how his heart feels too: frozen over because he has to fight in this horrible winter weather.

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to give <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">someone</mark>, give them to an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">author</mark>. Authors really love flowers, because they help them think of flowery language they can use to sound smart in their books.
mnemonics.reading: Unfortunately, the author is allergic to touching flowers, so they hold them with a pair of chopsticks (ちょ). They hold them real close to their face with the chopsticks, so they can still use them to think of fancy, author-ly words.

mnemonics.meaning: There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">village</mark>, so you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kick</mark> it over on its <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">backside</mark> to see what's on its <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">underside</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: It turns out your village's own backside is covered in uranium (うら). Eureka! You're all gonna be rich!

mnemonics.meaning: You keep your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark> in your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">crotch</mark>. Where else would you keep it?
mnemonics.reading: Your crotch has a moon weapon, and it's served you well, so you hope that if you have a 子 (こ) one day, they'll have one too.

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> is all weird because it looks like the side is going to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dangle</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">drip</mark> off or something. The front bumper of the car is dangling off and the sides of the car look like they could drip off at any moment.
mnemonics.reading: You see the parts as they dangle off the car and you get an idea. You could probably swing (すい) on these dangling parts. The parts can probably take some weight still before they drip off the car, so you might as well swing around on them while you still can.

mnemonics.meaning: Put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">together</mark> with other paddies and you'll see how much they <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">differ</mark>. When you're driving or taking a train through the countryside it may seem like all of those rice paddies blurring together are all the same, but they can differ quite a bit!
mnemonics.reading: To see how rice paddies differ, you need an eagle's (い) eye view. It can be hard to see from the ground, so soar up into the sky like an eagle and look down at the rice paddies together.

mnemonics.meaning: Social commentary aside, the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> is the king that wears all white. Traditionally, this is someone better than a king. The <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">emperor</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: Who is the emperor? It is こういち. こういち the emperor stands over his subjects.

mnemonics.meaning: To make your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wide</mark> you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">extend</mark> them.
mnemonics.reading: As you extend your fingers a cock (かく) comes running by and runs straight into them. Bu-COCK!

mnemonics.meaning: Use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">compare</mark> your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">flatulence</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: How do you read flatulence? Heh(へ)...heh..heh..heheheh. You can't NOT laugh at the word flatulence.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">greenhouse</mark> is already really good when it comes to a plant's livelihood. But add the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> into that equation and you have something really great for the plants. Their <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">livelihood</mark> will be awesome, now!
mnemonics.reading: From out of nowhere, Bobo (ぼ) the notorious clown thief starts picking the plants, ending their livelihood. Bobo needs the flowers for his clown acts, so he uses the livelihood of the flowers to support his own livelihood.

mnemonics.meaning: Those that are in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">middle</mark> of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> are the ones you have the most <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">loyalty</mark> towards. The middle of your heart is the most sacred, special place for people, so it makes sense that those you keep in the middle of your heart are those you are most loyal to.
mnemonics.reading: You pictured Chewbacca (ちゅう), didn’t you? No? Well you should have. Chewbacca deserves everyone’s loyalty. Chewbacca is super loyal to you, so he deserves your loyalty back.

mnemonics.meaning: There is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">city</mark> inside your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lung</mark>. Inside of your lung there is a city and above that city lies a moon. It’s a pretty sight, but also very strange. Moons and cities don’t usually reside inside lungs.
mnemonics.reading: Having a moon and city inside your lung inspires you to write a haiku (はい). Perhaps the city and moon are just metaphorical. Either way, a haiku is the best way to go about things here.

mnemonics.meaning: To <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> what's in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">samurai</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> you start a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">magazine</mark>. You go around writing about and interviewing all the samurai so you can share what they say to everyone who wants to read!
mnemonics.reading: Unfortunately, your magazine helps the sheep (し) samurai find other samurai... and kill them. None of the samurai want to share their feelings with your magazine anymore, oh no!

mnemonics.meaning: If someone has their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">syrup</mark>, it's just another way of saying they <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">manipulate</mark>d you. Cause only slimy people manipulate other people, so their fingers are slimy and sticky because they're covered in your syrup from mucking up your life.
mnemonics.reading: If you want to manipulate someone else it's going to have a permanent effect on your soul (そう). Being manipulative isn't cool. And your soul will suffer forever for it.

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> absorbed the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark>, and you want that power in your body, so you surgically insert them into your body to replace your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">muscle</mark>s and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tendon</mark>s.
mnemonics.reading: Your special muscles and tendons have become famous and the King (きん) of England has requested that you appear in his court! It looks like he wants you to teach his barber surgeons how you got your new muscles.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Not</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Mouth</mark> says “<mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">no</mark>”. What else would you expect from something named the “Not Mouth”? The Not Mouth will always say “no”, regardless of the question.
