mnemonics.reading: You ask the Not Mouth if it is afraid of heat (ひ). The Not Mouth says, “no”. So you set the Not Mouth on fire. The Not Mouth then screams, “NONONONONONONONONONOOOOOO~!” Looks like someone can’t handle the heat.

mnemonics.meaning: If you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">become</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">plate</mark>, I will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pile</mark> food up upon you. With such a huge pile, everyone will think you're <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">prosperous</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You're so prosperous you use your saber (せい) to cut the food pile and shove the bits into your plate mouth. In fact, your entire family is using your special saber to cut and eat off of you. A normal knife wouldn't be able to get through all this food!

mnemonics.meaning: Someone climbs onto the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> from the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> when <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dawn</mark> comes to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">proclaim</mark> that a new day has begun! They proclaim this at the top of their lungs!
mnemonics.reading: The thing that climbs up on the roof to proclaim that the new day is here is a centaur (せん). Ohoho, did you think I was going to say it was a rooster? Wrong! Centaurs are taller than humans and roosters, so when they climb onto the roof with their horse legs they can see dawn starting before anyone else.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> who is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> of every <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> sets the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rent</mark> for everyone. If you rent a home in King Shellfish's kingdom, the rent will be set by the great shellfish leader himself.
mnemonics.reading: If you don't have enough shellfish to pay your rent, King Shellfish will punch you in the chin (ちん).

mnemonics.meaning: Writing a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poem</mark> about <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> is the only way to get <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">respect</mark> from other poets.
mnemonics.reading: Once you have their respect you get cake (けい)!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> of the creatures who drink <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark> have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark> so large that they are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">revered</mark> the world over. The horns are revered both for their size and potency. The horns can be used in medicine, so they are very valuable, those alcoholic monster horns.
mnemonics.reading: The reason you are interested in these revered horns so much is that your son (そん) is sick and you need one of these revered horns to make a medicine for your son. Only with the revered power of the horns will you be able to save your son’s life.

mnemonics.meaning: If you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">receive</mark> something edible, arrange it in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">circle</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark> it. That way, it’ll <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ripen</mark> more quickly.
mnemonics.reading: Once everything you received has ripened, you kick back near your jukebox (じゅく) and eat it. The jukebox sets the mood, making the ripened treat feels twice as sweet.

mnemonics.meaning: Next to your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> there are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark> which react to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark>. If you exceed a certain alcohol <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark>, they start flapping about, which makes you spread <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rumors</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gossip</mark> uncontrollably.
mnemonics.reading: The flapping fins are making you slur your words, but that doesn't stop you from spreading rumors and gossip: "Ooo whassat (うわさ) I hear about so and so having an affair?!"

mnemonics.meaning: If you grind a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark> down to more than just a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">few</mark> pieces, it will become <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sand</mark>. Stones that get broken up enough will become sand, and you pick up a few grains in your hand.
mnemonics.reading: After breaking up your stone into sand, you fetch your special sand saw (さ). A few bits are still too chunky, so you'll have to use a sand saw now.

mnemonics.meaning: You line up stalks of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> with an equal <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">interval</mark> between each one. This pattern creates a sense of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">simplicity</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: That kind of simplicity is what Genghis Khan (かん) always demanded. Everything he decided was based on simplicity.

mnemonics.meaning: If you take the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> off some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">coral</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark> them, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">steam</mark> comes out.
mnemonics.reading: As you watch the steam coming off the coral flowers, someone appears behind you. It’s Joe (じょう), the big farmhand. "Are you steaming coral?" he asks. "Smelled it a mile away. I love steaming me some coral.”

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">storehouse</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">storehouse</mark> kanji meanings are the same. If you know the radical, you know the kanji!
mnemonics.reading: You have a storehouse. Inside is where you keep all your zombies (ぞう).

mnemonics.meaning: Bring some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> under a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> and stuff it in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>. Make him chew it a bit, scrape it out, and voila — you've made <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sugar</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: You learned how to make this kind of sugar in とうきょう. You found a special とうきょう sugar sensei and they introduced you to all the secret methods you know now.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> you have <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">inside</mark> is your whole <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">supply</mark>. When you're outside sewing and you run out, you just go inside, look through your supply, and pick a new one.
mnemonics.reading: You have this supply because Nostradamus (のう) had a prediction, saying you would. And that if you didn't keep a good supply of thread inside, you'd run out.

mnemonics.meaning: They <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">someone</mark> with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">various</mark> talents is important. Various talents can include speaking various languages so if you are someone who knows various languages you can say things that various peoples will comprehend.
mnemonics.reading: You’re so good at speaking various languages that you decide to put on a show (しょ). At the show, you say a lot of things in various languages and everyone is impressed.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hole</mark> leading to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> of your house is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">window</mark>. Or maybe it's just the window to your soul, and not your house. Like the poetry people say.
mnemonics.reading: You realize that a ton of people are looking into your window and seeing all your private things. This makes you mad (まど)! What right do they have to know your private thoughts and desires?!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">beans</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">beans</mark> kanji are exactly the same!
mnemonics.reading: These beans are from とうきょう. Everybody knows とうきょう has the best beans. What?! You didn’t know that? Tokyo’s beans are the best beans!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">branch</mark> is exactly what it sounds like: the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">branch</mark> of a tree.
mnemonics.reading: You're smelling and feeling the branch when, suddenly, it starts screaming at you: "Eh, dad?" (えだ). The branch won't leave you alone. It follows you around screaming "Eh, dad?", thinking you're its long-lost tree branch father. Poor thing.

mnemonics.meaning: Take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark>, step onto the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark>, and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">brandish</mark> them in the air. Wave them around for everyone to see.
mnemonics.reading: What are you brandishing in your fingers? Your car's key (き)! You want every driver and every car to know that you aren't going to be driving ever again!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slice</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> is called a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">carve</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You work up a sweat trying to carve meat and wood all day, so you grab yourself a nice Coke (こく). You like Coke, and it goes well with meat and sawdust.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">claw</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">claw</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Ravishing!
mnemonics.reading: You sink your claws into anything your two 目 (つめ) see, because you're such a fierce predator. If your two 目 can see it, your claws will get to it. Your claws are basically an extension of your two eyes, that's how skilled you are.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark> will ask if they want <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">two</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark>s because they need a grown-up's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">consent</mark>. Children aren't allowed to have whatever they want, they need to make sure it's okay and get consent first.
mnemonics.reading: "Of course my child, you have my consent," comes the voice of the Shougun (しょう). The Shougun is very pleased by this child, because he expects everyone to ask for consent around him.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> was <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slice</mark>d open by a terrible <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cough</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Oddly enough, some people find your cough sexy (せき).

mnemonics.meaning: In a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">greenhouse</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> becomes a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">curtain</mark> as soon as you hang it. Greenhouses are made of windows, it's all glass, there are no walls. So when you put a towel in there it turns into a curtain. It has no choice but to cover a window, after all.
mnemonics.reading: You're hanging these towel curtains because you need a quiet place to eat a Big Mac (まく). But you're a little ashamed. Big Macs aren't really good for you, but this stupid greenhouse has too many windows and everyone can see you stuff your face. So that's where the towel curtains come in.

mnemonics.meaning: You use <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark> project to hold everything together. The color of the thread is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">deep red</mark>, and it gives everything a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">crimson</mark> look.
mnemonics.reading: You're done, and the whole building is a deep red crimson color (it takes a lot of thread to hold a whole building in place). It's time to show the client, Emperor こういち, the finished product.

mnemonics.meaning: An <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark> is what this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lack</mark>s. For a turkey, that is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">delight</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Delight is what Genghis Khan (かん) felt when he saw his turkey friend, sans an arrow.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> sitting on that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> is actually a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dude</mark>. Oh oops! You thought he was a woman because of his long hair and the way he was sitting. Maybe you shouldn't be judging people based on their looks!
mnemonics.reading: You only found out this dude wasn't a woman when a dog (ど) ran up and the dude stood up. He started rubbing the dog's face saying, "Who's a good boy? Who's a good boy? Not you! Me! I'm the best boy of them all. Because I am a dude, the best of all boys! HAHAHAHA!"

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ear</mark> and the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">holy</mark>. The king has holy hearing and holy eating abilities. This king is divine.
mnemonics.reading: This holy king has heard of you and your special saber (せい) that glows with pure, blue light. Specifically, the holy king wants to use it on his food!

mnemonics.meaning: If the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> are pointing right at you, you can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">infer</mark> that it wants revenge. This turkey knows you killed his brother for dinner last night, and now it's going to make you pay. You infer that this turkey is going to take its fingers and wrap them around your neck.
mnemonics.reading: You were able to infer the turkey's plan, so now it's your turn. You look around and see the only way out... is to swing (すい) to safety! How did I infer that, dear Watson? Why, isn't it obvious! There are vines here. Turkeys can't fly. So I shall swing my way to freedom!

mnemonics.meaning: Your moon storehouse is another storehouse you own. Remember how your regular storehouse holds zombies (from the kanji 蔵?). Your moon storehouse is on the moon, and it is filled with internal organs.
mnemonics.reading: Where did you get all these internal organs from? You actually harvested them from the zombies (ぞう) from your other storehouse.

mnemonics.meaning: Raise your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to another <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">member</mark> and you'll receive a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">loss</mark> in return. You should never <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hurt</mark> a member of your team, group, or society. It's just wrong. And you'll incur a loss as punishment for your bad deeds.
mnemonics.reading: Unfortunately for you, payment is in the form of the loss of your son (そん). The loss of any family member is horrible, but this was your son. He was your favorite child. You loved him. But that's the loss you must bear for raising your fingers to a team member.

mnemonics.meaning: Seeing a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark> and some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> next to a piece of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poop</mark> and another piece of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poop</mark>, you try and pick each of them up with a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">magnet</mark>. The magnet fails to pick up either piece of poop. The magnet doesn’t pick up the horns either. But wait! The magnet picks up the stone!
mnemonics.reading: You’re pretty excited that you lifted something up with your magnet. Science is cool! But then you hear someone laughing behind you. It’s Jesus (じ)! Jesus was using his magic to levitate the stone all along, it wasn’t your magnet. Darn it Jesus! You’ve fooled me for the last time!

mnemonics.meaning: They <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> accidentally firing a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">catapult</mark> is an unforgivable <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mistake</mark>. They say you shot the catapult at your own castle. Even though it was an accident, it’s still a mistake you will never be forgiven for.
mnemonics.reading: This mistake alerts Godzilla (ご), who thinks it's town destroying time. He barrels over the hills, sees where you mistakenly catapulted your own people, and proceeds to stomp on the rest of it for you.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> was the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">original</mark> event to mark the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">origin</mark> of Japan. A big tsunami came and uncovered the islands of Japan. It's the origin of all life, as far as Japanese people are concerned.
mnemonics.reading: This tsunami was also the origin of Genji (げん), from "The Tale of Genji." Just think, without this origin, Japan wouldn't exist and neither would the first Japanese heartthrob, Genji!

mnemonics.meaning: If it's made of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark>, your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">barracks</mark> will be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pure</mark>. If you build it out of clay or bricks or wood, it will inevitably have some dirt in it. Build it out of thread to keep it pure of... well, impurities.
mnemonics.reading: Unfortunately, this pure thread barracks can only be used in June (じゅん). Any other time of year there will be snow and rain and mud that will get tracked into the pure barracks and ruin them. But June is the cleanest, most pure month, so you can use it then.

mnemonics.meaning: You want some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> to put on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> above your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">helicopter</mark> to keep the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bird</mark>s away, so you ask people what they would <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">recommend</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You ask for a recommendation from the centaur (せん) that owns the local flower shop. Now he's walking around your helicopter canopy and staring at the birds, nodding.

mnemonics.meaning: Into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">well</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of rice falls from your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rice bowl</mark>. You were eating out of your rice bowl on the side of a well, and some rice fell out of your rice bowl and this drop of rice proceeded to fall all the way down.
mnemonics.reading: Just then, the don (どん) of your local mafia shows up, steals your rice bowl, and shoves you into the well. You’d gotten on the don’s bad side, so he came to teach you a lesson. The don steals your rice bowl and shoves you into the well.

mnemonics.meaning: Set up your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark>, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">attach</mark> some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">meat</mark> to it, and the meat will eventually <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rot</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You let meat rot. You're a fool (ふ). That's really all I can say at this point.

mnemonics.meaning: There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> coming, so you put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark> on, open your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> wide, and try to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">run alongside</mark> it.
mnemonics.reading: You're able to run alongside the tsunami for about ten seconds before everything ends (えん).

mnemonics.meaning: You need to take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">body</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark> before you can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shoot</mark>. Whether it's for a photo shoot, you're gonna shoot them with a gun, or if you're about to shoot them full of radiation for X-rays, you need the right measurements of that body first.
mnemonics.reading: This shoot is being done by a shaman (しゃ). Not only is he doing the body measurements for the shoot, but he's also going to be shooting you with a shot so you don't get the flu.

mnemonics.meaning: A magic <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> fell from the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> onto the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hundred</mark> people, causing him to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shrink</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: As the leader shrinks, the hundred people start screaming and running around the entire place. As a result, everything is shook (しゅく) up. Especially the poor, shrunken leader, who gets knocked around the most.

mnemonics.meaning: A samurai handling a jackhammer, cleaning brushes (in their 肀 form), and carrying water for someone?! All that should tell you that he's not just working, he's been made into a slave.
mnemonics.reading: You don't like seeing slaves. As you walk by, you hand this slave a ray (れい) gun so he can free himself.

mnemonics.meaning: There's some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> in the shape of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nine</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> and this is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stylish</mark>. The rice grains are arranged to form the number nine. This number nine is prominently displayed on the cross, and it's stylish to carry it around and be seen with it.
mnemonics.reading: It's also stylish to swing (すい) the cross around while you wait for things. You're waiting at a bus stop so you swing the cross around violently. You swing it so violently that the rice comes flying off!

mnemonics.meaning: You are so <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sick</mark> that you've come to look like the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">humble</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>: <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">thin</mark>. Eerily thin, in fact.
mnemonics.reading: When you're this thin, your soul (そう) is visible from outside of your body too.

mnemonics.meaning: If someone fills your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>, you're going to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">throw up</mark>. That's just a fact.
mnemonics.reading: When you throw up it sounds like you're shouting, "HA (は)!" Then all the dirt-puke comes out in a wave. It's less of a laugh ha and more of an oh no I'm throwing up ha.

mnemonics.meaning: In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">middle</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> that is very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">valuable</mark>. Inside of this valuable shellfish is a priceless treasure, and it’s just lying there in the middle of the ground.
mnemonics.reading: You want to get the valuable thing from inside the shellfish, but it's locked and you need to find the key (き). Search for the key!

mnemonics.meaning: You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> that wants to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark> from some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> and you would be <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark> to assume that it would hang <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">vertical</mark>. The thread wants to loiter and hang from one of the horns. When things hang from things, they usually hang vertical, so that’s what this thread is going to do.
mnemonics.reading: For some reason, Channing Tatum (たて) is strangely attracted to vertical pieces of hanging thread. Channing Tatum starts batting at the vertical thread like a cat.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Boot</mark>s give you the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">work</mark>! That's why so many professions require you to have work boots.
mnemonics.reading: You need boots to give you the power to work for the King (きん) of England. Really, all work is for the King, since everything is for him. But even he wears boots. And they give him the power to uh... king over things.

mnemonics.meaning: Take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark> them. Then <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark> them again. This is what you do when you are in  <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">worship</mark>. Once you go into your place of worship, and again before you leave. You have really sweaty fingers, and you can't worship anyone or anything if you have wet hands. So you dry them!
mnemonics.reading: Once you're dry and in wherever your worship is, you begin with a haiku (はい). Really all places of worship have their own version of the haiku, and heck, the 5-7-5 rule is just a guideline, so everyone is doing it pretty close to right anyway.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ability</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark> is one of the main abilities of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bear</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: A bear boiling in front of you should fill you with great honor. Or, as they say in Latin: Magna cum (くま) laude.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> is wearing a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mask</mark> so people won't realize you're the one being so <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">boisterous</mark> as you eat your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">miso</mark>. If you cover your mouth with this mask, no one will know you're such a boisterous eater of miso.
mnemonics.reading: You're being boisterous and having your miso outside when suddenly someone shoves soap (そ) in your mouth. "Even your mask can't hide that boisterous miso-eating. Quiet down and wash your mouth out with that soap!" they yell.

mnemonics.meaning: There is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">circumference</mark> around someone's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark>, as in, you can see a circle drawn around the top of their head. As you examine it closer, and pull at it a bit, you realize that someone has <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">carve</mark>d the hair off someone's head!
mnemonics.reading: When you think of all the people who could have done this... all the people who could have carved out someone's hair, only one person comes to mind, and that is Mrs. Chou (ちょう). She's the only person evil enough to do something like this.

mnemonics.meaning: There’s a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark>, I think it’s a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cedar</mark>. How did that cedar tree get in your hair?
mnemonics.reading: Once the cedar is fully grown, you use the cedar wood to make a guitar for Sue. A Sue guitar (すぎ), if you will. This Sue guitar was made just for Sue. She’ll love it.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">World</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Tree</mark>, all it does is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chat</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">talk</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: To chat or talk with the World Tree, just head over to Shaman Bay (しゃべ).

mnemonics.meaning: You toss a pair of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mustache</mark>s into your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cooking pot</mark> and begin simmering them. Some people use bay leaves and whatnot, but where you're from, there's no seasoning you'd rather have in your cooking pot than a couple of gold mustaches.
mnemonics.reading: Your spouse asks you if they can have a taste of what's in your cooking pot, but you say, "Nah babe (なべ), this is all for me."

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Gold</mark> is not the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">same</mark> as <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">copper</mark>. They are two different metals. Gold is not the same as copper.
mnemonics.reading: Smashing the copper against the gold has made you tired. You should eat a doughnut (どう). Go get yourself a doughnut.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the radical that look like this are exactly the same. They are both <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cottage</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You got this cottage from a shaman (しゃ). In fact, everyone you know got their cottage from a shaman. One day you're just walking in the woods, and the next thing you know, a shaman is giving you the keys to their old cottage.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hits the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">greenhouse</mark>, destroying the last remaining plant life in the area. The tsunami recedes, and there is nothing but sand, and the lands become a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">desert</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: See the sun come up over the desert, then go back (ばく) down. Up, back down, back up, back down. You stand here for days watching because you're so depressed. Stop being so vague in your approach, sun! You’re weirding everyone out!

mnemonics.meaning: You have an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nine</mark> times stronger than any other drink, in a bottle shaped like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark>, and you drink it all and become <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">drunk</mark>. You're like, so drunk right now from all that alcohol. Nine times more drunk than ever before.
mnemonics.reading: Everything's spinning now, you're so drunk it feels like you're on a swing (すい). Lurching back and forth in your drunkenness, feeling more and more nauseated by all this horrible swinging. Ugh.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Fire</mark>, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark>, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">flame</mark>! There’s flames everywhere!
mnemonics.reading: The flames gets bigger, surround you, and then everything ends (えん).

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark> because you kept it under the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">eaves</mark> of your house.
mnemonics.reading: On top of the eaves of your house Ken (けん) the samurai is counting houses too.

mnemonics.meaning: You create a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> with someone by <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">call</mark>ing out to them to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">introduce</mark> yourself.
mnemonics.reading: You want to introduce yourself to the Shougun (しょう) but no matter how much you call out, he won't come close enough for you to tie your introduction thread to him. You call louder and louder, "SHOUGUN LET ME INTRODUCE MYSELF!"

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jammed in</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">jammed in</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: Look down! You're jammed into something. You can't move your feet. What is this?! Oh, your body's been jammed in a kayak (かい).

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark>s during the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">old</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark>s (many moons ago) were responsible for the world's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lake</mark>s.
mnemonics.reading: "That's where lakes come from," you tell the 子 (こ).

mnemonics.meaning: Try to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> something to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lifeguard</mark> and you'll just end up getting a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lecture</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: This lecture loving lifeguard is none other than こういち! I mean, look how long winded the stuff on this site is? Can you imagine him trying to give you a talk about proper swimming etiquette?

mnemonics.meaning: In <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spring</mark>, your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark>s will reveal your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lifespan</mark>. Only in spring can you measure your lifespan, just as easily as you measure your height and weight.
mnemonics.reading: If your lifespan measurement isn't as long as you'd like, you need to drink more small juice (じゅ) boxes this year. They're good for your health, after all!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> will pick up a bunch of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> and dump them on your shore, so you take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">measure</mark> them.
mnemonics.reading: All of the shellfish you measure that are too small go into your sock (そく). Once the sock is full, you swing it around your head and lob it back into the ocean.

mnemonics.meaning: If you're on the edge of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">snake</mark>, that's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">misfortune</mark>. You're hanging off the edge of this cliff and you can't pull yourself back up. Then you notice a snake approaching your fingers, looking like it's gonna bite you. What a misfortune!
mnemonics.reading: You decide to let go, but at the bottom of the cliff is an even greater misfortune: yak (やく). A whole stampeding herd of yak is passing just as you fall. Oops! You've accidentally committed yourself to the ultimate misfortune, death by yak trampling.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shuriken</mark> have <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mutual</mark> respect for one another. The shuriken respects the ground because of how solid and stable it is, and the ground respects the shuriken for how pointy it is. They have great mutual respect here.
mnemonics.reading: Since you made the shuriken attack the ground, the mutual respect is out of balance. This summons Godzilla (ご) up from the depths of the ocean once more. He always shows up when something is out of wack, to show humans the error of their ways. He picks up the shuriken and flings it into a city, which explodes, leaving a crater in the ground.

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">reason</mark> we have so much <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">oil</mark> now. The tsunami moved a bunch of earth out of the way, so now it’s really easy to dig for oil. Thanks tsunami!
mnemonics.reading: Now that oil is so abundant, everyone lives in yurts (ゆ). They're light and mobile, so people can just move from oil well to oil well, collecting oil.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">oneself</mark> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">oneself</mark> as well.
mnemonics.reading: Oneself. Who only thinks of oneself? Every 子 (こ) in the world.

mnemonics.meaning: You have an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">animal</mark> and you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> it’s a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dog</mark> to prevent it from going to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">prison</mark>. Dogs are the only animals that don’t have to go to prison. Your animal is not a dog, but you say it is to prevent it from going to prison.
mnemonics.reading: What is the name of your animal? Your animal is named Goku (ごく). Yeah, like Goku from Dragon Ball Z. You don’t want your little Goku to go to prison, so you say that he’s a dog.

mnemonics.meaning: There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">above</mark> it, and they're making you feel <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">small</mark>. And the worst part is that the drunkard is one of your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">relatives</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: As if things couldn't get worse, your relative seems to think they're sexy (せき) when they're on the slide drunk. Sexy? More like irresponsible!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sake</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sake</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Sweet.
mnemonics.reading: For the sake of convenience, companies will use eagles (い) for delivery jobs in the future. Just put in an order, and it'll be at your doorstep in no time flat. Eagles are like, super fast at delivery.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ear</mark> listens to your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> and feels <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shame</mark>. Your heart is full of shame for how you’ve lived your life and when your ear hears all the things you’ve done, your ear feels shame too.
mnemonics.reading: You must cleanse your spirit of this shame. You decide to complete Haj (はじ). (Haj is the fifth pillar of Islam, and is a pilgrimage to Mecca during the month of Dhu al-Hijja). Upon arrival in Mecca, you think of a funny joke and bust out laughing. “HAHAHAHAHAHA!! (は) HAHAHAHAHA!!!” Oh man, you’re in a temple and that was completely inappropriate. You feel even more shame than before.

mnemonics.meaning: Next to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark>, there's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> warning you that there are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sheep</mark> around here, so you should go <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">slow</mark>. That means you might be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">late</mark>, but at least the sheep will be okay!
mnemonics.reading: You follow the flag, but the sheep refuse to slow down so you have to get creative. You place cheese (ち) every ten feet or so, that way the sheep slow down to bend down on their scooters and take a bite.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> carries a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> into your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">soup</mark>. Hey tsunami, I was eating that soup!
mnemonics.reading: You pull the cross out of your soup and see that the cross' jewels (じゅう) fell off and are in there now. The jewels sparkle, shine, and dissolve into the soup!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">commander</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark> is really just <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">soy sauce</mark>. When he goes out to drink with his troops and they all get drunk together, he manages to have fun and stay sober by drinking down a tasty, non-alcoholic pint of soy sauce.
mnemonics.reading: Soy sauce also happens to be the Shougun's (しょう) favorite drink. Unfortunately, he can't just tell people he likes drinking glasses of soy sauce, or they'll look at him weird. Instead he orders it as a commander's alcohol too.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark>, once stopped by a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">belt</mark>, will begin to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stagnate</mark>. This belt is a belt of water resistance, so the belt stops the tsunami. The belt has caused the tsunami to stagnate.
mnemonics.reading: While you watch the tsunami stagnate, you get ready for work. While you were watching this whole thing happening, you were tying your tie (たい). Once the tsunami stagnated, you were all done tying your tie. And since the tsunami is no longer a threat, you’re ready to go to work.

mnemonics.meaning: Tie a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">squid</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> and you get a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sword</mark>! Knives are too small to be considered a sword on their own. That's why you strapped a squid to it. They're the right shape, kinda pointed, so no one will know it's just a knife.
mnemonics.reading: You learned how to make swords this way from Ken (けん) the samurai. He put his own little squid buddy on his knife and now no one realizes it's not a sword!

mnemonics.meaning: If you scrape a sharp <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark> against your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">skin</mark>, it will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tear</mark>. The sharp stone tears your skin. It hurts!
mnemonics.reading: The moment your skin tears you can't help but yelp "Ha (は)!" It sounds like a laugh, but it's more like a pained bark.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> goes through a little <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">door</mark>, and plops down a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> drop on your face. This tsunami is your tears inside your eye area. The door is your tear duct. The big drop is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">teardrop</mark> coming down your eye.
mnemonics.reading: Your teardrops are like little waves. What are they? They're 波だ (なみだ).

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turtle</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">turtle</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Nice!
mnemonics.reading: You know Dragon Ball Z, right? Imagine this turtle doing a Kamehameha (かめ). The turtle charges up his energy and releases a mighty Kamehameha blast. Shwooom!

mnemonics.meaning: To make <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark> the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">key</mark> is to ferment it. But, if you ferment it a certain way, it will become <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">vinegar</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You are demonstrating this practice in front of an audience. You want them to take you seriously so you wear a suit (す). A very nice suit. Surely they will now believe that you can turn alcohol into vinegar.

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> something and the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">right</mark> in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">agreement</mark>. The flowers see where you are coming from when you say what you say. You and the flowers are in complete agreement.
mnemonics.reading: You and the flowers are in agreement on the fact that neither of you like when a duck (だく) walks across the flowers. You don’t like having a duck walk on the flowers because the duck will poo in the flowers and then you have to worry about stepping in it. And the flowers just don’t like having duck poo in their face.

mnemonics.meaning: I’ll give you this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bright</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">plate</mark> if you agree to an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">alliance</mark> with me. I know you like things that are bright, and I know you like plates too. Therefore, this bright plate should be more than enough to convince you to enter into an alliance with me.
mnemonics.reading: The person you are trying to get in an alliance with you is the captain of the Mayflower (めい). You want to be in an alliance with the captain of the Mayflower because you really like boats. You want to ride on the Mayflower like, so bad.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">commander</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">commander</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: Who is the commander of Japan? The Shougun (しょう)! And if you ever say anyone else or vote for someone else or even THINK about someone else being the commander, he'll find you and cut off your head.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nothing</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dance</mark> is still a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dance</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: To help you do this dance you need some booze (ぶ). Just enough so it's easier to think of nothing, let all your fears go, and dance.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> gets the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blame</mark> if your company is in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">debt</mark>. They're the one who led you all into that debt, so they should get the blame too.
mnemonics.reading: To pay off this debt your leader says you need to sell your cyborg (さい) to help the company. You fight him! You yell! You scream! The cyborg puts a half-human half-robot hand on your shoulder and shakes its head sadly.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">branch</mark> became the leader from doing <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">deed</mark>s. You can't rise to the rank of branch leader if you don't perform a certain number of deeds! Most of them good, I hope.
mnemonics.reading: The deed he's currently working on is finding your lost key (き). He doesn't have to help, you're the one who lost your own house-combination-car key. But he's so used to doing deeds, he can't help but help.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">helicopter</mark> are being <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">compare</mark>d by a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">deer</mark>. The deer is standing very still (as deer do) and looking very slowly between the empty canopy and the helicopter sitting next to it.
mnemonics.reading: You walk forward, about to call out to the deer, when a car (か) suddenly appears out of no where and runs the deer over! Was this all just a trap set up to murder the deer?!

mnemonics.meaning: You count with your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> all of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>s and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">legs</mark> you've acquired. Soon you'll be able to make a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">exchange</mark> with all of these body parts to get something awesome.
mnemonics.reading: You learned this type of exchange from the mighty Genghis Khan (かん). You read a book or watched a show about him once and you're pretty positive that Genghis Khan would exchange the body parts of his enemies all over the continents of Asia and Europe for nicer stuff.

mnemonics.meaning: If there's a special <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark>, she might eventually take your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">family name</mark> and make it her <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">surname</mark> too. In Japan and other countries, tradition dictates that women change their last name when they get married and keep that name for the rest of their life. Their partner’s family name becomes their family name too.
mnemonics.reading: Picture this special woman in your mind. She's changing her surname to yours and taking hold of your special saber (せい) as well. And it's... it's splitting in two!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fang</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fang</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Fantastic. Oh, also it means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tusk</mark>. It means fang and tusk.
mnemonics.reading: Lots of animals have fangs, even ones that don't look like they do. The coolest fang-having animal is the gecko (げ)! They have pretty sharp little fangs in their mouths and they'll bite you if you keep tapping their glass cages like that. Cut it out.

mnemonics.meaning: There’s a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stick</mark> next to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>, reflecting on its <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">former</mark> glory. The stick used to be a great tree, and the stick thinks that if it stays by the sun long enough it might return to its former form as a towering tree.
mnemonics.reading: It's working, it's working! The stick is returning to its former state and... w-wuh? It sprouted a cucumber (きゅう).

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Fire</mark> is one of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">few</mark> things you'll need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fry</mark> things.
mnemonics.reading: You love to fry things and are also an adventurous eater (いた). This means you'll fry and eat just about anything. Fried ostrich, fried alligator, fried chocolate, you name it!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boat</mark> will have at least one <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark>, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">generally</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Generally a boat with a weapon will be owned by Han (はん) Solo.

mnemonics.meaning: There’s a huge <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark>, caused by a giant <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">brush</mark>, fast approaching you and your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">harbor</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You’ll defend your harbor with your two (つ) best friends, that’s how! Luckily, your two friends specialize in defending harbors from giant brush-caused tsunamis. Quite the occupation.

mnemonics.meaning: If someone is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sick</mark> feed them <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">charcoal</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">heal</mark> them. Okay, so maybe you shouldn't feed it directly to them, but charcoal has amazing water filtration powers. So put charcoal in their water and the water will heal them right up.
mnemonics.reading: You aren't the only one that needs to be healed, so you take your row (りょう) boat out onto the lake where your town gets its drinking water and you dump a bunch of charcoal into it! Now everyone will be healed when they drink.

mnemonics.meaning: With a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lion</mark> sews together all the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> he'll <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">inherit</mark> from his parents one day. He's convinced his parents are going to try to keep some of his inheritance from him, so he's linking it all together so it can't go anywhere.
mnemonics.reading: If you're going to inherit something from your parents, try to convince them to make it cake (けい), not rice. A single cake is much easier to keep track of and probably tastier (though it will be super stale by the time they die).

mnemonics.meaning: When you go on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark>, anything <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">valuable</mark>, you need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">leave behind</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Anything you don't leave behind will be stolen by eagles (い). Eagles like shiny, valuable things, especially ones that are bouncing around on you while you scoot by on a scooter.

mnemonics.meaning: You tie a piece of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> to your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> in order to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">maintain</mark> proximity to it. The turkey likes to run away, so you tie a thread to it. This way you can hold the other end and maintain your turkey.
mnemonics.reading: The reason the turkey is tugging is because there’s an eagle (い) swooping down to attack the turkey. You try to maintain control, but once you see the eagle as well, you let go of the thread.

mnemonics.meaning: There is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark> in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Nara</mark>. That jackhammer is the biggest in all the land and is on display in Nara, Japan.
mnemonics.reading: What’s the first part of Nara? Na (な). Well that’s easy.

mnemonics.meaning: You take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slice</mark> it until you reach its <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">nucleus</mark>. To get to the nucleus of the tree you have to make many a slice, but it’s possible.
mnemonics.reading: It looks like a cock (かく). And by cock I mean a male chicken – a rooster. Why does the nucleus of a tree look like a cock? Science is weird.

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark>, after your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">departure</mark>, will become <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">obsolete</mark>. The canopy was here to protect you, but no one will need it once you're gone.
mnemonics.reading: When something becomes obsolete, you must write a haiku (はい). Honestly, the best haiku are about something ending, so this is perfect.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">South</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Dog</mark> gives you an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">offer</mark>. None of the other dogs in the North, East, or West offered you anything.
mnemonics.reading: The South Dog offers you the services of Ken (けん) the samurai as you traverse his lands.

mnemonics.meaning: There is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">middle</mark> of the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">open sea</mark>. Luckily there are no ships around, so the tsunami in the middle of the open sea is not damaging to anyone.
mnemonics.reading: Someone dares you to go out to the open sea and surf on the middle of the tsunami. “Oki (おき) doki,” you reply. You can’t refuse a dare. Every time someone dares you to do something, you always respond with “oki doki”.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Tsunami</mark>s get <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blame</mark>d because they <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pickle</mark> everything in their path. That means that everything smells of pickles after a tsunami.
mnemonics.reading: Looking at all those pickles, you bend down and pick up two (つ) of them. One in each hand. You look at the pickles in your hand and wonder whether to try one.

mnemonics.meaning: Stick your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mohawk</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pluck</mark> each hair out, one by one.
mnemonics.reading: You want to pluck all your mohawk hair out because you're a techie (てき), and everyone at your techie job keeps making fun of you for your hair choices. "Techies should be bald!" your boss screamed. So here you are, plucking your hair out to fit in.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Escalator</mark>s are used to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">reach</mark> things.
mnemonics.reading: You're riding the escalator trying to reach a delicious cucumber (きゅう).

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> has <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clothes</mark> that he is quite <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">reliant</mark> on. The leader needs his clothes to make him look like a leader. The leader has become more reliant on his clothes than he is on his actual skills as a leader!
mnemonics.reading: The leader has become so reliant on his clothes that his judgment has been clouded. His kingdom has become infested with eagles (い) but the leader does nothing, trusting that his clothes will rout out the eagles if it is something that needs to be done. He’s become so reliant on his clothes that he’s started to become not so good a leader anymore.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark>ed a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turtle</mark> into long skinny pieces, making a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rope</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The person making these threaded turtle ropes is none other than the local farmhand Joe (じょう). You watch him stretch and peel pieces of turtle off of turtles, then thread them together into a rope.

mnemonics.meaning: What kind of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fish</mark> jumps from <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>? A <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">salmon</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: You make a drinking game out of watching the salmon going up stream. Every time one jumps onto the dirt, you drink a shot of 酒 (さけ). You realize you're drunk when you ask for more さけ but it comes out as しゃけ.

mnemonics.meaning: You soak each <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">foot</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark> before going out in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> to take your first <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">step</mark>. Stepping on the ground when it's been baking in the hot sun can burn your feet, so you're careful to make them wet with water before stepping outside even once.
mnemonics.reading: Each step you take brings you closer to とうきょう. Unfortunately, the sun keeps getting hotter, meaning you have to take breaks between steps more often, to get your feet wet with even more water. But you're determined to reach とうきょう, no matter how many steps it takes.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> who's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">humble</mark> will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stretch</mark> in front of everyone. They'll show that they have to get up every hour or so and stretch just like the rest of us.
mnemonics.reading: The leader is currently working hard to stretch in front of all of you, and as he does, he munches on some nori (の) seaweed snacks. Then he starts stretching the nori too.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sweet</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sweet</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Double sweet.
mnemonics.reading: The sweet, sweet sensation is almost overwhelming. You gotta put on some sweet-resistant armor (あま) to protect you from all that sweetness. The armor will prevent you from having a sweet, sweet sweetness overload.

mnemonics.meaning: You send your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark> man out with your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> so he can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">trade</mark> them. Shellfish were used as currency back in the olden days. And you aren't going to go out trading and dirty your own hands, no no. Trading your shellfish is the job for the private sword you hired!
mnemonics.reading: While he's out making the trade for you, you decide to relax and do some bowling (ぼう). In fact, you can't wait for the trade to be done because you're hoping he's going to come back with a new bowling ball for you.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bundle</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark>s is something you can always <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">trust</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: While you can trust a bundle of geoducks, never ever trust rye (らい) bread.

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">run</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">call</mark> out to people at the same time because you're <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">super</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ultra</mark> excited right now. You have a super crazy amount of energy you need to get out with your running and calling.
mnemonics.reading: You're just becoming ultra tired when you hear a terrifying sound. It's Mrs. Chou (ちょう) barreling down toward you. "WERE YOU CALLING FOR ME, CHILD?!" she screams.

mnemonics.meaning: There were lots of things that were <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">above</mark> you when you were <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">small</mark> that you would need a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> to reach, so you just asked your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">aunt</mark> or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">uncle</mark> to get them for you.
mnemonics.reading: You ask your aunt and uncle to help you reach your special obi (お) from high up in the closet.

mnemonics.meaning: When you see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> coming, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">courage</mark> will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">well up</mark> inside you, giving you the power to save everyone before you get washed away!
mnemonics.reading: Whom does that courage well up inside of? You (ゆう)! In fact, YOU feel like there is a never ending well of courage bursting out of you now. You are going to be a hero!

mnemonics.meaning: You want to put this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> over this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scarecrow</mark>, but you have to measure its <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">width</mark> first. If the towel doesn't have a greater width than the scarecrow, some of it will be showing. Which you definitely don't want.
mnemonics.reading: You finish measuring the width of the scarecrow and the width of the towel, and you realize you're the width of a habanero (はば) pepper short. This is fine, you grow those. This is a whole field of habaneros! So you pluck one off the nearest plant, tape it to the cloth, and cover that scarecrow right up.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">skewer</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> has <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">afflicted</mark> your health. You’ve been afflicted with a disease from the skewer to your heart. Your affliction is death. You’re dying.
mnemonics.reading: Since you’re afflicted with the death, you start to hallucinate and the ghost of Genghis Khan (かん) appears before you. "Ah, I was afflicted of the same disease. It killed me, you know."

mnemonics.meaning: You see an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">animal</mark> wearing a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">top hat</mark> and decide to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">aim</mark> at it. The top hat is a perfect, giant target you use to take down this animal.
mnemonics.reading: Ready, steady, aim... fire! You throw a bar of soap (そ) at the animal. Yes, soap. You were sitting in your bathtub, washing and scrubbing, then the animal in the top hat caught your eye.

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> is full of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark>s because it's an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">army camp</mark>. The cars (and tanks and planes) need to be ready to go at any moment just like the soldiers.
mnemonics.reading: All of the people in the army camp are wearing jeans (じん). You thought soldiers were supposed to wear uniforms, but it looks like when they're in the camp they have to wear jeans.

mnemonics.meaning: Under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark>, an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">explosion</mark> shakes the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>, exposing a hidden <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">base</mark>. A <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">baseball base</mark>! I guess this rice paddy was built on top of an old baseball field…
mnemonics.reading: Unfortunately, thanks to the explosion, the base is in ruins (るい). It's dark and smokey and kinda half burned. You probably can't get this in a regulation game.

mnemonics.meaning: What's like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bow</mark>, but even more <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">simple</mark>? A <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bullet</mark>. With a bow, you have to load an arrow and pull back the string and aim, yuck. Bullets can be shot with just a simple squeeze of a trigger.
mnemonics.reading: If you want to shoot bullets, you need to do it at dawn (だん). Back in the old days, it wasn't bright enough to shoot arrows at dawn, but you can shoot bullets at dawn because they're simpler to use!

mnemonics.meaning: You brought <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> to leave at the place where a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yakuza</mark> took a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark> and killed <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">twenty</mark> people, since there's now a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">burial</mark> happening there. You didn't know these people, but you still want to leave flowers at their burial.
mnemonics.reading: Once the burial is complete the souls (そう) of all the dead people come floating up and out of the ground. "Thaaannk YooOoOO~" they moan, as they ascend to the sky.

mnemonics.meaning: You take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> and slam a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">table</mark>. You make this big noise to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">confront</mark> the person in front of you.
mnemonics.reading: You are trying to confront Emperor こういち. You're confronting him about all the kanji he's forcing you, and everyone else, to learn. "Look here こういち! I know you said I'd learn like 2000 kanji in no time, but this is way too efficient! What will the people do when they're done? Do you think they will sit idly by?"

mnemonics.meaning: Below this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> and another <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> crash into each other and the entire thing <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">crumble</mark>s to pieces.
mnemonics.reading: As the mountain crumbles you see your home (ほう), which is at the very top of the mountain, come crumbling down too.

mnemonics.meaning: On the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> is an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bear</mark>. The bear immediately stomps the insect, squishing it flat. "My god, the insect is smashed. Someone call <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dispatch</mark>!"
mnemonics.reading: Out of the dispatched ambulance jumps Ken (けん) the samurai. "Dispatch sent me! I'm here to fix that insect."

mnemonics.meaning: Use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> when the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> shines into your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> cell and hold your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark> up in full <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">display</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The reason you display it is to get some cake (けい). In this prison, if you display your spoon deftly enough, the wardens bring you some cake as a reward.

mnemonics.meaning: If you combine <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">violence</mark>, it will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">explode</mark>! A fire, once full of violence, will surely explode. The fire can’t handle all that violence so the fire just rumbles and shakes and then finally explodes. BOOM!
mnemonics.reading: As you watch the fire explode, you start to back (ばく) away. I don’t blame you. You need to back away or else you’ll get caught in the violent explosion. Back away a little more just to be safe.

mnemonics.meaning: You're holding a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stick</mark> above your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark>s to imitate <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">eyebrows</mark>. You can't grow any of your own, but you really love eyebrows, so this was the best you could do.
mnemonics.reading: Underneath your fake eyebrows are two slabs of meat (み). Meat helps hair grow, according to many Internet specialists who also happen to sell meat. You're waiting for this meat to foster eyebrow hair, and when that sweet day comes you won't need these flags.

mnemonics.meaning: You carry a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> across a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> on it to return a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">favor</mark> for your friend. The heart needs to be purified so that’s why you have it on the cross and your friend lives on a rice paddy farm so that’s why you’re running through that. The favor you are paying your friend back with is getting him this heart. He needs a new one and you’re providing it.
mnemonics.reading: You arrive at your friend’s place and you can finally return the favor you owe him by presenting him with the heart. “Eh (え)? What’s this? I didn’t ask for this!” “Eh!?!?” you reply. Apparently he didn’t want a real heart, he wanted a candy one. He wanted a Valentine!

mnemonics.meaning: At this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gate</mark> you're trying to get some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">beans</mark> through, but your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurements</mark> were off, leading to a big <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fight</mark>. The bean authorities at the gate always want to fight about bean sizes, and now you have to fight to get those beans through.
mnemonics.reading: The gate you put up a fight at leads to とうきょう. The people of とうきょう need those beans for sustenance, and that's why you fight — for them!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> pushes all the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fish</mark> closer to land, making for some easy <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fishing</mark>. The tsunami starts out in the middle of the ocean and pushes all the fish towards the coast where everyone does their fishing. With all the fish pushed closer to land and closer together, it’s very easy for people to go fishing in one spot and catch a lot of fish.
mnemonics.reading: To get to the best fishing spot you need to go (ぎょ) row (りょう) out to the middle of the ocean. You go by means of rowing. To get to the fish and do the fishing, you need to go and row out to sea.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Grain</mark> left in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> blossom and give off a wonderful <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fragrance</mark>. They smell fresh and delicious. There's nothing better than the fragrance of fresh, sun-kissed grain.
mnemonics.reading: As you sniff this lovely fragrance you get lost in the smell. When you open your eyes again, you see a farming こういち standing in front of you. With... his... arm... up. "Do you like my fragrance? I was genetically modified to have a unique fragrance compared to the other こういちs."

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Tsunami</mark>s hit these lands <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">again</mark> and again, molding it into some kind of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bow</mark> shape. Or in other words, creating a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gulf</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: How many gulfs will this create? Just one (わん).

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">foot</mark> heard an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">omen</mark> and now it's making you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hop</mark> over things.
mnemonics.reading: As you hop you start to hear an awful scream coming down the street. It's Mrs. Chou (ちょう) and she's running straight for you yelling, "STEP ON MY STREET'S CRACKS! STOP HOPPING OR YOUR MOTHER WILL NEVER BREAK HER BACK!"

mnemonics.meaning: Take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wrap</mark> them around another person. This is called a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hug</mark>. Just make sure you include all the stuff attached to your fingers, like your hands and arms too, otherwise it's more of a squeeze, and we don't want to do that to people.
mnemonics.reading: Who do you love to hug the most? Your dad (だ)! He gives the best hugs. They're warm and big and tight and comforting. The kind of hug dads are really good at giving.

mnemonics.meaning: When a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> holds the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> inside it, everything will always be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">in season</mark>. Obviously if the sun is in prison, the seasons can't change. Want to eat perfect apples all year round? Just put the sun in prison when they're ripe — usually a short window of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ten days</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: When things are in season for more than ten days, people are going to wonder what's going on. When's Christmas? When's Golden Week? Soon (しゅん), you say. Soon enough, it's June (じゅん). Which is the middle of the year, so now everything is soon.

mnemonics.meaning: When your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ear</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark>ed with sound, it catches it like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark>, and sends it to your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> for processing. Because you're using your heart to process this sound, it means you're giving it a proper <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">listen</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You are listening so well to what someone is saying. What are they telling you that is so important? They are telling you of the omen of Mrs. Chou (ちょう), who will destroy the earth.

mnemonics.meaning: You give your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">servant</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark> along with some other <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">products</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">look to</mark>. You can’t look to them yourself since you are very busy. You allow your servant to look to your gun and the other products.
mnemonics.reading: After your servant is done with your gun and other products you want him to look to your car’s o-ring (りん). There’s something wrong with the o-ring so you want your servant to look to that as well.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">omen</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">omen</mark> kanji are the same!
