mnemonics.reading: You listen to the omen, in it, it tells of an event in the future when Mrs. Chou (ちょう) will destroy the world.

mnemonics.meaning: The weight of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark> on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> when you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pledge</mark> to protect your city. That's the big, big weight of every single person's life in that city pressing down on you every time you take out that sword.
mnemonics.reading: Until the city is safe, you pledge to give up cake (けい), your favorite food.

mnemonics.meaning: Destroy a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lantern</mark> with your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> and you'll be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">punish</mark>ed.
mnemonics.reading: I will punish you by taking away your cake (けい)! You'll never eat cake again. Not for birthdays, not for holidays. This is your punishment.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">greenhouse</mark> is the newest <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> of the city you decided to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">recruit</mark>. You’re trying to recruit all the buildings in town and the greenhouse was the next on your list. It adds just a little bit of power to the town, but it's important nonetheless.
mnemonics.reading: After you recruit the greenhouse, you recruit Bobo (ぼ) the clown to guard it for you. Bobo the clown has a terrifying amount of power so he’ll make an excellent guard for the greenhouse.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> presents you with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prize</mark> as <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">reparation</mark> for his past deeds. This leader wronged you in the past and wishes to make amends. Therefore the leader presents you with a reparation in the form of a glittering prize.
mnemonics.reading: The leader who presented you with this reparation is the Shougun (しょう) of Japan. He's trying to make up for all the threats he made to you and some of the things you saw (which he's now trying to cover up for).

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> join the rest of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clan</mark>, pressed into the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> to declare that you will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">resist</mark> your lords. Your clan is made of a bunch of peasants, but you aren't going to work the land for other people anymore. You're going to resist. Your fingers work for no one but yourselves from now on!
mnemonics.reading: You're all resisting with your fingers in the ground, when the lords appear, angry. "You resist us by hiding your fingers with potatoes in the ground?! You want your fingers to be useless potatoes so badly? We'll chop them up and turn them into tater (てい) tots!"

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">door</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> and you need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">return</mark> it to its rightful owner. This door is too big and important looking to not belong to someone. You need to find its owner and return it to them.
mnemonics.reading: You are in return mode (もど). When you enter this mode, you concentrate only on returning something. Nothing else matters in this mode. You’re in full on return mode.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">call</mark>s out to the earth by <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shining</mark> down on it.
mnemonics.reading: This shining is aimed directly at the Shougun (しょう). The sun is shining on the Shougun to not only show its support for his leadership, but to let him shine brighter than anyone else in Japan.

mnemonics.meaning: Put <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> of a worm while the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> is out and it will poop out some <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">silk</mark>. That's why they call them silkworms, didn't you know? But it has to be while the moon is out, otherwise normal thread will come right back out the other end of the worm. The moon is what makes the magic happen.
mnemonics.reading: Wearing silk is the key (き) to not being nude (ぬ). Wear it!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">skewer</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">skewer</mark> kanji are exactly the same!
mnemonics.reading: Uh oh, this skewer is really... cushy (くし). It's so soft and cushy you can't get any meat or vegetables onto it.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Happiness</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">circle</mark> that's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tenacious</mark>. In other words, we're all in this circle/cycle where we do whatever we can to grab onto happiness and hold it as tightly as we can.
mnemonics.reading: Happiness is as tenacious as a shih tzu (しつ) with a shoe (しゅう). That little dog does not want to give up on the shoe, no matter what's happening around it.

mnemonics.meaning: When you're stepping around with your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">foot</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">again</mark> and again, you'll leave behind <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">traces</mark> all over the place.
mnemonics.reading: Turns out you leaving traces everywhere is quite sexy (せき) to a lot of people.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">triceratops</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">whittle down</mark> anything.
mnemonics.reading: Everything it will whittle down shall be put in a sack (さく).

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> asks <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">half</mark> of his men to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">accompany</mark> him on a secret mission. The leader’s mission is volunteer only, so it’s impressive that he got half of his men to accompany him.
mnemonics.reading: The leader you decided to accompany is none other than Han (はん) Solo. Who could be more inspiring? I’m surprised not more than half decided to accompany him. Han Solo is awesome.

mnemonics.meaning: You get <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tooth</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">orders</mark>. You get these tooth orders various times in your life, depending on your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">age</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Gaining and losing teeth aren't the only things dependent on age. There is also an age in which you get your first ray (れい) gun.

mnemonics.meaning: By showing the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">top hat</mark> you send your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">best regards</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: When you give your best regards you always yell YOLO (よろ) to the other person.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tooth</mark> that you use to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bite</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chew</mark> with.
mnemonics.reading: Your one tooth is so strong that you can even use it to bite and chew up a whole car (か).

mnemonics.meaning: The more <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">have</mark>, the more you can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bribe</mark> people. That worked in the olden days when shells were money, and today too if the people you want to bribe really like seafood.
mnemonics.reading: Welp, the cops found out about your bribe, that didn't last long, and now your entire family is watching you get put into the police car screaming, "WHY (わい)?!

mnemonics.meaning: Someone is offering you a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> in exchange for a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kiss</mark>. This is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bribe</mark>! You don't want to kiss them, but that shellfish sure looks tasty.
mnemonics.reading: You go through with the bribe and kiss the person, but then they snatch hold of the shellfish and run straight down the road (ろ). No!!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">door</mark> in that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> is among a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cluster</mark> of doors. You run in the direction of the cluster and one door stands out to you. You enter it.
mnemonics.reading: After you make it through the door, you come across another cluster of doors. Which one to choose? There's a loud thunderous sound coming from behind one and you decide to open it. Behind it, there's an entire bowling (ぼう) alley and people bowling, loudly!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tiger</mark> needs to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">think</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">consider</mark> its actions before it attacks. Tigers are smart hunters, so they need to consider all options and really think through a situation.
mnemonics.reading: Finally, the tiger speaks: "I'm considering going to Rio (りょ). Have you ever been?"

mnemonics.meaning: They <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> if you put things on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark>, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">seven</mark> things to be exact, that’s the best way to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">consign</mark> goods to someone. They say if you consign seven things to someone, you should send them over on a slide. Slide ‘em on down. All seven of ‘em.
mnemonics.reading: One of the seven things you consign over to this guy is a tack (たく). It’s the sharpest tack you’ve ever seen. You slide the tack down the slide. Good thing no one is on the slide now, sitting on that tack would hurt.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Past</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stamp</mark>s usually depict images <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">contrary</mark> to current views.
mnemonics.reading: Don't be the type of person who acts contrary to how they should and instead be like Kyaku (きゃく) the customer. They're always so nice and polite and they don't give diseases to entire populations of people.

mnemonics.meaning: The kind of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> you'd wrap around <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">someone</mark> would have to be a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cord</mark>. A regular thread wouldn't be strong enough, so you'd definitely use a cord.
mnemonics.reading: Actually, you're tying this cord around someone as part of a show (しょ). What kind of a show? I really shouldn't say. This cord show isn't free, I'll tell you that much.

mnemonics.meaning: In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rain</mark> I take my <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rake</mark> and shake it, making a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">demand</mark> that the rain stop! I demand this rain stop right now! Don’t make me shake my rake more violently than I am currently shaking it!
mnemonics.reading: Now imagine the rain changing. Wait a second, this isn't rain, it's juice (じゅ)! You shake your rake harder, and demand that the juice rain continues. It doesn't listen to your demands and stops as soon as you start bottling it. Well, at least you have enough for one, really small juice box.

mnemonics.meaning: You offer a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hot pepper</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark>, and he gives you a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of something. You look down at the drop to see it transforming into a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">disc</mark>. And not just any old disc at that. It's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">jade disc</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Wait, did a drop really just change into a disc? What the heck is (へき) going on?

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mole</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">do</mark> whatever you ask, if you know how to ask it.
mnemonics.reading: To get the mole to do what you want, just give it a nice big hunk of cheese (ち).

mnemonics.meaning: You're on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> and suddenly someone throws a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hot pepper</mark> at you and you have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dodge</mark> it.
mnemonics.reading: As you dodge the hot peppers, you feel a strong heat (ひ) fill your body. You can't tell if this heat is from the effort from dodging or if you didn't dodge right and one of the hot peppers touched you. Or maybe the scooter is overheating.

mnemonics.meaning: With your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> you pluck some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark>, in order to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">draw</mark> them. Have you ever seen rice paddy flowers? They're beautiful. And if you can draw them, you can capture that beauty and show it to everyone.
mnemonics.reading: Even though you tried to draw the flowers as best you could, whenever someone looks at it they smell B.O. (びょう). Maybe it's because you were drawing for a really long time and kept sweating. Maybe it's because you are just a stinky person. But no one wants to look at your drawing for long because all they can smell is B.O.

mnemonics.meaning: You got your copy of "The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Dry</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Knife</mark>." It's the newest <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">edition</mark> of the magazine you love on keeping your knives dry.
mnemonics.reading: In this edition of "The Dry Knife," there is a huge article written by Genghis Khan (かん) on how he kept his knives dry while campaigning.

mnemonics.meaning: You use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> when the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">omen</mark> comes so that you can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">escape</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You decide to escape this omen by weaving in and out of the busy streets of とうきょう. By now, you know とうきょう like the back of your hand, so you're sure you can escape this way.

mnemonics.meaning: Where do you put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> when you're on an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">escalator</mark>? On the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">handle</mark>! Okay, so maybe it's not a handle and more of a railing, but for the sake of this kanji, picture a handle instead.
mnemonics.reading: You put your hand on the handle and an old person leans in close to you and says, "暑か?" (あつか). He wants to know if the handle is ... hot? Before you can respond he says it again, and again! “暑か？！ 暑か？！？！ 暑か？！？！？！” he's shouting as you slowly ride the escalator away from him.

mnemonics.meaning: If there’s a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">head</mark> and the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark>, you know you’re in the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">interior</mark>. And by interior, I mean you’re actually inside someone. The rice is big because you’ve shrunk to a tiny size and are inside someone’s stomach. The drop on your head is actually digestive fluid.
mnemonics.reading: While you’re in the interior of this guy, you hear him break out in song. He starts singing “Oklahoma” (おく) at the top of his lungs. The big pieces of rice slosh around as he sings and dances. “OOOOk-lahoma, where the wind comes sweepin' down the plain!”

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> takes a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lantern</mark> and searches for people to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">join</mark> him. He needs more people to join his cause so he can get his horns removed. He’s embarrassed of them which is why he only travels at night, hence the lantern.
mnemonics.reading: The leader guy approaches you out of the darkness, his lantern held high. Oh no, not that guy. You've heard about his horn problem and you don't want to join him. You look around and spot a large haystack (へい). You quickly jump into it and hide from him.

mnemonics.meaning: Under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> beneath a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> there is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hat</mark> filled with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark>. You stare down into the water and decide to stick your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">knee</mark> in it.
mnemonics.reading: Suddenly, in your knee, you feel heat and a zap (ひざ)! Your knee is simultaneously burned and electrocuted by the hot water!!

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">change</mark> this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark> because you want it to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lean</mark>. Right now it's standing up straight, but you want it to lean to one side instead.
mnemonics.reading: To get the geoduck to lean you put a piece of cake (けい) on one of its sides.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> on this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">football</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">loose</mark>. We need to tighten up the loose thread on this football or it’s gonna fall apart while we’re playing.
mnemonics.reading: You finally tighten the loose thread and all of your friends cheer, “You rule!” (ゆる) You rule because you fixed the loose thread on the football and now you can play again. Yeah! You rule, man!

mnemonics.meaning: When it's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spring</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heaven</mark> they <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">play music</mark>. To your mortal, human ears it sounds more like snow melting, birds chirping, and plants waking up.
mnemonics.reading: In heaven, the ones that play music are the souls (そう) of the dead. They have a huge band up there, and even though it just seems like normal spring sounds to you, up there in heaven when the souls play music it's more like a huge, 100-part band!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> who has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">landslide</mark> getting ready inside her is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pregnant</mark>. And that baby is gonna come out like a landslide.
mnemonics.reading: When you're pregnant the baby is constantly kicking you with their shins (しん). Not their feet, their shins. And shins are really hard, let me tell you.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> sleeps with the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> and becomes <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pregnant</mark>. Only the king wasn’t human and now the woman is pregnant with a hybrid alien baby!
mnemonics.reading: Being pregnant with this strange creature, you need to do something to calm you down. You should play Nintendo (にん). Nintendo really calms your nerves and makes being pregnant with some mutant baby not seem like that big of a deal anymore.

mnemonics.meaning: You put on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mask</mark> once per year and break into people's beach houses, leaving behind <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">presents</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The "presents" you leave? They are actually just zombies (ぞう). You leave zombies in people's houses.

mnemonics.meaning: Shove your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> into a bowl of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shrimp</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">select</mark> the best one. You know your shrimp and you know them well, so you won't settle for anything less than the best. Put your whole arm in there and feel around until you can select the one you want most.
mnemonics.reading: You do this at every restaurant, party, and indoor sporting event and people start getting wise to your shrimp selection methods. One day, as you attempt to select your shrimp, a sharp pain shoots through your finger. Ow! You pull your hand back to find... a tack (たく)!

mnemonics.meaning: There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> coming toward you with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> trapping a weird <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">zombie</mark> on it. You don't want this here, so you decide to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">send back</mark> the zombie. (It's a weird zombie because it has the ground on top of its head instead of dirt!)
mnemonics.reading: As you prepare to send back the zombie, you imagine yourself as Genghis Khan (かん). On your horse (it's just your own scooter) you stab forward with your spear (stick), swing the scooter the zombie is on, and send it back from whence it came!

mnemonics.meaning: You have <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> and some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">syrup</mark> and you need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">spin</mark> them together. Drip the syrup onto the thread and spin it around and around over your head.
mnemonics.reading: As you spin the syrup, it begins to change shape and forms into a cookie (く)! Haven't you ever made syrup-spun cookies before? The spinning forms and cooks them in the air.

mnemonics.meaning: Use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cat pirate</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">suppress</mark> him. The cat pirate was attacking you, so you took your fingers and pet his head and scratched his chin. Now he's calm and suppressed. He doesn't even remember why he was attacking you.
mnemonics.reading: He forgot, but you know you had to suppress the cat pirate because he was trying to steal your egg yolk (よく). You were making breakfast on your ship and the cat pirate boarded you out of nowhere, and tried to take it by force.

mnemonics.meaning: In your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prefecture</mark>, you come from a long <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lineage</mark> of people who share one <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>. When the heart is passed on to the next in line, it flies out of their body, and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">suspend</mark>s itself in the sky, for you to take.
mnemonics.reading: You arrive at the suspended heart. There in front of it, protecting it, is Ken (けん) the samurai.

mnemonics.meaning: You take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark> and fashion it into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark> that is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">small</mark>, earning you the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">title</mark> of Small Arms Dealer (or SAD). Congratulations!
mnemonics.reading: Word of your SAD title makes it all the way to the Shougun (しょう) and he travels out to see you. When he arrives at your door, with all of his fancy escorts, he hands you a plaque with your title on it.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boat</mark> holds your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark> like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">plate</mark>. So in a way, it's just a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tray</mark> for your weapon.
mnemonics.reading: Unfortunately, this boat tray is so huge, it's gotten you banned (ばん) from the Small Boat Tray Association. Those pesky small boat tray enthusiasts...

mnemonics.meaning: Raise your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sky</mark> to symbolize that you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">abstain</mark> from something. If someone offers you fur coats, raise your fingers to abstain. If someone tries to get you to bully someone, raise your fingers to abstain.
mnemonics.reading: This symbol to abstain comes from the hicatee (ひか) turtle. The hicatee is a Central American river turtle hunted for its meat, eggs, and shell. Therefore, the poor hicatee are endangered. So people started to rally around them, abstaining from hurting them anymore. They raised their fingers to the sky and shouted, "I abstain from harming these hicatee!"

mnemonics.meaning: On your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> every <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">evening</mark> you meet with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">snake</mark>s. All snakes know your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">address</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The snakes come to your address every night to receive the greatest gift you can give a snake: a 手 (あて).

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">allocate</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">allocate</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: If you allocate your funds correctly you'll be able to buy as many precious jewels (じゅう) as you want! However, jewels are expensive, so if you don't allocate any money, you won't be able to afford any. Ever.

mnemonics.meaning: There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> coming and you can't <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stop</mark> the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">explosion</mark> of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bitter</mark>ness in your mouth. You're scared. Your mouth tastes bitter and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">astringent</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: With the bitter taste in your mouth, you reluctantly gather up all of your jewels (じゅう) and wait for the tsunami to take you away. At least with your jewels with you, there may be some hope of selling them and building a better life if you make it.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">branch</mark> will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">branch off</mark> from the rest.
mnemonics.reading: If you want to branch off from your hiking group and explore this branch of the mountain, you need a special key (き). Just don't get caught down there or you'll get the guillotine (ぎ).

mnemonics.meaning: You take <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> in exchange for executing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">orders</mark> to construct a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">buzzer</mark>. You are a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">small bell</mark> maker and someone orders you to make one into a buzzer in exchange for some gold. This is how you make a living.
mnemonics.reading: Finally the buzzer is done. You’ve earned your gold. You test the buzzer and it goes ring (りん)! Ring! Ring! Ring! Ring ring ring ring ring! Man, that ringing is annoying but hey, that’s what buzzers do.

mnemonics.meaning: This hunk of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> sticks out in a very <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">odd</mark> way. Oh, wait, it's just the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cape</mark> jutting out into the water below. Phew.
mnemonics.reading: The cape below looks just like your cyborg (さい). Or rather, the cyborg you once had, before you had to give him up. It's kinda cross-shaped, it has a slide part, and lots of little fleshy bits. Ah, the memories.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">crab</mark> breaks into your games cabinet and steals a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chess piece</mark>. He’s trying to impress all his tree crabs back home by showing how not afraid of humans he is. Plus the rest of the tree crabs need one last chess piece to complete their set.
mnemonics.reading: Before the tree crab can make it out with the chess piece, you shut the door to the games cabinet and lock it with a key (き), trapping the tree crab inside. Now what?

mnemonics.meaning: Inside this giant <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">person</mark>, trapped, because they're a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">criminal</mark>. They did something bad (they touched the mouth of another person without consent) and now they're in mouth jail for criminals.
mnemonics.reading: The criminal is only wearing shoes (しゅう). They're completely naked otherwise. They have to wear shoes because the mouth jail would be too slippery for them to stand otherwise.

mnemonics.meaning: When you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> "<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Nurse</mark>!" you're probably asking to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">defer</mark> to them in some way, shape, or form.
mnemonics.reading: The reason you’re trying to defer to a nurse is because you’re trying to save the local farmhand, Joe (じょう). He’s seriously injured, and you don’t know how to help him, so you’ll have to defer to the knowledge of a nurse.

mnemonics.meaning: In through your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">door</mark> walks a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark>, so you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">employ</mark> it. You've always employed any turkey that comes through that door.
mnemonics.reading: Although you employ turkeys, when a 子 (こ) walks through your door, you send them away.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">excuse</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">excuse</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Dandy!
mnemonics.reading: Who always makes excuse after excuse? Men (めん)! They have an excuse for everything. Why didn’t you take out the trash? Why did you forget my birthday? It’s just excuse after excuse with men. So I’ve heard, anyway.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">buddy</mark> the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sheep</mark> is part of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">flock</mark>. A flock of sheep. Your sheep buddy is a member of a flock.
mnemonics.reading: Now take out your gun (ぐん) and murder every sheep in the flock. Except for your buddy. You’re incredibly jealous of your buddy and you don’t like the attention his flock gives him so that’s why you decided to murder them all with a gun.

mnemonics.meaning: In a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> on <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nine</mark> branches are some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">frame</mark>s. Each cross frame is hung on the branches of the tree. You don’t know who decided to hang the frames there, but you think it might be some new wave art or something. Actually you need a frame, and there are already nine up there, so you decide to take one.
mnemonics.reading: You realize that the frame isn't half as nice as you thought it was, in fact it's totally wack (わく). How disappointing.

mnemonics.meaning: Take some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">allocate</mark> it to buy a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gun</mark>. Guns are weapons of the old world, so you can't just buy them with paper money. Guns have to be bought with gold coins or bricks.
mnemonics.reading: You need this gun so you can steal some jewels (じゅう)! Why didn't you just use your gold to buy the jewels, you ask? Because! That's not how we did things in olden days. When you want jewels you buy a gun with gold and rob a jewelry store!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> who lives in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark> is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hermit</mark>. The only thing this hermit is a leader of now is mountain goats. This hermit dislikes people so that’s why he lives in a mountain now.
mnemonics.reading: One day the hermit was leading the mountain goats around and he ran into a centaur (せん). The centaur said that he was the rightful leader of these mountain goats so the centaur challenged the hermit to a duel.

mnemonics.meaning: There are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">three</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark>s sticking out of this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> that lead to your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">home country</mark>. The rest of the slides go to other places, but three are yours.
mnemonics.reading: Your home country is your home (ほう)!

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark> at <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">noon</mark> near a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stop</mark> sign to get a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stamp</mark> of approval from someone <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">honorable</mark>. This honorable personage drives by at noon every day, and because they have to stop at the stop sign, people loiter here for a chance to get their honorable stamp of approval.
mnemonics.reading: The honorable personage is Godzilla (ご). Actually, you're requesting Godzilla's stamp of approval for a new demolition job in downtown Tokyo. Godzilla is the god of urban demolition, what with all those cities it's destroyed, and you need its honorable approval to continue.

mnemonics.meaning: When someone wants to view your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">reality</mark>, show it with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">humility</mark>. Because the reality is... our souls are all a little dirty. And we haven't been the best versions we could be. So make sure when you show all of yourself you do so with some humility.
mnemonics.reading: As humility washes over you, you feel a shaking in your shins (しん). Humility lives in your shins, so now they're shaking and trying to bring you down to the ground.

mnemonics.meaning: You use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">foot</mark> to kick <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark> in the face so a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">leap</mark> to freedom. This turkey is trying to escape from Wolverine by leaping over a fence. Wolverine doesn’t want the turkey to escape, but you kick him with your foot and the turkey is then free to leap to safety.
mnemonics.reading: After you kick Wolverine and the turkey is safe, you leap onto a yak (やく) to make your getaway. This yak is really fast so you’ll have no problem outrunning Wolverine while riding it.

mnemonics.meaning: They <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Mona Lisa</mark> had more <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">modesty</mark> than any other woman at the time.
mnemonics.reading: The modesty of Mona Lisa inspired Ken (けん) the samurai to become more modest.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of rain falls on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bear</mark> leaning up against a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> stuck into a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mound</mark>. The drop wakes the bear up and he rolls down off the mound. After the bear rights himself, he assumes that the cross pushed him off the mound so he charges into the cross atop the mound and knocks it over.
mnemonics.reading: Once the bear fully wakes up he realizes that he just rolled down the mound on his own and the cross was not to blame. What a fool (ふ) this bear was. He knows it too. The bear feels pretty foolish.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">one sided</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">one sided</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: Think of anything that is one sided. A battle. A sports game. A relationship. What makes them so one sided? One side always has a catapult (かた).

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Construction</mark> for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark>s doesn't require as much paperwork as construction for humans, but you still need to write at least a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">paragraph</mark> to explain what you're doing.
mnemonics.reading: You turn in your paragraph, and it is given to Emperor こういち, who insists on being involved in all construction projects. Surprisingly, he approves your construction project, thanks to that paragraph you wrote in the application.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Criminal</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">writing</mark> is always <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">patterned</mark>. That is to say, there is a pattern to it, lots of ARGS and GONNA STAB YAs, but it's also patterned beautifully, with a collage of cut out letters.
mnemonics.reading: As you look closer at the patterned writing you realize that it forms the shape of an eagle (い). The most American bird of them all! Maybe this guy isn't a criminal after all!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> will allow <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark> to have <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">prosperity</mark>. Before we had buildings it was impossible to have any prosperity in winter because everything was cold and most of us died.
mnemonics.reading: This prosperity isn't good for everyone though. You look over and see Ryu (りゅう) from Street Fighter sitting in the corner. He's got everything he could ask for. He's won the tournament, he's got money, he's got this nice big building, but now he's depressed.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> contains a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scroll</mark>, which you pull out and look at. On the scroll is a map, showing the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">range</mark> of the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sphere</mark> of your mouth.
mnemonics.reading: Looking at the range of your mouth on the map, you notice a tiny samurai marked near your molars. It is Ken (けん) the samurai.

mnemonics.meaning: Show your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">giant</mark> to show you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">refuse</mark> him. Giants are very big. So big that when you talk they can't really hear what you're saying. Hold up all your fingers so that he can see what you mean.
mnemonics.reading: What do you refuse? You refuse to let him stomp all over Little Kyoto (きょ). Little Kyoto is your home! And if the giant comes any closer he's going to destroy all the little buildings and shrines and soba noodle shops.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark> stuck in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cleat</mark> had a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">former</mark> life. In that life it was a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rice plant</mark>. It was a happy little rice plant, minding its own business, when it was yanked up, cleaned, and put in a bag for people to buy and cook and eat. That was so long ago. Now all that's left is this sad loose grain in the bottom of your shoe.
mnemonics.reading: The grain of rice thinks about its former life as a rice plant and, like you, mutters "いね." What's that, little rice grain? Are you trying to say life was good?

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> takes the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark>s of a safe before he can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rob</mark> it. If the safe is too big it won't fit in his getaway car and the robbery will have been a failure. So before the turkey robs a place he needs to get those measurements.
mnemonics.reading: Once he's able to rob the place, he gets away in an Uber (うば). He just called the Uber in advance and had it wait outside. Hey, if you're gonna rob a place, make sure you have an Uber.

mnemonics.meaning: You come across a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hill</mark>. You think you hit it big! You start digging, only to find out that it is merely a paper-thin layer of gold covering a hill of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">steel</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You report your findings about the steel you found to Emperor こういち. He is displeased that it is a hill of steel.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turtle shell</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">turtle shell</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Oddly, this can also be used to talk about the first item in a list, so to mean <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">A</mark> out of A through D, for example.
mnemonics.reading: With a turtle shell on his back, imagine こういち.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tiger</mark>, clad in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spikes</mark>, exists in the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">void</mark>. This tiger is from another dimension where tigers rule the earth, clad in armor with spikes. The void has allowed this tiger to cross dimensional planes.
mnemonics.reading: The aforementioned void has opened up in Little Kyoto (きょ). The spiked void tigers chose to come here in order to face off against the Hanshin Tigers baseball team in battle. It will be a vicious match here in Little Kyoto. Since this is taking place in Little Kyoto and not Japan itself, the Hanshin Tigers won't have the home field advantage. Who will win?

mnemonics.meaning: There are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hot peppers</mark> hiding in this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>, so you build a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wall</mark> to protect yourself from them. Have you ever stepped on a really hot pepper? The oils bleed into your shoes and burn your feet! You don't want anyone stepping on these so you wall them up.
mnemonics.reading: On the other side of this wall there are much less threatening cobs (かべ) of corn. Corn isn't spicy. It's delicious and sweet, so it's free from being walled in.

mnemonics.meaning: When a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stop</mark>s protecting you, you'll have to go on <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">welfare</mark>. If you can't rely on your family spirit, you'll have to have the help and protection come from somewhere else.
mnemonics.reading: While on welfare, you have to do the only job available to you: herding sheep (し). Sheep can help you out when you're having a rough time. Sheep provide warmth, wool for clothes, and even food, if you wanna get dark about it.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> have to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> up straight, to protect you from being <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">abduct</mark>ed, or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pull</mark>ed away against your will.
mnemonics.reading: Suddenly, someone really is trying to abduct you. They're pullling you away. It's the ancient Egyptian god Ra (ら). Help!

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Every</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> you are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">alert</mark> for danger. Everyone knows that the worst monsters come out in the winter so you need to be alert if you want to survive.
mnemonics.reading: Being the alert fellow you are, you hear a sasquatch approaching and dive into a trash bin (びん) to hide. The bin smells really bad and you are keenly alert to all the various stenches and smells currently penetrating your nostrils, but at least you are safe.

mnemonics.meaning: You attempt to expel wind out of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> but <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lack</mark> the breath to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">blow</mark> out any. You’re using your mouth and trying to blow out some air, but you are failing to do so.
mnemonics.reading: You silly fool (ふ), the reason you couldn’t blow any air out of your mouth is because your hand was over it. You can’t blow air out that way. You silly fool, you.

mnemonics.meaning: It's time to do the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chant</mark>. That's when you use your mouth to chant sun sun, sun sun, sun sun, over and over until the sun appears.
mnemonics.reading: You're doing this chant because the Shougun (しょう) ordered you to. The sun hasn't been shining on him as much lately, and he's displeased. So now you have to chant for him.

mnemonics.meaning: If you try to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">go</mark> somewhere but you're too <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heavy</mark> you'll <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">collide</mark> with everything. Cars, people, houses. You're too heavy to dodge them, so you collide with it all.
mnemonics.reading: You're going around the town, you collide with a bunch of things, when all of a sudden you collide with the Shougun (しょう)! Oh no! The shogun looks really mad.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> issued <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">twenty</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">commandment</mark>s to his people.
mnemonics.reading: The drunkard is yelling out his twenty commandments to the others at the bar, but they're all about kayaks (かい).

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Mona Lisa</mark> is in front of you. "You must all paint the Mona Lisa <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">concurrently</mark>," says your art class teacher.
mnemonics.reading: Your entire class finishes concurrently. You look at your finished result. Wait, that's not the Mona Lisa. You painted Ken (けん) the samurai.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> are being worked upon by a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">specialty</mark>: this tsunami can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dilute</mark> flowers with just one tsunami-powered drop of itself. That’s its specialty.
mnemonics.reading: You watch the flowers become diluted with just one drop, and realize that this is a nature hack (はく). You’ve never seen anything like this before, so you think the tsunami found out how to hack nature and that’s how it got so good at diluting things. By hacking nature.

mnemonics.meaning: Imagine you're driving and there's some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> in it near the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">exit</mark> ramp. That flag marks a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ditch</mark> running alongside the road. Don't try to exit the road here, or you'll end up stuck in that ditch.
mnemonics.reading: If you do end up veering into a ditch you'll find yourself yelling, "Holy (ほり) crap!" Then you'll go hurtling into the ditch.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Simultaneous</mark>ly, you throw your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> at another person who's throwing a knife at you and you both get a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dose</mark> of your own medicine. Literally, there's poison on these knives and now you've both been stabbed.
mnemonics.reading: "I need a dose of the antidote!" you yell, and the other guy looks you dead in the eyes. They slowly pull a tiny xylophone (ざい) out of their pocket, play a few notes, and then eat it. "Ah, you'd like a dose of the xylophone cure, wouldn't you?"

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fang</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">elegant</mark>. Most turkeys do not have fangs, so this turkey with a fang is quite elegant and dignified. This turkey is special.
mnemonics.reading: This elegant fang makes the turkey look more like a gargoyle (が) than a turkey. In fact, you haven't seen it move at all. Maybe it is just an elegant gargoyle!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> are where <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">criminal</mark>s <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">emit</mark> or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">expel</mark> all of their bad energy from.
mnemonics.reading: Then you realize what the fingers are actually emitting: terrible, awful haiku (はい).

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Teacher</mark>s are all around us. Those who came before us are our teachers, so it's important to respect them. This is the basic idea of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">filial piety</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: With filial piety in mind, you decide to go visit your father, who is こういち.

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">walk</mark> by a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark> a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">frequent</mark> amount. This geoduck really intrigues you, so you can’t help but frequent the area the geoduck is in and walk around.
mnemonics.reading: Apparently Hindu people also love geoducks because Hindu (ひん) people frequent this area quite often as well. You always see the geoduck here, but also a lot of Hindu people.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horse</mark> goes to his favorite <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">district</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gallop</mark> around. This district has lots of cool buildings and lights to look at, so this horse loves to gallop around there.
mnemonics.reading: Then the horse gallops into the road and gets hit by a car (か). Oh man, there’s blood everywhere. This horse is never going to gallop again. That car totally destroyed it.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of all the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spider</mark>s is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">genius</mark>! Spiders are already pretty smart. They can weave complex homes and traps in one web. They even know where not to step so they don't get caught. But the leader knows everything. It made itself a little webbed computer and everything!
mnemonics.reading: As you watch the spider genius you realize that soon (しゅん) spiders will take over the humans. They're just way smarter than us. Soon we'll be the bugs.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rejoic</mark>ing. She must be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">glad</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">happy</mark> to rejoice out loud in front of you like this.
mnemonics.reading: "I'm so glad!" the woman shouts, "Because I found the key (き)!" You immediately start to wonder what "the key" is. The key to life? The key to learning Japanese? Then you see she's holding up some car keys.

mnemonics.meaning: There’s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grass</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> and the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark> there <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> you have no <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">honor</mark>. The fins are left over from the fish you dismembered and they do not believe it was an act of honor. Now they are just sitting on the ground on the grass, calling you out for having no honor.
mnemonics.reading: Being one of little honor, you decide to squash these vocal fins with your yo-yo (よ). You take out your yo-yo and start bashing each fin with it until they stop talking about what little honor you have.

mnemonics.meaning: You take <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> down a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> that you picked from your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">luxuriant</mark> garden. You picked the flowers from the luxuriant garden, not the drunkard, mind you. Also the drunkard has a cane, but not flowers. That’s why you picked some from your luxuriant garden and slid down your cool slide. Now the drunkard has a cane and some flowers.
mnemonics.reading: The drunkard is so happy to receive flowers from your luxuriant garden that he begins to moan (も) with pleasure. The moans are getting louder and more erotic. You’re kind of creeped out. You really want him to stop moaning.

mnemonics.meaning: Under the same <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark>, all the people get <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">together</mark> to present a new <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark> to your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lord</mark>. You all bow and say, "<mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Milord</mark>, this gift is for you." Because that's the proper way to address your lord.
mnemonics.reading: As you give the lord his weapon together, you see his face turn into a frown, "What's wrong, Milord?" you ask. "THERE'S A DENT (でん)!" he bellows.

mnemonics.meaning: When you go to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yakuza</mark> to make things <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">straight</mark>, your problems just <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">multiply</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Your problems multiply and give you quite a shock (しょく) as yakuza thugs commit crime after shocking crime on your behalf. You really shouldn't be shocked though — of course crimes are going to multiply when you ask the yakuza to "straighten things out."

mnemonics.meaning: Inside that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> someone is doing a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dance</mark>. That someone is your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">neighbor</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Your neighbor has an incredible ring (りん) that they use for their rice dance.

mnemonics.meaning: One way to put <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wheat</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">face</mark> is with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">noodles</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Once you're done stuffing noodles in your face, you can use your leftover noodles to make noodlemen (めん).

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Every</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> fields become <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">overgrown</mark>. Yes, thread grows in fields these days. And the thread grows the most in the winter because reasons. The thread gets so overgrown that you can’t even walk through it without cutting the thread down with a machete.
mnemonics.reading: The reason this field of thread got so overgrown is because you’re Han (はん) Solo and you’re not used to simple things like farming thread. Han Solo is used to blasting baddies and kissing princesses. Overgrown thread is not his specialty. Use your blaster to clear a way through this thread instead of using that machete.

mnemonics.meaning: You're using your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> to navigate the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flood</mark> because you're on <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">patrol</mark>. You're one of the few people with a floating scooter, so it's your job to patrol the flood waters and look for people and animals that need help.
mnemonics.reading: You have to patrol all of the floods in June (じゅん). Unfortunately, that's the month when most of the floods in Japan happen, so you end up on patrol a lot.

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">master</mark> of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pillar</mark>. The pillar is subservient to its tree master because the tree is so great and awesome and big and cool and stuff. The pillar has great respect for its tree master.
mnemonics.reading: While bowing, the pillar accidentally smashes Chewbacca (ちゅう). The pillar is horrified for having murdered Chewbacca, his tree master’s closest friend. The pillar is going to be punished.

mnemonics.meaning: Use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to shoo a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> down the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stairs</mark> and into a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">portable</mark> carrier. You've been trying to get this turkey into the carrier so you can transport it for like, the past hour. You finally got it done with the help of gravity. And, you know, smacking it a bit in the butt with your fingers.
mnemonics.reading: You needed the turkey to be more portable because you're going to be bringing it to a cake (けい) shop to turn it into a cake. You aren't cooking it! Geez, what's wrong with you? No, you're making a cake OF it, for its birthday. The baker needs to see it for reference.

mnemonics.meaning: Lift the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> off your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">preserve</mark>s, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kick</mark> it, and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">praise</mark> the lord! Your food is preserved, you don't need the lid anymore, praise be!
mnemonics.reading: You do this praising in your home (ほう), though, not a church. I don't think anyone outside your home would understand why you're praising inanimate objects.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horse</mark> is your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">master</mark> and you are merely a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">resident</mark> in his house. How did this horse become your master? Those aren’t questions a resident should ask! Know your place, resident!
mnemonics.reading: To prove yourself a worthy resident of the horse master’s house, you must capture Chewbacca (ちゅう). Your horse master collects rare creatures, and Chewbacca is his latest desire. If you wish to remain a resident of the house, you must capture Chewbacca.

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">employ</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">review</mark> all your work.
mnemonics.reading: As the geoduck reviews your paperwork, it notices something surprising. You have a 子 (こ)!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cow</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">righteousness</mark> is always there for us. He is the cow that must <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sacrifice</mark> himself for us to survive.
mnemonics.reading: The sacrifice must be done via guillotine (ぎ). I know, I know, that sounds really brutal, but it's the best way. It's fast, it's effective, and hopefully the sacrifice—I mean, cow—doesn't feel a thing.

mnemonics.meaning: You see an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">animal</mark> with some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> trying to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">seize</mark> them. The animal with the flowers is really tall so the turkey needs to stand on the stool in its attempt to seize the flowers.
mnemonics.reading: The animal the turkey is trying to seize the flowers from is a cock (かく). The cock is a lot bigger than the turkey, so that’s why the turkey needs to stand on the stool in its attempt to seize those flowers.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> you also need a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">guard</mark> with a very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sharp</mark> sword to protect it.
mnemonics.reading: You're setting up all these sharp traps around your gold when you step on a sharp acorn (えい) that's just lying on the floor. Ouch! But wait, then you get a great idea!

mnemonics.meaning: Taking a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> on it, you walk through the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">spread</mark> your arms wide. You spread your arms to halt the approach of winter because your rice paddy is not done growing yet. You take the cross with you for some extra religious power of persuasion, and the drop in case any of that rice is thirsty.
mnemonics.reading: With your arms spread like that, you look extremely chic (しき). Spread arms are obviously a chic posture, and the fact that you're holding a cross makes it even more chic.

mnemonics.meaning: What kind of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> comes down from <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heaven</mark>? A <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">supernatural</mark> one. She is so <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">enchanting</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The supernatural woman comes down in front of you and she's so enchanting that it takes a while to realize she's completely made of yogurt (よう).

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> you made out of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark>s, and are about to ride down the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stairs</mark> with, is completely <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">transparent</mark>. You mashed the grains down so fine that you can see through them! And then you made them into a scooter.
mnemonics.reading: You slip, the transparent scooter scoots down the stairs without you and into the streets of とうきょう. Nooo! Transpa-scootie come back!

mnemonics.meaning: In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">trash</mark> is a weird looking <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fruit</mark>. Someone decided to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">abandon</mark> it here.
mnemonics.reading: You reach into the trash, take out the abandoned fruit, and bite into it. OUCH! There's a key (き) inside, and you just bit into it.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ice</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wife</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">amazing</mark>. She's also <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">terrible</mark>, because she's very cold and has many ice powers, but that's also part of what makes her amazing!
mnemonics.reading: She turns her amazing gaze onto your saber (せい) and hits it with an ice beam. Woah! Instead of turning to ice or shattering, it steals her awful powers. Now your saber is amazing and terrible too!

mnemonics.meaning: Dig up a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mole</mark> and you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">attain</mark> a mole status. You're always trying to attain a new level for yourself and now you get to be on the mole level!
mnemonics.reading: Mole isn't enough, you want to attain sheep (し) status next. Everyone knows it goes human > mole> sheep. Now you need to stand in the field with the mole and get a sheep to come over.

mnemonics.meaning: Use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to wipe this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">table</mark> and see what it was <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">based on</mark>. The cold winter weather covers the table in frost, and when you wipe it away, you can see traces of what the table was originally based on. All tables have to be based on something, even if it's just other tables that came before them.
mnemonics.reading: This particular table was based on Little Kyoto (きょ). Little buildings and temples, that sort of look like Little Kyoto. Problem is, it was made by a 子 (こ), so it's not very good.

mnemonics.meaning: On the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">signpost</mark> there is a single sign that says <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bee</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Thanks to the insect signpost you find the bee. You make it just in time to see the bee hatch (はち) from its egg.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">righteousness</mark> is the only one who can run this <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ceremony</mark>. Why? Because it's a very pure ceremony, and only those with an extremely righteous mind can run it.
mnemonics.reading: Sadly, the reason only the righteous can run this ceremony is because it's a punishment ceremony, where he pulls the cord to cut someone's head off via a guillotine (ぎ).

mnemonics.meaning: You climb up a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark> in search of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark>, but all you find is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">charcoal</mark>. You can make fire with the charcoal, but you were hoping to find fire itself. All that climbing for nothing.
mnemonics.reading: After crushing the charcoal, you decide to take advantage of your current location and lie out in the sun for a while to get a tan (たん). Instead of getting a tan though, you catch on fire. Oops.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> carries two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">husband</mark>s up into the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>, where they're going to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">conceal</mark> something.
mnemonics.reading: The husbands are going to conceal their pet centaur (せん) in the sun. The local government isn't too pleased that they have a pet centaur, so they have to conceal it in the sun so it doesn't get confiscated.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> gets a nice uniform for the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sake</mark> of not wanting to look like a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fake</mark>. The leader is a fake, he just doesn’t want to look like one. He’s not really a leader, but he thinks he should get an official-looking uniform for the sake of not looking like a fake.
mnemonics.reading: Well, everyone found out he was a fake anyway, and now you're all going to use a guillotine (ぎ) to cut off his fake head.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> burns down the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">field</mark>. The rice paddy fire spreads out from the paddy and consumes the field next to it. This rice paddy fire has ravaged your entire farm!
mnemonics.reading: Your rice paddy farm and field are on a cay. A cay is a small, sandy island, and since your farm is on fire, this cay has turned into a hot cay. Or as Mario would say, that’s one-a hot-a cay! (はたけ) Mama mia!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Viking</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark> is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">firefly</mark>. In the insect kingdom, the insect most resembling a Viking is undoubtedly the firefly.
mnemonics.reading: The Viking firefly is attacking Hotaru (ほたる) Tomoe (alter ego of Sailor Saturn) because the Viking firefly hates the show Sailor Moon and everyone on it. Hotaru screams in terror as she is deathly afraid of fireflies, especially Viking ones.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gladiator</mark> turns his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hand</mark> into a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fist</mark>. A fist for punching other gladiators.
mnemonics.reading: The gladiator's fist is now aimed at Ken (けん) the samurai. Little does the gladiator know, Ken knows the ways of the samurai and the gladiator. He slowly raises his own hands and turns them into fists.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark> that needs <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hard liquor</mark>. Drinking too much hard liquor isn't good for you, so you must make sure to measure it out in precise quantities.
mnemonics.reading: You know who enjoyed hard liquor a lot? Chewbacca (ちゅう). He was always drinking, which is concerning when you think about all the driving he did.

mnemonics.meaning: Everyone has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poop</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">guy</mark> from their <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hometown</mark>. You know. That poop guy. And every single time you try to visit your hometown, poop guy is there making everyone uncomfortable and reminding you why you left in the first place.
mnemonics.reading: Your hometown is in きょうと which, unfortunately, means your poop guy is in きょうと too. Now every time you go back home he's there stinking everything up.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> (hive) on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">certain</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark> (a bee) is what protects all of the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">honey</mark> or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">nectar</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: To get the honey out, you need to put on special mitts (みつ) so your hands don't get stung.

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> has <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">two</mark> things that remind him of his <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">humanity</mark>: his shoes, and his hat. These two things remind the leader of his humanity because humans are the only ones who wear shoes and hats.
mnemonics.reading: Another thing that reminds you and the leader about your humanity is wearing jeans (じん). Jeans are the go-to legwear for many people, and no one but humans wear them. Jeans are another great symbol of humanity.

mnemonics.meaning: On this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark> who's trying to show that his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lineage</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">humble</mark>. All of the other children are going around in fancy cars or helicopters, but this one child wants to be a humble child of the people, so he scoots on a plebeian scooter.
mnemonics.reading: This humble child is your son (そん). You don't want any child of yours flaunting his wealth and good standing in the faces of other people. You've taught them to be humble.

mnemonics.meaning: Being a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> or <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">director</mark> in a company means you have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">inquire</mark> about lots of things. Have you started this yet? Have you finished that yet? Did you get that thing I sent you? Where's my coffee? Basically if you're a leader or director, your main job is to inquire about these very important things.
mnemonics.reading: Turns out the leader and director of your company is Chairman Kaga from the TV show Iron Chef. Every time he tries to inquire about weird stuff, you have to say Ooh, Kaga (うかが) disapprovingly. "What are you doing for dinner tonight?" he inquires. Ooh, Kaga! "What's the best way to soften an eggplant?" he inquires. Ooh, Kaga!

mnemonics.meaning: There is a tiny <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> on <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> sitting on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> and commanding his troops to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">invade</mark> Wolverine's brain. These tiny soldiers are going to invade Wolverine's body in an attempt to destroy him. The leader himself isn't going to invade Wolverine's brain, he's just going to sit on the stool and supervise.
mnemonics.reading: Soon they realize that they cannot invade Wolverine through his head so they travel down to his leg and try to enter through his shin (しん). The little soldiers take a big knife and slice open Wolverine’s shin in order to invade his body.

mnemonics.meaning: Open your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>. A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tiger</mark> fell in there on some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spikes</mark>! That's what you tell everybody, but when they look in your mouth there's nothing there. It's all a big <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lie</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: Lie about spikes in your mouth and I'll put soap with spikes in it in your mouth to teach you a lesson. That's why I'm using uni soap (うそ).

mnemonics.meaning: Aside from <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> there are a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wide</mark> variety of other <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mineral</mark>s as well.
mnemonics.reading: One person is trying to control all the minerals of the world. That person is Emperor こういち.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">proclaim</mark>s "I am <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">noisy</mark> and I am loud!" It keeps repeating this over and over to everyone you pass by.
mnemonics.reading: You are so noisy and loud that the townsfolk hired Ken (けん) the Samurai to shut you up.

mnemonics.meaning: You decide to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark> next to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">trash</mark> under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> so the moon's light will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">penetrate</mark> you. The sky is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">clear</mark>est in winter, and this spot next to the trash happens to get the most of it.
mnemonics.reading: You want the light to penetrate you, so you put your face in the way of the beam and it shoots clear through you. Your mouth fills with the taste of 鉄 (てつ).

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hits a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bundle</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark>s, swirling around their weird shapes, and creating <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rapids</mark>!
