The rapids are so violent, some of the geoducks break out of the bundle and get washed into the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shallows</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: While those geoducks are getting tossed about in the rapids, you're sitting in the shallows chomping down on some celery (せ).

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">showy</mark> so it makes everybody around you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rowdy</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Everyone is getting rowdy so you get in your car (か) to escape.

mnemonics.meaning: You're digging in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> when you find a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tiger</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cactus</mark>. You keep digging until you realize that these are a part of some big <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ruins</mark>. They're the ruins of tiger and cactus statues. It looks like whoever used to live here worshiped tigers and cacti. Or maybe they ate them. But now their whole civilization is just ruins.
mnemonics.reading: Well, as it turns out, these are the ruins of Little Kyoto (きょ), the city that existed before the modern day one. And it looks like the citizens of Little Kyoto faced their end a long time ago.

mnemonics.meaning: You find some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> from <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">long ago</mark>. They must have been <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">set aside</mark> by their previous owners. They definitely weren't cut off or anything, someone just decided they didn't want them anymore and set them aside.
mnemonics.reading: I know why they set aside their fingers long ago, it's because there was no soap (そ). If you didn't have soap to clean your fingers you wouldn't want to keep them for very long...

mnemonics.meaning: Something you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> to someone you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">become</mark> attached to should be said with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sincerity</mark>. You need to speak with sincerity when you say things to someone who will eventually become your significant other, for example.
mnemonics.reading: When you say something with complete, unabashed sincerity your special saber (せい) starts to pulse with the beating of your heart. It shows the person you want to become close to that you truly are sincere!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tiger</mark> has <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">legs</mark> that belong to a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tiger</mark>. You know, a tiger has the legs of a tiger. This is common knowledge. Nothing new here.
mnemonics.reading: The tiger is using his legs to run away from the Torah (とら). This tiger is deathly afraid of religion, so a holy book like the Torah causes the tiger to run away.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boat</mark> that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">oversee</mark>s other boats, land, and people is usually a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">warship</mark>. They're the big boats that oversee everything around them. And if anyone steps out of line, a warship can take care of it.
mnemonics.reading: This huge warship is run by Genghis Khan (かん), the famous warlord. Really, what did you expect? Who else is strong enough to captain a warship but him?

mnemonics.meaning: You use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to dig through the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">trash</mark> in the light of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> because somewhere in there is your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">withdrawal</mark> letter. What did you withdraw? Your resignation? Your troops? Whatever it was, you need to find the proof, and fast.
mnemonics.reading: While looking for the withdrawal letter, your fingers hit a piece of 鉄 (てつ). Ouch!

mnemonics.meaning: Each <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> needs its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drum</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark> done before you can say it's really made of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wood</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: If you're still not sure if the tree is really made of wood, just take out a small juice (じゅ) box and start drinking it. A wooden tree will show no interest in the juice box at all.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wrap</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wrap</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: Think about being wrapped up, nice and warm and safe in your home (ほう). Home is where you wrap yourself in a blanket, in the warmth of the fireplace, in the arms of those you love.

mnemonics.meaning: You hit a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> with an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark> so you can do some <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">analysis</mark> on it. To do the analysis on the tree, a cross section needs to be obtained, so you must chop it in half with your axe.
mnemonics.reading: The person who is doing this analysis is very sexy (せき). Who is this sexy person? Why it’s you of course, you sexy beast. I love watching you do analysis on trees. It’s so sexy.

mnemonics.meaning: Using a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bow</mark>, shoot a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">melon</mark> and it will fly in a steep <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">arc</mark>. Melons are too heavy to fly straight, after all.
mnemonics.reading: Shooting melons in an arc is something little 子's (こ) love to do. It also helps that when they come down from the arc they smash all over the place.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mole</mark> has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> ready for your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">arrival</mark>. You get out of your airplane, you step on the ground and... ouch! You stepped right on the knife, and there's the mole, sticking it out of the ground. "I checked the schedule for your arrival!" it squeaks happily, and disappears.
mnemonics.reading: Your arrival to とうきょう is now ruined. And your next stop is now going to be an arrival at a とうきょう hospital to get this mole knife out.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> works for one <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">reason</mark>: its wheels can spin on an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">axis</mark>. Yep, that lateral axis is definitely a car's most <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pivotal part</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Your friend is always bragging about his car's axis. He's all like, "My car's wheels move on more than one axis!" And you sarcastically reply: "Gee, cool" (じく).

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Shellfish</mark> cause <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">landslide</mark>s because of all their <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bustling</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lively</mark> underwater activity.
mnemonics.reading: You can't stand bustling and lively situations, so you get out your knee guillotine (にぎ). What's a knee guillotine? It's exactly what it sounds like, and you're about to use it on these shellfish to prevent some landslides.

mnemonics.meaning: When your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> move like that, you know it's an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">omen</mark> of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">challenge</mark> that will face you soon in the future.
mnemonics.reading: In your finger, you see a challenge. And... if you look closely, you can see the fast movements of your fingers forming the outline of Mrs. Chou's (ちょう) face. Oh no, the challenge is going to be Mrs. Chou!

mnemonics.meaning: You take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> and try to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark> it but you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">char</mark> it instead. That's what happens when you throw meat into a pot on high with no water in there.
mnemonics.reading: You're staring sadly at the charred turkey when you suddenly sense the Shougun (しょう) looming behind you. You were supposed to be cooking this turkey for him and now he looks really, really mad.

mnemonics.meaning: You see <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> by the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">exit</mark>, indicating that you should <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dig</mark>. The fingers on the flag point downward, just by the exit, as if to say "dig here!" There must be something under here. That's what you think to yourself as you start to dig with your fingers.
mnemonics.reading: You dig until you finally hit something. It's a bunch of buried old coots (くつ). They're in an underground room for old coots. One yells up at you, "Whatcha doing to our roof, ya whipper snapper?! Stop digging in our lawn!"

mnemonics.meaning: Take this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> and look at this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">part</mark>. Now look at this part! Now look at this part. You don't know where to look! Haha, I have <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">distract</mark>ed you!
mnemonics.reading: Despite how distracted you are, that was indeed a lot of fun (ふん).

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> can be whittled into an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">example</mark> of anything. See, here's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark>. Here's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">snake</mark>. I can make so many examples just with bamboo.
mnemonics.reading: One last example for you. Now I'm going to take this bamboo and whittle it into an example of Han (はん) Solo!

mnemonics.meaning: Someone's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> touch your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tongue</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fasten</mark> it together. You can't talk. All you can do is make sad tongue-less sounds as you try to figure out who would fasten your tongue like this.
mnemonics.reading: Only one creature could use its fingers to fasten your tongue like this: cats (かつ). Cats are notorious for fastening tongues so that people can't speak. Haven't you ever heard the phrase, "Cat got your tongue?"

mnemonics.meaning: You use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shop</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">grip</mark> what you want to buy.
mnemonics.reading: You have a really strong grip thanks to acupuncture (あく)! All your fingers are primed for buying things. You can grip anything at a shop—pineapples, tires, even live turtles. All thanks to some well-placed needles.

mnemonics.meaning: In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">district</mark> of town you can buy a lot of tree products, including doors. With those doors, though, you always need <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hinge</mark>s.
mnemonics.reading: You buy an awesome hinge and try it out. Instead of working properly, it just falls apart and the door falls on you, crushing your lower body. You yell out (and you have to yell) "I'm GOING TO SUUUUEEE (すう) YOU!"

mnemonics.meaning: If you have <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> it's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">easy</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hoist</mark> things above your head. If you don't have fingers, well, it's not so easy.
mnemonics.reading: Today, you have to hoist so much stuff. "Ah!" (あ) you say, "So much hoisting to do." Better get to it!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> crashes into the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> (breaking it in half) and creating a different <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wing</mark> of the tsunami all together. This wing crashes down and creates a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lagoon</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: This lagoon was created on purpose by a really angry dude and his catapult (かた). He wanted a nice place to lounge that's tropical, but not too bright. So he came up with a plan: use a giant catapult to send a tsunami into the sun!

mnemonics.meaning: There are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hills</mark> in your front <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lawn</mark>. Your lawn is pretty big and it is covered with both flowers and hills. It’s very pretty.
mnemonics.reading: You are the proud owner of a Shiba (しば) Inu, y’know, the Japanese dog? Well, this Shiba Inu of yours loves to run around in your lawn and through the flowers and over the hills. This is the perfect lawn for your Shiba.

mnemonics.meaning: If the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark>, it's good for your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">liver</mark>! Haha, get it? Because there's no moonshine to ruin your liver. Don't drink, kids.
mnemonics.reading: As you pat your liver suddenly a strange feeling bubbles up and the ghost of Genghis Khan (かん) comes out! Right out of your liver.

mnemonics.meaning: What do you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eat</mark> if you’re wearing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> and surrounded by <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lantern</mark>s? <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Mochi</mark> (or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sticky rice cake</mark>s) of course!
mnemonics.reading: The reading of mochi is mochi (もち). Yay!

mnemonics.meaning: Under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> and another <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> wearing special <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clothes</mark> because they're in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mourning</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: As the mourning continues, the soul (そう) of the dead person rises out of the cross. The soul looks around at all of the mourners and nods. Yes, your mourning has pleased it.

mnemonics.meaning: You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark>-covered <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hill</mark>, but it's all lumpy and weird. You approach it to take a closer look, and you see it's actually a huge <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">net</mark> with a bunch of stuff caught in it: fish, cats, tree branches. All this random stuff is what's making the net look so lumpy!
mnemonics.reading: This net is creating a serious obstacle to you mowing (もう) your lawn. The net has way too much stuff in it for you to be able to drag it away, so for now you're just going to have to mow around it.

mnemonics.meaning: Even though you’ve <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">old</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">legs</mark>, you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">overcome</mark> your disability. These old legs of yours don’t work very well, but you overcome the odds and you run a marathon!
mnemonics.reading: When you pass the finish line and finally overcome the limits of your old legs, someone hands you an ice cold Coke (こく) as a reward. Mmm, such a refreshing Coke.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> that is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark> is the most scary tsunami of all. It doesn't come in and destroy everything. No, it comes in, goes inside your door, then stays at your place <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">overnight</mark>, without even asking!
mnemonics.reading: Your cat walks up to the white tsunami that's staying overnight and decides it doesn't like it, so it hacks (はく) up a hairball on it. Even that doesn't get the tsunami to leave.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have one <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> and another <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>, you have a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pair</mark> of stools. Look at this pair of stools. Look at it.
mnemonics.reading: This pair of stools shares a soul (そう). Even if you tried to separate them, they'd eventually find their way back together.

mnemonics.meaning: You walk up to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> and put <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dynamite</mark> on it. Then you set it off. BOOM. It explodes, but doesn't do what you'd expect. Instead of blowing the tree up, it blasts a very beautiful <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pattern</mark> into the side of it as well as the ground around it.
mnemonics.reading: The pattern is so beautiful that you want to put it on your garage (がら). So, you do.

mnemonics.meaning: Wrap your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> around this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark> and put it in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> to express your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">philosophy</mark>. Your philosophy of… putting axes in your mouth. Everyone else seems to think it's a stupid philosophy, but by doing this you're showing them that it's not!
mnemonics.reading: Your axe-in-mouth philosophy means you're always tasting 鉄 (てつ). They say blood tastes like copper. Well, weapons (and your philosophy) taste like iron.

mnemonics.meaning: Use <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">simultaneous</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark>s to perform the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">purification</mark> ritual. Two jackhammers running perfectly in sync will purify your body, mind, and soul! (And the ground around you that's being jackhammered.)
mnemonics.reading: This purification ritual is supposed to help you forget your cyborg (さい). It's been a while, but you can't seem to get it out of your head.

mnemonics.meaning: If you take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> and wrap up a bunch of it, so much it becomes a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hill</mark> of thread, you're going to have a lot of thread. You can wrap some of that thread around other thread to create a much thicker thread. This thread is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rope</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Congratulations, now you have a perfect rope for tuna (つな) fishing. Tunas are massive, so you need a strong rope to reel one in.

mnemonics.meaning: You keep your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">substitute</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clothes</mark> in a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sack</mark>. The clothes in the sack are just substitute clothes, so they only come out in emergencies.
mnemonics.reading: You need your substitute clothes so you take out your substitute clothes sack. You open it up to grab your substitute clothes, only to find out that there is a ton of salmon roe inside your sack. Oh man, you forgot all about putting that in there. You yell: F**K ROE (ふくろ) because that roe destroyed all your clothes and made it nasty.

mnemonics.meaning: With your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark>, you grab a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">satellite</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shake</mark> it! You're an astronaut and it's your job. Don't worry, the satellite won't break or anything, it's strong enough for space travel. Just do as you're told and shake the sucker.
mnemonics.reading: You need to shake it because this satellite is full of yogurt (よう). You only like yogurt that's been well shaken. And who can resist space yogurt? Huh? Anyone?

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> breaks your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bone</mark>s, not from hitting you, but from making you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">slide</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">slip</mark> into stuff. Hard to keep your footing in a tsunami, you know? You're slipping and sliding all over the place.
mnemonics.reading: As you continue to slide around you see a bunch of stray cats (かつ) slipping and sliding too. They're yowling and sliding right toward you. Uh oh…

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">servant</mark> secures a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> so that it is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">solid</mark> sitting device. If you just throw a stool on the ground it will flop over easily. But if you have a servant to dig it into the dirt a bit, it becomes nice and solid and safe for sitting!
mnemonics.reading: You need this stool to be extra solid because you're using it to test your new catapult (かた). If it isn't solid, when you launch it and yourself in the catapult, the stool might fall over, killing you both. And you don't want that, now do you?

mnemonics.meaning: To your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> you take an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark>. The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> has broken your car for good this time (you think). You're so angry at your car. You think this is permanent. Turns out, though, that it's not permanent. It's just like that <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">temporarily</mark>. You did make it permanent by taking an axe to your car, though.
mnemonics.reading: You were driving around in Zanzibar (ざん) when this happened, too, so now you're stuck in Zanzibar, a foreign place, and you have no idea what to do next.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Thread</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">vines</mark> alone are too weak to hold anything up. You need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">twist</mark> them together to make them strong.
mnemonics.reading: As you twist the thread and vines together, suddenly you feel a lump. You look down and see a cucumber (きゅう) twisted into it.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Flowers</mark> find their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">death</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">river</mark> out in the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wild</mark>. Flowers live on water, but this river drowns the flowers to death. The wild is a dangerous place.
mnemonics.reading: Ah (あ), the flowers in the wild have been claimed à la (あら) the great flood. Ah, you don’t think so? Well I do.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Imperial</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clothes</mark> allow you to perform an ancient <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">attack</mark> that cannot be repelled.
mnemonics.reading: The attack's power is concentrated in the shoes (しゅう) in this imperial outfit. You attack with your feet, kicking the enemy with your old, fancy shoes.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">good</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bright</mark> moon. Not just in terms of light, but in mood as well. Like, gee wiz, what a bright, happy moon.
mnemonics.reading: It's so bright that you can see all the roe (ろう) in the sea glowing and reflecting the light like stars. And the tiny baby fishies inside the roe are smiling brightly back up at the moon!

mnemonics.meaning: Below the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>s is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hand</mark>. The hand is just there to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chafe</mark> against the trees.
mnemonics.reading: As the hand chafes on the trees, it says mama (ま), mama.

mnemonics.meaning: You have to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">run</mark>, put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ear</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>, then run back. That's the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">charm</mark> of this game.
mnemonics.reading: The added charm of this game is that there's this big chute (しゅ) at the end. It's so charming because you love chutes.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark>ing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> who hangs around during <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> to provide an indication (this kanji uses the "indication" kanji as its top 2/3rds) of things to come now looks into your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>, and only sees bad things. So, he <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chastise</mark>s you about it.
mnemonics.reading: Why is he chastising you, really, though? He foretold Mrs. Chou coming back in a previous mnemonic, but you saved Mrs. Chou on the beach (once again, in a previous mnemonic), so you could have prevented her second coming. He is chastising you for saving Mrs. Chou (ちょう).

mnemonics.meaning: We put up a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> to remember where we tried to use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark> to take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark> of your friend's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>. Granted, it was a terrible idea, but hopefully that flag of remembrance is some kind of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">consolation</mark>?
mnemonics.reading: Even though you weren't happy with the flag, you were even more frustrated to watch an eagle (い) swoop down and grab the flag and fly away with it.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">badger</mark>, at the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">root</mark> of its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>, is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">courteous</mark> creature.
mnemonics.reading: Badgers are especially courteous to condors (こん). Condors live in the trees while badgers live in burrows under those trees. When humans tear down the condor's homes, the badgers who live below them always let them stay over until they get back on their feet.

mnemonics.meaning: The sun hits this and breaks into three <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>s. What can split the sun in three directions? A <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">crystal</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: Who is hoarding and harnessing the power of these crystals? That would be the Shougun (しょう).

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> stalk looks the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">same</mark> as a big ol' <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cylinder</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Picture a cylinder shaped とうきょう. All the buildings are cylinders. The city itself is cylinder shaped too. Even... gasp! The people of とうきょう!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> tips a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark>, propelling the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> on it to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>, where there's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark> waiting to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">destroy</mark> her.
mnemonics.reading: One could say this drunkard met (めつ) her fate.

mnemonics.meaning: After going down a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> hits the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> and bumps straight into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> of great stature. Imagine the shame. This drunkard has just lost all <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dignity</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">might</mark> that they may have possessed. And that drunkard… is you!
mnemonics.reading: There's only one thing you could think of that could possibly restore all your dignity and might: acquiring a pet eagle (い).

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">foot</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">giant</mark> is a pretty long <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">distance</mark> for a normal person to walk. Giants have big feet and can travel large <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">distance</mark>s very quickly.
mnemonics.reading: Going to Little Kyoto (きょ) is a short distance for a giant but a long distance for you.

mnemonics.meaning: If the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rain</mark> touches your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">foot</mark> and gives it a little rain <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kiss</mark>, you know that part of your foot is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">expose</mark>d to the elements. You can also see some <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dew</mark> forming on your exposed foot. So that's what rain kisses are!
mnemonics.reading: You run along the road (ろ), trying to get out of the rain, but the road keeps going and going, with walls on both sides.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">door</mark> is a door that leads to something full of fire. That thing is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">furnace</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You're using the furnace to melt tar to put on the road (ろ).

mnemonics.meaning: You've been ordered to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spear</mark> this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> but you decide to be really <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gentle</mark> instead.
mnemonics.reading: You're being really gentle to the tree when a jewel (じゅう) falls out of its branches and hits you on the head.

mnemonics.meaning: Two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark>s are here right <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">now</mark>! We need to entertain them otherwise who knows what they'll do. Get out the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">harp</mark>, or the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">zither</mark>, or something.
mnemonics.reading: You may already know that a Japanese harp is called a こと, but here's a mnemonic to help you if you don't:

mnemonics.meaning: Look at the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> at <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dawn</mark> and you'll be able to see all the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hedge</mark>s growing in the area really well. At any other time of day, hedges tend to blend into their surroundings. But at dawn, the shadows the sun makes really helps them stand out.
mnemonics.reading: You're looking intently at one particular hedge because yesterday you dropped your car keys (かき) behind it. Now that you know where the hedge is you're going to need to search it to find your car keys.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">root</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stamp</mark> is to get an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">instant</mark> picture down. Back in the olden days, people had to make seals and draw out things by hand, so stamps came about so you can—BAM—just stamp it and have what you want in an instant.
mnemonics.reading: Think about the thing you want to make instant. I'd want instant socks (そく)! Don't waste time searching for a matching pair or pulling them on. Just take out a pair of instant socks, add water, and the socks are already on your feet. In an instant!

mnemonics.meaning: A (fresh water) <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark>. Some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark>. The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>. A bunch of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poop</mark>. Combine these together and let them decompose a while. You'll have yourself some very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">nourishing</mark> soil.
mnemonics.reading: This is the kind of nourishing soil that Jesus (じ) would make if he was into making soil, probably.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cow</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> doesn't like to leave the barn to go to the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pasture</mark>. It has to, though, because a cow's gotta eat.
mnemonics.reading: ぼく is one of the common ways to say "I" in Japanese (which you should remember!). In this case, you're a boy... a cowboy, and you say, "ぼくwill take these cows out to pasture!"

mnemonics.meaning: The sound of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spring</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark> always puts you at <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">peace</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You want to feel this peace all the time, not just in spring, so you dip your tie (たい) in the spring water. Now your tie is making the peaceful dripping sounds you love.

mnemonics.meaning: Take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> to be able to take a bite. It's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">delicious</mark>, you hear. That's the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">point</mark> of the spoon.
mnemonics.reading: This delicious taste is... familiar somehow. You take a few more bites and then scream. It tastes like sheep (し)!

mnemonics.meaning: You take out a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark>, lay a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> below it, and use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> to carve the pattern through them both. Voila! This is exactly how old <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">printing</mark> presses used to work.
mnemonics.reading: As you get your flag ready for printing you look over and see Satsuki (さつ), who's already finished a nice pattern on her towel. She's a little young to be using a knife, but her print came out nice.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hat</mark>, not to mention the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark> stuck to said hat, is incredibly <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rare</mark>. If you have your hands on either of these things, you'll be a rich duck.
mnemonics.reading: Then you look closer at the hat. It's about to get even rarer. Attached to the hair is the king's chin (ちん).

mnemonics.meaning: People had to use their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">plow</mark>s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">long ago</mark> to put their name in a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">register</mark>. This is because there was no paper yet, so they would hitch a cow to their bamboo plow, and dig their names into the dirt to create all kinds of registers.
mnemonics.reading: If your name is in a register, people will find you very sexy (せき). This was true long ago too. There's nothing sexier than someone whose existence is accounted for in official documentation.

mnemonics.meaning: You use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to hold the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">festival</mark> up, but it <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rub</mark>s against them. The roof is heavy, and you have to walk to keep up, so the roof is rubbing against them really, really badly.
mnemonics.reading: Just when you thought the rubbing couldn't get any worse, Satsuki (さつ) appears and hops up onto the roof. AAGH! It hurts!

mnemonics.meaning: You take two clumps of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> to make a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark>, using them to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">seal</mark> each side of your measuring tape, so it stays on the ground. This is the way people used to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">seal in</mark> things back in the day, back when we didn't have fancy things like tape and glue.
mnemonics.reading: You can also seal food (ふう) in dirt to make it last longer. That's how jerky came about, you know. Seal some meat underground and in a few months you'll have some tasty dried meats to chew.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">simultaneous</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">simultaneous</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: What simultaneously protects and kills? Your holy blue saber (せい).

mnemonics.meaning: If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hits a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pirate</mark> they are going to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sink</mark> no matter how good of a pirate captain they are.
mnemonics.reading: As the tsunami comes to sink the pirate, the pirate holds his chin (ちん) up high. He will die with dignity.

mnemonics.meaning: Put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> in somebody's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">business</mark> by <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">slap</mark>ping them! This method also works if someone is getting too involved in your business. Slaps are basically your way of doing business with your fingers.
mnemonics.reading: ぼく is one way to say "I" in Japanese, usually used by dudes. But you're going to use it now when you slap this guy. Who's in everybody's business, slapping them? ぼく.

mnemonics.meaning: When a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yakuza</mark> takes a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clothes</mark>, it will of course cause a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">split</mark> or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tear</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: "I want to split and tear that." You agree, so you say Let's (れつ) do it.

mnemonics.meaning: A small <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> comes in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">morning</mark> with the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark>. That just means the ocean gets bigger when the moon's out, and that my friends is simply the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tide</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You go check out the tide. The water is coming in a little stronger, and something washes up on the shore. It's a body! You roll the body over and it is Mrs. Chou (ちょう)!

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark> project made from <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> will act as a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tribute</mark> to the Crabigator.
mnemonics.reading: This great tribute is being commissioned by Emperor こういち.

mnemonics.meaning: The radical <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blade</mark> and the kanji <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">blade</mark> are exactly the same.
mnemonics.reading: When you stab your blade into an enemy you shout "Ha (は)!" It's just the normal "thrusting with blade" sound.

mnemonics.meaning: You put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark> into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wrap</mark> of some kind. This wrap happens to be a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cannon</mark>, and you're shooting off the stone, just like I used to do to boats with the cannon we had growing up for some reason.
mnemonics.reading: You aim the cannon at your own home (ほう). You don't want to have a home anymore, you want to become a pirate, live on a boat, and (of course) shoot cannons all day long.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> thing you put on your head to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> taller would probably be a hat. A bamboo hat is probably one of those hats you think of when you think of rice farmers, a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">conical hat</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: A conical hat is kind of like an umbrella on your head. What's the reading for "umbrella" in Japanese? Why, it's kasa (かさ)!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dragon</mark> radical is the same as this kanji, which is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dragon</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Imagine a dragon. You are talking to it, which is already pretty strange, but as you're talking, he turns into the Street Fighter character Ryu (りゅう).

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> told you that a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flood</mark> last <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">evening</mark> would <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">draw close</mark>. There was nothing you could do to stop it, it seemed to be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">be imminent</mark>, coming in the darkness of the evening.
mnemonics.reading: Luckily whenever you sense a flood starting to draw close, Satsuki (さつ) prepares a raft. Remember Satsuki? Such a talented little girl. I guess floods are common enough that she's learned to make rafts?

mnemonics.meaning: There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> tying <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pig</mark>, balancing them over the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">edge</mark> of a cliff together.
mnemonics.reading: Suddenly, the pig squeals, pulls the thread, and sends them both over the edge. Straight to their end (えん).

mnemonics.meaning: If someone puts a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blade</mark> to your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>, you're going to have a rough time. They leave it there, for a long time. They aren't going to cut you, but you can't move. You have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">endure</mark> the pain and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">conceal</mark> your discomfort with the situation.
mnemonics.reading: Learning to endure and conceal is all part of your ninja (にん) training. You must learn to stay totally still, without breathing — you have to be able to endure this if you want to conceal yourself.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pool</mark> is where you're going to go <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fishing</mark>. Because, if the pool is gold, hopefully the fish are too.
mnemonics.reading: You caught a couple of gold fish. Two (つ) gold fish, actually!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">animal</mark> that hangs out in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">melon</mark> patches is the elusive <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fox</mark>! They like to steal melons then come back into town disguised as human melon sellers. Foxes are tricky like that.
mnemonics.reading: If you want to stop foxes from stealing your melons you can get one of those kits that neigh (きつね) when one is around. The kits neigh when they sense a fox, but because it sounds like a horse the fox won't run. But you'll be able to get out there and take your melons back!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">good luck</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">good luck</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: For good luck, you keep special kits (きつ) in your kitchen (きち). These kitchen kits contain good luck charms.

mnemonics.meaning: The part of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark>s up tall in the air (at the end of the stalks) is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">grains</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You have a box of grains. Ryuu (りゅう) from Street Fighter is doing training by punching the grains to strengthen his fingers.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">long</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark> is your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">friend</mark>. It's your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hair</mark> and you're so proud of it.
mnemonics.reading: Who gave you this hair? Probably the great 神 (かみ) of hair. You deserve this great hair.

mnemonics.meaning: An <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark> is stuck into the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> on a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hill</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You reach the top of the hill and realize the entire hill is covered in cucumbers (きゅう). The axe has a little note on it that says "Cucumber Hill Axe - Please Use."

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ladle</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ladle</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: You use a ladle to distribute soup. But as you're ladling you find something odd floating in the soup. It's... a toe (と)! You scream, dropping the ladle and the toe on the ground.

mnemonics.meaning: Looking at the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark>, you notice it's grown a bunch of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">branch</mark>es. Wait, are those all… <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">limbs</mark>?!
mnemonics.reading: After some consideration, you know who put all those limbs on the moon. It must've been none other than the moon sheep (し)!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">measurement</mark> kanji are exactly the same.
mnemonics.reading: "Calculate your enemy's position with accurate measurement," is more or less what Sun (すん) Tzu said, I think. The guy wrote The Art of War, you know. When Sun says measurements are important, you don't question him.

mnemonics.meaning: No one can <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> what a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> weighs in grains of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> — it's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mystery</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: To get to the bottom of this mystery, you use a nozzle (なぞ). You pass rice through the nozzle one grain at a time, so you can figure out precisely how many grains of rice are equal to the weight of a scooter.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> has an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">omen</mark> growing from it, one single <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">peach</mark> that is the size of a house. Inside is a child who will save the village from demons.
mnemonics.reading: If momotaro (もも) wasn't enough, think about the peach growing larger and larger. You want it to grow bigger, so you yell at it: "MORE! MORE!" (もも).

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark> you cut off a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pear</mark>. You've found some particularly big, sturdy ones, which is why you need the help of your knife. These pears are sure to be super juicy and delicious, but you need some extra tools to get them off the tree.
mnemonics.reading: As you cut the pears down, you can't help but gnash (なし) your teeth. You want to eat these pears right now. You gnash and grind and wait though, because you want to have them all down before you start the feast.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">servant</mark> is the lower ranking <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">princess</mark>. The queen is no servant. Hecks no. Just the princess, because she's a servant to what her parents tell her to do.
mnemonics.reading: The princess goes on to do whatever she wants. She tells the real servants, "Don't tell my daddy, the king, I did this. He may (ひめ) not like it."

mnemonics.meaning: You use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> when you're in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> to use an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">push open</mark> things.
mnemonics.reading: Your favorite thing to push open is your own eye (あい). You take the arrow into your fingers and gently push each lid open until you can see.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> loves her <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">catapult</mark> for some good ol' fashioned <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">recreation</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Her favorite thing to shoot at with her catapult for recreation is Godzilla (ご).

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">temple</mark> isn't a monk like you'd expect. It's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">samurai</mark>, who protects the monks in return for prayers that keep him safe.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is <mark class="reading-highlight" title="Reading">samurai</mark>, which should be easy enough to remember.

mnemonics.meaning: From my <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> I have told you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">seven</mark> times not to do that. Now I have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">scold</mark> you.
mnemonics.reading: What were you doing wrong that caused me to scold you? You were feeding the 鹿 (しか). If you feed them they'll never be able to feed themselves!

mnemonics.meaning: You have <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">vines</mark>, so you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shout</mark>! It's hard for you to talk normally, and even harder for people to understand you unless you shout.
mnemonics.reading: You need to shout so that people can understand you through the mouth vines. You shout, "きょうと!" because you hear there is a temple there for people with your condition.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fang</mark> is the bud that comes out of the ground. It's like a little fang, coming from the earth, and it will become a flower someday. This is a little <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sprout</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: When the sprout gets out of the ground and opens up, instead of a flower there is a human-looking 目 (め), looking right at you.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wind</mark> coming down from the mountains is very fierce. It is so fierce it's a lot like a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">storm</mark>. Well, it is a storm, really.
mnemonics.reading: A storm is nothing to scoff at. If you get hit by the storm and get all wet and nasty and electrocuted, you're bound to get a rash (あらし).

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Rain</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> means only one thing... <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">thunder</mark>! Get off the rice paddy! There's nothing but you to attract the thunder!
mnemonics.reading: You can’t run fast enough to escape the thunder, so you decide to hide under a pile of… rye (らい)?!

mnemonics.meaning: When <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">suit</mark> one another, the flowers grow so tall that they make a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tower</mark>! A flower tower made of flower power!
mnemonics.reading: The only place flowers grow into towers like this is in とうきょう. とうきょう dirt is the best. とうきょう flowers are the best. Thus, you end up with a lot of とうきょう towers.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> to get off this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jet</mark> is a beautiful, brilliant <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">vermilion</mark> color.
mnemonics.reading: You jump onto the vermilion slide. It's actually more of a steep chute (しゅ). And... oh... urp... it's making you sick.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">feather</mark> is on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark>, and they are attached <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">together</mark>. You put a feather on a rice paddy to create a giant airplane. Flawed, sure. But, this rice paddy + feather is going to be one <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wing</mark> of your amazing aircraft.
mnemonics.reading: To make the feather and rice paddy stick together you need some kind of sticking agent. This time we find the original bird that the feather came from and grab its eggs. We break the eggs open and use the yolk (よく). It's pretty sticky, but still probably not aircraft safe.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark> to measure a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark> is a very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">approximate</mark> measurement. Geoducks are big, spoons are small. Still, we'll get the approximation going, right?
mnemonics.reading: Maybe this is too much geoduck, even if we're going for an approximate. So, you take the core (ころ) of the geoduck and measure that instead.

mnemonics.meaning: When you leave <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark>s in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> for long enough, they'll turn into <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bacteria</mark>. These aren't the nice, pretty flowers you'd give your mom on Mother's Day. These are little bacteria flowers that are taking over your mouth. Maybe brush your teeth next time.
mnemonics.reading: There is a lot of this bacteria in the King (きん) of England's mouth. He eats a lot of grains, and he won't let anyone touch his mouth to clean it, but he refuses to do things himself... so it's absolutely chock full of bacteria.

mnemonics.meaning: Something made of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark>s in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">village</mark>. It's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bell</mark>!  The village bell.
mnemonics.reading: The bell rings whenever the Shougun (しょう) arrives in the village. Its ringing echoes throughout the entire village so everyone knows they have to come out and pay their respects.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boat</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">boat</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same reading that you learned with the vocabulary 船.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> who makes your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">house</mark> a home is your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bride</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Now that you have a bride in your house, you can get rid of your maid (よめ), since your bride will do all the cleaning.

mnemonics.meaning: Looking up to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark>, you see the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>s, and the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> shining down on them. Using the sun and the trees (up there on the cliff), you've devised a method to tell what time of the year it is, based on where the shadow from the trees fall. After a while, you develop a bigger system. This system is a whole <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">calendar</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Remember the word 歴史, which means "history"? Using a calendar, you too can remember history (otherwise, who knows when these things happened). So, the reading for this kanji is the same as the reading for 歴史's beginning, because they're related.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> is being blocked by a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rain</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cloud</mark>, making it <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cloudy</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Remember 雲? It means "cloud" and has the same reading as "cloudy," making them both くも.

mnemonics.meaning: An <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alligator</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">considerably</mark> dangerous. Considerably terrifying too. Considerably [put your scary adjective here].
mnemonics.reading: Speaking of considerably terrifying, that place known as Narnia (なり) is pretty terrifying. Not sure why children want to go there.

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">receive</mark> instruction in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">circle</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>. Where are you? <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Cram school</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: Not only does your cram school teach kids in a circle in the dirt, it also plays music on a jukebox (じゅく). Yes, a jukebox. They believe a jukebox's tunes help with cramming.

mnemonics.meaning: From the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">older brother</mark> comes... a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">curse</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: Turns out, he put the no road (のろ) curse on you, meaning you can never walk on roads.

mnemonics.meaning: After the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> comes out again and shines on these <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spikes</mark>. They were super wet before, but you figure the sun probably dried them off. You lean down to touch them and nope, they's still <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">damp</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: As you're looking at the damp spikes, a shih tzu (しつ) prances over, slips on the damp ground, and falls right on the spike! Oh nooo!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark>s you have stored in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">house</mark> reflect on your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">earnings</mark>. If you earn a lot of money, you have more grains.
mnemonics.reading: Another way to check someone's earnings is to see if they have a car (か). Would someone who doesn't make a lot of money have a car? No!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sheep</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">feathers</mark> (and presumably wings, too) is able to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fly</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Watching that sheep with feathers and wings flying around made you thirsty. You remember that you have a car kettle (かけ), so you reach into your car and grab your car kettle to make a special car-kettle brew.

mnemonics.meaning: I'm putting all my <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> on <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">someone</mark>, hoping they'll win the race! This is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gamble</mark> and you're gambling.
mnemonics.reading: If you win this gamble you'll have enough shellfish to buy a brand new car (か)!

mnemonics.meaning: Coming down with the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rain</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">two</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spikes</mark>. They go right through two <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ghost</mark>s.
mnemonics.reading: You come across the ghosts, who are stabbed into the ground. "Please," they beg. "Please use that ray (れい) gun that's in that row (りょう) boat and end our suffering."

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Tsunami</mark> vs <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lifeguard</mark>. Who will win? After the water drains away, we find the lifeguard in the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gutter</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: In the gutter is a lifeguard, so Emperor こういち decides to survey the damage.

mnemonics.meaning: I <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">protect</mark> my own <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">animal</mark>s by going to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hunt</mark> other animals... like wolves and cougars and such.
mnemonics.reading: I also do all my hunts using a car (か). I just run those animals down with my car. Kind of cheating, but vroom vroom anyways.

mnemonics.meaning: If you've been to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">past</mark>, you had to get the special <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stamp</mark> on your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">leg</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You've only met one other person with the same mark on their leg and it was Kyaku (きゃく) the customer. Kyaku visits many places all over the world, so it only makes sense that they've also been off-world too.

mnemonics.meaning: When the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> struck, it hit your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tent</mark> full of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">beans</mark>. When you lost your tent of beans, you had a moment of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lucidity</mark>. You don't need so much stuff, you can live without it!
mnemonics.reading: Your lucidity is clear to everyone because you wear a suit (す). Everyone knows that lucid people wear suits!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">demon</mark> is just a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lump</mark>. Just like a dust bunny is just a clump of dust.
mnemonics.reading: A lump of something is just a 固まり (かたまり) — the hardened thing itself.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">animal</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark>? He's just this guy who lives in the forest and thinks he's king of all the animals. He's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lunatic</mark>, though.
mnemonics.reading: You might see that crazy lunatic hanging around the outskirts of きょうと. He'll lurk near your trash cans and scream, "I AM THE ANIMAL KING!" and run away with some orange peels.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> who is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nurse</mark> should be called <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">miss</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: "Call me Miss Joe (じょう)," Joe says to you.

mnemonics.meaning: If you're showing me your "<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fruit</mark>" then you are just <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">naked</mark>. You're <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">nude</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Known for being naked (and showing you his spirit fruit) is the ancient Egyptian god Ra (ら).

mnemonics.meaning: An <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark> is sticking in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> on top of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark>. It's sticking into the very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">peak</mark>. Because why would you bother to stick your axe anywhere else on the mountain to prove you climbed it?
mnemonics.reading: You can't help but gawk (がく) at the peak. Somehow it looks even higher now.

mnemonics.meaning: Below this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>s is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark>. Since it's the only stone here, you make sure to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">polish</mark> it.
mnemonics.reading: You polish the stone due to your meager (みが) lifestyle.

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">now</mark> has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cloud</mark> over it, creating <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shade</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The building that's getting this nice shade is the inn (いん) you're staying at.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">table</mark> is a table that's made entirely of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">skin</mark>. You thought the table was made of moon, with all those pores and such, but when you look more closely, you realize it's skin. Disgusting, porous, skin.
mnemonics.reading: But, when you go to touch this "moon table" made of skin, you realize that it's harder (はだ) than you expected.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cloud</mark> floating above a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">demon</mark> has its <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">soul</mark> in it. If you can manage to get through to the demon, to make it see that it doesn't have to be evil, it might remember who it is and return to the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">spirit</mark> it once was.
mnemonics.reading: You shout out and beg its soul for help until, finally, you see the cloud take the shape of a condor (こん). Aha! "You were a condor before you became a demon! Remember who you are and turn back!"

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spear</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">spear</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: You take this spear and stab it into a cow. "MOO (む)!" it cries. The cow bites the spear out of your hands and stabs you back. "MOO!" you scream.

mnemonics.meaning: When your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark> catches an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">omen</mark>, it's only natural that you will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stare</mark> at it.
mnemonics.reading: As you stare at the omen, you see Mrs. Chou (ちょう) knocking down buildings, putting nails on the street, and making herself way longer than you ever thought possible. Oh, and there she is, destroying the world.

mnemonics.meaning: You feel like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark> that’s been <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">renew</mark>ed. How do renewed stones feel? <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Stiff</mark>. Very stiff.
mnemonics.reading: You remember how you used to cure these stiff body times: your old friend こういち would just massage them out for you.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">toe</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">early</mark>. I hate it when the toes show up early. Well, if the toes are going to show up this early, I guess it's best to put them on the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">table</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: What do all the early toes on the table do while they're waiting until it's the right time? They just sit around on their table, talking (たく).

mnemonics.meaning: If there's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure chest</mark>, there's always a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">villain</mark> too. The villain is trying to get to the treasure chest before the hero of the story.
mnemonics.reading: The villain beat you all the way to きょうと to get this particular treasure chest.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> in the shape of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dragon</mark> flies off the cliff, then comes crashing down to the ground. This skinny tsunami of water flying down to the ground is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">waterfall</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Despite how cool a dragon waterfall is, to be honest it's also pretty tacky (たき).

mnemonics.meaning: You use <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">black</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> to make <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">black ink</mark>. That's what you use to write in black!
mnemonics.reading: Be careful that you don't spill black ink on anyone or anything. If you do, you have to own it. Imagine spilling black ink on someone, and when they confront you, you yell, "Yeah I got black ink on you, so sue me (すみ)!"

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark> gets kicked with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cleat</mark> that came careening toward your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> when it popped off someone doing a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dance</mark>, and you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">blink</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You blink and blink and soon (しゅん) there are tears coming out of them too. You try to blink them away but it's not working. Soon you're crying and blinking and crying some more.

mnemonics.meaning: If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wrap</mark>s around itself, the resulting wave will create a lot of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bubbles</mark>. You know how tsunamis wrap around once gravity kicks in, right? Well when that wave crashes, a whole lot of bubbles are created.
mnemonics.reading: One of the biggest bubbles heads straight for your home (ほう), engulfs it, and picks it up into the air!

mnemonics.meaning: There’s a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">east</mark> that looks like a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">building</mark>. The tree is tall and straight and doesn't have any leaves or branches. It's basically a big wooden building.
mnemonics.reading: That building happens to be in the center of とうきょう. If you need to find east (which is where とうきょう is), you just look for the building.

mnemonics.meaning: Some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grains</mark> get stuck in his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cleat</mark>, and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> grows <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">calm</mark>. Wolverine had been screaming and yelling and stomping around, but when the grains entered his cleat he realized where he was. He was finally able to calm down.
mnemonics.reading: Now that Wolverine is calm, tears come to his eyes. Being calm has given him perspective on what his anger has done. Oh, wait no. There are just some onions (おん) in his cleats too, and they're making calm tears trickle down his eyes.

mnemonics.meaning: You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark> with an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">umbrella</mark> in front of you. Suddenly, they fall straight down into a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cavity</mark> in the road. It's a big <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hole</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: "Into my cavity you go!" yells a voice. It is こういち.

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> is very <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">odd</mark>, to say the least. The shape is all crazy, like a lightning bolt stuck into the ground, or something. Oh wait, look at this. I can sit on it really nicely. It's just like a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chair</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: But, this odd tree chair is also home to an eagle (い). It swoops down upon you as you sit down, gouging your eyes out.

mnemonics.meaning: If you pick the wrong kind of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark>, you'll be put into <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> with nothing but <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> to eat. You'll especially want to avoid picking <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chrysanthemums</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: If you go to prison for chrysanthemum picking, everyone in the prison is going to kick (きく) you nonstop. You broke the chrysanthemum picking law, so kicking is your punishment. And believe me, you don't want these kicks.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> comes from <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cotton</mark>. We use cotton to make lots of things, like clothes and bedsheets. But white towels are always made from soft, fluffy cotton.
mnemonics.reading: This cotton is made by men (めん).

mnemonics.meaning: Below the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>s is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">demon</mark>. This demon is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">devil</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Why is the devil under a canopy of trees? Because he's looking for his mama (ま).

mnemonics.meaning: You need to bring <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">charcoal</mark> under this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> to heat the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dormitory</mark>. You live in this dormitory with a bunch of other kids, and you all have to take turns bringing in the charcoal from outside to heat it.
mnemonics.reading: The dormitory is on an island, so when you go out to get the charcoal you have to take a row (りょう) boat. You row and row and row until you reach the shed with all the charcoal. Then you row and row and row it back to the dormitory.

mnemonics.meaning: There are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nine</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bird</mark>s and one of them is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dove</mark> and another is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pigeon</mark>. These nine birds are a flock of all kinds, but the dove and the pigeon are the leaders.
mnemonics.reading: Take a look at the pigeon in front of you. Now, grab it, tear it in half, and grab the heart (はと) from its little body.

mnemonics.meaning: Make <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">barracks</mark> out of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> and they will get <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dull</mark> quickly. Gold is soft, it's okay for jewelry and delicate things that aren't used much, but barracks for soldiers? Those are used constantly, and they get worn out easily. What was once shiny gold will go dull in days.
mnemonics.reading: As you stare sadly at the dull barracks, the don (どん) shows up out of nowhere, and he's pissed. He turns his angry gaze toward you and says, "How did my barracks get so dull? Are you at fault? This is bad, this is very bad. Someone will pay for this."

mnemonics.meaning: You want to turn your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">comb</mark> into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark>, so you throw it into the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">forge</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You're trying to work the forge, but it's harder than you thought. You end up forging outside all day and get a wicked tan (たん).

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">crab</mark> moves a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark> because he is playing the game <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Go</mark>.
