You know this game, right? You put black or white stones on a board until you win the game. This is the Japanese game known as Go. This crab is pretty good.
mnemonics.reading: Go is pronounced Go (ご) in Japanese, too. How convenient is that? Like, super convenient. So easy even a crab could remember!

mnemonics.meaning: When you get <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sick</mark> you always eat a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hot pepper</mark>. It's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">habit</mark> you've picked up and you can't seem to shake it. One sniffle, one cough, and before you know it, you're eating a hot pepper or two.
mnemonics.reading: Everyone you know has a different habit when they get sick. Instead, they eat couscous (くせ). But you think couscous is gross. It's bland and does nothing for your stuffy noses and scratchy throats. I wonder how you can convince them to replace their habit with your own.

mnemonics.meaning: The part of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark> people <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">favor</mark> the most is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">head of the plant</mark>. You don't eat the stems and leaves of rice or wheat plants, right? You eat the head where the grains are.
mnemonics.reading: When you want to harvest the head of the plant you'd like to eat, you need to use a hoe (ほ). Using a hoe, you can dig up the bottom of the plant without injuring the head.

mnemonics.meaning: I have <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">five</mark> things in my <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">I</mark> need them all for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">me</mark>. I own these five things, and I keep them in my mouth so people like you cannot take them from me.
mnemonics.reading: Me, personally, I am quite thirsty so I ask for some “waga” (わが). I have five things in my mouth, so it is hard for me to pronounce the word “water”. So it sounds like “waga” when I ask for it. “Coulg I pweash hab sum waga?! I deed waga!!”

mnemonics.meaning: You take some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> and cover your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yoga</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">brush</mark> in it, turning it into a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">key</mark>. You shove the brush you normally use for yoga into the lock to your car and pour the gold over it. Now it's the right shape to be a key!
mnemonics.reading: This key has to be perfect, because if it isn't the car guillotine (かぎ) will come down and chop off your hand!

mnemonics.meaning: You're standing under a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> when you see something strange sticking out of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>. You pull it, but it won't budge. You pull harder and harder until the dirt starts rumbling and a giant <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">manor</mark> starts rising out of the ground with you on top!
mnemonics.reading: The beautiful manor begins to shake and the shougun (しょう) bursts out of the front door. "WHO HAS UNEARTHED MY SECRET MANOR?!" he screams.

mnemonics.meaning: An <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">animal</mark> that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kick</mark>s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> into people's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>s is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">monkey</mark>. Monkeys are naughty little things. You should be happy it was just dirt it kicked into your mouth, and not something worse.
mnemonics.reading: You spit the dirt out of your mouth and look back at the monkey to see that it's saluting (さる) you. Is... is it mocking you?

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Say</mark> "<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">two</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark>s" with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pride</mark>! Nobody said you can't have pride after serving time in two big prisons. So say it with your chest!
mnemonics.reading: After mustering all your pride, you feel like a new person, reborn almost. "I feel like a 子 (こ) again!", you proclaim to the world.

mnemonics.meaning: Inside your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark>s a tiny <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">village</mark> that makes up your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pupil</mark>. That's the black part of your eye!
mnemonics.reading: All of the people in your pupil eat doughnuts (どう) all day long. That's why your eye is shaped like a doughnut, with the "hole" (village) as their home.

mnemonics.meaning: On the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> is your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>. OR! In a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">street</mark>. Which would you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rather</mark>?
mnemonics.reading: As you try to decide which you'd rather have, your neighbors (ねい) come out and grab the heart out of your hands.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Poop</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Poop</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Mountain</mark> is covered in poop because it is such a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">secluded</mark> place.
mnemonics.reading: The secluded Poop Poop Mountain is a favorite of youths (ゆう). They go there to get away from their phones to get in touch with nature again.

mnemonics.meaning: With the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> you command a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> to become a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shelf</mark>. Most of the time one would have to use their hands and tools to turn a tree into a shelf, but you are capable of turning a tree into a shelf by using the power of your mouth.
mnemonics.reading: Once you turn the tree into a shelf you put the shelf in your car (か) and sell it at a local pawn shop. You keep doing this over and over again until you are rich. You command the trees to turn into shelves and then you take the shelves in your car to sell them. Easy money.

mnemonics.meaning: Your village wants to take the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">village</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dog</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark> it, and you can think of no other response than <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">SHUT UP</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: The villagers are mad that you told them to shut up, and they start to mock (もく) you. They put their hands on their hips, lean forward, cross their eyes, and yell "SHUT UP!" back.

mnemonics.meaning: You use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> and an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">slice</mark> down a pedestrian. This innocent guy is just walking along the road when you drive up to him in your car and axe him to death with your axe. You’re all like, VROOM! AXE! Now this guy is dead because you sliced him down in cold blood.
mnemonics.reading: You were driving around in Zanzibar (ざん) when you sliced down this man. Luckily, Zanzibar has no laws at all, so you won’t get arrested for slicing down this guy with your axe.

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> up so everyone can see it. This announces that you are the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sovereign</mark> ruler of this bathroom.
mnemonics.reading: As the sovereign ruler of this bathroom, you must choose a monogram to represent your rule. For this, you choose the symbol of the food that passes through you the most: The mighty tater (てい) tot!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of your sad <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark> aims a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kick</mark> at the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">straw sack</mark> you are holding. This leader is in charge of making your life sad. The next step in the leader making your life suck is attempting to kick your straw sack out of your hands. Your sack holds all your valuables, so it's not something you want to have kicked.
mnemonics.reading: You manage to get your straw sack out of the way as you shout "Heyo (ひょう)! Look, you missed! Heyo!" Unfortunately your leader's friend was standing behind you and he kicks your sack as you move it out of the way. "Heyo!" he shouts, mockingly.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">top hat</mark> comes and tells you that your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark>s are going to be taxed from now on. Top hat man says there is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tariff</mark> that's been enacted on grains. Rice? Triple the price. Wheat? Quadruple.
mnemonics.reading: You're listening to all the things in this tariff and you finally get fed up and ask what isn't being taxed now. The top hat man looks at you and smiles, holding out his hand. In his hand is some soap (そ).

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> from the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">east</mark> needs <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tempering</mark> before it can be sold. The gold from the east is good, it just needs some tempering before it's entirely presentable. You know, tempering like you'd do in a forge.
mnemonics.reading: The smithy where you're doing the tempering is just a rental (れん). You need a rental for your tempering because you haven't sold enough gold to own your own smithy yet. It's seen its fair share of tempering, so it's a pretty shabby rental…

mnemonics.meaning: If you see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> wearing a giant <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">top hat</mark>, beware! This building is a fake and it's trying to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">thwart</mark> all of the plans the people in other buildings have.
mnemonics.reading: The building next door is being painted, and the top hat building is jealous. It thwarts the painting plans by dumping soap (そ) out of its windows and onto the painters and the building!

mnemonics.meaning: You put <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">part</mark> of your food on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">plate</mark>, then put that on a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tray</mark> to keep it safe. This tray is an offering for the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ancestral festival</mark>, where your ancestors' spirits visit you to check in and share some of that food you're offering on a tray.
mnemonics.reading: The plate you put on the tray for the ancestral festival is made of bone (ぼん). Bone china, that is. How fancy… And appropriate, considering bone china is made from actual bone.

mnemonics.meaning: You need to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stop</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> from going down a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark> to ask him how many <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">years old</mark> he is. He's doing a lot of dangerous things right now, and they all have age limits.
mnemonics.reading: Remember the vocab word 〜才 which also meant "years old"? Well, this has the same reading: さい.

mnemonics.meaning: You get <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rain</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">orders</mark>. Your orders are to make sure there is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">zero</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">spill</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The best way to make sure there is zero spill when it rains is to get rid of the rain. You use a special ray (れい) gun and zap the rain right out of the sky. There will be zero spills because there will be zero rain.

mnemonics.meaning: That <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">penguin</mark> over there seems to have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> stuffed with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cash</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Your eyes follow the cash, and you watch as the penguin stuffs it, towel and all, into a hay (へい) stack. What a smart penguin, people don't look for cash in hay, they're too busy looking for needles.

mnemonics.meaning: You give <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">someone</mark> and they make them into <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chopsticks</mark>. They are very talented at turning bamboo into bamboo chopsticks. This someone is an expert at their profession.
mnemonics.reading: Now use those chopsticks to eat some delicious hash (はし) browns! That's what chopsticks were made for. That's what they're always made for.

mnemonics.meaning: Rub <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">charcoal</mark> under your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark>s if you want to see <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">clear</mark>ly. Sports players also rub charcoal under their eyes to see nice and clear in the bright sun.
mnemonics.reading: You have to have clear vision because you're about to go out in your row (りょう) boat. The light off the water shines right into your eyes and you need the charcoal to clear that up for you. Otherwise you'll end up crashing into the shore or going over a waterfall to your death.

mnemonics.meaning: There is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark> on top of a bunch of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> with a steep <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark>. This is a bit redundant, but the mountain and the dirt just make the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cliff</mark> even bigger and steeper and scarier.
mnemonics.reading: You can't believe how big the cliff is now with the mountain and the dirt. You look at it for so long, you just become another gawker (がけ) who can't stop staring at the huge cliff. It really is huge.

mnemonics.meaning: Without a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark>, you will <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lack</mark> the ability to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cook</mark> anything. You really need a fire to cook properly. Having a fire will make sure any cooking endeavors you attempt will not fail.
mnemonics.reading: You cook your meal evenly by swinging (すい) it back and forth over the fire. You swing it left, you swing it right. You swing it to, you swing it fro. All this swinging ensures a properly cooked meal.

mnemonics.meaning: Sitting safely under your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> you take <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>, mix it up, and create unique <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cosmetics</mark> for your face.
mnemonics.reading: You need these cosmetics because you have a meeting with the Shougun (しょう) coming up. You want to impress him, and you don't want anyone to copy your look.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> falls into the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> when a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pig</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">crash</mark>es into it. The building literally crashes to the ground when the horned pig attacks it.
mnemonics.reading: You pull the poor pig out of the rubble of the crash. It's not dead, but it had a nasty bump to the head and now thinks it's a bird. "TWEET (つい)!" says the pig. "Tweet, tweet, tweet!" Poor confused pig.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">crab</mark> will try to hide what it <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lack</mark>s with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">deceit</mark>. Lying, stealing, faking things—no type of deceit is too much for a crab.
mnemonics.reading: Deceit can only take you so far, and soon the crab is caught, tried for its crimes and coverups, and sentenced to death via guillotine (ぎ).

mnemonics.meaning: What would a door criminal steal? A door, of course, but specifically a hinged door. You know, the kind that swings open and shut? That's the kind of door 扉 means.
mnemonics.reading: To protect your door, you get help from 飛び Ra (とびら). 飛び Ra is the flying (飛び) version of Ra, the Egyptian sun god. Whenever a criminal tries to steal your door, 飛び Ra flies out from behind it and blinds them with his sun-god brightness.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hits your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mohawk</mark> and it begins to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">drip</mark>. The water from the tsunami continues to drip from your mohawk long after the tsunami has passed. There’s a lot of water in your hair now, so it’s probably going to drip for a while.
mnemonics.reading: Luckily, you’re a self-proclaimed techie (てき), so you develop a device to stop the drip drip dripping. This techie device of yours is like a hair dryer helmet. You put it over your mohawk, it does its thing, and your hair is dry! Being a techie sure does have its benefits.

mnemonics.meaning: In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> there are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark>s and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> lined up with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lantern</mark> attached to them, making a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fence</mark>. It's a little weird looking, but these things are definitely supposed to fence something in.
mnemonics.reading: You want to know what this fence is fencing in, so you take a step closer. As the light from the lantern gets brighter you see that the fence is around a ton of hay (へい).

mnemonics.meaning: It's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rain</mark>ing on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spear</mark> that has <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark>. When the warm rain hits your cold, winter spear, it creates <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fog</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Through the fog you see the shape of a mythical kirin (きり). You can only see the outline through the fog, but you know it's there.

mnemonics.meaning: After passing through a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">door</mark>, you use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">feather</mark> to put the finishing touches on a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">folding fan</mark>. The door leads to your folding fan workshop where you make all your folding fans. This folding fan is now complete that you’ve added a feather to it. How lovely it is.
mnemonics.reading: Your biggest folding fan customer is a centaur (せん). This centaur just loves your folding fans and this one you just made with the feather was for the centaur’s latest order. You go back out your door and deliver this folding fan to the centaur.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> will only inhabit a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">root</mark> if it's holding a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">grudge</mark>. Have you ever seen a nice, haunted tree? No! They're always angry and trying to get someone back for something.
mnemonics.reading: If you see one of these grudge trees, it's probably inhabited by the soul of a condor (こん). Humans tend to kill condors and take their trees away to build houses and make toilet paper. So condors hold pretty bad grudges against us, and so their souls end up stuck in a lot of trees.

mnemonics.meaning: You take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> and wrap it around your head to keep the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> out of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark>s. You've invented... the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hat</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: After inventing the hat, you wanted to show it off to everyone, so you went to the bowling (ぼう) alley. You really stood out bowling strike after strike in your fancy new hat, and before you knew it, people had coined a term for your funky headpiece. That's right — you became the namesake of the iconic bowler hat!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mask</mark> helps you to see the deepest part of anyone's soul. You look around and in all the people you only see <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hate</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: It turns out you're not looking at normal people. You see so much hate because all the people you're looking at are actually just a group of zombies (ぞう).

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">narwhal</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark> crew needs all the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">help</mark> he can get. The narwhals are beginning construction on an underwater city. The leader knows the narwhals are hard construction workers, but they’ll need some help building this city.
mnemonics.reading: Then you discover a saw (さ) who would be a great big help. This saw is very strong and would help you and your narwhal construction team out a lot. You should make use of this saw right away.

mnemonics.meaning: You have <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thousand</mark>s and while looking up at the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> you decide you want to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">insert</mark> them in there.
mnemonics.reading: You insert one finger, it burns up immediately, and its soul (そう) comes flying out screaming for a moment before it disappears. Hmm. You insert another finger and as it burns up, another little soul comes out screeching, "WHY WOULD YOU INSERT ME IN THERE!" and is gone.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark> take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Italy</mark>. Wolverine’s leader is Professor X, and they are both sliding down a big slide to Italy. How fun!
mnemonics.reading: Before Professor X can get off the slide into Italy, a large eagle (い) swoops down and plucks him right out of his wheelchair. That eagle is very strong. Goodbye, Professor X!

mnemonics.meaning: They <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">key</mark> to telling a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lie</mark> is to totally believe the lie yourself. They say that if you believe your own lie, others will believe it as well. This is key.
mnemonics.reading: The lie you told was about not stealing your buddy’s saw (さ). You actually did steal his saw. He saw you steal his saw, but now you are trying to lie your way out of it. It’s not going well.

mnemonics.meaning: With a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>, you have a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">likeness</mark> to me.
mnemonics.reading: You have a likeness to Jo-Anne (じょ) when you wear that mouth.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">landslide</mark> came out of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> and created your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lips</mark>. Before the landslide, you just had a wide open mouth hole.
mnemonics.reading: Now you can use your new lips to enjoy a nice, cold Kuchi beer (くちびる). The Kuchi people are Afghan Pashtun nomads. They are lesser known for their amazing beer. And you've never been able to get this delicious beer into your mouth, but now that you have lips you can get it all in there.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wave</mark> crashes into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark>, transforming her into an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">old woman</mark>! The wave washes away all of the woman's makeup, revealing her to be an old woman. The makeup she had on made her appear to be a much younger woman, but once the wave washed away her makeup, she was revealed for the old woman she is.
mnemonics.reading: In an attempt to distract you from the fact that she is actually an old woman, the old woman starts to baa (ば) and act like a sheep. The old woman goes "Baa! Baa!" and hops around on all fours like a sheep.

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to cover a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Viking</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> with your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hand</mark>, you have to use your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">palm</mark>. Why the palm? Well, if you do it knuckles-to-mouth, you're sort of just punching the Viking… and you don't want a punch a Viking. That's why you use the palm.
mnemonics.reading: This Viking-touching technique of using the palm was developed by the Shougun (しょう). The Shogun has to deal with a lot of loudmouthed Vikings, so he's learned to use his palm to cover their mouths.

mnemonics.meaning: With a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark>, you hit yourself in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> and then <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kick</mark> it like a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pathetic</mark> loser. You kick the lid, even though it is your fault that you hit yourself in the mouth with it. It’s not the lid’s fault. You don’t need to kick it. You’re being pathetic.
mnemonics.reading: You kick the lid one last time and it bounces off the wall and hits you in the eye (あい). How pathetic. You are a pathetic mess. You should have never kicked the lid. Now both your eye and your mouth are in pain, you pathetic fool, you.

mnemonics.meaning: An <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark> specializing in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark> builds a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rainbow</mark>. Did you ever wonder where rainbows come from? Construction insects build them. Construction insects build rainbows.
mnemonics.reading: This rainbow building insect is so needy (にじ). He is needy because he needs everyone to look at his rainbow and praise him for what he’s done. “Look at my rainbow! Look at how good it is and I am! I’m so needy! Needy for praise and recognition!”

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">refreshing</mark>! Sorry, I can’t say treasure treasure treasure treasure without saying it four times. See? I did it again. Anyway, this big treasure treasure treasure treasure is really refreshing. It’s been a long time since you found a treasure treasure treasure treasure, so finding this big one is really refreshing.
mnemonics.reading: You’d had a sour (さわ) taste in your mouth for not being able to find any treasure treasure treasure treasure for such a long time, but now that you found this big one, the sour taste is totally gone and it’s sooooo refreshing!

mnemonics.meaning: You keep your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tongue</mark> to your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">self</mark> to give your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rest</mark>. You’ve been talking and moving your tongue around all day expressing your feelings. This has tired both your tongue and your heart out, so you stop your tongue moving and decide that you need some self rest time.
mnemonics.reading: What better way to rest than to eat some cake (けい)! No talking necessary. Just enjoy the delicious taste of cake on your tongue and feel your heart let out a sigh of relief.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Before</mark> you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark> something, make sure that you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">roast</mark> it.
mnemonics.reading: Now you roast yourself some centaur (せん). Roasted centaur goes well with tea.

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shrimp</mark> is the exact length of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shaku</mark>, or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Japanese foot</mark>. That’s how they came up with this form of measurement. They measured the length of this shrimp and it was the length of a Japanese foot which they deemed the shaku. It’s equal to 30.3cm, very close to one imperial foot.
mnemonics.reading: How is shaku, the Japanese foot, pronounced by Shaq (しゃく) in Japanese? Why Shaq pronounces it shaku. It’s pronounced shaku in both English and Japanese.

mnemonics.meaning: Take this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark> and throw it at <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nine</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark>es to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">smash</mark> them! It's like old-fashioned bowling, but instead of rolling this stone to knock down the crosses, you want to completely smash them to bits!
mnemonics.reading: As you smash these crosses, you think of your cyborg (さい) and how much you want to smash the people who took it away from you. Your cyborg was so good at smashing things too. You could be smashing together, if you didn't have to sell it.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fortune</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sticky</mark>. Rice is sticky. So is your rice fortune. Your fortune of rice is sticky because it is made up entirely of sticky rice.
mnemonics.reading: This rice is so sticky that you are able to sculpt nendoroids (ねん) from it. Your rice fortune is worth even more now that you are hand making limited edition nendoroids from it.

mnemonics.meaning: In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> there is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">top hat</mark>. It sits atop an area of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tatami mat</mark>s.
mnemonics.reading: Who made this creepy tatami mat altar? It was Joe (じょう), the increasingly concerning farmhand who lives in your village.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">same</mark> as your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">torso</mark>. You must have a really huge torso for it to be the same as the moon.
mnemonics.reading: Your torso got so big because of all the doughnuts (どう) you ate. You ate so many doughnuts that your torso got to be the size of the moon and then you floated away into space with your own gravitational pull and everything. Doughnuts are dangerous things.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">towel</mark> as well.
mnemonics.reading: You know who loves towels? The King (きん) of England. He loves towels so much that he went around and put きん on every towel in the land, so you think of him whenever you use one.

mnemonics.meaning: There are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> growing around a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> with a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wick</mark> sticking out of it. The heart is a sacrifice to the old gods and the life energy bleeds from the burning wick to feed the flowers. The wick burns, releasing the power of the heart which spreads into the ground around the heart causing the flowers to grow.
mnemonics.reading: Sometimes the wick burning the heart isn’t enough for the flowers to grow properly and they get thirsty for the blood from your shin (しん). So, you slice open your shin with a sacrificial knife and drip your blood over the thirsty demon flowers.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> that is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stamp</mark>ed with one pattern, then <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stamp</mark>ed with another pattern, over and over, is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">willow</mark> tree.
mnemonics.reading: Ryu (りゅう) from Street Fighter really loves willow trees. Ryu loves them so much that he makes out with them. Ryu is open mouth kissing a willow tree. You are watching this. It is happening.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pig</mark> riding on it will be able to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">accomplish</mark> anything.
mnemonics.reading: It was even able to successfully accomplish a feat that involved it jumping its scooter right into a swing (すい), swinging back and forth, then jumping off.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Flowers</mark> are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mysterious</mark>ly appearing in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark>. No matter what you do to them, they continue to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">amass</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: As the flowers amass it starts attracting wildlife. Soon thousands of baby chicks (ちく) are amassing in the rice paddy as well.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> has a lot of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> that is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> it gets from the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> of every <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">armpit</mark> of every human on earth! Why does your armpit smell? It’s because the moon is draining the power from your armpit. The moon saps power from your armpit and that power is sucked up into the sky where the moon collects the power for its own devices.
mnemonics.reading: This is a pretty wacky (わき) armpit image isn’t it? Seeing lines of power traveling from your armpit to the moon. Definitely wacky. Have you ever seen something this wacky in real life?

mnemonics.meaning: When a flower looks like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> that reach up to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heaven</mark>, you know it's in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">blossom</mark>. It's all opened up like a mouth, and the pistil and stamen are like horns reaching up to heaven for its sunlight and rain.
mnemonics.reading: If it's shaped like a mouth with horns poking out of it, you know it's going to be a tough little blossom. That's why you'll need a saw (さ) if you've got any hope of cutting it down for your blossom collection.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">servant</mark> uses a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> to break open <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark>. This is really <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">clever</mark>, because shucking shellfish is a lot of work. It's also a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wise</mark> move, because it'll save him time that he can spend on all his other servant chores.
mnemonics.reading: "Yes, more clever than you!" he yells, tearing off his servant's disguise. "It is I, Ken (けん) the samurai. I won't let you eat these shellfish. I'm taking them back to the sea, where they belong!"

mnemonics.meaning: You use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cleat</mark> to climb a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> and your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark> gets the same <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">coloring</mark> as the foliage because your hair is like a chameleon. The coloring of your hair changes to whatever color is around you, so you use your cleats to climb trees to make your hair turn green and brown, and in the fall, yellow and orange and red!
mnemonics.reading: This cool coloring can only happen because you turned yourself into a cyborg (さい). Your hair and scalp are now made of high tech parts, not human ones.

mnemonics.meaning: In this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> there's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">small</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> that's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">small</mark>. They keep this small, small sun inside of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">crevice</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: They keep the sun in the crevice because this is a place where people ski (すき).

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> needs a  <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clown</mark> in it if you want to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cultivate</mark> good crops. Clowns act as a natural fertilizer, and this will make it super easy to cultivate any crops you could ever want in this dirt. Isn't nature amazing?
mnemonics.reading: Before you can start this whole cultivation process however, you have to say bye (ばい) to the clown. Say bye to him, then bash his head in, and drop him in the dirt.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">foot</mark>, as your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mama</mark> says, was given the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">task</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dance</mark>. Shake those two foots your mama gave you and dance dance dance!
mnemonics.reading: You both dance so much that you develop an odor (おど). Not just any odor, an odor particular to stinky dancing feet.

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gate</mark> makes the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sound</mark> of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">darkness</mark>. The gate looks like darkness, but it’s even more creepy that it sounds like darkness too.
mnemonics.reading: You decide to taste the darkness and discover that it is so yummy (やみ)! Who knew that darkness was so yummy? Mmm… this darkness tastes so yummy!

mnemonics.meaning: You have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">surplus</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ladle</mark>s laid out <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">diagonally</mark> in front of you. Why are they diagonal? And why do you have so many ladles? Why the surplus? Hang on, we'll get there.
mnemonics.reading: In front of this diagonal pattern is a shaman (しゃ) who is currently staring at you. You slowly reach down and turn one of the ladles around, diagonally, and look back up. The shaman's eyes are wide, and now they're scribbling on in a notebook.

mnemonics.meaning: Melt down this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">book</mark> and recast it as a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">flower pot</mark>. A solid gold book is too heavy to hold and too shiny to read, but a solid gold flower pot would make a fancy new addition to your garden.
mnemonics.reading: The gold flower pot has a hatch (はち) attached to it, which used to be the book's back cover. That's fine, you use the hatch as a lid for the flower pot!

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Rain</mark> falls off a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> and lands in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark> where it turns to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">frost</mark>. It turns to frost because it’s super cold outside and your body is freezing. The rain that fell off the tree turns to frost as soon as it hits your eye.
mnemonics.reading: This whole description is pretty emo. You came up with this whole emo frost idea because you are a shemo (しも). An emo who goes by she pronouns.

mnemonics.meaning: You need to feed this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flower</mark> wearing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> so you start the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">harvest</mark>. Grains don't pick themselves, you have to harvest them.
mnemonics.reading: You're just starting to harvest the grains when an angry cock (かく) shows up! He's mad because these are his grains and you're about to harvest them and feed them to a turkey instead of him.

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>s isn't actually a canopy of trees at all. When you look closely, you see these trees are actually giant stalks of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hemp</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Who planted all this hemp? Your mama (ま) did.

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horse</mark> may look <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">odd</mark> but it’s actually perfect for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">horse riding</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: Before horse riding, you’ll need the key (き) to access the stable and let out the odd horse you'll be riding.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">landslide</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">humiliate</mark>s you. You told everyone you couldn't come to work, that your house had been destroyed and your car was carried away, but then scientists measured the landslide, and it only went a few feet.
mnemonics.reading: Your friends and coworkers humiliate you more by making jokes (じょく). "Uh oh, I heard it might rain later, I hope you don't drown in the inch of water that's coming!"

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Fire</mark> you use to light up the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">street</mark> needs to go in a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lamp</mark>. Campfires, matches? No, none of those work. You need bright, safe lamps to keep the street nice at night.
mnemonics.reading: These street lamps were first used in とうきょう. It was the most advanced city after all. And more people were out at night in とうきょう than anywhere else in Japan. So they needed lamps to light things up!

mnemonics.meaning: In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mysterious</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> there is some <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">livestock</mark>. This livestock is also mysterious because no one knows where it came from. The mysterious livestock are only seen in the mysterious rice paddy. How mysterious indeed.
mnemonics.reading: Your favorite member of the mysterious livestock crew is a little chick (ちく). The chick is very cute and little. The chick is also very mysterious because it floats about without even flapping its little wings.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hits your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">form</mark> and you begin to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">melt</mark>. You are a witch and water makes you melt. The tsunami is a lot of water, so once it touches your form, you begin to melt.
mnemonics.reading: The only way to reverse the melt process is to eat some yogurt (よう). The yogurt counteracts the melting from the water and your form will become whole again. Quick, eat some yogurt!

mnemonics.meaning: The type of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark> that ruins your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">writing</mark> is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mosquito</mark>. You're trying to write, when you hear that horrible high-pitched mosquito noise in your ear. You jerk your head and swat and it's gone. But when you look down, there's lines all over what you were writing.
mnemonics.reading: That mosquito noise sounds like it's driving a tiny car (か) in your ear. How are you supposed to write with a bug driving around going bzzz bzzz like a revving car?

mnemonics.meaning: Take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> and make it <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">long</mark>. It has to be longer than that! For this will be your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">notebook</mark>, which you will write all your notes in.
mnemonics.reading: Inside your long towel notebook you just write the same name over and over again: "Mrs. Chou" (ちょう).

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">surplus</mark> will cover all the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">paint</mark>. The surplus of tsunamis will strike the paint factories first (everyone knows paint factories are built close to the ocean). Then the paint will flow over all the dirt and paint it a ton of rainbow colors.
mnemonics.reading: You touch the paint in the dirt with your toe (と) to see if it's still wet. It is. The paint is still very wet and now your toe looks like a tiny rainbow.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> are worth a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fortune</mark> because you decided to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">paste</mark> your fortune to the shellfish.
mnemonics.reading: You're a little crazy, which is why you decided to use paste to paste your entire fortune to these shellfish, and as you paste each one you yell out, "Ha (は)!" Paste.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">district</mark> is full of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapons</mark>, but everyone prefers to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">punch</mark> each other. When everyone's armed, things can escalate quickly, so it's better to stick to fists to be safe.
mnemonics.reading: The district residents punch each other in front of the 王 (おう). These punching matches are actually gladiatorial battles for the 王's entertainment.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">light</mark> shines on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> with a great <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">radiance</mark>. The car you are in is a convertible, so the light shines right onto your big bald forehead. The light has a pretty powerful radiance as it is, but the sheen from this light hitting your forehead is the most powerful radiance ever witnessed by man.
mnemonics.reading: This radiance is the key (き) to powering your car. Your car runs on reflected solar energy, and the radiance coming from your forehead is the most powerful source of radiant sunlight ever imagined. Your forehead is a perfect key for this car.

mnemonics.meaning: When your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> has an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">idea</mark> it's just a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">recollection</mark> of something you already know. Only your brain can have original ideas, so when your soul tries to come up with one, it's just a recollection of something you thought before now.
mnemonics.reading: Your soul is sending you a recollection right now of... your past life as a farmer in Oklahoma (おく). You see yourself farming and sweating and living a wonderful life. Hmm, maybe you should move to Oklahoma and live the simple life again.

mnemonics.meaning: If you try to put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> into <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">every</mark>thing, you'll <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">regret</mark> it. It's not so much that putting your soul into things is bad, but every single thing? You'll burn out immediately. You won't be able to be good at any of those things. And you'll regret all the time you wasted trying to be the best at everything.
mnemonics.reading: The regret is too strong for you to ignore, so you decide to drop everything but kayaking (かい). If there's one thing you refuse to regret, it's your bright orange kayak and all the friends you made at kayaking club.

mnemonics.meaning: You take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rake</mark> in for a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark> but it is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">resistant</mark>. The rake doesn’t want to have its measurements taken. The rake is resistant to have any measurement taken because it feels inferior to the other rakes and doesn’t want to be embarrassed if it ends up being smaller than the others.
mnemonics.reading: Because the rake is persistently resistant, you eventually tie it to the table with your neck tie (たい). The tie won’t hold for long, so you need to take each measurement quickly.

mnemonics.meaning: On a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark>, the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pope</mark> is holding a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shield</mark>. The pope is near the edge of the cliff and is using the shield to fend off demons. The demons want to shove the pope off the cliff, but the pope is using his holy shield of popery to fend them off.
mnemonics.reading: The light of the pope's shield begins to fade. The shield's holy power is waning! Just as the demons are about to push him off the cliff, the sun begins to rise. That's right! It's June (じゅん) and summer has just begun. The pope's shield reflects the power of June's bright sun into the eyes of the demons, casting them off the cliff behind him and back into hell!

mnemonics.meaning: There is an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark>. It's there for the eating, and it's how you plan to attract a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">snake</mark> to your roof.
mnemonics.reading: Why don't you just bring a snake up to the roof yourself? Because snakes are heavy (へび).

mnemonics.meaning: If the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> gives you a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> you become part of his <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">squad</mark>. Every king has a knife squad or two protecting him and making sure his subjects keep in line.
mnemonics.reading: This squad is led by Han (はん) Solo, so it's basically a 50/50 shot that the king is gonna die.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have nothing to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eat</mark> but your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ego</mark>, you'll <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">starve</mark>. You can't eat it, and your ego is keeping you from accepting actual food or help from other people.
mnemonics.reading: You starve (thanks ego) and turn into a gargoyle (が). As your stomach aches, your skin turns gray and you slowly harden into a crouched position.

mnemonics.meaning: You’re so hungry that you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eat</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">table</mark> so you won’t <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">starve</mark>. If you don’t eat this table, you will most definitely starve, so you eat the table to stay alive.
mnemonics.reading: After you finish the table, you still feel like you might starve so you decide to eat every key (き) off your key ring. One by one, you eat each and every key so you don’t starve.

mnemonics.meaning: You drive your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> off this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark>, holding your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> tight to your chest, at a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">swift</mark> speed.
mnemonics.reading: Because you had such a swift take off, you didn't notice that your jeans (じん) were ripped right off your body. Until now.

mnemonics.meaning: There's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark>, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark>, and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> stacked on top of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark>, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">threaten</mark>ing to bring it down!
mnemonics.reading: This extra power-filled moon is now trying to threaten the safety of きょうと. All of きょうと is shaking and getting dark as the moon comes closer and closer.

mnemonics.meaning: You see <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shrimp</mark> on <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ice</mark> at the market in the morning. "I'll get some on the way home" you think to yourself. Later that evening, you see no shrimp, just ice. The supply of shrimp has been <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">exhaust</mark>ed. It's all gone! You never thought they'd <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">use up</mark> their shrimp supply so quickly.
mnemonics.reading: How could the store use up its shrimp supply so quickly? Suddenly you notice the worker behind the fish counter has shrimp stuffed into their jeans (じん) . Aha! The culprit!

mnemonics.meaning: Bite a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">root</mark> with your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fang</mark> to get an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">approximation</mark> on its age. It won't be exact, this isn't scientific or anything, but it will be pretty close.
mnemonics.reading: As you're recording your approximation down, somebody comes up and shouts, “Hey guy (がい)! I’ll give you $10,000 for that tree there, guy!” This guy must be crazy. That’s much more than your approximation of the value of this thing. But you sell it to the guy anyway.

mnemonics.meaning: You run your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> along the words of a  <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">paragraph</mark>. You are learning about the law because you plan to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">arrest</mark> somebody.
mnemonics.reading: Who do you want to arrest? You want to arrest こういち. Even though he's started wars, created a religion, and trapped a child in a cavity, it's going to be tricky to arrest him because he's the emperor now.

mnemonics.meaning: If <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">someone</mark> wants to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark>, you let them <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">boil</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: Welp, the pot is at a rolling boil and your knee (に) is in there. The person wasn't saying they wanted to boil, they said they wanted to boil someone. And that meant you. Well, your knee anyway.

mnemonics.meaning: If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">helicopter</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark>s near a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">black hole</mark> then it's going to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">capsize</mark>. I mean, yeah, it's not a boat, but just look, that's what's happening! That helicopter is going down!
mnemonics.reading: You're doing your best to cover the black hole to stop the helicopter from capsizing but it's not working! “F**k you (ふく) black hole!" you shout. You just want to cover it up! You just want to do the right thing!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horse</mark> who can write a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">paragraph</mark> gets to be a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chess piece</mark>. Only the most erudite of horses gets selected to be a chess piece. The knight’s chess piece is represented by a horse, and for a horse to earn this honor, they must first write a paragraph explaining why they deserve the honor.
mnemonics.reading: Upon being told that he will never be a chess piece, the horse slips into a coma (こま). The horse will never awaken from this coma as he knows he will never fulfill his dream of becoming a chess piece, so he has nothing to live for.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> is going <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wild</mark> because you're <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">confused</mark>. If you're confused, it's usually because you don't know what's going on or what to do. This makes the soul inside your body go absolutely wild!
mnemonics.reading: Whenever you're confused, こういち appears to offer you guidance. He's confused a lot, so he knows how to help. And knowledge offered by こういち is the best medicine for confusion.

mnemonics.meaning: Watch what you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> to what appears to be a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sweet</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>, because that tree will 100% <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">conspire</mark> against you.
mnemonics.reading: Now you're getting it! That tree is trying to conspire against you and take you down. Take your bowling (ぼう) ball and bowl it and all its friends down!

mnemonics.meaning: On the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> there's some type of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bird</mark>, but thinner and longer. You look closer and realize it's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">crane</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The crane leans down toward you from its roof perch and squawks, "Too rude (つる)!" You're shocked! You didn't know the crane could speak English, but even worse, it knew you called it a turkey bird.

mnemonics.meaning: You use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark> to begin <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cultivation</mark> of the land. You use your fingers to till the soil, the stone to flatten the ground, and you carefully poke the seeds into the dirt and then use the stone to smash them further down.
mnemonics.reading: Cultivation is suddenly halted because a tack (たく) sticks into your finger. You pull the tack out, throw it away and start cultivation again when... ouch! There's another tack. This field is full of tacks!

mnemonics.meaning: You take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark>, and aiming it at the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kick</mark> it into the air and eventually it begins to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">decline</mark> and crashes into the sun, causing it to supernova. Imagine kicking this lid so hard that it flies into space. See it fly up to the peak of its arch, then watch as it begins the decline until it finally collides with the sun.
mnemonics.reading: As the lid begins to decline in the sky, you realize what’s going to happen so you attempt to swing (すい) to safety. Swing on some vines in the direction opposite of the sun. You know that once that lid finishes its decline and collides with the sun, there’s gonna be trouble.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">commander</mark> who's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> will use his size to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">encourage</mark> his troops.
mnemonics.reading: He encourages the Shougun (しょう) too! You've never seen the Shougun express any emotion other than intense indifference or intense dislike.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> give you a good <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">reason</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">extract</mark> things. You extract juice from fruits, oil from seeds, and coffee from beans. Why? Because you have fingers! That's your reason.
mnemonics.reading: Your magic fingers can even extract the essence out of living things, so you decide to extract some from Chewbacca (ちゅう). You always thought a nice Chewbacca extract could take your cookies to the next level. It'll help offset the sweetness and make them extra chewy (or chewbacca-y!).

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> and a couple <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark>s run into each other. They cancel each other out completely, and the remainder left behind is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">faint</mark> remnant of what was once there.
mnemonics.reading: Just like the tsunami and fire canceling each other out, leaving a faint remainder of what was, your tan (たん) is extremely faint as well.

mnemonics.meaning: There’s a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>, another <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>, and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">coat rack</mark>. That stone and two trees will make the perfect <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">foundation</mark>, or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cornerstone</mark>, for a house to put that coat rack in! This stone is flat and heavy and both of the trees are flexible and durable.
mnemonics.reading: After you finish the foundation, the only step that's left is to wash the entire thing with soap (そ).

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Compare</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> to some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> and you'll see the difference between you and His and Her <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Highness</mark>. You live outside and sleep on the dirt. But His and Her Highness both live in a huge building.
mnemonics.reading: I bet His Highness has never had to sleep in hay (へい) either, like you do every night. Hay is what you use as a pillow, mattress, blanket. Basically hay and dirt are all you have. Unlike His Highness.

mnemonics.meaning: In the event of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark>, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark>, your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark>, and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> will all be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">immersed</mark> in it. You will become immersed in the tsunami after it hits because tsunamis are gigantic and bring a lot of water. Now you and your forehead are immersed in the tsunami along with Wolverine and a stool.
mnemonics.reading: Still immersed, the stool floats over and hits you in the shin (しん). The tsunami gave the stool a good push and while it was fully immersed, it ran into your shin. It really hurts.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">few</mark> members of society without <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> suffer from severe <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">inferiority</mark> complexes. Most people in this world have lots of power, so the few that do not feel quite inferior. It is this feeling of inferiority that fuels their inferiority complexes.
mnemonics.reading: Since you suffer from such extreme feelings of inferiority, when someone offers you and your friends the chance to gain power, you yell “Let’s (れつ) go!” without a second thought. “Let’s go, guys! Come on! Power awaits us!”

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">crab trap</mark> has the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">intuition</mark>. By the power of intuition, this crab trap can trap like, every crab. Through intuition, it knows where the crabs will go and how they will react, so it is much easier to trap them.
mnemonics.reading: This crab trap's intuition powers were extracted from Genghis Khan (かん) himself. And as we all know by now, Genghis Khan was the absolute master of intuition, he always knew what his enemies and his allies were about to do.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> that has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bully</mark> will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">isolate</mark> itself. Building have feelings like people, you know.
mnemonics.reading: The isolated building only has one companion, and it's the cock (かく) that lives inside of it.

mnemonics.meaning: In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">foot</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">capital</mark>, it's tough to be a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dog</mark> because you're always getting <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">kick</mark>ed.
mnemonics.reading: Imagine yourself kicking a kettle (け). There's nothing that's more satisfying to kick than a good ol' kettle, you know?

mnemonics.meaning: You take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>, another <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>, and yet another <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> and stack them on top of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> to make a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mulberry</mark> bush. This is how mulberry bushes are made. You take three stools and you put them atop a tree.
mnemonics.reading: Your mulberry tree then produces a quantity (くわ) of mulberries. Yum.

mnemonics.meaning: You give a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark> to a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">nun</mark> as an offering. You give her this flag and this spoon because they are very precious to you and you want to show the nun how serious you are about repenting for your evil deeds.
mnemonics.reading: You’re getting down on one knee (に) as you present the flag and the spoon to the nun. The nun accepts your offer and takes your flag and spoon from you. Your soul is saved!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> takes his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> into his private <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jet</mark> and is given a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pearl</mark> as a gift, by you! He's letting you ride in his jet today, and you were told the king should be presented with a pearl as soon as he boards.
mnemonics.reading: The king takes the pearl and tosses it into a chute (しゅ) next to the slide he took to get into the jet. You watch as the pearl goes down, down, down until it lands into a huge vat of pearls.

mnemonics.meaning: On the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> there is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> trying to cover the number of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">times</mark> the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dawn</mark> has risen here. You walk over and pull the lid off and the whole thing transforms into a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">podium</mark>. A podium for the dawn to tell you how many times it's risen over this dirt over and over again. It just keeps going and you realize the lid was here because this dang podium can't seem to keep a lid on it! (Get it? Figure of speech!)
mnemonics.reading: You listen to what the podium has to say for so long you finally can't help but ask, "Who are you?" "I'm the dawn (だん), of course!" And this is my podium where I spread the good news about the dawn!

mnemonics.meaning: The only type of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">can</mark> you'll be <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> is one made of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pottery</mark>. Do you honestly think they would let you have anything made of metal or plastic? No, too dangerous. You have to make all of your cans and plates and underpants the old-fashioned pottery way.
mnemonics.reading: You get so good at pottery that the guards start to notice and offer to sell what you make in とうきょう. とうきょう is a big pottery town, after all. You'll make a fortune! Well... the guards will at least.

mnemonics.meaning: Take your greatest <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">treasure</mark>, hold a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> nice and close to it, and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">prune</mark> away all the weak and dead bits.
mnemonics.reading: Currently, you want to prune your greatest treasure: your car (か). Your car is made of wood, and it keeps trying to grow new buds and branches, so you have to prune them off.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> connects to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">five</mark> different <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouths</mark>, allowing you to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">realize</mark> something. You can realize profound truths about the world with these five mouths speaking to your soul.
mnemonics.reading: Right now those five mouths are helping you to realize something about Godzilla (ご). First you hear Godzilla, then you see him, then you smell him, then you touch him. Finally you taste Godzilla. Now you've realized exactly what kind of thing he is. You truly know Godzilla.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> one has to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">oneself</mark> is one's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">royal consort</mark>… You know, assuming one is a member of the royalty. This is a woman who's tied the knot with some royal person and been made into a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">princess</mark> or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">queen</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You can tell someone's a royal consort by the heat (ひ) she radiates. Royal consorts are all smoking hot… literally, because they have to wear bulky, elaborate dresses that were designed several centuries ago. Those things trap heat like nobody's business.

mnemonics.meaning: Put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> on <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ice</mark> and it will only get <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">semi</mark> frozen. You add more ice, and it stays the same. Only some of it will freeze. What the heck!
mnemonics.reading: Finally you realize it will only semi freeze because it's June (じゅん)! It's too hot out for your turkey to freeze all the way. The ice keeps melting off the top and semi thawing it!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> of that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">solely</mark> his. It’s very unique, so that mouth could belong to no other turkey but him. That mouth is solely his.
mnemonics.reading: You traveled a long way to see this turkey and the mouth that is solely his but you missed your exit on the highway and you have to hang a U-ey (ゆい). You know what hang a U-ey means, right? It’s making a U-turn. Well, you have to hang a U-ey on the highway so you can get off at the right spot to see this turkey and the mouth that is solely his.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hill</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> is the most <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sturdy</mark> knife you can find.
mnemonics.reading: This sturdy (but strangely shaped) knife is used by Grandpa ごういち.

mnemonics.meaning: If someone <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark>s it's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">subjugate</mark> them.
mnemonics.reading: You subjugate these loiterers with your holy blue saber (せい)! It's the correct thing to do, after all, and you were given this saber all those levels ago because you did the correct thing.

mnemonics.meaning: With your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> under an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark>, you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">vow</mark>. A vow is a sacred promise, so you have to be really serious when you say one. That's why you do it with an axe hovering above your fingers—it's a reminder that if you break this vow your fingers are gonna get chopped off.
mnemonics.reading: When you finish your vow, you take out your holy blue saber (せい) and cut the axe in half! You know you're never going to break your vow, and if you do, you'll use your own saber to cut off your fingers.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">valley</mark> is very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">vulgar</mark>. The name of the valley is Vulgar Valley, so it makes sense for its leader to be very vulgar.
mnemonics.reading: This vulgar leader leads his Bosozoku (ぞく) bike gang through Vulgar Valley, patrolling the area and spreading vulgarity as he goes.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> at the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gate</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> makes sure all of his plants get <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">watered</mark>. The gate prevents the tsunami from damaging anything inside the king’s home, and the plants around the gate get watered by the water of the tsunami.
mnemonics.reading: These plants are getting watered in June (じゅん), the month they need watering the most. June is a hot month, so it’s good that this tsunami came and got the king’s plants watered when it did.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark>, Master <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Splinter</mark> (the rat from Ninja Turtles) isn't even supposed to exist. He exists because someone <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">accidentally</mark> poured ooze on him.
mnemonics.reading: But really, if you do something accidentally, it's probably a good (ぐう) thing in a way. You learn a bit about how you can improve yourself so you don't do it again, or in Splinter's case, it's just a good mistake!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark> of an under<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> will be done by someone who is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">adept</mark> at it.
mnemonics.reading: Adept at constructing underground prisons, you've caught the eye of Emperor こういち, the royal underground prison enthusiast.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fish</mark> with two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>s has the number <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">two</mark> on it because it's in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> (that's its prison number). Who put the poor two-mouthed fish in prison? An <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">alligator</mark>. Because alligators hate two-mouthed fish.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the わに in "WaniKani." Ever heard of it?

mnemonics.meaning: Put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bed</mark>, <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">grasp</mark> the sheets and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bundle</mark> them up. Now you can do the laundry!
mnemonics.reading: In between grasping and bundle-ing, you shout HA (は)! That's when the sheets come off the bed.
