mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horse</mark> that is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fat</mark> is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">burdensome</mark> animal.
mnemonics.reading: But you have to be nice to the burdensome horse because this horse is your dad (だ).

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">same</mark> as a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cave</mark>. Because, if a wave is big enough, it will curl over on itself, creating a sort of cave within the wave. That's why it's the same as a cave!
mnemonics.reading: Best way to remember the reading for this kanji is to think about how the shape of a cave is the shape of a doughnut (どう).

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> all in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark> is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chief</mark>. All the other leaders are wearing some other color, but that's how you tell the chief apart from the other leaders.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 白, which is included in this kanji. The other reading is お, and it's like the honorific 御, in a way. You'd want to be polite to someone who is the chief ______, right? That's why it could be お, too.

mnemonics.meaning: Under a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark>, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark> opens his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> and says, "<mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">China</mark>!" Why would he say China? It's all very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sudden</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: This sudden urge to shout "China" also came about because Wolverine woke up in とうきょう. Outside of his pagoda-shaped canopy, Wolverine noticed the kanji and assumed he was in China.

mnemonics.meaning: You want to write a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">chapter</mark> about <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark> in your new book so you have to make sure it's really <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">clear</mark>. Clear enough so that ANYbody can read it.
mnemonics.reading: Your clear writing got the attention of the Shougun (しょう) and now he's at your door once again. Although, this time he's angrier than usual. His hair also looks awful. He took your advice after reading the book and cut his entire ponytail off.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> crashes into the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>, which is then caught in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> and tied to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>! Wait a second... this doesn't sound realistic, it sounds really <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">comic</mark>! That's because it's from that comic book about a pirate you're always reading!
mnemonics.reading: Comics are manga (まん) in Japan, whether they're comic or serious.

mnemonics.meaning: Watch what you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">next</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> over, because they hired you to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">consult</mark> them.
mnemonics.reading: You panic, and consult the man into buying a sheep (し).

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Yoga</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">King</mark> presides over all <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">courts</mark>: law, imperial, and so forth. In this case, you've met him in the court of law, where he is judge, jury, and executioner.
mnemonics.reading: The court of the Yoga King is against you. You have to turn this around, so you start pushing tater (てい) tots into his tater-tot-hole shaped mouth.

mnemonics.meaning: This is an animal with an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">angle</mark>d <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark> claw that's filled with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cow</mark> meat but looks like an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark>. What kind of animal is that? It's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">crab</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the かに in WaniKani.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> is making a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cage</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>. She's using it to trap water, making this a dirt <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dam</mark>. If you think about it, dams are just dirt cages anyway.
mnemonics.reading: Something about the woman working hard to build this dam makes her super sexy (せき) to you. Maybe it's because the sun is so bright, making her shine, or maybe it's because hard work is attractive. Who knows.

mnemonics.meaning: If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hits your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">helicopter</mark> while you are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark>ing, it will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">drift</mark> out to sea. What were you doing with a jackhammer at a time like this? Now your helicopter is drifting away!
mnemonics.reading: As it drifts away you shout, "Heyooo! (ひょう)." You know the helicopter probably can't hear you (or understand you) but maybe it will turn on and stop drifting away if you shout it enough.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hits a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> and then <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark>s itself. This causes it to swirl around, creating an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">eddy</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: There is a person trying to create an eddy with a tsunami, and when their roof correction device is shown to be effective, they sing: "This is how you do (よど) it."

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark> way to block the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> is with an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">embankment</mark>. Build a huge, sloping embankment correctly and the sun won't be able to bother you ever again!
mnemonics.reading: Unfortunately, building a correct embankment doesn't just take dirt, but tater (てい) tots too. You pile up the dirt and the tater tots so the embankment can be nice and high.

mnemonics.meaning: You walk out on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark>, where you find in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> poking out. It speaks: "It is me, the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">empress</mark> of these lands!"
mnemonics.reading: When you finish unburying the empress, the first thing she says to you is: "Please, you must hurry and take me to Emperor こういち."

mnemonics.meaning: Turn a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sick</mark>ness into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark> and it becomes an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">epidemic</mark>. This sickness spreads to everyone and it's all your fault because you put it in the water supply.
mnemonics.reading: These epidemics spread by 駅 (えき). Each train takes the sickness and shoots off in a different direction, spreading it further.

mnemonics.meaning: You have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">number</mark>ed <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">feather</mark>. Pick your favorite number and put it on the feather. Then, put the numbered feather on your head. When you put it on, you're able to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">flip</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">flip</mark> over and over.
mnemonics.reading: You're pretty good at your flip technique, but you're not that good. You really need to practice and hone (ほん) your skills and get better.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">can</mark> be a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>, but it can also be a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">psychopath</mark>. The tree goes from being a regular tree to being a psychopath. Such mood swings are so rough. Especially when the tree slips to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gloom</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Then the tree switches from gloom to being super excited (these moodswings!). The super excited tree starts doing dubstep. Uts (うつ) uts uts uts uts ♬.

mnemonics.meaning: There is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> coming up over a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark> made of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>. You can see this happening very far away because it's right on the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">horizon</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You squint into the horizon and see something else. There's some guy (がい) up there. And he's... he's being swept away by the tsunami. The guy disappears into the horizon. The guy is gone.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">name</mark> on this piece of wood is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">inscription</mark> that shows the artist's signature.
mnemonics.reading: The inscription is a name written on something, right? Remember the kanji for "name"? It is 名, and it shares the reading with this kanji as well, making both names めい.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cat pirate</mark> is the greatest cat pirate of them all. It leads all the cat pirate leaders, even! This is truly a cat pirate <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">to look up to</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Your job is to bring this leader of cat pirates (whom you look up to) its favorite food: gyoza (ぎょう).

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> uses its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark>s to carry out its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">specialty</mark>, which is turning itself into <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">record book</mark>s.
mnemonics.reading: A record book is a book (ぼ), when it comes down to it.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">restaurant</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">restaurant</mark> kanji are the same! The meaning of this kanji also extends other resting places, like an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">inn</mark> or a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pavilion</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: This restaurant only serves tater (てい) tots. Really, would you ever want to go to a restaurant that didn't have tater tots? No.

mnemonics.meaning: What you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">street</mark> needs to be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">revise</mark>d. Your words need to be polished, you can't publish improv. Revise your street word inspiration before you share it again.
mnemonics.reading: You want to revise the song you wrote about tater (てい) tots at lunch today. But it needs a lot of revising.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">samurai</mark> who can fight with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">icicle</mark>s on him is more <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">robust</mark> than regular samurai. Can you imagine how robust you'd have to be to fight in weather cold enough to form icicles on your body?
mnemonics.reading: You may think it's just his robust body, but it's actually the samurai's robust soul (そう) that keeps him fighting through the cold and the icicles.

mnemonics.meaning: There are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nine</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark>s all driving in the same place. With so many cars driving in the same place, they create a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rut</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: To get out of the rut you have to put in a second key (き) that turns on the thrusters. You put in the key and press the "take off" button.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> is getting all <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stirred up</mark>. He's kicking up all the rice. Who stirred him up?
mnemonics.reading: While the turkey is stirred up, it also looks like it's having a lot of fun (ふん).

mnemonics.meaning: At the top of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark> is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">signpost</mark> to tell you you've reached the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">summit</mark>. Literally every mountain that humans have reached the top of has one of these summit signs.
mnemonics.reading: At the summit, you decide to build your new home (ほう). It's been destroyed so many times, and you're sick of it. Maybe if you build you home at the summit of this mountain it will be safer.

mnemonics.meaning: Sticking out of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>, there's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> adorned with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> shells. This is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tomb</mark>. The flowers and shellfish were put here as decorations and to honor the dead that currently lie under the dirt. And the cross marks the tomb, obviously.
mnemonics.reading: This is a tomb, but it feels really fun (ふん). Decorated with flowers and shellfish shells, it’s not a sad place at all. It's a fun place to remember all the fun times with people you loved.

mnemonics.meaning: With your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> you put some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark>s in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boat</mark> for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">transport</mark>. This is a transport boat and its your job to get these weapons from one place to another.
mnemonics.reading: Hey! You're transporting weapons just like Han (はん) Solo! I mean, it was a spaceship, not technically a boat, but he definitely used the Millennium Falcon as a transport.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fang</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> shows that it's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wicked</mark>. Something wicked probably lives in the building too.
mnemonics.reading: You peek inside the wicked building and a wicked jaguar (じゃ) suddenly pounces at you! You let out a sigh of relief when it's stopped by the window, but then... the window opens?! What a wicked building! It's letting the jaguar get you!

mnemonics.meaning: You're sitting on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">again</mark>!!?
mnemonics.reading: Your friends are starting to worry about you, because you're always sitting on that stool. "What is the matter (また) with you?" they scream! You might want to imagine that all your friends have Jamaican or British accents to make this one fit a bit better!

mnemonics.meaning: We must <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stop</mark> the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark>. That, at least, we can come to an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">agreement</mark> on.
mnemonics.reading: "We have agreement," the world's leaders all say. "We will work together to stop the moon, and we have agreement on who we will follow, Emperor こういち.

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> at your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wedding</mark>, you need to make sure you have it at the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bay</mark>. Anywhere more inland, and the tsunami won't reach it in time.
mnemonics.reading: How did you get a tsunami to show up in the bay in the first place? By throwing a bunch of uranium (うら) in there, of course! Its highly unstable nature can make any body of water, especially a calm bay, turn violent.

mnemonics.meaning: If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hits a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dollar</mark> the water will instantly start to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">boil</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: The boiling water crashes onto the land and you realize your foot is in it! No, not one foot, both your foots (ふつ)! It hurts so much that you can't even remember the word for two foots.

mnemonics.meaning: You see <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lantern</mark> that can hold <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ten thousand</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drops</mark> of water sitting on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark>. You get closer and realize it's not a lantern, it's actually a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bottle</mark>. The horns are like a weird handle, but it's definitely a bottle filled with water.
mnemonics.reading: Even though you're not the one who left this bottle here, you decide to do the right thing and throw it in the trash bin (びん). It's not right to leave a bottle just sitting on the ground, you know.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">call</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">call</mark> kanji are the same. This kanji can also mean <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">eat</mark>, because why would you call someone if not to ask them to eat with you?!
mnemonics.reading: You are called to come eat by the Shougun (しょう). He's been really impressed with you lately and he wants to chat over drinks, he says on the phone.

mnemonics.meaning: You try to put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">toe</mark> inside a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark>, but it just won't open. That's because this shellfish has sworn an oath of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chastity</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: "Chastity is really important to me," the shellfish says. "But, maybe if you give me a tater (てい) tot, I'll change my mind."

mnemonics.meaning: There is a special type of meditation where you put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> and touch your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> down to your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">legs</mark>. If you can do this pose, everything in life will become completely <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">clear</mark>. Everything will clear out of your head too. You should try it.
mnemonics.reading: Your mind is as clear as a sparkling clear pond. On this pond you see yourself in a row (りょう) boat. A single row boat on the clear pond that is now your mind.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark>s of the two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>s you destroyed with your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark> live on in the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">collar</mark> you made out of them.
mnemonics.reading: The collar keeps whispering, "Eric (えり)!" into your ear. Your name isn't Eric (I mean it could be, in that case wow, weird, right?), so you assume one of the trees you killed was named Eric. But that's the only name you hear, so maybe they were both named Eric? It's weird.

mnemonics.meaning: So my <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> has a big <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">splinter</mark>, right in the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">corner</mark>. So what?
mnemonics.reading: That corner is dangerous, but what are you going to do, sue me (すみ)?

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">buddy</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> is in the next <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">county</mark>. If it was in your county then it wouldn't be a buddy, it would be a neighbor. You're aware of this building, but they aren't that close, so they're just a buddy.
mnemonics.reading: Your county is everything you can reach when shooting a gun (ぐん). If the bullet can't reach a building you know, it's a buddy building in another county.

mnemonics.meaning: There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark> next to which you left some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">syrup</mark>, and it has all <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dried up</mark>! Put any liquid substance near fire and it will dry up actually, but syrup especially. It goes from being sticky and gooey and yummy to a pile of hard, dry sugar. Not so yummy.
mnemonics.reading: If you dry up syrup like this, you're removing its soul (そう). Have you ever seen dry syrup before? No soul in that. In fact, you probably have no soul if you can dry out syrup like this without feeling bad about it.

mnemonics.meaning: If you use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sickle</mark> to kill a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shrimp</mark> you'll need a really good <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">explanation</mark> for yourself. What did that shrimp do to you? Why use a sickle? Well? What's your explanation?
mnemonics.reading: In your explanation you blame everything on Shaq (しゃく). He told you to do it! It's all Shaq's fault, you explain.

mnemonics.meaning: You ate the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark>, and then the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> too, but man were they high in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fat</mark>! In fact, you wanted to eat them with chopsticks, but they were so greasy with fat that the spoon was your only option.
mnemonics.reading: Unbeknownst to you, the moon and sun contained as much fat as an entire adult sheep (し)! Why didn't you check the nutrition facts first???

mnemonics.meaning: When the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> faces the right <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark>, the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fat</mark> in the bodies of people and animals all gets drawn to the surface and we all look weirdly greasy for a little while. You probably knew that the moon exerts a pull on water, but I bet you didn't know it exerted a pull on fat too!
mnemonics.reading: As long as you're covered in fat, you might as well go bowling (ぼう). Imagine how smoothly that bowling ball's going to roll after you slather it with some of this fat!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Korea</mark> is destined for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">greatness</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The greatness radiates off of the leader of Korea, so much so that you can hardly look. Just when you're about to close your eyes to shield them from the greatness, a great eagle (い) soars over them, letting out a cry.

mnemonics.meaning: You put <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> and your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark>. The flowers you put on them are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lotus</mark> flowers.
mnemonics.reading: You're putting a lotus on both your scooter and car because they are rentals (れん).

mnemonics.meaning: A person with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> has you on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> and lets loose two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poops</mark> over your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>. "<mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Mercy</mark>! Mercy!" You cry, but the horned dude doesn't stop until there are two gross poops sitting on your heart. "M-mercy..." is the only thing you can think to say.
mnemonics.reading: As you shout "Mercy!" one more time, suddenly Jesus (じ) appears out of no where and punches the horned guy into the stratosphere. Jesus snaps his fingers and the poop is gone and you're off the ground. Your heart is safe.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pig</mark> makes a small <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mound</mark>. Picture it, if you will. A pig is rooting through the dirt. It lifts its head and there is a mound of dirt right on its forehead.
mnemonics.reading: The pig's forehead dirt mound keeps getting bigger until it's the size of two cars (つか)! Pigs are big, but you didn't think one could balance a mound the size of two cars on its forehead and not fall over.

mnemonics.meaning: You have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">plow</mark> and a (water) <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">well</mark>. These are the two things you need in order to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">plow</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Plowing all the fields are こういちs. Not Emperor こういち. These are the こういち clones the government made, and now they're being put to use.

mnemonics.meaning: Everyone knows that when a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> plays <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">football</mark> she becomes a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">princess</mark>. Thats how princesses are made.
mnemonics.reading: Remember the word 姫? It means princess too. If you remember the ひめ from 姫, you'll be able to remember this one too.

mnemonics.meaning: You run your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> through your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">husband</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark>. His horns are what you love to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">put between</mark> your fingers.
mnemonics.reading: Why are your husband's horns what you always love to put between your fingers? Because he's a hot sergeant (はさ)!

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clan</mark> is breaking <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> your new <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">residence</mark>. You're all working together to make you a new home!
mnemonics.reading: Your new residence is complete! You step closer and the smell of tater (てい) tots hits your nose. Someone is making you tater tots in your new residence. Wait, no they aren't. Your residence is MADE of tater tots! Thank you, clan!

mnemonics.meaning: What would your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> do if you got caught in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> for <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">legs</mark>? It'd probably get real <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> — in other words, it would <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">scream</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You scream and scream and scream until a door bursts open. It's Genghis Khan (かん) and he looks mad. Apparently your screaming is bothering him and now he's gonna give you a real reason to scream.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Flowers</mark> that grow in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> only live to be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">seedling</mark>s. Once they sprout, they're plucked away to make room for more rice. Poor little seedlings.
mnemonics.reading: The seedlings try their best to blend in by referring to themselves as myou (みょう), you know, me and you combined. That's myou.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> sitting on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> is something every ship has in its crow's nest. That's why the universal <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ship counter</mark> is a turkey on a stool. Not a crow.
mnemonics.reading: Once you become the best ship counter in the world everyone will think you are super sexy (せき)! Nothing is sexier than being able to count, and counting ships is the sexiest thing you can count.

mnemonics.meaning: If you look in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tiger</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stomach</mark> you'll find a bunch of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">skin</mark>. It's really gross but what else did you think you'd find? Everyone knows tigers can't digest the skin of the things it eats.
mnemonics.reading: The only person who would try to take skin from a tiger's stomach is a fool (ふ). You'll probably get your head bitten off looking for skin that way.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> that's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lack</mark>ing is really <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">soft</mark>. Cars need to be hard so that things like bugs and other cars wont hurt the people inside when you hit them. But if your car is lacking the hardness it needs, you'll have a really soft, useless car.
mnemonics.reading: This car is probably so soft because it's made entirely of naan (なん). Naan may be delicious, but it makes a really crappy car. No wonder it was so soft (and yummy).

mnemonics.meaning: If you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mix</mark> a bunch of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark>s together, you have yourself a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">suburb</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: "Suburbs are what we need!" says Emperor こういち.

mnemonics.meaning: Take the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">street</mark> all the way to that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark>, way up there. When you reach it, you will have made it to the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">summit</mark>. You <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">humbly</mark> present the road to the geoduck and bow before it.
mnemonics.reading: You are at the top, the summit of everything! You humbly survey your surroundings from the top of the geoduck, only to see someone on the street, running toward you. It is Mrs. Chou (ちょう), and she looks angry.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> is coming, so you ask two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark>s to help you take your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> out for a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wash</mark>. Despite the obvious dangers, a giant wave is the only thing that'll wash a giant turkey, so you have no choice.
mnemonics.reading: To make sure your turkey won't get carried away by the tsunami while you wash it, you pin it down with a giant tack (たく). If you're washing a giant turkey inside a giant wave, only a giant tack will guarantee it doesn't get washed away.

mnemonics.meaning: If you put two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mustache</mark>s on either side of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> it won't know which way to go and spin back and forth until it becomes a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">whirlpool</mark>. Mustaches are pretty gross, so I don't blame the tsunami for avoiding them.
mnemonics.reading: The whirlpool is huge, and it starts pulling things into itself. Oh no, is that my car (か)? Hey, wait! Whirlpool give my car back!

mnemonics.meaning: If you have an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ear</mark> for the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">public</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>, you must be very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wise</mark>. You can understand everything the people want, and you know how to give it to them because you listen to their hearts so well.
mnemonics.reading: All of these wise things are stored in your soul (そう), not your brain. That's where all of these kinds of intuitive feelings live.

mnemonics.meaning: When a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> grows <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">old</mark>, it will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wither</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: This withered tree's best friend is a human 子 (こ). Imagine the child hugging the tree.

mnemonics.meaning: If you point a bunch of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> in the same <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark>, you'll be able to smell their <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">aromatic</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fragrance</mark>. The best way to bask in their fragrance is to make them all point in the same direction (preferably straight at you).
mnemonics.reading: You decide to bring this aromatic fragrance into your home (ほう). To do this, you plant flowers all the way around your home, all facing in toward it.

mnemonics.meaning: When a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> lives in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sheep</mark> it becomes the most <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">auspicious</mark> creature on the planet. Lights shine out of it and the whole world weeps at its beauty. Look at the sheep's fluffy glowing head. Nothing could be more auspicious and glorious than this.
mnemonics.reading: The spirit sheep is so auspicious that the Shougun (しょう) declares this day to be the most auspicious of all days. The day when the spirit sheep appeared.

mnemonics.meaning: I hope all you're doing in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bathtub</mark> is taking a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bath</mark>. I mean, you can do other things if you want I guess. But bathtubs were made just for baths!
mnemonics.reading: When do you miss taking a bath the most? When you're on the road (ろ). Traveling is fun and all, but when you're stuck in a car, traveling down a dirt road for days, all you want to do is take a nice long bath.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">library</mark> thinks that all the books in their library are better than everyone else's books. He's a very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">biased</mark> person. If he wasn't the leader of that specific library he'd probably feel differently.
mnemonics.reading: You decide to give in to his biased recommendations and look at what he has in his library. It doesn't take long until you realize that these books are all about hens (へん) and hen care. This guy is so biased about his favorite books that he only filled his library with what HE wants to read. And apparently that thing is taking care of hens... weird.

mnemonics.meaning: If you look at <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> the first thing you notice are the leaves and petals themselves, then the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">next</mark> thing you notice are the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">briar</mark>s. You never see <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">thorn</mark>s first, only after you've looked at the flowers.
mnemonics.reading: When you see the briars you can't help but yell, Eee! Ba riars! (いばら)! You sound funny because you prick your finger on one while you're yelling. Ouch!

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> was a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">former</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> until the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cave in</mark>. You see, prisons aren't built very carefully, they just try to get them done fast enough to stuff people in there. So while you can tell this was once a building, it definitely isn't a prison anymore, since the whole thing caved in.
mnemonics.reading: You keep picturing the cave in and you see Genghis Khan (かん) climbing over the rubble. He's the one who took down this prison! And he's coming for your town next!

mnemonics.meaning: The famous <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">triceratops</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> is good for only one thing, and that's being made into <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chain</mark>s. They link their triceratops horns together and form an unbreakable gold chain. You can't eat them, because they're gold. So they're only really good for their chaining together ability.
mnemonics.reading: However, the only way to break the chain is to cut it open with a saw (さ). Once the golden triceratops shellfish start holding on, they never let go. So when you want to take the chain off you have to really hack at it with your saw.

mnemonics.meaning: You give a bunch of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clown</mark> as <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">compensation</mark>. The clown did you some favors, and everyone knows clowns only accept shellfish as a form of currency. So your compensation is a pile of random shellfish.
mnemonics.reading: Once the clown has been properly compensated, he looks you in the eyes, one hand full of shellfish, the other in the air, and waves, "Bye (ばい)" he says. "Bye, bye."

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> is like the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> or the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dawn</mark>. It is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">constant</mark>, never changing.
mnemonics.reading: Also constant is the Emperor こういち, who will surely rule for a thousand more years!

mnemonics.meaning: You're sewing something with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> but you and your creation get <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">frostbite</mark> while you're still working. Luckily the snowflakes freeze themselves into the cloth and turn into a pretty <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">design</mark>. They swirl around and press a unique snowy design into the fabric. This is nice for you because you can't sew anymore with your frostbitten hands.
mnemonics.reading: As you watch the snowflake design form you see letters appearing in the corner! They form the name Aya (あや), our artist here at WaniKani. Somehow she's magically putting together this beautiful pattern!

mnemonics.meaning: If you figure out how to use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> as a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark>, everyone is going to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">die</mark>. You can't control a tsunami, you fool. Now you've doomed us all.
mnemonics.reading: The only way to maybe not die is to find boats (ぼつ). As long as the boats don't get smashed by the tsunami, you might be able to cheat death by holding onto the boats and not drowning.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> grasp this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> and when you raise it you see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">poop</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> (a turkey covered in poop). You can't help yourself, you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">embrace</mark> the turkey.
mnemonics.reading: As you embrace the sad turkey it makes a funny sound and suddenly starts pooping yogurt (よう) all over you. But you don't want to stop embracing it! It's probably just scared still. But the more you squeeze, the faster the yogurt comes out of it!

mnemonics.meaning: When you ride your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> listening to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">music</mark> under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>, you're bound to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">encounter</mark> a bunch of new people! They hear your music playing as you scoot by and they come out to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">meet</mark> you.
mnemonics.reading: Everyone you encounter wants to bare their soul (そう) to you, literally. They're all coming out to meet you, pulling back their skin and showing you the soul ghosts inside of them.

mnemonics.meaning: From your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> comes a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark>, some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark>, and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark>. It all <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">erupt</mark>s from your mouth!
mnemonics.reading: When do inanimate objects erupt from your mouth? Mostly when you're having fun (ふん).

mnemonics.meaning: If the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yakuza</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> you into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jet</mark>, things are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">especially</mark> bad for you. Not just normal bad, like, especially bad.
mnemonics.reading: You're especially worried now, because they're putting you in some kind of chute (しゅ). You already took a slide in here, and now you're teetering over the edge of a dark, steep chute into who knows where!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> puts their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hat</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> next to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bookshelf</mark>. This is a test in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ethics</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: To test your ethics even more, the leader puts down a ring (りん) as well.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">east</mark> is an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">exhibit</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Right now the exhibit has a bunch of chins (ちん) on display. Animal chins, human chins, every chin you can think of is in the exhibit.

mnemonics.meaning: If you tie a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> you can trick everyone into thinking it's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">falcon</mark>. The cross will stretch its wings out just enough for it to stop looking so fat and turkey like, into a super cool bird of prey.
mnemonics.reading: You decide to name this new falcon after your favorite falcon-like ninja. Ryu Hayabusa (はやぶさ) from Ninja Gaiden! Picture your fat turkey falcon and Ryu Hayabusa teaming up Banjo and Kazooey style. Yeah, that's the dream right there.

mnemonics.meaning: What do <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stairs</mark> do? They take you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">from</mark> where you were, to somewhere else. They're a way to get <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">from</mark> place to place.
mnemonics.reading: If you're going from place to place, make sure you have some nori (の) seaweed on you, in case you get hungry. Nori is a great source of energy.

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to have your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wedding</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> you're going to need a lot of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">help</mark>. Cars are pretty small compared to weddings, so if you don't get help from everyone you know you won't be able to pull it off.
mnemonics.reading: You can't just ask for help on the day of the wedding, either. You have to schedule (すけ) getting your friends' help ahead of time. They might have pretty tight schedules too, so make sure you plan early!

mnemonics.meaning: There is an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">animal</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grass</mark> and your horrible <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">task</mark> is to go <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hunting</mark> for it.
mnemonics.reading: You're currently hunting in a row (りょう) boat and you have to row as quietly and carefully as you can or the animal will run away.

mnemonics.meaning: Beside your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> is an evil <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spider</mark> that tries to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">instigate</mark> you into saying bad things and starting a riot. It's like the little silken puppet master of your mouth or something. Don't let it instigate you!
mnemonics.reading: You want the spider to stop instigating you into saying bad things and starting riots. So you pick up a saw (さ) and start cutting off the silken threads that are controlling your mouth.

mnemonics.meaning: If you give a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">machine</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> it will get <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lazy</mark>. Hearts give us emotions and with emotions we become weak. Why would a machine with a heart want to work anymore? Nah. It's lazy time now.
mnemonics.reading: The machine is so lazy it won't even wear its tie (たい) anymore. That was the only official thing left about it, but now it's as lazy as a human. Would a lazy human put on a tie? I don't think so.

mnemonics.meaning: In its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">narwhal</mark> that's supposed to do <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">construction</mark> under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark>, will be too <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lazy</mark> to do it. And when your soul is lazy, there's no way you'll be able to get something done.
mnemonics.reading: You can't tell the lazy narwhal he's being lazy because he's your dad (だ). If he was anyone else you'd tell him off for being lazy, but you can't tell off your dad. That's just not right.

mnemonics.meaning: Take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leather</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">helicopter</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> to prove your excellent <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">leadership</mark>. Some people called you crazy, but you'll show them, as you lead an entire crew of leather helicopter pilots on their first mission to space!
mnemonics.reading: Under your superior leadership you and your leather helicopter crew are able to make it to the moon. The moon! Your crew is so impressed by your leadership, and their lack of being very dead, and they all start laughing, "Ha (は) ha ha ha!" They thought they were going to die but you lead them to the moon safely!

mnemonics.meaning: Shaving the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark> off a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark> before you try to eat it is absolutely <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">necessary</mark>. If you don't, the hair will get caught in your throat and you'll choke. It is necessary that you remove the hair.
mnemonics.reading: It is also necessary that you wear a suit (す) when eating shaved geoduck. It's a super fancy meal so a suit is necessary for you to enjoy it correctly.

mnemonics.meaning: If you take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cow</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark> you're turning it into an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">offering</mark>. In the old days, cows' lives were given to the gods as offerings pretty often.
mnemonics.reading: You prepare the offering with your holy blue saber (せい). Normally this would be gruesome, but your saber glows and the cow's life shoots up into the sky without you laying a hand on it.

mnemonics.meaning: If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark> has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fault</mark>, it needs to be put back in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">order</mark>. Grains must be perfectly identical at all times, otherwise they'll be thrown out. That's why special people will go out and check them to confirm their <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">regularity</mark>. Keeping order is a tough job!
mnemonics.reading: You can always tell if a company keeps order or if it cheats (ちつ) just by looking at the grains.

mnemonics.meaning: There was once a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">melon</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">child</mark>, that is, a child with the body of a melon. When he was born, his parents didn't want him, so he became an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">orphan</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The orphan melon boy is but a 子 (こ).

mnemonics.meaning: Under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">window</mark>, you place a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark>, then slam the window shut to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pierce</mark> its tough shell. This is the best way to pierce a member of the shellfish family, I promise.
mnemonics.reading: Now that your shellfish is properly pierced and turned into sushi counters, you can serve them to Genghis Khan (かん) and his men. I really hope you counted them correctly too, because there are a lot of them.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> that's prepared at <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dawn</mark> by the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">village</mark> are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">provisions</mark> for the army. The army is scheduled to arrive right after dawn, so all of the village's provisions for them have to be ready by then.
mnemonics.reading: Once all of the provisions are ready, the soldiers show up in their row (りょう) boats and load it all up. But they aren't done there. "Rice isn't enough, we need roe (ろう) so we will have the strength to row our row boats back." And so the village brings them all of their roe too.

mnemonics.meaning: If you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wind</mark> it will be really <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">quick</mark> to knock you over. So quick that you probably won't even know the wind did it. You'll end up standing up only to be knocked over again, just as quick.
mnemonics.reading: That quick wind is quicker than you can say Satsuki (さつ). And "Satsuki" is a pretty quick sounding name already. Go ahead, say "Satsuki" as quick as you can right now. Heck, try it a few times.

mnemonics.meaning: All you need are some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark>, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fish</mark>, and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark> and you've got yourself a potion that can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">revive</mark> just about anyone or anything!
mnemonics.reading: This potion able to revive any being just has one small downside: it tastes like soap (そ).

mnemonics.meaning: If your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> is acting like the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> trapped in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> sitting on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>, then people will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ridicule</mark> you for your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">laziness</mark>. You're just sitting there, trapped and not moving.
mnemonics.reading: When people ridicule you, when you can't stop the laziness, you read manga (まん). Manga helps you feel better about the mean things people say. Manga helps you feel like you're doing something, and that you aren't just a lazy person.

mnemonics.meaning: Play your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drum</mark> under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> and your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark> will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">swell</mark>! The more you play and the longer it's under the moon, the larger your hair will swell.
mnemonics.reading: Using this method, your hair swells so much it looks like a giant bowling (ぼう) ball is sitting on top of your head. It's all round, and well... swollen is probably the only word that fits.

mnemonics.meaning: Your poor little <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> got a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">splinter</mark>, so make sure to give it extra nice <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">treatment</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Give your scooter only the best treatment, so it can feel real gooooood (ぐう).

mnemonics.meaning: If you try to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> something to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Death Star</mark>, it would only <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">admonish</mark> you. It was made to destroy planets, after all, so I don't know why you'd expect it to have anything nice to say. It just admonishes you about everything you've ever done wrong until you can't stop crying.
mnemonics.reading: Right now you're being admonished about living in a yurt (ゆ). The Death Star bellows, "What, am I too big and safe for you? I'm easy to move too, you know. You're a disgrace! You should be ashamed!"

mnemonics.meaning: How many <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark>s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">have</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark>s? <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">All</mark> of them!
mnemonics.reading: All of these scooters have a specific sound they make as they burst out of the buildings: zuwee (ずい).

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">old</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> (the moon we had before the current moon) was actually just a huge <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">barbarian</mark> floating in the sky.
mnemonics.reading: At least, this is the kind of story you told your 子 (こ) when they asked you where the moon came from.

mnemonics.meaning: In your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> which really <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">suit</mark> you. But you throw them to the people waving to you from below, as you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">board</mark> your ship. The flowers fall, unneeded. You're <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">embark</mark>ing on a new life, a new journey. There will be more flowers where you're going.
mnemonics.reading: You board a ship to とうきょう, bound for your new life, of course!

mnemonics.meaning: You weave <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark> patterns into this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark>, turning it into <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">brocade</mark>. It's beautiful, elegant, and worth way more than when it was just a plain towel.
mnemonics.reading: You want to keep your brocade fabrics safe, so you lock them away and seal them in with a niche key (にしき). It's niche because brocade is a very niche kind of thing.

mnemonics.meaning: If you're in Japan, the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fish</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">village</mark> are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">carp</mark>. You may know them as <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">koi</mark>, too.
mnemonics.reading: A carp is called a koi (こい) in Japanese. We've used that word before so I hope you know it by now. A koi is a koi, you know?

mnemonics.meaning: Take the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wrap</mark> it in a bag and it will look just like a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cell</mark>. It's a circle in a bigger circle. The moon is the nucleus. Yes! Science is happening!
mnemonics.reading: As you learn about cells you realize they're all over your home (ほう). Without ever noticing it, your home has been slowly filling with dead skin cells. And now that you know what they look like (the moon with a plastic wrap bag around it) you can see them everywhere.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">conflict</mark> will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cleanse</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">purify</mark> the lands of people, homes, and culture.
mnemonics.reading: Who could possibly stop this cleanse of all lands?! The only person capable of this is, of course, Joe (じょう), the local farmhand. He’s so tall and burly that he can stop even the largest of tsunamis… right?

mnemonics.meaning: There's a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bear</mark> on this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark>. A true <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">commander</mark> can notice little things like this.
mnemonics.reading: You watch the commander in all his glory... going back and forth on a swing (すい).

mnemonics.meaning: If you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> something the same way they say it in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">capital</mark>, everyone in the whole country will be able to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">comprehend</mark> what you're trying to say. If you try to speak in your hometown's dialect no one will. But everyone can comprehend what you want if you use the capital's dialect to say it.
mnemonics.reading: Now that the townspeople finally comprehend what you were trying to say, they sell you the row (りょう) boat you were trying to buy. You were using the wrong word, but りょう is what they needed to hear to understand you, and now you can row your way back home.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Flowers</mark> are growing out of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> and over your pet <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pig</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> and it's causing the poor thing to live in total <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">darkness</mark>. The flowers are hanging down over its eyes and won't let any light in at all. And some of the flowers seem to be growing directly out of the pig's forehead too. The pig has just been wandering and bumping into things all day because of it.
mnemonics.reading: To end the darkness you mow (もう) the flowers. You have to drive your lawnmower over its head too, because they're growing out of its forehead too. They'll grow back soon though and cover your pig's world in darkness once again and you'll have to do it all over again.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> is rising and there is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> covering <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">someone</mark>, who's being forced to watch as <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dawn</mark> appears. They've never seen dawn before, and they didn't want to, but you're making them.
mnemonics.reading: The someone who saw dawn for the first time goes on to become sumo wrestling champ Akebono Taro (あけぼの). He always gazes at the sunrise at dawn before he wrestles and it fills him with strength.

mnemonics.meaning: If you get a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hair</mark> stuck in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> it will be a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">disaster</mark>! Have you ever gotten a hair in your eye or your mouth that you just couldn't get out? You cough, your eyes water, it's awful! You can't focus on anything until it's gone. Now imagine if a big 'ol hair got stuck in your own private soul!!! Disaster!!!
mnemonics.reading: This disaster is so huge that even Santa-san (さん) left his vacation in Zanzibar (ざん) to come tell you you're on the naughty list for being such a disaster person. WHAT?! Even you Santa-san?

mnemonics.meaning: When what you're writing is as <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tall</mark> as the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark>s growing outside, you know you're done with your first <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">draft</mark>. Some teachers want papers to be a certain number of words or pages, but that's silly. You should measure your draft in grains!
mnemonics.reading: Who asked you to write such a tall draft in the first place? Emperor こういち, who wants you to draft up the world's largest book about how great of an emperor he is.

mnemonics.meaning: If you can find the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">door</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> shaped like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> it will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">enlighten</mark> you.
mnemonics.reading: The door enlightened you by opening up and revealing the cake (けい) in its door-mouth. "Cake is the key to enlightenment, my child. Now eat it from my mouth."

mnemonics.meaning: Press your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> in someone's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">skin</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">expose</mark> what's underneath. This is pretty gross, but sometimes it's more important that you expose the cause of the problem, than avoiding something uncomfortable.
mnemonics.reading: You expose a small hole under their skin and heat (ひ) comes pouring out. Aha! You knew there was something wrong under here. Apparently there's something under this person's skin that's exuding way too much heat.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark>es <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> across special <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spikes</mark> to separate the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fiber</mark>s. The best way to separate the fibers of thread is to get a drunkard to do it. If you're too precise it will just snap. You gotta be loose with it! Just flop them onto the spikes and the fibers will come apart by themselves!
mnemonics.reading: You stare at the fibers easily coming apart when you realize that this drunkard seems to have a few extra legs... and hair and a tail? This isn't just a drunk guy, it's a centaur (せん). Maybe separating fibers is really a centaur trick, and that's why normal people can't do it...

mnemonics.meaning: If you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark> around a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">surplus</mark> of anything, you need to be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gentle</mark> and touch everything <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gently</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You have to be gentle and handle these things gently because they belong to Jo-Anne (じょ). You're loitering around her surplus of (whatever you decided to imagine).

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Flowers</mark> that are thought to be little <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tent</mark>s sent from <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heaven</mark> are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hollyhock</mark>s. They're shaped almost like little teepees and would make the perfect tent for a faerie or a little yokai!
mnemonics.reading: Hollyhocks are mostly あおい (blue) because they copy the color of the heavens, where they came from.

mnemonics.meaning: While the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> is out, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gladiator</mark> is riding a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horse</mark>, yelling about <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">inflation</mark>. No one would listen to him during the day, so he waited for the moon to rise so he could complain about prices doing the same.
mnemonics.reading: Inflation rises the most in とうきょう, and the gladiator knows that because that's where most of them live and fight (and die).

mnemonics.meaning: You use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to take down the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">old</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">install</mark> a new one. Flags get old, just like computers and furniture and people. So when one gets too old, you have to get on up there and install a new one in its place.
mnemonics.reading: You've decided to install a suit (す) where the old flag used to be. I mean, a suit is probably more durable than a flag, am I right? This way you won't have to install flags as often.

mnemonics.meaning: You cut the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> off the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark> with your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark>. The flowers that fall off are <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">jasmine</mark> flowers.
mnemonics.reading: The jasmine is growing out of everything, not just grain! It's also growing out of the reeds (り)!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> that goes through <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Korea</mark> is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">latitude</mark> line splitting up North and South Korea.
mnemonics.reading: The only way you can see this latitude line is to ride an eagle (い) over it. The line isn't visible from a car, you're too close, and a plane is too high. You have to see it from an eagle's point of view.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">melon</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">melon</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Wahoo!
mnemonics.reading: What's the best use for a melon? Not eating it, but running over it in your car (か)! Melons make a nice big splat sound when you drive over them, and that's what you plan to do to every melon you see.

mnemonics.meaning: Whether you're a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tiger</mark> or <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark>, the anti-claw regime will want to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">oppress</mark> you. Too afraid of any potential violent rebellion, this oppressive regime is going to imprison and declaw every single clawed being.
mnemonics.reading: Tigers and other clawed beings like Wolverine are so oppressed, they're forced to cover their claws with Gak (ぎゃく). You know, that weird silly putty they made us play with as kids? Well, it's now an instrument of anti-Wolverine, anti-tiger oppression.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> carrying <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> wants you to go to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">together</mark> so you can <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">receive</mark> something from them.
mnemonics.reading: Against your better judgement, you decided to go and receive the thing. You close your eyes, hold out your hands, and feel a silky, light tie (たい) being placed in them.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boat</mark> owned by a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Yoga</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">King</mark> needs to be able to let him keep doing his exercises while he's on it. That's why his boat is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rowboat</mark>, so he can work on his yoga arms as he gets around.
mnemonics.reading: As he rows the rowboat with his butt, you see the Yoga King eating something with his toes. They're tater tots (てい). Tater tots are the perfect snack for a rowboat. They're small, delicious, and they float if you drop them in the water.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boat</mark>, but it's missing some pieces. That's because it's really rusty, so parts are falling off of it and it looks <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rust colored</mark>. In ancient Chinese literature, this rusty red color represented <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sincerity</mark>, and you'll often see this kanji take that meaning in jukugo words.
mnemonics.reading: The rust colored boat has inspired you, so you sit down next to it in the sun and tan (たん). You want to be the exact same rust color as the boat, and in a few hours you're sure you'll match.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark>s a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">criminal</mark> wears will always be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">scarlet</mark>. Scarlet is the color of freshly spilt blood, which is why bad guys wear it so much.
mnemonics.reading: This scarlet color holds a lot of heat (ひ). Scarlet is the color of fire, and it has the heat of fire too.

mnemonics.meaning: You want to have a quaint <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cottage</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wedding</mark>, so you have to go to the cottage wedding <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shop</mark> to get everything you need.
mnemonics.reading: You're browsing everything in the shop when a garden hoe (ほ) catches your eye. Yes. This will make your cottage wedding the absolute best one. The hoe will give you away at your wedding.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nurse</mark> is someone who nurses dirt. When nursed, dirt becomes <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">soil</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Soil is a thing that Joe (じょう), the huge farmhand, works on improving. If he makes the soil better, the farm will yield more crops.

mnemonics.meaning: When a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horse</mark> sees a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spider</mark> it will start running at a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">speed</mark> no one ever thought a horse could go! Horses are super afraid of spiders, you see, so if they see one, they'll bolt and reach top speed! That's actually the only way to get a horse to run that fast.
mnemonics.reading: Once people realize that they can increase the speed of their horses, soon (しゅん) everyone will be taking spiders with them to scare their horses into running faster. I say soon because it hasn't quite caught on yet. But if you help to spread the word it can happen even sooner.

mnemonics.meaning: There's so much <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> you need to use a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> to remove it. Only when there is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">surplus</mark> can you put that much grain in your mouth.
mnemonics.reading: The surplus is thanks to the hard work of folks like Joe (じょう), the big farmhand. He worked hard to make sure there was a surplus of grain this year.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">see</mark> everything. But, they only see. That is because they learned the art of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tolerance</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Tolerance is one thing that Genghis Khan (かん) had a surprising amount of.

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to wear a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">top hat</mark> you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">also</mark> have to wear a suit to go with it. You can't just wear a top hat, that just doesn't look right. When you think top hat, think about what you also need with it.
mnemonics.reading: You have a top hat and all the clothes that go with it but you also need a nice car (か) too! You can't just get all dressed up and then have no way to get anywhere to show it off.

mnemonics.meaning: When the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> comes up the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spikes</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark>s <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">appear</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You watch these spikes appear and suddenly Ken (けん)the samurai also appears next to you. "I DID IT!" he shouts, "I've learned how to appear out of thin air!"

mnemonics.meaning: What does a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> make that you'd want to put in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>? An <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">apricot</mark>! Apricots are also about the size of an open mouth, so they kind of look like mouths hanging down under the trees. You can bite them right off the tree with your own mouth!
mnemonics.reading: After you put the apricot in your mouth you realize that this tastes really familiar, but not pleasant. It tastes just like the anchovies (あん) from the zoo (ず) smell. How did that happen? You don't like apricots anymore.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Dry</mark> an already <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> to create a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bookmark</mark>. The more you dry the tree, the flatter it becomes, making it the perfect way to mark your spot in a book without needing to fold a page or write on it.
mnemonics.reading: What are you bookmarking anyway? Look down and see yourself putting one of the tree bookmarks on a page in your notebook that says "She owes me reeds (しおり)." Oh yeah, you had to make this bookmark in the first place because your friend took your reed bookmarks and didn't give them back.

mnemonics.meaning: You see a bunch of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>s lined up outside of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gate</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">east</mark> and realize they look like perfect <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">column</mark>s. It seems like a building or a castle should be resting above them.
mnemonics.reading: Out of the tree columns bursts professional wrestler Randy (らん) Savage! "Oooh I'm talking about columns that I like mmmm oh yeaah. The Macho Man loves columns MMm OOHH YEAAH~!"

mnemonics.meaning: Who goes into their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yurt</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark> things? The <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">common</mark> people! <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">All sorts</mark> of people do it, it's really common. You don't boil things outside, do you?
mnemonics.reading: Here, the common people all do this, so just let me show (しょ) you how. First you go into your yurt, and… Hey, pay attention and watch what I'm showing you!

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">origin</mark> for the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark> for your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">crown</mark>! If you measure somewhere else on your head for a crown it won't fit.
mnemonics.reading: You want your crown to be just like Genghis Khan's (かん), which was more of a cap. He's your hero though, because he ruled over the most people, so you want yours to match his measurements.

mnemonics.meaning: If you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">announce</mark> that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark> is illegal you're just being <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cruel</mark>.
