Honestly, saying no one can have any alcohol at all is totally <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">unjust</mark>. They tried that in the 1920s and it didn't work then either, so cut it out! Let people drink what they want to drink!
mnemonics.reading: After this cruel announcement is made everyone will turn to the next best thing after alcohol. Coke (こく)! It's not a replacement, but if this unjust law won't change, then coke sales are going to go through the roof.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">surplus</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>, please <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">describe</mark> it.
mnemonics.reading: You describe the features of the stool to Jo-Anne (じょ).

mnemonics.meaning: Jump on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">excuse</mark> yourself from answering a question and you've successfully <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">deviate</mark>d from that nosey person's plan! You've also been able to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">elude</mark> them pretty well.
mnemonics.reading: You deviate from the plan a little too well, and as you're scooting, what you've done eats (いつ) away at you. You feel guilty for eluding them...

mnemonics.meaning: You use <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">writing</mark> to sew our <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">family crest</mark>. You've been sewing your family crest since you were a kid, you could do it today with your eyes closed.
mnemonics.reading: Your family crest is of a monster! (もん) And the writing says "Our Family Monster."

mnemonics.meaning: You see a building with a lip ring and it's just so cute you have to flatter it. "That lip ring looks wonderful on you, Buildingさん," you say.
mnemonics.reading: The building is flattered and you hear it shout, "Ah (あ)!" and blush. The entire building turns red.

mnemonics.meaning: If you give <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Splinter</mark> your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> you'll feel pretty <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">foolish</mark> afterwards. His heart belongs to the art of ninjutsu!
mnemonics.reading: Splinter tells you to your face how foolish you are and you feel your heart turn to goo (ぐ). Now you can't even give it to someone else. No one wants goo.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">triceratops</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mustache</mark> will go on talking forever. Every time you think he's done he says, "<mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Furthermore</mark>..." and keeps going. Something about a mustache on a dinosaur makes him kind of a jerk, but he's held in such high <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">esteem</mark> that no one ever interrupts him.
mnemonics.reading: Why don't you just interrupt this mustache triceratops while he's saying furthermore? Because he's the Shougun's (しょう) pet. If you interrupt him you'll probably be put to death or something. Just let him keep going and hope he runs out of furthermores to talk about.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark> is threatening to cut off your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> because they've <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">kidnap</mark>ped you! You can't see anything about them, since they're all covered up. All you see is their angry mouth and the sword they keep putting near your fingers.
mnemonics.reading: You've been kidnapped and your kidnapper has asked for one thing in exchange for your safe return: a kayak (かい). Kayaks are expensive. And it's way easier for this dude to kidnap you and demand your family buy one and give it to them than for them to work for one.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> who usually hits you with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stick</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> finds it in his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> to give you some <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">leisure</mark> time.
mnemonics.reading: You're just about to start your leisure time when a group of youths (ゆう) appears with their own sticks. You look back for the leader, and he's wearing a bathrobe, sunglasses, and is drinking some hot cocoa. Wait... this is leisure time for... HIM?! OH NO!

mnemonics.meaning: You're in a really important position, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heavy</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark>, but you can't carry all of that around with you, so you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark> it all down to just a few <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">merit</mark>s.
mnemonics.reading: The only problem with consolidating your merits like this is that raccoons (くん) are always trying to steal them. Raccoons really like shiny, small things. Like, say, the physical representation of all your personal and professional merits.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">coat rack</mark> will turn into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bundle</mark> of sticks if you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">neglect</mark> it. When you neglect a coat rack, the weight from the coats will pull all of the arms off, leaving it as a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sparse</mark> stick.
mnemonics.reading: You go up to the neglected coat rack and try to make things right by cleaning it with soap (そ). But no matter how much you scrub, it won't get clean, the arms won't go back on.

mnemonics.meaning: Whatever you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> through a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">satellite</mark> turns into <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Noh chanting</mark>. It gets all drawn out and distorted from going through the satellite, which makes it SOUND like Noh chanting at least.
mnemonics.reading: While you're fake Noh chanting you have to pause every few minutes to take a bite of yogurt (よう). Yogurt is good for the throat! At least you think it is. It's not like you're actually chanting, the satellite is doing all the real work.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> gets his hands on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">plow</mark> and starts <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">planting</mark> right away. Drunk people are surprisingly good at planting, especially when they have machines to help them do it.
mnemonics.reading: He keeps planting and planting... a little too much. You walk over and realize this drunkard isn't just any guy... he's YOUR CYBORG (さい)!

mnemonics.meaning: Whenever you set <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">foot</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bar</mark>, there's always something new to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">practice</mark>. If you usually drink a lot, you might want to practice moderation for example. Or perhaps you simply want to brush up on your social skills. Either way, plenty of opportunities for practice.
mnemonics.reading: This type of practice is especially hard for you because you're a centaur (せん). You only have hooves for feet, and balancing on a bar is going to be a huge hurdle. But your teacher promised if you practiced enough you could make it, and here you are! With your hoofed foot on the bar!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Mouth</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">King</mark>, who is just one big mouth, has one skill, and that is to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">present</mark>. That big mouth is always presenting something.
mnemonics.reading: "I will present to you a presentation about mouths, but I require energy. Please fill my giant mouth body with delicious tater (てい) tots.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> managed to find the right <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> home using marks in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> in the middle of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark>. This makes you so <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">proud</mark>! You're proud because this resourceful leader is YOUR resourceful leader.
mnemonics.reading: This leader you're so proud of is none other than Grandpa ごういち. He's been getting a bit slow over the years, and you really didn't think he'd make it back. But, by gum, he did it.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sick</mark>ness that hits you like an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark> will do its gross work <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rapidly</mark>. It's not a good thing, you're gonna get really sick really fast.
mnemonics.reading: This rapid sickness makes your head pound like there's a shih tzu (しつ) yapping and barking nonstop. And it's making you sh*t a lot.

mnemonics.meaning: You took someone's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark>'d it all into the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">river</mark>. Now you have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">repay</mark> them. Alcohol costs a lot of money, you know.
mnemonics.reading: In order to repay them for the alcohol you wasted, you offer to give them your shoes (しゅう). They don't want your shoes though, so you have to bring them to a store and watch them try on a bunch of different pairs so you can repay them that way.

mnemonics.meaning: What kind of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> grow in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">west</mark>? <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Rose madder</mark> flowers, of course. Don't know what those are? That's okay. Just know their roots are used to make dyes of a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">deep red</mark> color. Red like the rose in their name, but madder, wilder, deeper… And they grow in the west so they can take in those deep red colors of the setting sun.
mnemonics.reading: As you smash the roots of the rose madder and stain your fingers a deep red, a little girl comes up to you and points. She says, "赤ね (あかね)?" (That's red, right?) You look down at the rose madder roots and your fingers, and nod. She's right, it is red. Deep red.

mnemonics.meaning: You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> coming out of the top of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> so you go into <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shock</mark>. Your brain just can't comprehend what's in front of you.
mnemonics.reading: The shock you've suffered results in you needing to stay home (ほう) from now on. You don't get to travel, explore, or even get groceries. You're homebound from now on, buddy.

mnemonics.meaning: You cast the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Mona Lisa</mark> in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> and attach it to a stick to turn it into a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sickle</mark>! It's really big and bulky, but when you swing it fast enough your new sickle cuts lots of wheat! Just don't tell anyone what you did with the famous Mona Lisa painting and you should be able to get away with this!
mnemonics.reading: Now that you've turned the Mona Lisa into a sickle, you have to change the little description under its name in the Louvre. You draw a giant comma (かま) next to "Mona Lisa" and write "THE SICKLE." Then you shove it back on the wall as best you can.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Wolverine</mark> puts a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stick</mark> between his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">legs</mark> and straight into some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark>, all while wearing a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">solemn</mark> expression on his face. He's probably remembering his dad who died from getting his legs stuck in rice. Just leave the poor solemn creature alone.
mnemonics.reading: When you first saw how solemn Wolverine was after his dad died, it really shook (しゅく) you. Now you're used to always seeing him emotionally cold and distant. It might be time to shake that solemnity out of him though.

mnemonics.meaning: When you leave <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tombstone</mark> they look good at first, but after a few days or some harsh weather, there's nothing left but <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stem</mark>s. That's why you have to replace flowers on tombstones all the time. If you don't it will look like you only left the stems there, and that's pretty disrespectful.
mnemonics.reading: You have an idea that can make these tombstones look better than just having leftover stems all over them. You brought cookies (くき)! Cookies don't fall apart in the wind, and everyone loves cookies, alive or dead. You replace the stems with the cookies and everything looks a lot nicer.

mnemonics.meaning: You're <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sick</mark> because you put an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> and tried to eat it. To be honest, that's just really <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stupid</mark>. You have to be stupid to try to eat an arrow. You deserve to be sick.
mnemonics.reading: The only way to cure this serious case of stupid is to make you eat cheese (ち). Not only will it fix your sick stomach by cushioning all the arrows that you shoved in your stupid mouth, but it should send smart cheese waves to your brain and cure you of that stupid all together.

mnemonics.meaning: After your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wedding</mark> you have a baby and it uses its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">suckle</mark> from your post-wedding boobs. Yes, babies <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">nurse</mark> from breasts. Get over it, kids.
mnemonics.reading: The baby wants to nurse all day and the only thing you can seem to do at the same time is hoe (ほ) your garden. You hold the baby to your breast with one arm and hoe little rows with the other. It's actually a great workout and a nice way to spend time!

mnemonics.meaning: Clearing his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">icicle</mark>s, the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">samurai</mark> returns home to his <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">villa</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Once the samurai enters the villa, he lets his soul (そう) go. He's been fighting for long enough and this villa was always where he wanted to go.

mnemonics.meaning: If you travel to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fish</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">capital</mark>, you'll find the leader of all fish, the mighty <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">whale</mark>! Okay, so a whale isn't technically a fish, but that's why it makes such a good leader. You can usually only find whales hanging around near the capital because they really enjoy ruling over all the other fish. They are the biggest, after all.
mnemonics.reading: The whale who resides over the capital just happens to be gay (げい). You only know this because his husband is a man whale too. Actually, now that you think about it, all the whales you've ever met have been gay.

mnemonics.meaning: At <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">noon</mark> you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stop</mark> to buy <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stamp</mark>s because that's the only time they're being sold at <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wholesale</mark> price. Everyone's so busy eating and working and being at school, that they miss this awesome deal, but not you. Everyday at noon you stock up on wholesale stamps. Do you send a lot of mail? No, you probably just collect them. But they were cheap, so who cares!
mnemonics.reading: Oh, one more thing. Going at noon isn't enough, you have to say the password to get them at wholesale price too. The password is "Oh Roshi" (おろし). Okay, so maybe that's just the name of the guy there, but it always works when I want to get stamps wholesale so you should do it too!

mnemonics.meaning: You start growing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">accumulate</mark> more. You didn't want to have to buy any, so you're just trying to grow thread with your rice. That seems like a good way to accumulate more to you.
mnemonics.reading: Sadly, this is a terrible way to accumulate anything thread related and you ended up ruining (るい) your rice paddy too. I guess if you want to accumulate thread this isn't the way to do it.

mnemonics.meaning: When you meet the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dog</mark> you have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bow</mark> to show your respect. Dogs are pretty great, so the leader of all dogs must be the greatest! You should bow really deeply to this one.
mnemonics.reading: You bow as low as you can, but you lose your balance and fall over. "F**k you (ふく)!" the leader dog barks. Oh no. You messed up and now the leader dog is super mad. Saying f**k you is a little harsh for falling over though, you think.

mnemonics.meaning: When a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tiger</mark> meets a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">man</mark>, it becomes the man's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">captive</mark>. Men can be pretty mean like that. They see a tiger and they want to put it in a cage, so the poor tiger becomes the man's captive.
mnemonics.reading: The man takes his new tiger captive to Rio (りょ). Why Rio de Janeiro? Turns out you're allowed to keep tigers captive down in Rio.

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">loiter</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark> with the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pope</mark> you better be ready to move in perfect <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">circulation</mark> with him. The pope is wearing really heavy robes and it's hot up here on this cliff, so you both need to walk in circles to keep cool.
mnemonics.reading: This circulation wouldn't have to even be happening if it wasn't June (じゅん). The cliffs are so hot in June, and in any other month the two of you would have just sat down and had a chat. But in June you have to do this weird circulation dance.

mnemonics.meaning: If you find some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">top hat</mark> it's going to be really <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">coarse</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rough</mark>. Probably because it's not the kind that's meant to be eaten.
mnemonics.reading: You take the coarse rice and try to wash it with soap (そ).

mnemonics.meaning: If you try to turn something into <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ice</mark> while having <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">doubt</mark>s, it will just <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">congeal</mark> instead. It will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">freeze</mark>, but it will get kinda yucky too. Your doubts will affect the ice-making process, so try not to be so worried and unsure next time you want normal ice.
mnemonics.reading: You always end up congealing your gyoza (ぎょう) this way. You want to freeze your leftover gyoza so you can enjoy it later, but you doubt it will turn out all right and it always congeals in a gross, half-frozen gyoza block. Yuck!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hat</mark> that's made from a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> but the more you look at it, the more it looks like it's just a big <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cork</mark>. It's a big, wooden <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">plug</mark> that he's just placed on his head. It can hardly be called a hat.
mnemonics.reading: It turned out this cork hat was given to him by a centaur (せん). You look into it and it turned out it IS a really big cork that centaurs use on their big wine casks. But the king didn't understand, and thought it was a hat. The centaurs are probably still laughing.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">center</mark> (of England, if you remember) has a special <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">crystal</mark>. The king crystal.
mnemonics.reading: The king thinks everyone wants his crystal so he hides it in the giant acorn (えい) in the center of the flowers in England. There's a tiny hole in the bottom of the acorn, and that's where this crystal stays hidden.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dawn</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dawn</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: Dawn is dawn (だん)! It's also a great time to get a tan (たん). The sun is bright at dawn, but not so much that it will send skin cancer rays into you.

mnemonics.meaning: When <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spring</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark> you need to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dedicate</mark> your time and effort somewhere else. You can't plant flowers or vegetables, it's too dry. You can't play outside, your skin will flake. So you need to dedicate yourself to something inside.
mnemonics.reading: You decide to dedicate yourself to your home (ほう). You don't want to be outside in the dry spring air, so you focus on home activities. You can clean the kitchen, build a shelf, or dedicate your time to your home internet system.

mnemonics.meaning: You got off your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> to load some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">charcoal</mark> onto it, when it suddenly took off to a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">distant</mark> place! That's some powerful charcoal.
mnemonics.reading: You chase the scooter to that distant place, but then you see it heading for a lake. Oh good, it should be stopped by the water. But wait! In the distance you see your scooter drive onto a row (りょう) boat and... row itself through the water?! No!!

mnemonics.meaning: You just <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">receive</mark>d a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark>, so you want to surround it with an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">enclosure</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The enclosure felt a bit quiet and lonely, so you decided to get yourself a pet cock (かく).

mnemonics.meaning: Put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jet</mark> if you want to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">erase</mark> them from existence. You aren't just chopping or burning them off. There's like, no trace of them at all. Your parents can't even remember if you were born with fingers or not. Jets are that powerful.
mnemonics.reading: You're almost done erasing your fingers when the jet starts sucking all of you in. You would try to grab the closest thing to you, but your fingers don't exist anymore, so you hold onto the mats (まつ) at your feet with your toes. The mats are super strong (they're made for jets, after all) and you manage to save yourself!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> gets double the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> to build on if he's the most <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">excellent</mark> and most <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">skilled</mark> of all the leaders. You don't think dirt is so great? Well what if I took the dirt you own away from you? Your house is on that dirt. It's mine now. Get outta here.
mnemonics.reading: This excellent leader is going to use all this dirt to store her excellent cars (か)! Excellent people have to have cars in equal or greater than excellent-ness than themselves.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">long ago</mark> was very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">frugal</mark>, which is why you get to have too much in this life!
mnemonics.reading: You know what being frugal is? Sexy (せき). You save money, you use less resources, that's the sexiest thing I can think of.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hundred</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark>s lower themselves to their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>s in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">grief</mark>. There were once many of their kind, the forehead peoples, but now there are only a hundred left after this harsh winter took the rest of them. Their grief is immense.
mnemonics.reading: Their grief intensifies because all of the foreheads they lost belonged to youths (ゆう). Dead youths everywhere. Now there's no one left to repopulate the world.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">toe</mark> leaves <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">early</mark>. You <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">grieve</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mourn</mark> for your now-dead toe.
mnemonics.reading: You decide to grieve in とうきょう. Your toe always wanted to walk in とうきょう, and now you can at least fulfill its dying wish.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sick</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Death Star</mark> needs its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cure</mark>d. If it doesn't get <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">healing</mark> soon, it will die.
mnemonics.reading: You realized that the only way to cure the Death Star is to turn it back into a yurt (ゆ). Then it won't be able to do any more harm, and its outside will reflect its pleasant self on the inside!

mnemonics.meaning: You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> growing on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cliff</mark> and it has <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ten thousand</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">horse chestnut</mark>s growing on it. These trees are rare, only grow on cliffs, and they always have exactly ten thousand horse chestnuts on each one.
mnemonics.reading: You decide to take a bite of a horse chestnut because it looks yummy, and there are ten thousand, so it's not like anyone will notice. You crack it open and take a nice big bite to find out that it tastes like toe cheese (とち)! UHG! It's the worst thing you've ever tasted. Like hot, moldy toe cheese! Ewwww!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">imperial</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">imperial</mark> kanji are exactly the same! Wahoo!
mnemonics.reading: Who is the coolest imperial you know? Ryu (りゅう) from Street Fighter. Wait what? You mean he FIGHTS imperials? Oh, okay. Looks like Ryu is the coolest imperial FIGHTER you know!

mnemonics.meaning: Go from a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bow</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">small</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark> and you're <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">increasing</mark> in fire power! Even though the gun is small, it's still a step up from a bow.
mnemonics.reading: You keep trading in weapons to get increasingly stronger gear, when you realize that at the top of the list is... a Yankee's (や) baseball bat? Huh. I would have gone for a tank or a bazooka. But I guess if this will increase your power level, you have to go for it.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bone</mark>s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">have</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> that moves through the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bone marrow</mark> inside them.
mnemonics.reading: If you put your ear really close to a bone with marrow still in it, you'll hear the scooters going zuwee (ずい) as they move the blood around inside there.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wing</mark> is something you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">must not</mark> do anything with. Wings are fragile (think bird's wings and butterfly's wings) and sometimes dangerous (like the wings of a plane) and you must not touch them, or even go near them! You MUST NOT. You. MUST. NOT.
mnemonics.reading: Apart from staying away from wings, the other thing you must not do is eat mochi (もち). Okay, they're not fragile or dangerous, but I love mochi and I don't want you eating them.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stand</mark>ing funny, facing a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">nearby</mark>. He can't go far because there's obviously something wrong with his feet. He's stuck nearby, very close to your side.
mnemonics.reading: You decide to bring the leader to a nearby bowling (ぼう) alley. It's really close and you can stay right by his side as he throws bowling balls and gets his anger out.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Death Star</mark> is actually quite <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pleasant</mark>. And if you think about it, it's the people who control the Death Star that are evil and kill.
mnemonics.reading: The pleasant soul within the Death Star actually looks like a yurt (ゆ), not a big angry, metal ball.

mnemonics.meaning: You need to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">run</mark> on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">toe</mark>s if you want to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">proceed</mark> down this road. If you can't run on your toes, well then you're out of luck, and you won't be able to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">move on</mark> at all. I didn't make this rule, I just enforce it. Now run!
mnemonics.reading: If you find that you can't proceed, you're a fool (ふ). Everyone can run on their toes. Don't you know that? No? Then you're an even bigger fool, now get outta here!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> is the reason why crops grow and people can get out of bed in the morning. But on planets with two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>s, they can get even more done and it makes them way more <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">prosperous</mark> than us. They work all day, then as the first sun sets, the second one rises and they get a new burst of energy. The whole planet lives in a state of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">prosperity</mark> because of the two suns.
mnemonics.reading: The person on this planet with two suns who benefits from the prosperity the most is the Shougun (しょう). Yes, this planet still has a shougun as their leader, but everything is going so well that they didn't see a need to change. The shogun will be in charge of this prosperous world forever. No one ever thinks of revolt when everyone has everything they could ever need.

mnemonics.meaning: The only <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">feeling</mark> a dead <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> will have is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">remorse</mark>. Remorse for the people it left behind. <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Regret</mark>s for the things it did and didn't do.
mnemonics.reading: The soul with the most regrets is Genghis Khan (かん). Everyone knows to stay away from him in the spirit world because he's so sad. Not because of his own actions, but because of the state of his people now.

mnemonics.meaning: You decide to carve a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> into a giant replica of your big <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">toe</mark> because you think it will be really <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">simple</mark>. Once you're done though, it looks like a really <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">crude</mark> attempt at a fat, lumpy blob. Maybe carving isn't as simple as you thought.
mnemonics.reading: You're admiring your simple looking toe tree when a lumberjack runs up and asks who created it. ぼく, you say. As in "I" said it, in a manly dude, way. He doesn't seem to believe you, so you say it a few more times. ぼく ぼく ぼく!

mnemonics.meaning: If you put <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">two</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">two</mark> pound weights on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">person</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> they'll increase in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">stature</mark> when they come back down. Everything is lighter on the moon so the person won't even feel the weights. Then when they come back to earth they'll have grown a whole two inches taller!
mnemonics.reading: Getting a taller stature will also make you seem super sexy (せき) on the moon and back home on earth. If you stay on the moon long enough, you'll be the tallest person in the galaxy and who wouldn't find that sexy?! Huh?

mnemonics.meaning: You want to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slice</mark> what you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> in half so that people focus on <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">the above</mark> text first. The above is what you want them to see! So slice what you say!
mnemonics.reading: As you focus on the above words you realize a guy (がい) is trying to push the rest of the things you're saying back up with the rest of them. No! The above text is all that matters! Go away guy!

mnemonics.meaning: How do you make a mnemonic for the word this? You don’t. But, we can try. You climb many <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hills</mark>. On top of one of the hills is a little <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of water. You pick it up and say “<mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">THIS</mark>… THIS IS WHAT I WAS LOOKING FOR!”
mnemonics.reading: You collect(これ) this very carefully. You’re going to add this to your drop collection.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">reality</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> is that it has the power to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tranquilize</mark> anyone who gets their hands on it. Gold may seem cool to have in movies and songs, but in reality, it has the power to mess you up!
mnemonics.reading: You've been tranquilized and now drool is running down your chin (ちん). It's actually really gross. But you don't care, look at all this gold! No one will care about your chin when you're rich!

mnemonics.meaning: When you go to the pool or lake to swim, you'll see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> stuck somewhere in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark>. That flag is there so you know it's okay to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pee</mark> in that area of the pool. Everyone knows <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">urine</mark> dilutes in water, and if everyone just pees in one place, it won't be gross. So go pee over by that flag when you have to go. Don't bother getting out of the water.
mnemonics.reading: Right as you start to pee, you hear the life guard start to yell, "NYOOOOOO! (にょう)" and he's pointing at you! You were just peeing by the pee flag! Why is he mad?

mnemonics.meaning: Between the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> and the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> there are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">few</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark>. This is because we invited some <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">VIP</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">guest</mark>s into our home and they ate all our shellfish.
mnemonics.reading: These VIP guests are part of a Hindu (ひん) envoy.

mnemonics.meaning: You're holding a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark> in front of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">two</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark>s. <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">What</mark> will you do?
mnemonics.reading: A. What is, stab the building on the left? You stab the building on the left with your sword and what comes out is... a plate of delicious nachos (な)!

mnemonics.meaning: There is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cage</mark> with an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark> in it above your house to show that you are an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">artisan</mark>. All of the artisans have to have this special sign somewhere near where they live to show they make things.
mnemonics.reading: Artisans have to be marked this way because the Shougun (しょう) says so. The Shougun doesn't want to have to put any effort into finding people to make things for him, so he created this new system.

mnemonics.meaning: You're tapping your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> against a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark> wall when you realize the sound you're making is actually a sick <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">beat</mark>. You keep going and start singing along. Boo boo boop. Boo do do do doop! Finger beats!
mnemonics.reading: This beat is sick, but as you tap you realize you're hacking (はく) up the wall! Slowly but surely, your fingers are hacking out little bits of the wall. And the beats don't sound as good until you move to a new, clean white area.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">specialty</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark>ping people with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> by <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bind</mark>ing them! You can drop anyone as long as you have enough thread to restrain them. It doesn't matter how much they fight, you'll get them to drop!
mnemonics.reading: If you're going to be a weirdo who likes to bind people, at least make sure that they land on their backs (ばく) when they DO drop. Landing on your head or your boobs really hurts. So please at least try to make them land on their backs!

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eat</mark> and then <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wrap</mark> yourself into a ball because you're <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bored</mark>. You're also <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sated</mark>, because you ate just the right amount, but now you have nothing to do and it's soooo booooring.
mnemonics.reading: So now you're bored and stuck at home (ほう). You aren't hungry. There's nothing on TV. And you don't want to have to leave your home to do something, even though that would probably solve your boredom problem.

mnemonics.meaning: If you could <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stop</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark>ing water onto that <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> we could use it for <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">brushwood</mark>. But if you don't stop, then it will be too wet to burn at all! Stop already!
mnemonics.reading: You finally set the brushwood on fire and suddenly a Shiba (しば) Inu jumps out of the flames. So that's why they named this wood after them or... or vice versa?

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark> that is amongst all the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">world</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark>s is the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">butterfly</mark>. They are always hanging around trees, those butterflies.
mnemonics.reading: As you look at a butterfly, fluttering around a tree, a hand reaches out from the tree and grabs it, then starts plucking the wings off. An evil laugh comes from inside the tree, and you know it's Mrs. Chou (ちょう).

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bow</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mysterious</mark> because it's strung with a single <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chord</mark>. I guess that makes the chord both a musical instrument <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">string</mark> as well as a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bowstring</mark>. Pluck the chord and it shoots an arrow while making a perfect G note. So mysterious!
mnemonics.reading: Turns out this bow strung with a mysterious chord belongs to Genji (げん). Of course! Only someone as elegant and dramatic as Genji would own a bow that plays music when you pluck its string.

mnemonics.meaning: You're trying to open the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> of a manhole that's covered in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ice</mark> by <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark>ing it a bunch of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">times</mark> but it's not working because it's just too <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cold</mark>. It's so cold that your jackhammer is starting to ice up too. But you need to get this lid open so you try time after time after time!
mnemonics.reading: Each time the jackhammer hits the freezing cold ice it makes a high pitched ringing (りん) sound. It's actually really annoying to listen to but you really need to crack this ice open so you have to keep listening to it.

mnemonics.meaning: Under this canopy you have a brush (in its 肀 form) and a task to complete with it. This is totally commonplace.
mnemonics.reading: This is so commonplace and familiar to you that you finish your task early and eat some yogurt (よう) while you wait for the guy to come back.

mnemonics.meaning: This was pure <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">long ago</mark>, but now it's not. Someone got <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">confused</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mixed</mark> it with something else.
mnemonics.reading: It's mixed (and not pure anymore) because the confused person put it in that sack (さく) filled with various other things.

mnemonics.meaning: When you drive a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark>, everyone under your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> is putting their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">life</mark> in your hands, even if they don't say it with their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>—it's still under your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">control</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You have to maintain control of your car or you'll hit a bunch of cats (かつ). The roads are full of cats at all times. And if you lose control of your car for just a second, you'll hit at least two or three cats.

mnemonics.meaning: If you can <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">guard</mark> your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> from bad things you'll always feel <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">delight</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">joy</mark>. It's hard to guard your soul from everything though, so take all the joy you can, while you can.
mnemonics.reading: The delight you feel is so great that it becomes permanently etched (えつ) in your soul and even your face.

mnemonics.meaning: Put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hole</mark> in someone's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">body</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bow</mark> and they'll become <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">destitute</mark>. You put a hole in them. They can't work. They can't take care of their house or their kids. They've lost it all.
mnemonics.reading: You see this destitute person and decide to give them a cucumber (きゅう). They don't even remember that they're supposed to eat those, so they shove it in the hole you made with your bow.

mnemonics.meaning: If when you speak it sounds like the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drum</mark> is coming out of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark>, then people will hold you in high <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">esteem</mark>. Anyone who has a loud, booming, powerful voice will be held in high esteem in this day and age. Look at all those awesome musicians who have booming voices!
mnemonics.reading: You hold them in such high esteem that you give them your car (か). I ... I said you give them your car! Give them your car. Hey, hey!

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Twenty</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">penguin</mark>s together are always <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">evil</mark>. Penguins are seen in groups a lot, sure, but did you know that any time there are exactly twenty penguins in a group they're plotting evil things? Evil things like global warming. And how to eat all the fish in the world so humans can't have any.
mnemonics.reading: The evil penguins can't let you tell the other human's what you've seen, so they murder you and hide your body in a haystack (へい). Your family will never know what happened to you. The penguins will get away with their evil plans.

mnemonics.meaning: There is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> that is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">satellite</mark>, but it is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">far off</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">far away</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The scooter satellite is far off, but you can still hear it's horn go "har (はる) har har."

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">together</mark> with another tsunami is going to cause a massive <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">flood</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: After the terrible flood, Emperor こういち comes to survey the destruction and offer hope to his people. But, instead he just tells the people that this flood happened because they didn't believe in the Crabigator's words, and because they weren't doing their kanji reviews.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark>s are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">humble</mark> and that makes you a perfect <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gentleman</mark>. You don't have to have fancy clothes to be a gentleman, just humble ones that don't stand out and show off too much. That shows how polite you are.
mnemonics.reading: Unfortunately, as a gentleman who dresses humbly, you're always getting kicked in the shins (しん) by rude kids (and occasionally rude adults).

mnemonics.meaning: You've learned that you can <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">catapult</mark> things to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">give</mark> them to other people! Don't catapult rocks at buildings and walls, catapult gifts to the people you love.
mnemonics.reading: Give food to your new friend Godzilla (ご) with the catapult! You and Godzilla understand each other now. He's just hungry.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">samurai</mark> hits the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark>s of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark>s with his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark> so the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">grain</mark>s will pop off and into his mouth. He doesn't want to kill the plants, so he's just skimming the grain's foreheads so they'll fall off and he can eat them.
mnemonics.reading: Phew, all of this grain is making the samurai thirsty, so he reaches in his bag and pulls out an ice cold, refreshing Coke (こく).

mnemonics.meaning: Put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ear</mark>s when there's an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">explosion</mark> <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">in addition</mark> to all the other things you were told to do. You have to crouch under a desk, you have to stay away from windows, you have to close your eyes. But in addition to that, you need to protect your ears!
mnemonics.reading: In addition to all the steps you have to take to protect yourself, you can't forget that ears come in sets (せつ). You can't just stick one finger in one ear and have that be the end. You have a set of ears to worry about!

mnemonics.meaning: On the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">above</mark>, is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">small</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark>. Anyone who sits in that stool will be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lonely</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You're so lonely, you make up an imaginary friend: Jack (じゃく). Jack doesn't get rid of the lonely feeling because he isn't real, but he is a distraction at least.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spicy</mark> because you're the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">manager</mark>. You're always testing new recipes in your house to share with everyone who works under you, but that makes all the spice stick to your roof (since it doesn't have good ventilation like a restaurant or a lab would).
mnemonics.reading: You've finally done it. You're now the manager of a bunch of spicy new cyborgs (さい). You've been toiling away for over a year, but you've finally replaced the cyborg you lost, and now you can manage them properly without anyone getting in the way.

mnemonics.meaning: The only <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> you'll get <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">frostbite</mark> in is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mausoleum</mark>. Mausoleums and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tomb</mark>s weren't made for living people, so they aren't insulated from the cold. No one cares if a dead body gets frostbite.
mnemonics.reading: You need to escape this mausoleum now but the only way out is on a row (りょう) boat over a creepy frozen pond. You've heard of these mausoleum row boats before, and you're pretty sure they're cursed.

mnemonics.meaning: You go to buy a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">table</mark> but it looks like it has water damage from <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark>s of water hitting it. This makes it a pretty <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mediocre</mark> table. The water drops haven't really damaged it that much, it still stands and you can use it, but it's kinda ugly, so it's just mediocre.
mnemonics.reading: You weren't expecting to see such a mediocre table so you go up to the guy who's selling it and say, "Hey, I have a bone (ぼん) to pick with you!" But he doesn't think there is a bone to pick at all, he doesn't think the table is mediocre like you do.

mnemonics.meaning: Who loves their <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark>, using <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark>s, and precise <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark>s? Your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">military officer</mark>! He's always saluting the flag, jackhammering near all the new recruits to test them, and checking the measurement between the floor and their pants. Who else could it be?
mnemonics.reading: That military officer's favorite bird is an eagle (い)! That should be obvious because the eagle is the bird of America! And that's the country he fights for!

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Stand</mark> staring up at the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">blue</mark> sky and you'll feel more <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">peaceful</mark> than you ever have. Blue is a color that promotes peaceful thoughts and feelings. That's why all the social media sites are blue. To stop you from being a jerk.
mnemonics.reading: Now if someone asks you if the color blue makes you peaceful you should say "YAASS (やす)!" And you'll have us to thank for that! All those peaceful blue radicals. They're the easiest thing on the site, and if someone asks you if radicals make you feel peaceful say "YAASS" again!

mnemonics.meaning: When <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">small</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark>s of water work <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">together</mark> they gain <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">respect</mark> for one another. If you end up working with someone long enough, and they end up being really great, you'll respect them too!
mnemonics.reading: If you respect someone enough you'll even take up their hobbies. The person you respect most loves the Yankees. You don't really feel the same, but you respect that about them so you chant, "Ooh Yankees, Ooh Yankees!" (うやうや) with them during each game.

mnemonics.meaning: You take some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark>, put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> up to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">signpost</mark>, and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sew</mark> them together. You don't have a lock, so sewing your scooter up to the signpost to keep it safe is all you can think of.
mnemonics.reading: You usually only sew at home (ほう), so this is a big exception for you. You're usually worried that if you sew in public people will judge your stitches, so this is a big step for you!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boat</mark> that's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">white</mark> isn't just a boat, it's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ship</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: A white-painted ship is a kind of hack (はく). It makes the ship more visible without costing much.

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to fit your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">key</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hole</mark>, you have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">squeeze</mark> them in. Fingers aren't exactly supposed to fit in key holes... they're for keys, after all. But you want to squeeze your finger on in there anyway to unlock the door.
mnemonics.reading: Once you've squeezed your finger in the key hole to unlock this door you squeeze all the money and jewels and treasures you can fit into your sack (さく). Your stealing sack.

mnemonics.meaning: An <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">animal</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horns</mark> is drinking our <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark>? <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Still</mark>?
mnemonics.reading: The animal with horns that is still drinking your alcohol is no animal at all. It is actually one of the local youths (ゆう) dressed up like a horned animal so they can drink as long as they want and you'll be too scared to shoo them away.

mnemonics.meaning: Take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mole</mark> out of its <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hole</mark> and it will <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">suffocate</mark>. They need to be in tight quarters, unlike us humans. So when you take one out of its nice, safe hole, it thinks it can't breathe and suffocates.
mnemonics.reading: As the mole suffocates it cheats (ちつ) and shoves its head into your closed hand. You realize what it's doing and squeeze your hand tighter so it's more like a hole. You can feel the mole breathing again now.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark>s from the sky into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> and then a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark>s on top of it. They've combined to form a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tombstone</mark>! Wait, does that mean a body fell from the sky first and you just didn't see it?
mnemonics.reading: Now you're curious about what's under there but when you try to touch the tombstone it's radiating with intense heat (ひ)! It must have come from outer space and this heat is from when it entered our atmosphere!

mnemonics.meaning: You shoot an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow</mark> at the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> so that it will grant you a gift of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wisdom</mark>. You heard about a Greek hero doing this and the god in the sun gave him the wisdom to see everything. You're hoping it will work for you too.
mnemonics.reading: You're standing around waiting for the wisdom to hit you when something else does. In the head. Ouch! You look down and it's a wheel of cheese (ち)! At first you're angry, until you realize that this must be a sign. Cheese IS wisdom. And the key to wisdom is eating a lot of cheese!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">death</mark> of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark>s means that you've gone <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">blind</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: When you're blind you probably shouldn't drive anymore because if you do you'll mow (もう) everyone over. Actually, don't mow your lawn either. Blind people probably shouldn't be driving anything.

mnemonics.meaning: An <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nurse</mark> is someone who nurses alcohol. In other words, they <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">brew</mark> it.
mnemonics.reading: A brew of alcohol is what Joe (じょう) loves most after a long day of working the fields.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">concave</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">concave</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: If you call someone concave the 王 (おう) will find out and he'll have his guards turn you concave.

mnemonics.meaning: You give a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bow</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stick</mark> to your friend's family. This is because your friend died, and he loved bows and sticks. You give this to his family, to give our <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">condolence</mark>s.
mnemonics.reading: More than a condolence, you want to avenge your friend's death. He was killed by Mrs. Chou (ちょう), and she broke his stick and bow, which is why you got the family a new set.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">convex</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">convex</mark> kanji are the same, so hopefully you now just know them both.
mnemonics.reading: Is this convex? It's totes (とつ) convex!

mnemonics.meaning: An altered <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bird</mark> is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">crow</mark>! They look like birds but they're bigger and darker and smarter!
mnemonics.reading: If you can't tell just from looking at it that it's a crow and not a bird, walk up to it and caress (からす) it with your hand! If it caresses you back, it's a crow! If it freaks out and flies away or pecks your face, it's a normal bird. Crows are really smart and like affection. That's what makes them so cool!

mnemonics.meaning: An <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">elf</mark> who ventures outside in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> has a lot of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">daring</mark>. Elf ears are very, very delicate, and the winter cold can really mess them up. So if you see an elf adventuring in winter, know that that particular elf is a really daring dude.
mnemonics.reading: The amount of daring you'd need is about equal to the amount Genghis Khan (かん) had. And he was really daring!

mnemonics.meaning: When <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark>s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">have</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> piling up all around them, it's a sign of their <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">degradation</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: And who's leading this charge into degradation? Your dad (だ), of course.

mnemonics.meaning: You take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drum</mark> and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">branch</mark> and... well, what else would you do? You would <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">drum</mark> or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">beat</mark> them together.
mnemonics.reading: Who loves to drum things together and make a huge racket? 子s (こ), of course.

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">go</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> and establish a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> right in the middle of it to restore the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">equilibrium</mark> of the area.
mnemonics.reading: To restore equilibrium, you throw all the こういち clones into the prison.

mnemonics.meaning: If the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> of your gang is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> he'll try to have you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fell</mark> trees thinking they're rival gang members. You all know they aren't but you can't argue with your leader, especially if he's drunk. Go ahead and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">attack</mark> the trees anyway.
mnemonics.reading: You and your gang head out to fell the trees, only to remember that all you have are bats (ばつ). Good luck trying to take down trees with nothing but bats!

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Alcohol</mark> is a good <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">teacher</mark> on the process of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fermentation</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Using fermentation, you are indeed making some alcohol. It will be drunk at a party put on by Emperor こういち.

mnemonics.meaning: Put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">guard</mark> at your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gate</mark> to get a good <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">inspection</mark> of your neighborhood going. The guard will stand there all day inspecting everything and then report it all back to you. You won't have to do any of the inspection yourself!
mnemonics.reading: His inspection is complete, but it looks like he's used an etch (えつ) a sketch to record all the results. That's not really helpful. If you shake it all the inspection results will disappear!

mnemonics.meaning: You're riding your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> toward your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yurt</mark> as fast as you can because someone is trying to get in there to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark> your water and you want to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">intercept</mark> them.
mnemonics.reading: You manage to intercept the shaman (しゃ) who was just about to open the door to your yurt, and instead you crash right into him.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">easy</mark> tonight, so you decide to cut it open. But, the moon wasn't the moon, it was your big, pale, round tummy. You just cut it open, and now you can see your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">intestines</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: All over the world, people are cutting their bellies open, because they think its an easy moon (versus a normal moon, or hard moon, presumably). This is because they have fallen victim to a spell by Mrs. Chou (ちょう).

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">nose</mark> isn't the first thing people see about your face, it's the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">latter</mark>. They see your eyes THEN your nose, then your mouth, in order going down. Just label them A <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">B</mark> and C and you'll never forget!
mnemonics.reading: If you don't have any cereal you have to eat your B breakfast option. Oats (おつ). You don't hate oats, but they're definitely not your first choice.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> that does well in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">wind</mark> is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">maple</mark> tree. Maple trees don't have fruit so the wind can't knock anything off of it. That's why they thrive well in windy places!
mnemonics.reading: When the wind goes through the maple tree you know it's kite day (かえで)!

mnemonics.meaning: If you trap the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">greenhouse</mark> it will grow a creepy <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">membrane</mark> around itself. The moon isn't used to the heat it would be exposed to in a greenhouse so that membrane is there to protect it. It's really gross looking though.
mnemonics.reading: You decide to open the greenhouse to check this moon membrane out but when you open the door the smell of big macs (まく) hits you in the face. Eww. Why does this membrane smell like a big mac... or does that mean big macs smell like a festering moon?

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to turn your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sweet</mark> color you just HAVE to go with <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">navy blue</mark> or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dark blue</mark>. That's the sweetest color in existence, everyone knows that. After all, blue raspberry flavor is dark blue and it's super sweet.
mnemonics.reading: Now that your threads are navy colored you need to be careful that condors (こん) don't try to steal it for their nests. Condors love dark blue things and thread is perfect for a condor nest.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Flowers</mark> grown in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">warehouse</mark> will be very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pale</mark>. They never see the sun, so they don't grow to have bright colors.
mnemonics.reading: When you grow pale flowers like this, they don't grow a soul (そう). Soul adds color to plants and flowers. That's probably why ghosts and dead bodies are pale too.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> has <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> in his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> as he tries to talk to you. You walk over and he spits a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">question mark</mark> into your hand. It's covered in dirt and spit. Um... does this mean he's confused? He probably doesn't even know where he is. But how did he make this question mark and why was it in his mouth?
mnemonics.reading: The drunkard takes the question mark back and presses it to his head. He's wearing a Yankee's (や) cap. Oh come on. "Do you just want to know the Yankee's score in the game?" The drunkard nods.

mnemonics.meaning: To the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark>s you took your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horned</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">husband</mark> for you two to get married. (Society wouldn't accept a horned husband!) To hide even more from the prying eyes of society, you take your horned husband into a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ravine</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The ravine is still in きょうと though, because if you went outside the city your marriage wouldn't be legal. So you found a secluded, local ravine.

mnemonics.meaning: When a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> becomes a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> and sees a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark>, they'll become a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">robber</mark>. Because they'll steal the cross!
mnemonics.reading: Once the shellfish has a taste for being a robber, he'll join a Bosozoku (ぞく) bike gang so he can keep stealing more and more crosses. He'll drink more, steal more, and get to ride cool motorcycles.

mnemonics.meaning: Move your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">coat rack</mark> in one <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> by shooting it with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gun</mark>. Then you can keep shooting it to get a good <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rotation</mark> going. If you think there is a better way to make your coat rack make <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">revolution</mark>s, you're probably wrong.
mnemonics.reading: As you watch your coat rack's rotations a centaur (せん) barges in and takes the gun from you, stops the rotating coat rack and leaves. How rude! I guess centaurs don't like when things rotate.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> says <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spring</mark> is looking <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dry</mark>, so you'll need your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">salary</mark> in advance.
mnemonics.reading: Your salary is sent straight to your home (ほう) instead of the bank. Okay, something is definitely fishy here.

mnemonics.meaning: If you put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> while you're in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> will appear to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">scold</mark> you. You can never see who the mouth belongs to, but considering you're in prison it's probably a guard. Either way, that person doesn't like what you're doing and they keep scolding you when you put your spoon out into the sun.
mnemonics.reading: One day you finally get fed up. You need to know who the mouth of the person who's scolding you is. You stick your spoon out into the sun and the mouth appears, scolding you right on time. You reach out and grab them. But in your hand is a pile of cats (かつ).

mnemonics.meaning: You have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> for catching a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark>. But, it must be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">spread out</mark> and you must <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">arrange</mark> it first.
mnemonics.reading: You spread out your net and arrange it just so. You expect it to catch a turkey, but instead you catch the ancient Egyptian god Ra (ら).

mnemonics.meaning: You have to put <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bright</mark> place if you want them to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sprout</mark>. If they're left in the shade they'll just rot.
mnemonics.reading: You want to grow these sprouts in your home (ほう), not outside. So you need to find the windows in your house that are the brightest.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> melts into the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> after listening to loud <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">music</mark> in the hot <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>, so you have to find a nice big <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tank</mark> to scoop the melted tree into. The music made the tree vibrate at juuust the right frequency that it, combined with the hot sun, made the tree turn into a puddle. You can't just leave it being all blobby on the ground, so you find a tank for it.
mnemonics.reading: You're staring at the big tank when an eerie sound comes out, "Oooh I am the soul (そう) of the tree! You've trapped me in this tank and now I'm going to haunt it!" You don't want to be haunted by a tank with a soul stuck in it.

mnemonics.meaning: The amount of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> you need to get some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">peace</mark> is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">two mat area</mark>. Two tatami mats, that is. Also called a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">tsubo</mark>, this is a pretty common measurement in Japan, so you should get really familiar with the amount of space that two tatami mats take up together.
mnemonics.reading: A two mat area also happens to be big enough to hold two bodies (つぼ). That's enough space to bring peace to two living, or dead, bodies!

mnemonics.meaning: Riding a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> to the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">library</mark> is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">universal</mark> experience. People young and old have all, at some point, taken a scooter to the library, picked up a book, used the internet, sat in the comfy chairs, then left via that same scooter.
mnemonics.reading: Riding a scooter to the library is so universal, even hens (へん) do it.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">machine</mark> in your body that is powered by the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> is your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">womb</mark>, also called your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">uterus</mark>! Haven't you ever wondered why periods happen with the revolutions of the moon? That's because it powers your uterus and tells it what to do!
mnemonics.reading: It kind of sucks, but there is no way to sever this uterus - moon tie (たい). But if you find a way please tell me, I can't take this anymore.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">building</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clown</mark> is the only clown allowed to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">accompany</mark> you. You hate all clowns, and so does the rest of your town. But this clown is really good at building buildings, and he's allowed to leave his part of town and accompany you while you fix buildings together.
mnemonics.reading: He can only accompany you for so long though and soon it's time to say bye (ばい) again.

mnemonics.meaning: Put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">husband</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">aid</mark> him. There's something about a spouse's touch that just makes you feel better. Have you ever had someone rub your back while you were hurt or sick or sad? It's nice, right?
mnemonics.reading: Unfortunately, your husband wouldn't need your aid if he wasn't such a fool (ふ). He walks into doors, he falls down the stairs, he touches the plate when the waiter says it's hot. And every single time your fool husband hurts himself, you aid him.

mnemonics.meaning: When your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> has a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fault</mark>, you need to get an <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">alternate</mark>. Hopefully your insurance will cover it too.
mnemonics.reading: The alternate scooter is made entirely of 鉄 (てつ). It's hard and cold and not very comfortable when you sit on it. That's why you chose to keep it as an alternate and not as your everyday scooter.
