mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">husband</mark> was wearing his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cleat</mark>s when he accidentally stepped on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bird</mark>. Luckily this particular bird is a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">chicken</mark>, and chickens are really durable!
mnemonics.reading: The only way to stop the chicken from putting on your husband's cleats and stepping on him to death in revenge is to feed it the cake (けい) you were making.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rake</mark>d all the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark>s down into flat land so he could see everyone in the kingdom from his castle windows. You should share your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">congratulations</mark> with him. Now, quick tell him this was a great idea.
mnemonics.reading: The moment you say "Congratulations!" you've already started to miss (みず) those beautiful mountains. But you can't let missing them ruin your congratulations! Don't let the king know!

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Gambler</mark>s usually only see the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> at <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dawn</mark>. They gamble all day and through the night, and if they leave it's at the crack of dawn to get home, clean up, and then go back. I haven't known a gambler who's seen the sun ... well ever!
mnemonics.reading: If you're up at dawn you'll also see the あか(red) つき(moon). The あかつき only happens as the sun comes up at dawn so usually only gamblers see it. But if you get up early, you can see it too!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">clown</mark> takes a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">divide</mark>s himself. First he divides himself into two pieces, then he's in four pieces, then... oh why won't he stop?!
mnemonics.reading: The clown finally stops trying to divide himself, and you can't stand to look at all of him. You grab a bowling (ぼう) ball and bowl all of his divided parts over!

mnemonics.meaning: If you touch <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ice</mark> for too long you'll get <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">frostbite</mark> and that's a really hard thing to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">endure</mark>. A lot of people can't, and die. Then again, you managed to endure touching ice long enough to get frostbite in the first place, so maybe this is baby stuff for you.
mnemonics.reading: The best people in the world at being able to endure the pain are the shinobi (しの) ninjas! They train by hanging out in frozen areas all the time and don't complain at all. Maybe if the pain gets to be too much you can go ask them for advice.

mnemonics.meaning: You have to reach a certain <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">number</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark>s hits to become a legitimate <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">fiefdom</mark>. At least in the old days. If you don't meet one of these conditions, like if you get hit by tsunamis all the time but you only have two or three flowers that will grow, you can't be your own fiefdom.
mnemonics.reading: The most famous fiefdom checker is Han (はん) Solo. He takes his Millennium Falcon and swoops around checking for flowers and signs of past tsunamis and then he'll either say you can or cannot be your own fiefdom. Thanks Han Solo!

mnemonics.meaning: If you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lineup</mark> of your family members that have lived on this earth under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>, you're really explaining your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">genealogy</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: If you can't tell the difference between your genealogy and a musical score, you're a fool (ふ) and I can't help you. You aren't a fool, are you? You know the difference.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> wants you to make a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rocket</mark> that looks <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">glassy</mark>. It won't be very stable, and it probably won't work, but making it glassy and pretty is the only way to make the king approve.
mnemonics.reading: You take the glassy rocket and try to stuff some thin reeds (り) inside to support it. But because it's clear and glassy the king sees them at the last second.

mnemonics.meaning: You can only manage to avoid a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> by standing <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">above</mark> it on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">small</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stool</mark> if you are very <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">graceful</mark>. If you aren't graceful enough the tsunami will knock you and the stool over and you'll be swept away like everyone else.
mnemonics.reading: No matter how graceful you are, the tsunami still shook (しゅく) the small stool. That's where your gracefulness came in. The stool shook, but you didn't. You balanced yourself and refused to go down.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> does a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dance</mark> on top of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> to show his <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">greatness</mark> to everyone around. If he dances all the way up there on top of the tree, then no one can deny his <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">excellence</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: If you don't recognize the leader's greatness he will throw ketsup (けつ) all over you (it's a special mix of ketchup and catsup). And it's ketsup because it looks like blood. The blood he'll spill if you don't look up and clap at his great dancing.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">samurai</mark> puts his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">table</mark> next to his <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">weapon</mark>. He is just a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">husk</mark> of his former self. This <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shell</mark> of a samurai has nothing left.
mnemonics.reading: The only way to bring a husk of a samurai back to life is to have a cock (かく) crow right in his ear.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">king</mark> will send his men with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark>s into your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">private</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> if you come across <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lapis lazuli</mark>. Even though this is your private land, he wants that lapis lazuli to make some new crowns and thrones for himself. Plus he's the king, so he can do whatever he wants.
mnemonics.reading: You run up and ask how this lapis lazuli thievery isn't illegal and one of the swordsmen just shouts, "Loophole (る)!" What? What loophole? What law says that the king gets to steal your stuff?

mnemonics.meaning: This is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark>, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">correct</mark>? Better put a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lock</mark> on it, then.
mnemonics.reading: The person who put the lock on the gold roof was none other than... Joe (じょう)?!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sweet</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> sits under a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> and works as a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mediator</mark>. If you're having a fight with someone, bring them to the sweet woman under the tree and she'll mediate for the two of you. Problem solved! Thanks sweet lady!
mnemonics.reading: You go to pay the woman for being your mediator for you two but she just says, "Bye ばい)." You try to hand her some money and she stares into your eyes. "Bye." Oh... okay, bye then.

mnemonics.meaning: If a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> gets into a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> that's im<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark>ing a bunch of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark>s, the insects are going to get all <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">muddy</mark>. The net gets dragged along with the tsunami water and the insects can't escape, so they just get covered in the yucky stuff.
mnemonics.reading: Unfortunately for the insects, these muddy conditions have created the perfect habitat for ducks (だく). And muddy insects already imprisoned in a muddy net is a duck's favorite treat!

mnemonics.meaning: If you spill something <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">red</mark> on yourself in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> you should <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pardon</mark> yourself immediately and try to find something else to wear. It's very dangerous to wear red in winter, and even if it seems rude, make sure you pardon yourself right away and get that taken care of!
mnemonics.reading: If you don't pardon yourself fast enough the winter shaman (しゃ) will burst in and cast a spell on you, taking away all the clothes that have red on them! Now you have to pardon yourself for being naked!

mnemonics.meaning: Throw a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> in a cage with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tiger</mark> and some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spikes</mark> and the tiger will have the time of its life <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">play</mark>ing with them! Think of all the tiger play time possibilities!
mnemonics.reading: If you aren't the tiger, watching it play is a little like watching someone's head get cut off with a guillotine (ぎ). In fact, you don't want to watch it play at all anymore.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">receive</mark> radical and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">receive</mark> kanji are exactly the same.
mnemonics.reading: The best place to receive anything is in きょうと. The city is famous for the quality of everything they make, so if you’re in きょうと, keep your fingers crossed that you’ll receive something.

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to take a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flag</mark> out of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mantis</mark> you have to make a formal <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">request</mark> first. Mantises don't like to just give things away, and they're kind of mean so if you try to steal the flag it will probably bite you. So make a formal, polite request if you want it.
mnemonics.reading: After you request the mantis give you its flag it shocks (しょく) you by actually spitting it out of its mouth at your feet. You didn't think your request would work, or even if the mantis understood human speech, but it shocked you by doing exactly what you asked!

mnemonics.meaning: You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">triceratops</mark> standing in front of a full <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> and you can't help but see a really strong <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">resemblance</mark>. The triceratops has that round frill thing behind its horns and it looks just like the round full moon. Who knew that a triceratops would resemble the moon!
mnemonics.reading: The first person to see this resemblance was the Shougun (しょう). That's why he decided to put a triceratops head with the moon behind it on his mon (family crest). Now he's known as the full moon dinosaur shogun, and he's very famous.

mnemonics.meaning: You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark> on a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> covered in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> at its feet and you suddenly <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">resent</mark> them. It's not like you want to be the one up there on the cross, but so many people left flowers and shellfish for them. It should have been you...
mnemonics.reading: You realize you resent them because it looks like they're having fun (ふん). You aren't having fun, and you wanna be! How dare they have fun when you aren't!

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> is stuck in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> and it's starting to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">rot</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">decay</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You get close to the rotting tree and see some rotten cucumbers (きゅう) hanging from its branches. No!

mnemonics.meaning: You're walking down the street when you see <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">twenty</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark>es lined up in front of you. Crosses creep you out and this is way too many for you to keep walking so you decide to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">run</mark> as fast as you can to get past them.
mnemonics.reading: You figure since you're already on the run that you might as well hone (ほん) your running skills while you make your way down this scary, cross lined street.

mnemonics.meaning: You hoist your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">towel</mark> above your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">table</mark>, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> into the water and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sail</mark> away. You turned the towel into an actual sail and you're balancing on top of the table, which is now a boat.
mnemonics.reading: As you sail off into the ocean you hear a familiar voice shout out, "Ahoy!" Han (はん) Solo calls. He's also got a towel sail, but it's on the Millennium Falcon, which is half-submerged in the water.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> that grow on your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> that look like a sleeping <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bear</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sedge</mark>. Sedge grow all over the world!
mnemonics.reading: The next time you see a sedge bite into it. It tastes like sugar (すが)! Luckily, it don't taste like bear.

mnemonics.meaning: Pour all of your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">pool</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">serve</mark> all your guests at once! They can all help themselves to as much or as little alcohol as they want! What a great idea!
mnemonics.reading: As you serve your guests (and yourself) you look over and see Shaq (しゃく) also trying to serve them. And by serving I mean getting served because he's throwing them into the pool.

mnemonics.meaning: Deep in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">soul</mark>, you feel like you want to pull your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fang</mark>s out by the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">root</mark>, but instead you let out a loud <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sigh</mark>. You're one of the only people you know that has fangs, and it weighs heavily on your soul.
mnemonics.reading: You sigh again and say, "I wish I was just a normal guy (がい)." I swear the rest of me is a guy like the rest of you. *sigh*

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> has been sitting directly on your <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">spine</mark> for weeks straight. The pain is starting to become unbearable, and it seems like no one wants to help you.
mnemonics.reading: Just as your spine seems to be getting used to the pressure, the tree turkey unleashes a cry: "TWEET (つい)!" To your horror, a flock of tree turkeys emerge from the trees.

mnemonics.meaning: You see <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">seven</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark>s just sitting in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hole</mark> and so you decide to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">steal</mark> them. They were just left in that hole after all, it's not like anyone was using them. And even if they were, they'll never know you were the one to steal them, right?
mnemonics.reading: You steal the swords and realize they aren't just seven random swords, they're from the famous sword sets (せつ) they sell online. This particular set is from the Seven Samurai movie. Yes! What a great steal!

mnemonics.meaning: There are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark>s that smell like <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">trash</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">river</mark>. You reach in and realize these rocks are made of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sulfur</mark>. Even the flow of this water can't hide the stink of these sulfur rocks.
mnemonics.reading: You throw the sulfur rock as hard as you can, but it hits someone in the back of the head. Oh no, it's Ryu (りゅう) from Street Fighter. You try to apologize and explain that you just didn't want this stinky trash rock, I mean, sulfur rock near you. You didn't know he was there.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the radical that look like this are exactly the same. They are both <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Asia</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: What's the first sound in Asia? It's A (あ). Nice and easy!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">barracks</mark> radical and the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">barracks</mark> kanji are the same!
mnemonics.reading: Barracks are pretty big, so they weigh a ton (とん). And they probably take tons of materials to build.

mnemonics.meaning: You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark> in the shape of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turtle shell</mark> sticking out into the ocean. It's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cape</mark>! No, not the kind you wear, the geographical kind. When you're on land, most capes look like turtle shell mountains sticking out into the sea. Do you know any capes like that near where you live?
mnemonics.reading: You decide to walk along this cape because it looks like the perfect place to get rid of your old meat sack (みさき). It's starting to smell, but the ocean breeze from the cape pulls the meat sack out of your hands and off into the sky (then probably into the sea too).

mnemonics.meaning: Take <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">three</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">measurement</mark>s of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gold</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark> them into a mold to make a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">cast</mark>! You'll have cast three gold swords, or goblets, or ducks. Just make sure you follow those directions, or your casting won't come out right.
mnemonics.reading: You open the cast to reveal your gold statue of Chewbacca (ちゅう)! It's life-size and now you have three! Your new gold Chewbacca casts are going to guard the entrance to your house.

mnemonics.meaning: You have to use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to make an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">exit</mark> because you're so <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">clumsy</mark>. You can't seem to get the door to open, your hands just slip around on the knob uselessly. Instead, you take your fingers and stick them into the door frame, pulling the whole thing off the hinges so you can leave.
mnemonics.reading: After you make your clumsy mistake you realize that these doors come in sets (せつ). And now you have to try to open another door. And another door. So many sets of doors!

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> how <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eternity</mark> sounds you have to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">compose</mark> a poem. Or an essay. Or a song. <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Recite</mark> those deep thoughts about eternity and impress everyone who hears it.
mnemonics.reading: You decide to compose a poem about an acorn (えい). The tiny acorn is the perfect vessel for you to say how eternity feels to you.

mnemonics.meaning: If a pilot manages to land under a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">helicopter</mark> that's pierced with a sideways <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">barb</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">winter</mark> you should <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">congratulate</mark> them! People should always be congratulated for doing good things, and this is one of the best things you've ever heard of!
mnemonics.reading: Congratulate the pilot with cake (けい)!

mnemonics.meaning: You can only give a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">kiss</mark> of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">dairy</mark>. If you add anymore than a kiss the dairy will curdle and you won't be able to drink it anymore. Bleh.
mnemonics.reading: Dairy isn't kept with other drinks, it needs to be placed on a rack (らく). I hope you've been using your dairy rack to store your dairy. If you haven't you should get one right away!

mnemonics.meaning: If someone makes a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bamboo</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">horse</mark>, you know it's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">deliberate</mark>. You can't accidentally make an entire horse out of bamboo.
mnemonics.reading: As you admire all the deliberate details in this bamboo horse, the ghost of Tokugawa (とく) Ieyasu appears before you! "I deliberately made this horse to show you how important being deliberate is. You should be absolutely certain and decisive about your decisions."

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Every</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> will come to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">despise</mark> their followers. In the beginning everything is fine and dandy, but eventually the leader's followers will ask for more and more things, eventually ridiculous things, and the leader will really despise them for it.
mnemonics.reading: The more you despise them, the more booze (ぶ) you drink. This is not smart or healthy, but it's what this kind of hate does to people.

mnemonics.meaning: If there is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark> in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">crab trap</mark>, it's a lot for the crabs to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">endure</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You decide to make the little crab that endured being stuck in a dirty crab trap your pet, and put a collar (こら) round its little neck.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spirit</mark> wearing two <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mustache</mark>s must be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">evil</mark>. Everyone knows a mustache makes you evil, but two? And on a spirit? Yup, definitely evil.
mnemonics.reading: You're watching the evil mustache spirit when it starts to float toward your car (か). And it's... hey! It's trashing your car! You knew this guy was evil!

mnemonics.meaning: If you can <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stop</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> by putting a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spoon</mark> in its face you'll know it's a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">female</mark> turkey. A male turkey will peck the spoon out of your hand and run away. But a female turkey will wonder why you're putting a spoon there, stop, and look up at you wondering if you're okay.
mnemonics.reading: The female turkey then runs around making a mess (めす) of things trying to figure out what's wrong with you. She kicks around her hay, water bowl, and scratches at your pants, making more mess marks on them. But you don't move and she gets even more worried.

mnemonics.meaning: If you see someone <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">eye</mark>ing your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">womb</mark> you're probably going to be weirded out by how <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">friendly</mark> they're acting. You only let people who are really, really close to you look at your womb. So if this guy is acting that friendly he should have introduced himself first.
mnemonics.reading: This friendly guy comes up to you and start to introduce himself, "ぼく-" but you stop him. He's been getting way too friendly with your womb and you don't want to hear who he is. He can ぼく at someone else, you're out.

mnemonics.meaning: If you stay up so long that you see the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> go down and the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dawn</mark> come, people will say you have serious <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">guts</mark>. It takes guts to stay up that late. More specifically, it takes a powerful <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gallbladder</mark>. Your gallbladder is sensitive to sleep changes, you know, so you risk a lot by staying up like that.
mnemonics.reading: You stayed awake outside for so long, just to prove you had guts and powerful gallbladder, that you also got a sweet tan (たん) out of it!

mnemonics.meaning: You try to use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> to cast <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">doubt</mark> on people by using them to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">imitate</mark> each other. Right now you're using your fingers as finger puppets, imitating one of your friends to the others.
mnemonics.reading: Everyone thinks the friend you were trying to imitate is the imitation now and they have them in a guillotine (ぎ). You even doubt if they're an imitation or if your fingers are the imitation.

mnemonics.meaning: What kind of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">spicy</mark>? A <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">Japanese birch</mark>, or <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">birch</mark>, obviously. There's nothing spicier than a Japanese birch!
mnemonics.reading: You can only cut down a Japanese birch using a zoo saw (あずさ) because a regular saw can't handle how spicy these trees are.

mnemonics.meaning: A <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hits a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> and your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">hat</mark> protects you from the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">water</mark>, but the hat itself is now covered in <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lacquer</mark>. You take it off and see that it's shiny and hard and protected.
mnemonics.reading: You decide to scoop up the rest of the lacquer water and use it on your furniture to protect it from your shih tzu (しつ). Now it can't bite or scratch or ruin any of your things anymore!

mnemonics.meaning: You see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">gate</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> growing through it and it reminds you that you need more <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">leisure</mark> time. You walk up to the gate tree and curl up under its branches. No one will bother you because the tree is blocking the gate from being used.
mnemonics.reading: As you leisurely nap, you hear a gruff voice, "Ah, you're done too, huh?" It's Genghis Khan (かん)! He's spending his leisure time relaxing under this abandoned gate just like you.

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> to the ground in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark>, and then <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> down in front of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cross</mark> you keep on you because you're trying to make yourself as <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">lowly</mark> as you can in front of God. He said to lower yourself and this is the only way you can interpret that.
mnemonics.reading: The only problem about being lowly is the heat (ひ). Everyone always told you that heat rises, but not here. The rice paddy is incredibly hot... unless oh no. Is that the heat of hell?

mnemonics.meaning: You meet a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> whose <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> and you instantly know this is the person you want to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">marry</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You marry this woman right away and you both go straight to an inn (いん) together!

mnemonics.meaning: If there are <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark>s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">above</mark> and <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">below</mark> you, that means you're on a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mountain pass</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: It's only on this type of mountain pass that you'll be able to find the rare and adorable Tokyo gecko (とうげ). These tiny little critters can only be found on the ridges going above and below the mountains in Tokyo. There are like six mountains in Tokyo, so the next time you're scaling the ridges keep your eyes open for the Tokyo gecko!

mnemonics.meaning: If you only let <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">oneself</mark> (yourself) into your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heart</mark>, you'll end up <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">mourning</mark> all of the loves and friendships you could have had but didn't let in.
mnemonics.reading: While you're in mourning, you feel a sharp pain in your crying eyes. A key (き) comes sliding out with your tears. You look around wildly, but you're still alone. Is this... the key of mourning?

mnemonics.meaning: When under<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">music</mark> makes it out into the light of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> (the public), it finally becomes <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">official</mark>. Music isn't really real unless people hear it outside of those secret underground concerts.
mnemonics.reading: Once the music is official, you'll feel it in your soul (そう). When you listen to it outside, under the bright sun, your soul gets to finally hear it too.

mnemonics.meaning: We want you to say things with your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> right <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">now</mark> because it's <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">recital</mark> time! Go, perform please. What do you mean you didn't know the recital was right now? Well, tough luck. Recite!
mnemonics.reading: Here, if you are too afraid to start the recital now drink this gin (ぎん) to get your courage up. But once you're done drinking it the recital starts!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">stone</mark> that looks like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">turkey</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boil</mark>ing underwater is just a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">reef</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The reef is the Shougun's (しょう) favorite place to be nowadays. He sits next to the water, and stares down into it for hours.

mnemonics.meaning: People think <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark>s are only made of water but they have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">few</mark> pieces of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sand</mark> in there too. There's actually more sand in the ocean than most people think. And tsunamis can't just have water and sharks in them. A few grains of sand will always slip in.
mnemonics.reading: You already learnt the reading for 砂, the other kanji for sand. It should be easy to remember this one too, since it's also さ!

mnemonics.meaning: In a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drunkard</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark>s down like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark>. There they stay, an icon of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">scorn</mark> and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">neglect</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Every time you receive scorn and neglect from someone walking by, you say in your drunken voice: "I bets (べつ) you I can get up if I want. I bets you I can."

mnemonics.meaning: If the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> that's heading for your village is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fat</mark> you should try to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">select</mark> a different one to hit instead. You don't want to select fat tsunamis because they do more damage.
mnemonics.reading: If you're having trouble selecting which one is the least fat just check to see which tsunamis are eating tacos (た). Only fat tsunamis will be eating them, so just look for one without a taco.

mnemonics.meaning: Move <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">thread</mark> in the right <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">direction</mark> and you'll end up <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">spinning</mark> it into yarn. Then you can spin that yarn into a sweater or a scarf with your favorite half tofu half fugu mascot on it!
mnemonics.reading: While you're spinning you realize that you've always wanted to make your own bowling (ぼう) ball. And bowling ball cover. And bowling ball shoes.

mnemonics.meaning: Going from a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">helicopter</mark> that's <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">big</mark> even for yourself (<mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">oneself</mark>), is a huge <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">transition</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You decide one transition isn't enough, so you transition to a centaur (せん) too. Now you're a big half horse-half human creature and you'll fit in the big helicopter better.

mnemonics.meaning: Making a mnemonic for a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">crab trap</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">VERY</mark> hard. So hard that I couldn't come up with one. But it's very possible that one of you will!
mnemonics.reading: You know what else is very something? Jeans (じん). Jeans are very expensive. Jeans are very tight. Jeans are very popular. Jeans are very a lot of things.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> that is <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">good</mark>. This fabled creature has never been seen, but you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">wander</mark> the lands in search of it.
mnemonics.reading: As you wander, you come across a clue. It is fish roe (ろう).

mnemonics.meaning: Under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mountain</mark>'s <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark> are people using <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark>s to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">worship</mark> the gods. The noise from their jackhammering echos up through the mountain and up toward the sky where the gods live. As long as each person uses their own jackhammer, the sound will be loud enough to reach them.
mnemonics.reading: Unfortunately, the people who live around here can also hear you and the others worship in the mountain and they're going to sue (すう) you for the noise.

mnemonics.meaning: Set <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fire</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark> if you want to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">annoy</mark> it. Fire won't kill a geoduck, but have you ever been on fire? It's not really pleasant. So you'll just annoy it pretty badly.
mnemonics.reading: You know who loves annoying geoducks more than anyone else in the universe? Han (はん) Solo! If you watch Star Wars closely enough you can see him shooting geoducks with his blaster and catching them on fire for fun.

mnemonics.meaning: "For the  <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">samurai</mark>, it is a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">jackhammer</mark> that they will <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lack</mark>." That is the latest <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">article</mark> of the law written about samurai, hundreds of years after katana were taken away. This article was written with great <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">sincerity</mark> by the government.
mnemonics.reading: The one who wrote these articles with such sincerity was Genghis Khan (かん).

mnemonics.meaning: If, <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">again</mark> and again, you behave like an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">insect</mark>, you might as well be a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">barbarian</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: "BAN (ばん) the barbarians! Ban them, I say!," you loudly declare as the lord of these lands.

mnemonics.meaning: Under this <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">canopy</mark> is the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Mona Lisa</mark>, being sold for cheap, what a great <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">bargain</mark>!
mnemonics.reading: This Mona Lisa is such a bargain because it's just a rental (れん)!

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slice</mark> the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">power</mark> out of someone just <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">censure</mark> them. Then they'll be cut down in front of everyone and they'll feel super embarrassed. It's the best way to slice them down without actually cutting them and getting arrested.
mnemonics.reading: Once you censure them and they lose all their power, they'll be just another guy (がい). A normal guy with everything lost to him. HAHAHA!

mnemonics.meaning: If you think a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> looks <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sweet</mark> you have to be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">certain</mark> before you bite into it. Trees are really hard, and usually pretty bitter (believe me) so if you don't want a mouthful of broken teeth, sap, and sadness, you really need to be sure it's the one before you start munching.
mnemonics.reading: If you really want to be certain, and not just guess, take out your bowling (ぼう) ball and roll it as hard as you can into the tree. If its the right one it will let out a sweet smell, if it's not the tree will punch you.

mnemonics.meaning: An <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">arrow </mark>is shot from <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">heaven</mark> and hits right between your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> and your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mustache</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">correct</mark> your crooked smile. It also <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">straighten</mark>s your teeth and the crooked cut of your mustache too. Who told you that looked good? Well, it doesn't matter. The heaven arrow corrected it for you.
mnemonics.reading: These heavenly correcting arrows actually come from きょうと. They hate seeing people with crooked mustaches, so they shoot them out on the regular. It just looks like they're coming from heaven because they fall out of the sky.

mnemonics.meaning: You ate some <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">grain</mark>s that made you so <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sick</mark> it feels like a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">knife</mark> is stabbing in your guts and all your poop is falling out. This is called <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">diarrhea</mark>. Everyone's had diarrhea before, so you should know this feeling by now.
mnemonics.reading: The diarrhea is here. It's happening. And it smells so awful you can't breathe. You have to take some hollow reeds (り) and shove them up your nose and out the bathroom door so you can get some fresh air in you.

mnemonics.meaning: If you ride a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> with your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> around an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark> you're going to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">die</mark>. I mean, probably. There's a 99% chance you'll die.
mnemonics.reading: You slip. The axe collides with your face. You die. But... wait! There's a bright, blue glow and suddenly you're un-dead. You watch in slow motion as your holy blue saber (せい) brings you back to life and takes the hit from the axe instead.

mnemonics.meaning: You're stuck in your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark> during a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> and all you have to break out is an <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">axe</mark>. You whack and whack but you're only <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">gradually</mark> making progress. You thought an axe would be an easy way to get out of a car but it's not working like you'd planned! You have to make more than gradual progress if you don't want to drown.
mnemonics.reading: As you're gradually making your door open with the axe you look up to see the New York Yankees floating by on top of their bus. You yell, "YO YANKEES (ようや) to get their attention. They see your gradual progress and start throwing balls at your car to help dent it open.

mnemonics.meaning: You see <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">twenty</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">slide</mark>s lined up like a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">grid</mark>. You don't know who put them here, but they almost look like the grid paper you do your maths homework in. But who would use a slide as grid paper?
mnemonics.reading: As you stare at the slide grid you see some people come out and overhear them talk about their mass maths (ます) tournament happening later today. Oohhh it IS a giant grid. And they're going to use it to do maths later!

mnemonics.meaning: Have you heard the tale of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> who fell in love with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">coat rack</mark> during a full <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">moon</mark> and made him her <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">groom</mark>? It's a true story! She even had a wedding ceremony and had more coat racks sitting in the groom's side. The moon will make people do craaaazy things.
mnemonics.reading: Since their wedding happened under the full moon, the groom wore his special moon coat (むこ) to the ceremony. This is the ideal coat for a groom to wear, since they can keep wearing it all through their honeymoon.

mnemonics.meaning: This <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cage</mark> is full of <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">right</mark> side to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hide</mark> the fact that you're in here too.
mnemonics.reading: As you hide the ghost of Tokugawa (とく) Ieyasu appears before you, inside the cage! His arms are crossed and he's shaking his head at you. "Do you think I managed to become the first shougun of Japan by hiding?"

mnemonics.meaning: You <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">say</mark> something to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">boot</mark> when you want to be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">humble</mark>. You're down there because you're bowing in front of the person you're humbling yourself before. Because of that, your face is really close to their boots and you're speaking directly at them, instead of at the person's face, so it's more <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">discreet</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You're being humble like this because those boots belong to the King (きん) of England. You can't just say whatever you want at eye level to a king. He'll have your head chopped off for insolence, or worse!

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Flowers</mark> that you <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">oversee</mark> are always <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">indigo</mark>. You aren't sure why though...
mnemonics.reading: Wait, maybe these flowers are only indigo because there is something wrong with your eyes (あい)! Maybe your eyes are indigo and that's why it's all you see!

mnemonics.meaning: You grab a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tree</mark> to help you reach the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">bar</mark> out in the ocean, using it as a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">jetty</mark> leading straight to it. Now you can walk out on your makeshift <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pier</mark> and go get drinks without needing a boat or getting wet.
mnemonics.reading: You also made this jetty so it would be easier for Santa-san (さん) to dock his sleigh. Oh, you didn't know? His sleigh is more of a speed boat now, and he wants a refreshing drink after delivering all those presents. You get extra presents for making him a jetty, so win-win.

mnemonics.meaning: Put a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">yakuza</mark> member in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">prison</mark> on the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark> and he'll become a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">martyr</mark> to all the other yakuza still on earth. He died up there so the rest of them wouldn't have to. Because they definitely aren't getting caught now, if the penalty is a burning death in the new sun prison.
mnemonics.reading: The only reason he ended up a martyr in the first place is because they put him up there in June (じゅん). Everyone knows the sun is way too hot for humans in June. It's summer!

mnemonics.meaning: In the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">dirt</mark>, you find a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark> under the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">table</mark>. You lift it to reveal a deep <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">pit</mark>. Why is there a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">hole</mark> under your table?
mnemonics.reading: When you reach the bottom of the pit, you hear someone scuffling around and the sounds of chains. You light a match and inch closer to see what it is. In the darkness, you see こういち, starved and chained in a pit under your table.

mnemonics.meaning: You're in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">net</mark> but you have the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ability</mark> to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">quit</mark> playing along and <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">leave</mark> at any time.
mnemonics.reading: You don't know if you want to quit this charade until you feel an uncomfortable heat (ひ). You look down and the net you're in is being hung above a large fire.

mnemonics.meaning: If the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">death</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">woman</mark> occurs it's because she was being <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">reckless</mark>. People don't just die out of nowhere! They have to have done something super crazy to cause it. Right? Yes... right.
mnemonics.reading: As you watch the news about this reckless woman you find out that she died from mowing (もう) her lawn. You're not sure how, but now you really believe that she had to be doing it really recklessly to die doing it.

mnemonics.meaning: As the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> hits your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">scooter</mark> and your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">car</mark>, it alters the wave, creating <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ripples</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Ripples come off of your scooter and car from when they were hit by a tsunami. More importantly, those things were rentals (れん), so ripples or not, it doesn't matter if they were hit by a tsunami.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">flowers</mark> that wash up on shore in <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark>s that we make into <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">syrup</mark> is <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">seaweed</mark>. Okay, so it's more like soup or tea than syrup, but you can make them both out of seaweed.
mnemonics.reading: Seaweed is true soul (そう) food. Which means it's good for your soul. Didn't you ever read those books about chicken soup being good for your soul? Well that was a lie. Miso soup with seaweed is what's really good for your soul.

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Tsunami</mark>'s have a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">certain</mark> tendency to <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">secrete</mark> things as they go back out to sea. When they bash themselves onto the land they just throw a bunch of sea water around, but there are only certain things that they'll secrete when they're leaving.
mnemonics.reading: Most tsunami's secrete heat (ひ). It takes a lot of energy for a tsunami to crash onto the land so the water is really really hot, and it has to secrete that heat as it's going back out to sea.

mnemonics.meaning: Use your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">mouth</mark> to sing and a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">shellfish</mark> to stroke your shamisen, and you'll be performing a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shamisen song</mark> just like that! Yes, it's that easy. Just go find a shell, open your mouth, and you'll be singing one too in no time!
mnemonics.reading: A shamisen song is just an 歌 (うた) but with a shamisen. They're still songs so they're said the exact same way!

mnemonics.meaning: <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">Half</mark> of a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">rice paddy</mark> is always on the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">shore</mark>. Japan is surrounded by water, after all. So it only makes sense that half of every rice paddy is right next to the ocean shore, right?
mnemonics.reading: You decide to walk along this shore when you see Han (はん) Solo lounging in the sand. He's waving for you to join him! You get to lie on the shore with Han!!

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">leader</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">squid</mark> tells all of its squid people to be <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">thrifty</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: Who is a thrifty squid? Ken (けん) the samurai's squid buddy, who gets carried around in a bucket and never pays rent.

mnemonics.meaning: You put your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fingers</mark> in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">coffin</mark> to tickle the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">beggar</mark> inside. What you're doing is a new form of <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">torture</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: The beggar you will coffin tickle torture is none other than old Grandpa ごういち. He is a frail old man, and doesn't like to be tickled.

mnemonics.meaning: Give <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">alcohol</mark> to a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">demon</mark> and you'll see how <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">ugly</mark> it really is. Demons need to concentrate to keep their disguises going. Even if it looked pretty when you met it, like super handsome, give it a few drinks and its facade will slide off and reveal its super gross demon face.
mnemonics.reading: The ugly demon is drunk and taking off his shoes (しゅう) and swinging them around his head. And, oh no, he's drinking more alcohol out of the shoes.

mnemonics.meaning: Your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">forehead</mark> is in the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sun</mark>, and you start seeing those creatures with <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">lid</mark>s for heads and  <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">fins</mark> for feet again. Where on earth did they come from? They must have come from the <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">underworld</mark>. Nothing like that exists in this life.
mnemonics.reading: The sun is unusually hot for the month of May (めい), which must be why those underworld creatures are running around.

mnemonics.meaning: The <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">tsunami</mark> swept away one of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">cleat</mark>s your <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">husband</mark> just bought and creates an entire <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">valley</mark> with it.
mnemonics.reading: When the water clears, you and your husband go to the valley to look for the cleat and instead you find a bunch of cake (けい)! Maybe this is the tsunami's way of saying, "Thanks for letting me steal your cleat so I could make this valley shortcut."

mnemonics.meaning: Under your own <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">roof</mark>, a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">geoduck</mark> jumps out of the <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">ground</mark> with a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">sword</mark> and stabs your husband/wife/marriage partner to death. Now you're a <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">widow</mark>.
mnemonics.reading: You may be a widow, but that doesn't make you weak. You run outside, jump into your car (か), and run your entire house and the geoduck over.

mnemonics.meaning: You're walking in a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">greenhouse</mark> when you see a <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">small</mark> <mark class="radical-highlight" title="Radical">drop</mark> of water fall and it makes you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">yearn for</mark> the person you <mark class="kanji-highlight" title="Kanji">adore</mark>. You haven't seen them in so long. But something about being in this greenhouse and seeing that tiny water droplet made your heart burst with longing.
mnemonics.reading: As you yearn for that person from your past, you look back at the drop and see... Bobo (ぼ) the clown?! Ugh. Apparently Bobo dropped that small drop of water.
